HEADLINE: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Collecting;
Hard-to-Get Cars Are Hot Wheels, but Cold Investments

BYLINE: By KEITH MARTIN 

 BODY:
WHAT is the common thread among Tickle Me Elmo dolls, Egghead.com shares and the Plymouth Prowler? Prices of all three skyrocketed when they were chased by speculators looking to flip them for quick profits, and all have come crashing back to earth.
To put a Tickle Me Elmo under the Christmas tree in 1996 might have set you back $200 or more, but you can buy all you want today on eBay for $10 each or less. Egghead.com stock, which soared to $108 a share in late 1998, now languishes around $16. 
 Prices rise, of course, when demand outstrips supply. When a carmaker has a particularly hot product, speculators and dealers try to obtain as many as they can at wholesale prices, then sell the cars for as much as the market will bear.
The sticker price on the original Prowler, a modern-day hot rod, was $39,000 in 1997. But in the four and a half years between when the prototype was unveiled, in '93, and the production car reached showrooms in '97, Prowler mania set in. Speculators sold contracts guaranteeing delivery of Prowlers for premiums of $20,000 or more over sticker price. The feeding frenzy culminated at a collectors' auction in Auburn, Ind., when the first Prowler available to the public brought the astounding sum of $149,500 (and whispers of "Hey, what has he been smoking?" in the audience). For a year, Prowlers changed hands for $75,000 to $80,000. Now that the novelty has worn off, the cars are advertised at sticker price or less.
Today's hottest and hardest-to-get cars include the Honda S2000, a racy roadster that will be imported in limited numbers (about 5,000 a year, Honda says) and the Porsche Boxster S, a high-performance version of the popular sports car.
Fast-talking salespeople may tell prospective customers that these cars are such good investments that it makes perfectly good sense to pay $5,000 over sticker to be first in line. (The industry jargon is A.D.P., for additional dealer profit.) But while being first in a coveted new sports car is an investment in ego-gratification, history has shown that very few cars are ever worth more than their initial sticker price -- and that even for those cars, it generally takes at least 20 years to recoup the original price. If you pay an extra $5,000 to have one of the first Mercedes-Benz ML55 "muscle sport utilities," you're buying an experience, not making an investment.
Even the cars that do eventually increase in value are, in financial terms, terrible investments. For instance, a nicely equipped 1965 Mustang convertible cost $3,200. Today, even in perfect condition, that car will bring barely more than $25,000. Although the Mustang has had a sevenfold rise in value, if you had put $3,200 in a Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fund in 1965, and reinvested the dividends, the investment would be worth $179,000 today. And you never have to change the oil on a stock certificate.
New-car mania is nothing new. The Oregonian newspaper recently reported that the first motor car on the streets of Portland was an 1898 Stanley Steamer, for which the owner paid $1,000. The car had a list price of $600, so he paid a $400 premium to be the first man in the city behind the wheel of an automobile -- the equivalent of paying $53,440 today for a $32,000 Honda S2000.
A century later, speculators are still working to make a big killing from limited-production cars. But few actually make money.
"There's never been a new car made that hasn't gone down in value once they start rolling off the production lines in quantity," said Craig Jackson, owner of the Barrett-Jackson Auction Company, which hosts a sale of more than 800 high-end collector cars each January in Scottsdale, Ariz. "If you want to make money on a new car, you've basically got to sell it the same day you buy it."
Mr. Jackson speaks not just as an expert on the collector market, but from personal experience. In his own garage is a '90 Chevrolet Corvette ZR-1 coupe that has traveled just 68 miles since new. Mr. Jackson paid $5,000 over the $59,000 list price in 1990, and was sure that given Chevy's announced plans to build just 1,000 ZR-1's -- which had distinctive bodywork and a four-cam, all-aluminum, Lotus-designed engine -- that he could double his investment.
"At our auction in 1990, the car was bid to $78,000," Mr. Jackson said. "Everyone was getting $100,000 for theirs, so I held onto the car.
"Then Chevrolet announced they were going to build 2,000 instead of 1,000, and then 3,000, and before the run was over they built almost 7,000. That just killed the value."
The auction company owner promised to "run it across the block at our auction this January, and if I can get $40,000 for it, it will be gone."
Automakers are constantly searching for a reason to create limited-run "special editions" of production cars, hoping to increase sales. For instance, Cadillac announced in 1976 that it would stop building convertibles and that the final 200 Eldorados would constitute a "Bicentennial Edition." The 19-feet-long, all-white softtops even had dashboard plaques affirming their status.
"Sticker price was around $12,000," said Rick Cole, a former auction company owner who is now chief operating officer of Bilstein Engine Flush Systems in North Hollywood, Calif. "But I was getting over $50,000 for them, and the demand was incredible."
The value of a Bicentennial Eldorado today? "If you could find one that was still in the wrapper" -- like new -- "you could probably get about $12,000 for it," Mr. Cole said. His value may be conservative; the National Automobile Dealers Association's price guide values a standard 1976 Eldorado convertible in perfect condition at $18,200; it puts the additional premium for the Bicentennial Edition at a mere $825. Cadillac resumed production of Eldorado convertibles in 1984, helping to depress the values of the older ones.
Mr. Cole says that paying a premium is not necessarily foolhardy, given the tremendous devaluation that always occurs when a costly car, like a Rolls-Royce, is driven off the lot. "Whenever you buy any expensive new car, price-wise, you might as well be putting your head in a vise and squeezing it," he said.
Mr. Cole recalled buying one of the first Acura NSX sports cars from a dealer in Idaho and selling it the same day for a $10,000 profit. The purchaser was a Japanese speculator who shipped the car home and resold it yet again at a higher price. "I wasn't about to hang onto it, and I told everyone who was trying to speculate on NSX's to get rid of them as fast as they could," he said. "I knew that once there was one in every Honda showroom, you'd be lucky to get sticker for them. And I was right."
It's not just big-ticket cars that attract speculators. Advertisements promising the Honda S2000 for "just $5,000 over sticker" have begun to appear. How long will this price inflation last?
"Only a few months," said Jay Lamm, author of "The Miata MX-5 Guide" (Motorbooks International). "In 1989, when the Miata was introduced as a 1990 model, it had a sticker of $13,800. One of the very first cars available sold for $35,000. Then, for the next nine months, you had to pay $2,000 or $3,000 over sticker. But ever since then, Miatas have been selling for list price or less."
The best reason to pay a premium for an early car in a new-model run is to be the first with a new toy. "If you want to be cool, and you think that being the first to show up with a new BMW Z8 will impress your friends, and you can afford it, then who cares what you pay?" Mr. Cole said. "It's not about an investment. It's about being the baddest boy on the block."

HEADLINE: THE ISRAEL-SYRIA TALKS: THE COST;
Paying for Peace Is Clinton's Challenge

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
Peace is expensive.
Any agreement reached in the Israel-Syria talks is certain to entail huge costs -- to monitor security arrangements, to relocate Israeli settlers and to bolster the Syrian economy. If the past is any guide, the United States will bear the lion's share of the burden. 
 President Clinton's immediate challenge is to continue serving as midwife in negotiations between Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel and Foreign Minister Farouk al-Shara of Syria, scheduled to resume on Jan. 3.
But even if the negotiations succeed -- and that is by no means certain -- the president will have to present a multibillion-dollar bill for peace to a bitterly riven Congress that lately has been reluctant to grant Mr. Clinton political or budgetary victories. That is likely to get worse in a presidential election year.
The president's position is complicated by Syria's record as a haven for terrorists, its presence on Washington's list of nations that tolerate large-scale narcotics traffic, and Mr. Clinton's dwindling term in office. Mr. Clinton has criticized Congress for what he calls growing isolationist sentiment, another factor that will undercut his appeal for billions of dollars more in foreign aid to bankroll reconciliation in the Middle East.
The president, in a preview of arguments he would make for new money to support an Israeli-Syrian accord, said that continuing conflict in the Middle East is more expensive than peace.
"For we have learned from experience that tensions in the region can escalate," Mr. Clinton said in a Rose Garden appearance with Mr. Barak and Mr. Shara at the start of the negotiations on Wednesday. "And the escalations can lead into diplomatic, financial and, ultimately, military involvement, far more costly than even the costliest peace."
Administration officials refuse to discuss the potential level of American financial support for a possible agreement between Israel and Syria, saying such questions are speculative and premature.
The cost would probably far exceed the $1.8 billion price tag of implementing the Wye River accords reached by Israel and the Palestinians last November. Even that relatively modest sum was hung up in Congress for weeks this fall in a battle over unrelated issues in the appropriations bill for foreign aid and State Department operations.
Israeli officials and Middle East analysts estimated that the immediate costs of a deal under which the Golan Heights would be returned to Syria would be at least $15 billion -- and perhaps several times that.
The United States has provided $100 billion since 1979 to support the peace deal between Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt and Menachem Begin of Israel, worked out at Camp David under the auspices of President Carter.
A deal between Syria and Israel would entail different costs, some higher and some lower. Part of the American commitment at Camp David was an assurance that Israel's military would always maintain a technological superiority over neighboring armies. The billions in American aid and Israel's own technological prowess have given Jerusalem a significant qualitative edge over any Arab state -- and over virtually any combination of Arab states.
As a result, American military aid following an accord with Syria would focus more narrowly on creating a security buffer between northern Israel and Syria, including sophisticated monitoring systems. While these would be expensive, they would not require the same level of spending as the 20-year effort to upgrade Israel's land and air forces.
Still, an Israel-Syria agreement would be a costly proposition, and Congress would have to sign the checks. The bad blood between the administration and the Republican-led Congress could make it a tough fight for a lame-duck president.
Advocates of Middle East peace say that Mr. Clinton must involve Congressional leaders early in the process if he wants to win their support for large new appropriations.
"If there is a deal -- assuming there is a deal -- the only way this is going to succeed is if both the administration and Congress get behind this historic opportunity," said Howard Kohr, executive director of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee. "Congress has to have some ownership of this issue. The administration cannot go it alone."
The price of ignoring Congress until late in the process was dramatized for Mr. Clinton this fall when Congress rejected a global treaty to ban nuclear testing. The White House and treaty supporters did not consult with Republican leaders on the treaty and had no idea of the depth of opposition until it was too late. Mr. Clinton tried to delay a vote on the nuclear treaty but was dealt a humiliating defeat by a well-organized Republican majority.
Congress has traditionally given bipartisan support for aid to Israel, but Syria presents a different case. President Hafez al-Assad has long been a leader of Arab hostility to Israel, and many in Congress may be reluctant to reward him for an 11th-hour conversion to the cause of peace.
Any direct economic reward to Syria, therefore, would probably have to come from Europe, Japan or the Arab world.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Rates Jump as Investors Ponder the Fed's Intentions

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates jumped to their highest levels in more than two years yesterday as the persistent strength of the United States economy convinced more and more investors that the Federal Reserve might have to raise interest rates sharply to rein in growth.
The view of how hard the central bank will have to push on the brakes seems to change almost daily. Just a month ago, after the Fed raised its interest rate target a quarter of a percentage point, the third increase this year, many analysts thought the Fed was finished. 
 But a few weeks later, the talk was of one more rate increase, but not until the March meeting of policy makers. Then the one rate increase moved up to February. Now the talk is of two rate increases. And there is even speculation that the Fed might raise its target for the federal funds rate, the overnight loan rate between banks, by a half-point in February.
"Fed policy makers are going to tighten until they see the economy slow down," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management. "And there is no sign the economy is slowing."
The yield on the benchmark 30-year bond jumped to 6.39 percent yesterday, from 6.32 percent on Wednesday. That is the highest the yield has been since October 1997, surpassing the recent high of 6.37 percent in October of this year. The price, which moves in the opposite direction, fell 27/32, to 96 17/32.
The yield on the Treasury's two-year note, which is more sensitive to threats of higher rates from the Fed, rose to 6.13 percent from 6.06 on Wednesday. The narrow gap between the yields of the 30-year bond and the 2-year note is also a sign that investors expect the Fed to act.
Stephen D. Slifer, the chief United States economist at Lehman Brothers, and Ethan Harris, the senior economist there, are two of many analysts who have been forced by strong growth to raise their expectations of Fed rate increases. A month ago they thought the Fed was through; now they are predicting two Fed rate increases in the first half of 2000.
At the same time, they have increased their forecast of fourth-quarter growth to 5.5 percent from 4.3 percent. And this week's economic data seem to confirm that judgment. Retail sales in November jumped 0.9 percent, well above expectations. Industrial production rose 0.3 percent, which was strong considering the revision of October's climb to 0.8 percent.
Yesterday's report of a record trade deficit in October was also a worry because the record imports for the month were another sign of relentless consumer spending. A decline in initial jobless claims to a 26-year low also showed how hot the economy is.
The force that seems to be driving the consumer is the continued strength of the stock market, which increases consumers' willingness to spend. So until the stock market slows down its pace, it will be hard to slow the economy.
Abby Joseph Cohen, the market strategist at Goldman, Sachs, said yesterday that the stock market would climb at a more moderate pace next year, in part because the market is fully valued. Her year-end target for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is 1,525, a 7.5 percent move from its close yesterday.
But to get this kind of performance, Mr. Harris said that the Fed would probably have "to take a few more warning shots across the bow of the stock market."

SECTION: Section B; Page 4; Column 4; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 467 words

HEADLINE: Ambulance Dispute Delays Changes in Budget

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
A disagreement between the Giuliani administration and the City Council over a plan by the mayor to increase the use of private ambulance companies on some overtime shifts now handled by the Fire Department has delayed the city's first-quarter budget modification.
The budget modification, involving routine revisions to reflect actual revenue and other changes since the fiscal year began in July, is normally agreed on by the mayor and the Council in November. But officials said yesterday that it would be delayed at least until early next month. 
 While the lack of an agreement will not disrupt the operations of city government, the delay is an embarrassment for city budget officials at a time when New York's continuing economic prosperity makes budget negotiations relatively easy.
Under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's November budget plan, which is presented to the Council as a draft of the budget modification, city tax revenues are expected to be $178 million more than was expected in the budget passed in June.
But the delay in passing the first-quarter budget changes has focused not on how to spend additional revenues but on about $1.6 million in savings that the Giuliani administration wants to achieve by turning over some overtime ambulance tours to ambulance companies run by local hospitals. Those tours are now handled by city ambulances, which are part of the Fire Department.
Council officials, including Herbert E. Berman, a Brooklyn Democrat who is chairman of the Finance Committee, have opposed the change, saying it represents a shift in policy that should not be made through the routine mechanics of a budget modification. The union that represents city ambulance drivers also opposes the change, saying it could be the first step in an effort to privatize ambulance services.
The mayor's budget director, Robert M. Harding, said the saving in overtime was an accounting issue, with the hospital ambulances already operating in the city. "This is not a large step," he said. "It's the fire commissioner doing a very good job of managing the budget and realizing that as a result of the voluntary ambulance work that's being done, there will be overtime savings."
Robert A. Ungar, a lawyer for the union, said that the city had recently allowed private and nonprofit hospitals to increase the number of their ambulances linked to the city's 911 system and that he was opposed to those ambulances potentially replacing city ambulances.
"The city always expressed that what they were doing was somehow supplementing the Fire Department's service," he said. "This is the first time that we have seen where they are actually saying, 'We are transferring ambulance tours from the Fire Department to private hospitals,' and there we have a strong objection."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Technology Shares Send Nasdaq to 53rd High of the Year

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks rose yesterday with the Nasdaq composite index streaking to its 53rd record this year as positive news from technology companies eclipsed a jump by bond interest rates to the highest in more than two years.
"The story all day has been Nasdaq," said Larry Wachtel, an analyst for Prudential Securities. "Technology has been powerful." 
 The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 19.57 points, or 0.17 percent, to 11,244.89, with Microsoft, a Dow component, countering weakness in financial services stocks that had weighed on the blue-chip index most of the day. Shares of Microsoft rose 5 1/4, to 113 11/16, on enthusiasm for its Windows 2000 operating system.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed up 5.46 points, or 0.39 percent, at 1,418.78.
The Nasdaq composite index surged 93.11 points, or 2.57 percent, to 3,715.06, topping Monday's close of 3,658.67, after sailing past the 3,700-level for the first time.
The technology-laden index was bolstered by earlier news of the Microsoft announcement, positive comments on semiconductor stocks by Morgan Stanley and a narrower-than-expected loss from the Internet company CMGI, traders said. Shares of CMGI surged 21 13/16, to 221 9/16, the day after it reported a first-quarter loss of $117 million, or $1.08 a diluted share -- much less than the per-share loss of $1.76 that had been expected. The company also announced a two-for-one stock split Wednesday.
The Nasdaq index is now up some 69 percent since the beginning of the year. Abby Joseph Cohen, Goldman, Sachs's United States stock market strategist and one of Wall Street's most influential forecasters, set her targets yesterday for the year 2000.
She now predicts that the Standard and Poor's 500 index will hit 1,525 by the end of 2000, a gain of nearly 8 percent over Wednesday's closing price. She set a corresponding target of 12,300 for the Dow Jones industrial average, a gain of 9.6 percent over Wednesday's close. Ms. Cohen's primary research focus is on the S.& P. 500 universe of companies.
It was the first time Ms. Cohen has made public her targets for the end of the year 2000. Previously, she had set a target of 1,475 to be reached by fall 2000.
American Express slumped 5 93/16, to 152 5/8, while J. P. Morgan dropped 1 1/2, to 128 7/8. It was the second consecutive day of weakness for these financial services companies because of the rise in bond interest rates.
Among other big movers, Sprint PCS Group was down 12 5/8, to 99 5/8, after Lehman Brothers cut its rating on the wireless unit of Sprint to "neutral" from "outperform."
Nextel Communications, another wireless company, was down 6 1/16 at 92 15/16.
In company news, the hotel franchiser Cendant announced a $400 million strategic alliance with Liberty Media, sending its stock up 6 13/16, to 22 1/2. Liberty Media's shares finished up 1 3/8 at 48.

HEADLINE: Buchanan, In a Change, Calls for End To Sanctions

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
Conceding "a dramatic departure from what I've argued and believed," Patrick J. Buchanan today called for an end to economic sanctions by the White House as a "sword that slaughters children" and entrenches dictators.
"Our sanctions are sowing seeds of hatred that will one day flower in acts of terrorism against us," Mr. Buchanan said in a speech at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. 
 Mr. Buchanan, who is courting independent voters and the Reform Party for its nomination for president, said his decision to oppose sanctions grew out of recent reporting on the effects of sanctions in aggravating the health and nutrition problems of rogue nations like Iraq.
"When Arab terrorists murder Israeli children," Mr. Buchanan said, "we Americans are rightly filled with horror and disgust. But what do Arab peoples think of us when U.S. sanctions bring death to literally thousands of Iraqi children every month?"
A supporter of sanctions in the past against Cuba, Mr. Buchanan said conditions had changed with the fall of Soviet Communism.
"Because of the siege mentality our embargo has created inside Cuba," he said, "our sanctions may today be the main pillar of Castro's power."
Sanctions, he continued, "may fairly be called America's silent weapon of mass destruction whose victims are almost always the weak, the sick, the women and the young."
In his address, Mr. Buchanan cited what he called counterproductive sanctions by the Clinton administration in a dozen countries, including Iran, Libya, Afghanistan, Haiti, Myanmar, India, Pakistan and Serbia. He vowed that as president he would end all sanctions depriving food, medicine and other basic necessities to the suffering subjects of rogue nations.
"Embargoes and blockades are weapons of war," Mr. Buchanan said.
They must be designed, he continued, "so that innocent people are not the principal casualties."
Speaking of Serbia, Mr. Buchanan criticized the administration for first "smashing" the country with a 78-day bombing campaign, and then denying Serbs heating oil and aid in removing the debris of war.
"This immoral policy shames us as a people," Mr. Buchanan said. "We are putting old men, women, and children under a sentence of death for failing to do what NATO itself could not do: overthrow Slobodan Milosevic."
Dictatorial governments do not justify sanctions, Mr. Buchanan said, adding, "No one has deputized America to play Wyatt Earp to the world."
He denounced "all this Beltway braying" about the United States being the world's indispensable super power. "Have we, too, succumbed to the hubris of hegemony?" he asked.
There are better ways to punish rogue states, Mr. Buchanan said, including cutting off overseas assets of dictators, denying them international loans and levying tariffs to deny them hard currency.
Accusing President Clinton of "monumental hypocrisy" in applying sanctions, Mr. Buchanan said, "He blockaded, starved and invaded tiny Haiti for human rights violations, but he proudly chaperones China into the W.T.O."
Later, when answering questions about his presidential campaign, Mr. Buchanan exulted that he was not caught up in the primary campaigns in Iowa and New Hampshire but was instead visiting Reform Party gatherings around the nation.
"I have seen no organized opposition," he said. "We are winning delegates quietly, and we are moving on this nomination."
Mr. Buchanan said he had always known he would be working at the complex Reform nomination process with little public notice. His aim is to "surface" again in March, when, he said, the two major party candidates will be clear and the public will begin to be anxious at the choice.
"People," he said, "are going to look out and say, 'Oh, my Lord, that troll is still out there under the bridge.' "

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Rises Again As Imports Continue Climb

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit swelled again in October, to $25.9 billion, setting a record for the seventh time this year as prosperous American consumers and businesses kept up their spending spree. Exports were essentially unchanged, while imports continued to grow.
Higher prices for imported oil, on which the United States relies for more than half its needs, more than offset reduced volume and accounted for one-fourth of the October gap, which was much larger than expected. Record deficits with China and Japan accounted for more than half of the deficit. 
 "Consumer demand in the U.S. is extremely strong," said Bill Sharp, senior economist at Chase Securities, predicting that booming sales of foreign cars would contribute to a further widening of the deficit in the coming months. Weak growth by some Asian and European trading partners, on the other hand, caused demand for American goods to lag.
"There's very rapid growth of our economy vis-a-vis the rest of the world," said William C. Dudley, chief United States economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The wider trade gap provides some ammunition for those who argue that the United States is being victimized by the unfair labor practices of other countries and that American workers need some protection, perhaps by imposing higher labor and environmental standards on some trading partners.
This was a significant issue at the recent World Trade Organization meeting in Seattle, where efforts to start a new round of trade liberalization failed amid unexpectedly widespread protests.
In addition, an agreement by the United States to support China's bid to join the W.T.O., in exchange for better access to Chinese markets is still subject to approval by Congress.
William Daley, the commerce secretary, cited the far faster rate of American economic growth as the main reason for the growing trade imbalance but warned of the political problems it posed.
"We have carried much of the burden," he said, referring to the way the United States has bought large amounts of goods from struggling trading partners, especially in Asia. "Politically, that gets very difficult over a long period and other countries have to understand that."
The rise in imports in October was 1.6 percent, to a record $107.9 billion, with the biggest increases in computer-related and other capital goods, including semiconductors. Some analysts had expected chip imports to decline because of an earthquake in Taiwan in September.
The nation's bill for imported oil, meanwhile, reached a new peak of $6.4 billion as the average price rose to $20.74 a barrel from $19.52 even as the number of imported barrels fell.
Exports edged down one-tenth of 1 percent, to $81.9 billion, with telecommunications equipment one of the biggest drags.
Through the first 10 months of the year, exports have climbed 1.9 percent compared with figures in the period a year earlier, while imports have surged 10.7 percent. This has resulted in a deficit running at an annual rate of $262 billion, far above last year's peak of $164.3 billion.
The deficits with Japan and China each climbed to $7.2 billion for the month, the most ever recorded with any country. The widening with Japan was 8.1 percent; with China it was 3.6 percent. Unlike the other figures, those for individual nations or other geographic areas are not adjusted for seasonal variations.
The deficit with Mexico narrowed to $1.4 billion as both exports and imports reached peaks, while the deficit with Canada, the nation's biggest trading partner, rose to $3.2 billion. Record imports from Western Europe helped push the American deficit with the region to $5 billion, the report showed.
It will probably take the better part of next year before the deficit starts to narrow, Mr. Dudley said.

HEADLINE: Gore and Bush 'Debate' Education at a Distance

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE and FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: NASHVILLE, Dec. 16

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush stood on Mr. Gore's home turf here today and sparred over their education plans, acting for all the world as if they were their party's nominees.
Mr. Gore, who today pledged a $115 billion federal commitment to education that drew positive reviews from teachers unions, accused Governor Bush of Texas of wanting to drain money from public schools to provide vouchers to students for private school. 
 Mr. Bush accused Mr. Gore, a Democrat, of advocating a big-spending liberal education program that invited the federal government to intrude into local decision making. The problem with the Gore plan, Mr. Bush, a Republican, said, is that it assumed that Washington was the source "of all wisdom."
Neither man has captured his party's nomination, but each held his party's fundamental principles aloft today in a preview of a classic fall election matchup. Their messages, delivered hours apart from the libraries of two schools here today, were noteworthy for the underlying assumption that each man would become his party's standard-bearer.
And their broadsides were delivered at the same time that their two maverick challengers -- former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey on the Democratic side and Senator John McCain of Arizona on the Republican side -- sought to capture the hearts of independents by making a joint appearance in New Hampshire on campaign finance.
With Mr. McCain and Mr. Bradley garnering much of the attention today, Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush both seemed eager to get on with their own show.
Mr. Gore was asked whether he wished he were involved in the session in New Hampshire.
"I'm involved in a debate here in Nashville," he replied.
And Mr. Bush clearly relished the idea of engagement in Mr. Gore's home state. He said he looked forward to debating Mr. Gore about education because Mr. Gore was focused on "bricks and mortar."
"The vice president talks about buildings," Mr. Bush said dismissively. "I'm talking about children. The vice president talks about bricks and mortars; I'm talking about hearts and souls. I'll be glad to make that debate all day long across America."
The two also collected money at the same saloon here, the Wildhorse, with Mr. Gore staging a fund-raiser Wednesday night and Mr. Bush following tonight, in his first fund-raising foray into Tennessee. Mr. Gore's wife, Tipper, introduced him by saying, "He's good enough, he's smart enough," an allusion to the idea that Mr. Bush lacks the intellectual heft to be president.
Mr. Bush appeared with the state's top Republican officials, including Gov. Don Sundquist and Senator Bill Frist and former Gov. Lamar Alexander.
Mr. Gore drew more than $1.6 million, and Mr. Bush took in about $750.000.
Mr. Gore set the tone for the day by filling in the numbers of the education plan he outlined in May. He said he would spend $115 billion over 10 years, $50 billion of it to provide universal access to preschool for 3- and 4-year-olds. He would use federal money to help increase teacher salaries, a novel proposal in a presidential campaign, and to provide incentives to failing schools to reverse course.
The plan engendered much support from the teachers unions, which have endorsed Mr. Gore.
Sandra Feldman, president of the one-million member American Federation of Teachers, liked the plan's comprehensive approach toward recruiting teachers and retaining them.
"Ultimately we have to have higher teacher salaries along with higher standards as we go forward because otherwise we aren't going to be able to attract teachers into districts that have the greatest needs," Ms. Feldman said in a telephone interview from New York.
Bob Chase, president of the National Education Association, the largest union in the United States with 2.2 million teachers, also hailed the plan.
"The whole preschool program is particularly important," Mr. Chase said in a telephone interview from Washington. "All research shows us those early years are vital to the ongoing success of the child, and when you couple that with smaller class size, and standards for students and teachers, tying that into questions of salary is appropriate."
More skeptical was Abigail Thernstrom, a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute and a conservative education analyst.
"Our problem is not class size, it's that we don't have a sufficient number of top college graduates going into teaching," Ms. Thernstrom said.
"The federal government doesn't have a track record of doing this kind of thing well," she said. Mr. Bush had a similar response when asked his reaction to Mr. Gore's plan.
"I heard the amount of money, which is fairly typical of somebody who runs around the country saying I'm going to spend money and solve your problems," Mr. Bush said. "We have a fundamental disagreement on the role of the central government. I believe the role of the central government is to do a few things and do them well. And when we have money left over, to pass it back to the working people."
That's what Mr. Bush would do with his proposal for a $483 billion tax cut over five years, which Mr. Gore today referred to as his "risky tax scheme" that would throw the nation back into deficits and back into a recession.
One big difference in the two candidates' education plans is how they deal with failing schools. Mr. Bush would take back federal money from nonperforming schools and give it to students to use as vouchers toward private schools. Mr. Gore said he would require the school districts to adopt an aggressive plan to turn around the school and provide pay incentives for teachers in districts that managed to do so.
Mr. Gore said that Mr. Bush's plan, in draining money from the public schools, would give new meaning to the three Rs: "Reckless and retrograde, reactionary, radical -- that's four Rs. I sincerely believe that it's an ideologically-driven mistake," the vice president said.

HEADLINE: White House, Citing Fraud Charge, Seeks to Block Russian Loan

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
White House officials called today on the independent Export-Import Bank of the United States to delay or cancel a pending $500 million loan package to Russia.
The officials said the aid, in the form of loan guarantees to a Russian oil company for the purchase of American equipment, should be blocked because of allegations that the Russian company had defrauded foreign investors in another deal. 
 The officials said their position was not related to Russia's war in Chechnya, but there has been a growing debate at the White House and at the State Department about whether approval of the transaction would send the wrong signal as the Russian Army wages an increasingly violent conflict in the Caucasus.
The International Monetary Fund, in which the United States is the largest shareholder, is also continuing to withhold a $640 million loan to Russia because Russia has failed to meet the necessary economic and financial conditions, though this explanation has been greeted with skepticism by Moscow.
The Export-Import Bank is an independent agency whose charter precludes it from making decisions based on political considerations. It had scheduled a board meeting for Friday to vote on the loan guarantees, but postponed the meeting until Tuesday.
Although the bank makes its decisions independently of the administration, the State Department can halt loans if it determines that the recipient violates human rights.
The guarantees are to go to the Tyumen Oil Company, which has been embroiled in a dispute with BP Amoco, one of the world's largest oil producers, and investors including George Soros. The fight is over Tyumen's acquisition -- at a bargain price through a bankruptcy proceeding -- of an oilfield in which BP Amoco and Mr. Soros were part owners.
Another investor in the oilfield, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, denounced the bankruptcy deal as a "sham" that raised questions about the Russian government's commitment to attracting foreign investment.
Asked about the issue by reporters today, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said, "I have my people looking into it."
But the White House took a harder line, clearly intending to send a public signal to the bank even as White House officials said the administration was not lobbying the bank.
White House aides said that Gene Sperling, the director of the National Economic Council at the White House, had concluded that there was enough merit to the allegations that Tyumen had acquired the oilfield in an unscrupulous manner that the bank should at least delay its decision while the legal fight over the acquisition goes forward.
They said Mr. Sperling was concerned that going ahead with the loans now could be perceived as a reward for a Russian company that had undermined Russia's halting efforts to develop laws and rules for the conduct of business.
The loans are tricky for the administration not just because of the Russian assault on Chechnya. Vice President Al Gore's rivals in the presidential race have intermittently raised questions about whether he failed to act aggressively enough in demanding that Russia clamp down on corruption.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Abbott Labs Is Abandoning $7.3 Billion Deal for Alza
Abbott Laboratories, the nation's largest maker of medical diagnostic devices, said that it was abandoning its $7.3 billion acquisition of Alza, a developer of drug delivery technologies, because of antitrust opposition from the Federal Trade Commission.
The development is the latest in a string of trouble for Abbott, including a record $100 million fine levied in October by the Food and Drug Administration connected to the manufacture of medical test kits. Page C24. 

Ex-Giants Star Awarded $10 Million
A jury in Newark awarded more than $10 million to Philip J. McConkey, the former New York Giants football player, after finding that Frank G. Zarb, left, the chairman of the group that runs the Nasdaq stock market, deceived Mr. McConkey into working for him at Alexander & Alexander, the insurance brokerage firm that Mr. Zarb formerly ran. The six-person jury unanimously found that Mr. Zarb fraudulently misled Mr. McConkey about the status of takeover talks between the firm and the Aon Corporation. C2.
 
Mannesmann Seen Receptive to Bid
Mannesmann of Germany may be willing to consider a friendly takeover deal from Vodafone AirTouch of Britain if it adds a cash sweetener to its hostile all-stock offer, executives close to Mannesmann said. C2.
 
Trade Deficit Set Record in October
The nation's trade deficit swelled again in October, to $25.9 billion, setting a record for the seventh time this year as prosperous consumers and businesses kept up their spending spree. Exports were essentially unchanged, while imports continued to grow. C24.
 
Yields Increase Sharply on Bonds
Long-term interest rates jumped to their highest levels in more than two years as the persistent strength of the nation's economy convinced more and more investors that the Federal Reserve might have to raise interest rates. The yield on the 30-year issue jumped to 6.39 percent from 6.32 percent. C11.
 
The Nasdaq composite index set its 53rd record this year, surging 93.11 points, or 2.57 percent, to 3,715.06. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 19.57 points, to 11,244.89, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed up 5.45 points, to 1,418.78. C11.
 
Nike Earnings Beat Expectations
Nike said that its profit in the most recent quarter rose 50 percent as sales outside the United States helped the athletic footwear and apparel company exceed expectations. The results were released after the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange, where Nike's shares closed at $45, up $3.125. In after-hours trading, shares rose even more. C24.
 
Supercomputer Chip Is Resurrected
Hewlett-Packard and STMicroelectronics, Europe's largest computer chip maker, plan to announce on Monday that they are forming an alliance to adapt a chip that failed commercially when it was introduced for supercomputers in the 1980's for home entertainment and other consumer devices. C8.
 
Year 2000 to Cost U.S. $8.38 Billion
While federal agencies have pronounced themselves ready for the Year 2000, they say the preparations have been costly. The Office of Management and Budget estimated that federal expenses relating to the Year 2000 problem would total $8.38 billion over five years, ending next September. A28.
 
Merger to Create Japan Phone Giant
In Japan, three companies -- KDD, IDO and DDI -- said they would merge, creating a telephone and data transmission business that would be No. 2 domestically to Nippon Telegraph and Telephone. C4.

HEADLINE: Transit Official Says Labor Accord Won't Increase Fares in Near Future

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
The executive director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority took pains yesterday to assure subway and bus riders that the tentative agreement with the transit union would not force a fare increase in the next few years.
The pact's increased labor costs, including a 12.5 percent raise in base pay over three years, were not so large and unanticipated that they would seriously affect the budget, said Marc V. Shaw, the executive director. 
 Mr. Shaw defended the deal in an interview as transit officials and union leaders spent much of the day rebuffing their critics. In a curious reversal of what the two sides were saying before they struck the deal early Wednesday, M.T.A. officials were arguing that the accord was not too generous, while union leaders asserted that it was plenty generous.
Even though the transit workers obtained the largest pay increases, after inflation, of any New York City public-sector union since the 1980's, Mr. Shaw said the agency had already budgeted money to cover most of those increases. "It's not going to have a significant effect on next year's budget above what was already budgeted," he said. "It's not going to have a direct impact on the fare."
Mr. Shaw defended the contract after Diana Fortuna, the president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a business-backed monitoring group, said the tentative deal was so generous that it might force an increase in the $1.50 fare for subways and buses. The contract will give transit workers, who earn an average of $39,000 a year, a 5 percent raise in the contract's first year, 3 percent in the second year and 4 percent in the third year.
Factoring in wage increases and reductions in the transit workers' pension contributions, several labor experts who analyzed the contract said it would effectively increase pay by nearly 18 percent over three years. But M.T.A. officials insisted that because of some complex financial factors and some savings caused by productivity increases, the authority's labor costs would rise considerably less than that.
Willie James, the president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, predicted that the city's 33,000 bus and subway drivers would vote to ratify the contract, which he boasted was one of the best public-sector labor pacts in years.
Mr. James praised E. Virgil Conway, the M.T.A.'s chairman, for being more generous than many labor experts had expected. He said Mr. Conway knew that the workers' poor morale could worsen if the workers thought the authority was being stingy with them.
Mr. James sharply criticized dissidents from the militant New Directions faction, who are urging rejection of the contract as they contend that the raises are too low and that there are too many concessions.
"If I got 20 percent in every year, they'd still say everyone should vote against it," Mr. James said in an interview. "Their agenda is not to be sensible or responsible. Their agenda is to take over the local. And they'll misinform the membership to do that."
He said the contract would benefit workers by substantially reducing their annual pension contributions and by improving the union's health plans. He added that the agreement revamped New York City Transit's strict disciplinary procedures by, for example, barring managers from suspending workers for minor infractions until a hearing is held.
Mr. James spoke yesterday at a board meeting of the New York City Central Labor Council, where he received a huge ovation from 20 other labor leaders, many of whom said they hoped his contract would serve as a model for the city's negotiations with its municipal unions next year.
"You put together one of the best contracts we've seen not only for public employees, but for collective bargaining in general," said Denis M. Hughes, president of the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O.
But Roger Toussaint, a leader of the New Directions movement, said that the pact was a disappointment and that it deserved to be rejected.
"This contract falls far short of all the major goals that the membership set," he said. "The amount of money we got doesn't make up for the concessions we made in the last contract. I believe we could have and should have gotten more."
The contract comes as the M.T.A. asserts it will have a $191 million operating deficit next year. But many fiscal experts said that the agency, during the contract negotiations, deliberately painted a negative financial picture and would actually have a surplus.
Mr. Shaw and Gary Dellaverson, the M.T.A.'s chief labor negotiators, differed with some experts over estimates of what the contract would cost the transit agency. While several experts said the increased health contributions would raise the authority's labor costs by 2 percent over the life of the contract, Mr. Shaw put the cost at less than one-fourth that amount.
In another important provision, the authority pledged to seek legislation that would enable transit workers now paying 5.3 percent of their income toward pension contributions to pay just 2 percent. While union officials said on Wednesday that such a move would effectively increase most workers' pay by 3.3 percent during the first year of the contract, the M.T.A. officials said that provision would not go into effect until the contract's second year.
This would mean most workers would receive a 5 percent effective increase in pay in the first year, and a 6.3 percent increase in the second -- that year's 3 percent wage increase plus the 3.3 percent reduction in the amount deducted from their paychecks for pension contributions.
Mr. Shaw said this pension provision would not require the M.T.A. to spend its own money to offset the workers' reduced pension contributions. Thanks to the Wall Street boom, he explained, the pension plan already holds enough money to cover the workers' pension obligations even with the smaller contributions. "This contract meets the fair and reasonable test and is not being done on the backs of the workers or the passengers," he said.
Several labor experts said the M.T.A. had hoped to keep wage increases to about 3 percent a year. But these experts said the wage increases averaging 4 percent would not unduly strain the agency's finances because each extra 1 percent in labor costs comes to just $16 million a year. New York City Transit's operating budget in the 1998 fiscal year was $3.8 billion.
Mr. Shaw said the contract would save the M.T.A. some money -- he would not say how much -- through more flexible work rules that allow individual workers to handle more responsibilities. An engine mechanic, for example, might also now do body work. He said this was in no way a concession. Mr. James said the union accepted these productivity measures because the contract promises no layoffs and because workers will be paid extra when they are trained to take on additional responsibilities.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Why India and Others See U.S. as Villain on Trade

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Dec. 16

 BODY:
The week after global trade talks collapsed in Seattle, India's commerce and industry minister rose in Parliament here to denounce what he called a pernicious attempt by the richest, most powerful nations -- led by President Clinton -- to rob developing countries of their great advantage in trade: cheap labor.
And, he said, what had really galvanized the developing countries' rebellion against the creation of a working group on labor in the World Trade Organization was Mr. Clinton's remark, in an interview with a Seattle newspaper, about an eventual use of trade sanctions against nations that failed to comply with international labor standards. 
 The cabinet minister, Murasoli Maran, who was India's chief representative at the talks, described Mr. Clinton's statements as having electrified envoys from developing countries, made the danger to their economic interests clear, and unified them in opposition to any linkage of trade and labor standards.
"Sir, finally the last straw was cast by President Clinton himself," Mr. Maran declared. "It made all the developing countries and least-developing countries to harden their position. It created such a furor that they all felt the danger ahead."
In large part because of Mr. Clinton's handling of the issue, the American attempt to add labor issues to the international trade agenda widened the gulf between rich and poor nations and contributed to the collapse of the latest efforts to further free up world trade.
In the eyes of India, Egypt and other third world nations, Mr. Clinton's call to link trade accords to labor standards for workers around the world was protectionism in the guise of idealism, motivated by his desire to woo labor union support for the presidential campaign of his vice president, Al Gore.
Some delegates from developing countries even expressed the belief that he had orchestrated the sometimes violent street protests in Seattle to justify the American position.
"The Western world, the industrialized world, wants to take away our comparative advantage," Mr. Maran said. "It is a pernicious way of robbing our comparative advantage. The developing countries consider it as a maneuver by wealthy nations to force our wages up, to undermine our competitiveness. This is the secret."
Opposition to the inclusion of labor standards in trade deals was not limited to government officials. In India, even labor unions that regularly battle employers for higher wages and improved benefits opposed using trade negotiations as leverage for a better deal.
Before the Seattle talks began, while American unions and others were planning street demonstrations to demand that trade accords protect workers' rights, Indian unions were quietly meeting with government officials and agreeing to oppose any linkage between trade and labor standards.
D. L. Sachdev, secretary of the All India Trade Union Congress, which represents 2.5 million workers in industrial and service jobs, said it was peculiar to stand on the same side as employers and the government.
But he and other union leaders here maintained that making trade agreements conditional on meeting labor standards could be used to keep out goods from low-wage countries like India, damaging workers and employment in those industries.
"Unfortunately, trade unions in developed countries feel that because of cheap labor and relocation of industries by multinational corporations, their employment prospects are imperiled," Mr. Sachdev said.
With some trade unions' backing, a group of cabinet ministers headed by Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee agreed before the country's delegation left for Seattle that India would oppose the proposal for a working group on labor and trade.
"This was not an issue on which there could be compromise," said N. K. Singh, a civil servant who is one of Mr. Vajpayee's top advisers.
The developing countries won vigorous backing from a group of African, Latin American and Asian academics, led by the Columbia University economist Jagdish Bhagwati. They, as well as a variety of labor and nongovernmental leaders, signed a statement against including labor and environmental issues in trade deals. Their contention was that the labor issues in particular are selectively used against developing countries for the economic gain of the richer nations. For example, President Clinton had cited child labor, a problem of developing countries like India, but had made no mention of lax enforcement of laws to protect workers in garment sweatshops or migrant farm workers in the United States.
Professor Bhagwati, who began calling for India to open itself to foreign trade and investment 25 years before it began to do so, said that those who signed the statement were strong opponents of child labor and bad working conditions, but thought that trade deals were the wrong place to combat them.
The Indian delegation arrived in Seattle not expecting that the labor issue would be at the top of the American agenda. Just a month earlier, the United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, had met in Lausanne, Switzerland with ministers from more than 20 countries, including India, Brazil, Egypt, South Africa and Argentina, and assured them that the United States wanted a group that would only study labor issues, officials here said. It had no intention, the officials added, of taking the matter any further.
Since the Seattle talks collapsed on Dec. 3, President Clinton has said that India and Pakistan, another outspoken opponent of linking trade and labor standards, had misunderstood his remarks.
The president said he had not meant to suggest that the United States would cut off American markets to India and Pakistan if they did not raise wages to American levels.
But government officials and labor leaders here say they see the United States as calculatingly pursuing its own interests on trade -- and they are girding for future battle.
Mr. Maran, speaking in Parliament, said, "If you ask me to tell you in one word what happened in Seattle, my answer will be, 'We have postponed D-Day.' "

HEADLINE: THE NEEDIEST CASES;
A License to Practice Medicinal Love

BYLINE: By RACHEL E. INGBER 

 BODY:
Although Nina A., a doctor from the former Soviet Union, told New York rescue workers that her husband, Boris, was having a heart attack, at first they diagnosed only his high blood pressure. Nina was unable to help because she could not speak English well, nor did she have a license to practice medicine in the United States.
Nina, who is 63, still practices medicine unofficially -- devoting six to seven hours a day to the care of Boris, who has been in a coma since the heart attack a year and a half ago. Nina finds hope in small improvements, like when her husband responds to her voice or flinches in pain. But Boris's doctors at the Cliffside Nursing Home in College Point, Queens, have told Nina that her only real hope is "to pray to God." Her husband's central nervous system is slowly deteriorating, and Nina cannot afford expensive neurological exams. 
 After spending a full day at the nursing home, and an hour and a half on two buses to return to her apartment in Rego Park, Queens, Nina rushes home to care for her mother, Evelina, who had a stroke four months before the family moved to the United States.
Nina, Boris and Evelina immigrated to the United States in 1994 from Uzbekistan, searching for greater religious freedom. During the Soviet years, anti-Semitism, from the government and neighbors, forced Nina's family to practice a "closed doors, closed windows" form of Judaism. Nina became used to schoolyard taunts of "move to Israel" at an early age.
Despite discrimination against Jews, Nina's family prospered in Uzbekistan. Nina and Boris met in the park as students, and married in 1965. Nina trained 10 years for a medical degree with a specialty in infectious diseases, and raised three children.
But the anti-Semitic climate at home only intensified in recent years, she said, once people were more free to speak their minds and the economy worsened. Even though their children immigrated to Israel, Nina and Boris moved to Queens to join a tight-knit community of Jews from their part of the world.
When the family arrived in the United States, Boris, who was a civil engineer in Uzbekistan, cleaned streets while learning job skills and English. Nina also dedicated herself to studying English so that she could retake her medical exams and practice in the United States.
Nina's studies were interrupted when a car hit her while she was waiting for a bus in 1995. She was in a wheelchair for eight months and had three surgeries within the next year, two knee operations and one to remove a tumor from her uterus.
In Uzbekistan, Nina led a productive life helping patients, but by July 1999, she was tired and depressed from long days of caring for loved ones and ashamed of being on public assistance. On a friend's suggestion, she called Bluma Palvanova, a social worker at the Rego Park Counseling Center in Queens.
The center runs support groups for recent emigres, helping them overcome culture shock, pass the citizenship test and learn English.
Nina diligently completes the homework and looks forward to her group sessions every Monday at the center, which is run by the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, a beneficiary of the UJA-Federation, one of seven local charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
Ms. Palvanova, who is also from Uzbekistan, leads six adjustment groups a week and helps Nina and her 90 other clients navigate the daunting system of immigration and welfare agencies.
The majority of Ms. Palvanova's clients are like Nina -- highly educated Russians over the age of 60 who have a more difficult time adjusting to the cultural changes than their children and grandchildren. Some staff members at the counseling center speak Persian and Hebrew, in addition to Russian.
Nina has access to Rego Park's staff of social workers and psychologists who offer therapy, emergency financial assistance and job placement to an average of 300 to 400 immigrants per year. The counseling center has found a Russian-speaking home attendant to care for Evelina four hours a day.
Since participating in counseling at the Rego Park center, Nina says she no longer feels as helpless and overwhelmed. The other members of her adjustment group telephone her often during the week to find out how she is coping.
With this emotional support, Nina has enough energy to devote her attention to Boris. She is positive that she makes him feel better. Every day, she lovingly bathes him and massages his hands so they do not turn blue from lack of circulation.
"When one is kind and shows good feeling, that is more important than any medicine or surgery," she says.

HEADLINE: Public Interests;
Hold the Gluten Gruel

BYLINE: By GAIL COLLINS 

 BODY:
A century ago, a writer named Paul Devinne published a novel about a man who falls asleep in 1900 and wakes up in New York City in the year 2000. Here's how the hero describes the area that's currently my neighborhood:
" 'Glorious' was the only word I could utter. As far as the mammoth city extended, I saw only one huge garden, pierced here and there by slender towers or giant cupolas. . . . Where in my time Morningside Park lay, I saw a gigantic Statue of Liberty, standing upon the great gold dome of a colossal building of vast extent and classic style." 
 Well, we do have some nice new plantings in the street divider by the Burger King. But we haven't quite gotten to Devinne's vision of urban renewal. It's just as well; rents are high enough already.
People falling asleep and waking up in the year 2000 was a very big theme around 1900. It started with Edward Bellamy's "Looking Backward," one of the biggest best sellers of the era. Bellamy's hero wakes up in an enlightened, egalitarian Boston in which the state owns all the businesses. Each worker gets exactly the same pay because everybody, from doctor to ditch digger, tries his or her hardest. People eat in beautiful public dining rooms. They shop at beautiful public stores, and the stuff they order arrives home before they do.
Readers fell in love with Bellamy's vision of a happy, cooperative and extremely white-bread society of the future. They formed Bellamy clubs to work on creating a utopia just like the one he wrote about. The book also launched a raft of imitators, like Devinne's "Day of Prosperity," in which everybody lives in marble hotels in what seems to be a state of perfect communism. In "News From Nowhere," the hero wakes up in a year 2000 London that's become a paradisical medieval village. Salmon swim upstream in the Thames.
One of the endearing things about these novels is the way the authors reorganize society to gratify their own particular little obsessions. "The Future Commonwealth" gives a great deal of attention to the efficient way travelers' luggage would be handled in 2000 -- and boy, are we glad that author didn't live to see the airports this weekend. In "Utopia Achieved," the hero spends about 70 pages describing the diet of the future. (Breakfast begins with "gluten gruel" and creamed potato. Supper is zwieback, cherry sauce and eggnog.) My favorite part of the Devinne book was not the four-hour workday, but the fact that you could call up any theater at 7 p.m. and get a ticket for the performance.
But the first thing you notice is the books' optimism, their excitement about the future's possibilities. (Well, actually, the first thing you notice is the awful writing. But the optimism would be next.) A hundred years ago, people all around the country were scribbling out their visions of what a good and just society would look like, and how to get there. Why aren't we spending this turn-of-the-millennium period working up utopian projections for 2100?
Maybe we're not into politics or societal self-improvement these days. Maybe that Soviet experience has made us leery of anything that looks like social planning. Or perhaps -- it's the holiday season, let's be optimistic -- we're just a lot more respectful of human differences. In all these utopias, uniformity was a given. Bellamy has every single person in the year 2000 behaving like a middle-class minister's son from Chicopee, Mass. In "The Ideal City," New Orleans is voluntarily segregated by happy black residents who enjoy keeping to themselves when they aren't doing the white citizens' grunge work. Written by a doctor, "The Ideal City" also has a general practitioner's view of the perfect society, in which the whole world is obsessed with hygiene. There are almost no traffic accidents because the streets are all one-way. Public kitchens provide everybody with exactly the same super-nutritious meal three times a day, and "no one thinks of demanding a variety merely to satisfy taste."
Middle-class Americans at the turn of the last century were unhinged by the huge influx of immigrants and labor unrest. They wanted the world to move forward in order to make it more like the homogeneous small-town America of the past. We're smarter, at least, in understanding that utopia ought to be an equal-rights community. And it definitely would not serve zwieback for breakfast.

TITLE: LOOKING BACKWARD (BOOK); DAY OF PROSPERITY (BOOK)

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%);

HEADLINE: With a 'Don't Be Vexed' Air, Chirac Assesses U.S.

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 16

 BODY:
Among allies, France has had for 50 years a unique capacity to annoy Americans who may love French fries, French wine -- and sometimes even the French themselves, at least in those rare moments when they stop their constant hammering.
Irritation at the French is running high now in Washington, so President Jacques Chirac and other French officials are putting out the word that it is time to apply a little Gallic charm to their sensitive American friends. 
 "I do not feel in any way irritated or annoyed at the United States," Mr. Chirac said in a relaxed interview in French in Elysee Palace.
But Mr. Chirac, 67 and in his fifth year as president, spoke out critically on subjects ranging from the Senate's rejection of a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty, to the failure of global trade talks in Seattle this month, to plans for a new European armed force early in the new century, which in his view will by no means be an American century.
"I sometimes read that France wants a multipolar world so as to take the United States down a notch, or create rivalries to American power," he said. "I talk about a multipolar world because I think it's inevitable."
China, India, Europe (as Mr. Chirac believes) and Russia (according to Foreign Minister Hubert Vedrine) will all be great powers in the next century.
French criticism of American ebullience may seem as relentless as Cartesian logic.
"There are moments when Americans get exasperated and think all we're trying to do is create difficulties for them," Mr. Vedrine told a group of American journalists here the other day, and those moments have sometimes stretched on endlessly since the days of de Gaulle.
Nothing irritates the French more than being dismissed as cranks rather than accepted as helpful critics. Mr. Chirac in particular bends over backward to assure Americans of his friendly predisposition, proudly telling visitors that he has credentials as a soda jerk from Howard Johnson from a student summer in Cambridge, Mass., and has scores of American friends he considers family. So he feels entitled to offer a little constructive criticism.
"I have been, of course, an observer of Congress for quite some time," he said. "To be perfectly frank, there used to be prominent people you could telephone, ask about things, discuss, consult, have a dialogue with. Today it's more difficult."
On the whole, he said, Congress does not seem as open to the world as it once was -- "Not the best attitude, given the responsibilities the United States has in the world." He was particularly critical of the Senate's rejection of the test ban treaty this fall, a vote that threatens, he said, "to set a bad example and start the arms proliferation race again."
A decision by the Clinton administration next year to build a limited antimissile defense against intercontinental rockets launched by small nations like North Korea, Iran or Iraq would create more global strategic instability than it would eliminate, Mr. Chirac believes.
"If you look at world history," he said, "ever since men began waging war, you will see that there's a permanent race between sword and shield. The sword always wins. The more improvements that are made to the shield, the more improvements are made to the sword."
"We think that with these systems," he said, referring to the possible United States antimissile shield, "we are just going to spur swordmakers to intensify their efforts."
"China, which was already working harder than we realized on both nuclear weapons and delivery vehicles for them, would of course be encouraged to intensify those efforts, and it has the resources to do so," he said. "India would be encouraged to do the same thing, and it, too, has the resources.
"And it would also increase tensions within NATO, which would be too bad."
"The threat from North Korean missiles is sometimes mentioned as well," Mr. Chirac said. "Quite honestly, it isn't persuasive, but I'm ready to talk about it. I could be wrong, but I'm not the only one who thinks this way. But these are such important subjects that they ought to be discussed."
American criticisms of the rapid deployment force Europe plans to build for itself by 2003 as an attempt to torpedo the NATO alliance, Mr. Chirac said, just about caused him to fall off his chair. "The Americans kept saying Europe had to do more for its own defense, so we finally said, all right, we will," he said. "Now you shouldn't criticize us for doing what you wanted us to do."
American ambassadors in European capitals made coordinated approaches before the Europeans agreed on the details in Helsinki this month, asking in no uncertain terms for close coordination with NATO and assurances that the European force would strengthen the alliance and not weaken it, according to French and American officials.
"The United States has to make a choice," Mr. Vedrine said. "They have always been for sharing the burden. They've never been much for sharing the decision-making. Obviously, there are some real questions we have to answer, such as how are we going to organize this so as not to interfere with the alliance. We are well aware that it's complicated."
Mr. Chirac was even more reassuring. "Very soon the Americans will understand that this is not going to cause them any problem," he said.
This time around, it was not the French but Tony Blair, the British prime minister, who in October 1998 first suggested a European armed force that could intervene in crisis situations where the United States did not want to get involved. Later, Britain and France, followed by other European allies, formally proposed one, and all 15 European Union leaders endorsed a 60,000-strong force in Helsinki last week.
"If there was going to be a real problem, Tony Blair would never have suggested it in the first place," Mr. Chirac said. "All this strengthens NATO, it doesn't in the least mean any diminution of our commitment to the alliance."
Mr. Chirac said he would not use Mr. Vedrine's word, "hyperpower," to describe the economic, military and technological power of the United States, perhaps because he knew it sent American officials into overdrive.
Still, Mr. Chirac, a Gaullist conservative whose current term runs out in 2002, said he understood the foreign minister, a Socialist who came into office in 1997 when Mr. Chirac called a parliamentary election he mistakenly thought the conservatives were going to win.
"In French, 'hyper' is a word kids like to use," like "super," Mr. Chirac explained. "When Vedrine said that America was a hyperpower there was nothing pejorative about it."
Mr. Chirac and the Socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin, along with the rest of the European Union, have said no to imports of American beef treated with hormones, despite American assurances that it is safe. The World Trade Organization authorized the United States earlier this year to retaliate by imposing high tariffs on European delicacies and luxury goods.
"We have been through some big traumas in France, in particular with blood contaminated with the AIDS virus," Mr. Chirac said, "so you have to understand that these things are highly sensitive."
"There are five or six hormones in hormone-treated beef, and of those, one is officially recognized by the highest scientific authorities as being carcinogenic," he said.
American officials have disputed such assertions, but, Mr. Chirac said, "You can't make us eat something we don't want to eat." The same goes for British beef, which France is refusing to import even though the European Union recently decided that it was now free of so-called mad cow disease, a neurological disorder in cattle that may be communicable to humans.
Mr. Chirac has called for an international world scientific body to resolve such disputes in the future.
Mr. Chirac and other officials say they are not trying to cause trouble for their powerful ally across the sea. Both Mr. Chirac and Mr. Vedrine, for example, charitably refrained from describing the collapse of the trade talks in Seattle early this month as an American failure.
"It's not an American failure, not a European failure, not a failure of the developing countries," Mr. Chirac said. "It will work out next time."
