HEADLINE: Mexico City Spawns Distant Suburbs

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 17

 BODY:
Cuernavaca, a city of gardens and golfers south of Mexico City, is still dark at 5:30 a.m. when Mario Betancourt, an executive with Pemex, the government oil company, crawls from bed, shaves in a rush and noses his car into a line of other commuters heading toward jobs in the capital.
In Cuautla, another city south of the capital, Roberto Aguilar boards a bus for his own two-hour trip to his Mexico City job varnishing antique furniture. 
 And at the same hour far to the north, in the city of Pachuca on the other side of the vast capital, Javier Chavez, a computer specialist, is beginning his daily drive to work at a Mexico City cellular phone company.
A new class of commuters has emerged in Mexico. A half-century after Americans began to abandon cities for suburbs, thousands of Mexicans are for the first time making a similar choice, fleeing the pollution and clamor of Mexico City in search of quiet houses, well-clipped lawns and safer streets in cities and towns hours away.
The commuters are bringing broad changes to the face of the countryside for 100 miles on all sides of the capital. Land prices throughout the suburban region are rising fast, and the few patches of farm or forest land that remain near major highways are quickly being bulldozed for strip malls and housing developments.
At the same time, the commuters appear to be fueling economic growth in dozens of towns and cities. Schools, hospitals and other services in some suburban towns are being improved to meet middle-class standards.
The daily commute here offers more daunting challenges than those faced by most straphangers and car-poolers in the United States and Europe.
Traffic jams are horrendous. And the cost of parking, gasoline and roadway tolls, which are among the highest in the world, can drive the price of the daily commute by car from many suburban towns above $20 a day. As a result, even many doctors, lawyers and other professionals prefer to travel by bus.
"This is a very Mexican-style suburbanization process," said Reina Corona Cuapio, an urbanologist at the National Autonomous University who conducted a survey that aims to provide the first preliminary profile of Mexico's burgeoning commuter class. "It's taking place with almost no governmental planning, and the costs for commuters in time, money and inconvenience are high."
North of the border, commuters have been polled, profiled and analyzed ever since the United States Census Bureau first included questions about "place of work and journey to work" in the 1950 census. The 1990 census showed that 24 percent of all Americans were commuting to jobs in a county other than the one they lived in.
In contrast, Mexican commuters have never been systematically counted, mainly because they have emerged in large numbers only recently. Ms. Corona's survey counted commuters traveling from Cuautla, 65 miles southeast of Mexico City, and she hopes to count commuters in the entire metropolitan area in broader studies later.
Based on calculations including revenues from highway tolls, she estimated that as many as 500,000 people may be traveling each day between the capital and six surrounding states. Probably a third of them are workers commuting to jobs, she said.
Even cities as far away as San Juan del Rio, 102 miles north of the capital, are being suburbanized, demonstrating Mexican workers' tremendous patience for grueling daily travel. Mr. Aguilar, the furniture restorer, who is 67, spent one recent month journeying by bus, subway and taxi to a job in a city far north of Mexico City, 180 miles from his home in Cuautla.
"I'd leave home at 5 a.m. and get back at 11 p.m." Mr. Aguilar said. "But I didn't want to turn down the job."
For most of this century Mexico City has been a powerful magnet, attracting millions of peasants to its industries and urbanity in one of the world's most extraordinary farm-to-factory migrations. The population of the Federal District, Mexico City's formal name, quintupled between 1940 and 1980, to 8.8 million from 1.6 million.
But early in this decade, experts studying Mexico's 1990 census detected a startling reversal. For the first time, the city's population declined in the 1980's, by about 600,000.
The figures showed a corresponding growth in many mid-size Mexican cities, leading some demographers to conclude that the tremendous forces of centralization that governed Mexico for more than a century had come to an end.
"Recently the process by which population has been concentrating in Mexico City has been turned around," concluded a 1995 essay in the population journal Demos. Because of crime, pollution and the high cost of living, "the city is now expelling rather than receiving migrants," the study said.
But further study showed that many smaller cities like Cuernavaca, Cuautla, Pachuca and Toluca that were showing rapid growth were simply being transformed into suburbs of Mexico City.
Eventually, the metropolitan boundaries of all settlements around the capital, from Cuautla in the south to Queretaro, 142 miles north of Mexico City, are expected to merge, creating one giant urban area.
"Towards the middle of the 21st century, this megalopolis will concentrate approximately 50 million people," Gustavo Garza, a demographer at the Colegio de Mexico, wrote in a recent essay. That will require Mexican commuters to be even more long-suffering.
"Sometimes the wasted time and the long distances drive me to desperation," said Mr. Betancourt, who moved his family to Cuernavaca because his wife came down with a respiratory disease in Mexico City's polluted air. "But you've just got to be patient."

HEADLINE: A Century Ends in Panama

 BODY:
It may be emblematic of our headlong, high-tech rush into the next millennium that a chance to reflect on one of the signal achievements of the American Century -- and one of its less noble subplots -- passed this week with hardly a ripple. The United States handed over the Panama Canal to Panama in a ceremony so bereft of American interest that neither President Clinton nor a single top official in his administration bothered to attend. It was a shabby way to treat a monumental human achievement created at the dawn of this century. Further, it slighted a profound and welcome evolution of American power as the century comes to a close.
The creation of a water passage across Panama linking the Atlantic and Pacific oceans was a phenomenal undertaking, the moon shot of its time. It relied on an ingenious "lake-and-lock" scheme whereby ships as long as the Empire State Building is tall were hoisted 80 feet into vast freshwater lakes created by dams and fed by torrential rains, connected by a cut through the Isthmus of Panama. But it was achieved at great human cost. Between 1904 and 1915 more than 5,600 lives, mostly Barbadian, were lost to disease and accidents. 
 The canal represented a coming of age for the United States as an assertive global power, better and worse. Theodore Roosevelt famously personified America's turn-of-the-century can-do ideal when, as the first United States president to travel overseas, he posed at the controls of a 95-ton Bucyrus shovel. But that zeal was inherently coercive, and over the decades it took on a neo-colonial dimension. Not a few United States armed interventions in Central America were aimed largely at protecting the canal from hostile powers.
"There is no Panama Canal! There is an American Canal at Panama," ran the slogan of opponents of the 1977 treaties signed by Jimmy Carter and Gen. Omar Torrijos that authorized a phased handover of the canal to Panama by 2000. Mr. Carter, who led the United States delegation at this week's handover, wisely persevered with a deal that signaled a more equal partnership between the United States and the nations of Latin America and removed the onus of maintaining a colonial enclave in a country whose people opposed it. Reflecting a belated respect for a small nation's sovereignty and pride, the world's only remaining superpower has voluntarily given up an immensely valuable asset.
One reason Americans can shrug off the deal is that the canal is no longer strategically or economically essential to American interests. Supertankers, aircraft carriers and nuclear submarines cannot pass through the canal, and software does not need to. Few doubt that Panamanians possess the wherewithal to make a seamless transition, but there remain legitimate fears of corruption and patronage in a country with little history of transparent government. Conservative critics of the deal have questioned Panama's decision to award port concessions to a Hong Kong company they say has ties to the Chinese military. But the treaties explicitly permit United States intervention if the canal's security is threatened.
President Clinton's lamentable reluctance to risk conservative ire by attending this week's transfer merely underscored the courage shown two decades ago by Mr. Carter and his Senate allies, who at great political cost forged an agreement that recognized how America's long-term interests in that important region were best served by partnership rather than domination. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: France Fretting That U.S. Could Become a Bully

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 17

 BODY:
Prime Minister Lionel Jospin of France, on a visit to Tokyo, said today that the United States should be "discreet" in exercising its global power.
Mr. Jospin, a Socialist, also made veiled criticisms of the United States in a speech in Tokyo on Thursday that were more pointed than remarks made by President Jacques Chirac, a Gaullist conservative, in an interview this week. 
 Both leaders chided Congress for sharply cutting the $370 million the Clinton administration had asked for to ease the debts of 41 poor countries, mostly in Africa, as President Clinton and other leaders agreed at a summit meeting in Germany this summer.
"The resistance of the American Congress on this point is worrisome," Mr. Jospin told his audience in Japan.
Mr. Chirac said: "Congress has recently made the participation of the World Bank more difficult. It's hard to tell why. It's not a very large amount of money, and we can settle it without the World Bank, or more precisely the World Bank will find the funds elsewhere. So why did Congress do this?"
Mr. Jospin also seemed to blame American negotiators for the collapse of the opening of a new round of world trade talks in Seattle early this month.
"Certain countries that chose to give priority to their domestic policy goals came with an intransigent attitude and refused to enter into real negotiations," he said. "That should reinforce our determination to counter any temptation to return to unilateralism."
In French political discourse, "unilateralism" is a uniquely American sin.
Mr. Jospin said France, which will hold the rotating presidency of the European Union in the second half of next year, wanted to hold a high-level meeting of member countries in the World Trade Organization to draw lessons from Seattle and make it "more effective, more open and more democratic."
He also took a dig at the United States for failing to pay all its dues to the United Nations.
"All member states should fulfill their financial obligations," he said. "France and Japan do that completely and unconditionally. A responsible attitude by all contributor nations would encourage the necessary reforms of the organization, including the Security Council."

HEADLINE: In Poll, New York Catholics Call Poverty a Top Concern

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO with MARJORIE CONNELLY

 BODY:
As Cardinal John O'Connor prepares to step down as archbishop, Roman Catholics in his New York archdiocese are hoping for a successor who will be more spiritual than political, a compassionate leader who will tackle poverty and homelessness as priorities of the church, a survey by The New York Times has found.
A strong majority of Catholics polled in the New York region said things were going well or excellently for the church in America. As Catholics do nationally, though, they favor modernizing and opening up the church, by allowing priests to marry, ordaining women as priests and granting lay people a greater say in naming bishops. 
 In the midst of an economic boom, Catholics in the financial capital of the world's richest country told pollsters in several ways that they consider poverty and homelessness the most serious problems the church should address.
The survey offered a snapshot of feelings among the New York archdiocese's 2.4 million Catholics at a pivotal moment in the life of their church. Church officials expect Cardinal O'Connor, the leader of the church in New York for the last 15 years, to step down soon.
Though the cardinal, following tradition, offered Pope John Paul II his resignation upon turning 75, the pope did not accept it. But next month, the cardinal will turn 80, automatically losing his vote in the papal conclave. He has also been battling ill health recently, after surgery last summer to remove a brain tumor. For the last two Sundays, he has not said Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral and has not appeared in public.
In addition to questions about the next archbishop, the poll asked Catholics about the cardinal, whose voice has been a prominent one on some of most debated issues of the day. But among New York Catholics, he seemed to carry a low profile.
While 57 percent had a favorable view of him, and just 6 percent had an outright unfavorable opinion, only a small percentage could name the best, or worst, things he has done as archbishop. Spiritually, they say they are more influenced by Pope John Paul II and by their local priests than they are by the cardinal. Forty-two percent said his stands on social and political issues had no influence on them at all.
The findings, religious experts said, appear to reflect the ambiguity inherent in the position of archbishop itself, which even Cardinal O'Connor's political visibility has been unable to overcome. A spokesman for the archdiocese questioned the usefulness of the poll and declined to comment on the results.
The findings also demonstrate the increasing independence of Catholics, a trend that most experts on the church say began with the changes of the Second Vatican Council in the 1960's and has deepened throughout Pope John Paul II's return to a stricter, more hierarchical tradition.
Though the cardinal leads the archdiocese -- through his public stands, management of finances and assignment of priests -- his influence is not always direct or obvious. To most churchgoers, archbishops are more distant figures than their parish priests, and yet not as exalted as the pope. Thirty-two percent of New York Catholics said their priests had "a lot" of effect on their spiritual lives, while 39 percent said the same of the pope. Only 16 percent said the same of Cardinal O'Connor.
"I don't really listen to what the archbishop says," said Abraham Blanco, 74, a retired butcher in the Bronx who was reinterviewed after responding to the poll. Mr. Blanco said he paid more mind to the pope, whom he admires for his extensive tours of the developing world.
Peter Awn, a professor of comparative religion at Columbia University, said the cardinal's role is more "as a father figure and the unifying symbol of the church in New York."
The poll showed that Catholics were evenly divided over whether the choice of the next archbishop would make a difference in the life of the church. Asked for the most important qualities that the next archbishop should have, Catholics most frequently said that the next archbishop should be compassionate and humane, and should help the poor and homeless, show strong leadership and not be overtly political. In addition, 8 percent of those polled said they hoped for somebody similar to Cardinal O'Connor.
Among the 37 percent of Catholics who offered an opinion on Cardinal O'Connor's best qualities as archbishop, the largest percentages, 25 percent, cited his work helping the poor and unifying the church.
Asked about the most important problems facing the church, 59 percent had definite opinions. The most common response was poverty, followed by the shortage of priests, abortion, declining membership, and failure to keep up with the times and connect with people.
More than half of New York's Catholics thought lay people should have a say in selecting the next archbishop. The selection is thoroughly secret and draws in only select churchgoers sworn to silence; then discussions among bishops result in nominations being passed to Rome under papal secrecy. The final decision rests with the pope.
"I think we should have input, but the final decision should be with the pope," said Jasmine Thompson, a Manhattan job recruiter who was polled. She said she hoped the next archbishop would prove "open as you can be." She added, "I understand that you still have to support and defend the position of the Catholic Church, but I think that in some cases there is room for flexibility and compassion."
But another participant, Aloysius Manz, 71, of Montgomery, a retired manager at I.B.M., disagreed. "What you'd get is a popularity contest," he said. "A lot of the decisions a cardinal has to make are going to be unpopular with people, Catholics and others, but when it's right, it's right."
The Rev. Joseph W. Koterski, a philosophy professor at Fordham University, said the support for giving lay people more of a say in selecting bishops reflected the American enthusiasm for democracy.
In applying statistical methods to understand faith -- which can be amorphous and changeable -- the Times survey revealed an intriguing mix of contradictions among believers and nonbelievers.
Nearly 40 percent of those who called themselves practicing Catholics, for example, said they consider the church as an institution to be out of touch with the needs of Catholics today. But they gauged specific people, like their local priests, deacons, the cardinal and the pope, as more aware of their problems.
Just the same, a majority of practicing Catholics said they seldom or never consult their priests about personal problems.
Nearly one in four people who identified themselves as former Catholics said nevertheless that the pope had some or a lot of influence on their spiritual lives.
Of all Catholics polled, only 2 percent consider the sacraments the most important aspect of being a Catholic. Far more important, they said, were faith, the church teachings and belief in Jesus.
The Rev. Thomas J. Reese, a Jesuit, said the survey's findings illustrate that faith is complex, and that the decision to go to church springs from the spiritual quest for meaning, not from feelings about a specific clergyman or even a teaching.
"It's not surprising that people recognize our limitations," said Father Reese, the author of the 1989 book, "Archbishop: Inside the Power Structure of the American Catholic Church." "What's remarkable is that people still come. They're seeing something that's deeper than the human reality."
The poll found practicing Catholics were much more inclined to be opposed to extramarital sex than to homosexuality: 68 percent said a person "who engages in homosexual relations" could still be a good Catholic, while only 42 percent said a person "who is having an affair outside of marriage" could be one.
New York Catholics appeared more accepting of homosexuality than church leaders are, and some found fault with the cardinal for taking a public stand on the issue. Elizabeth Gray, 45, of Monroe, said she generally liked the cardinal but disagreed with his condemnation of gays' marching in the St. Patrick's Day Parade. "It was like him telling the gays they're never going to see God, that they don't have a chance to go to heaven," she said.
New York's Catholics generally consider Cardinal O'Connor and other church leaders to be more conservative than they are themselves. For example, 57 percent favor allowing priests to marry, 48 percent say they favor letting gays be priests if they remain celibate and 61 percent favor ordaining women as priests.
But the survey found that Hispanics, who account for 36 percent of Catholics in the archdiocese, tend to be more conservative than other Catholics. They were less supportive of Cardinal O'Connor, largely because they felt they did not know him. While two-thirds of all Catholics in the archdiocese had a favorable view of the cardinal, less than half of the Hispanic Catholics did.
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
The latest New York Times Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from Nov. 29 to Dec. 5 with 1,615 adults who live in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York. Interviews were conducted in English or Spanish. The archdiocese comprises Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island and the counties of Dutchess, Orange, Putnam, Rockland, Sullivan, Ulster and Westchester.
Of these respondents, 567 said their religious preference was Catholic, 198 said they were former Catholics, and 853 said they were non-Catholics. For analysis, the responses of Catholics, former Catholics and non-Catholics were separated.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the 10 counties. The exchanges were chosen so as to assure that each county was represented in proportion to its number of active phone numbers. For each exchange, the final four numerals were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence, and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to geographic area, race, Hispanic origin, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results based on such samples will differ by no more than 2 percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all adults living in the archdiocese.
For smaller subgroups, the potential sampling error is larger. It is plus or minus 4 percentage points for Catholics.

HEADLINE: Racing in the Shadow of the City;
New York Area Seen as Ultimate Step in Nascar's Plan

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
Nascar has the answer, and it is that stock car racing is coming to the New York region, and the closer to the Manhattan skyline the better.
The 17 million people who live in New York's vast archipelago of city and suburb may still be contemplating the question: Are people here ready for the foot-stomping, rebel-yelling, hard-charging world of stock car racing? Will Manhattan sophisticates, Greenwich stockbrokers, Hoboken artists and the general run of suburban homebodies really want to jam the front-row seats to exult at the sting from bits of tar, tire tread and unburned hydrocarbons as the big cars go shrieking down the straightaway? 
 The country's two biggest promoters of National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing events are certain that enough people in the New York region want to do that to justify building a $200 million speedway somewhere in the region, most likely in New Jersey. To them, the New York market represents a $2 billion racing industry's final step onto the national stage as oval-track racing grows up and away from its Southern roots, where moonshiners first developed a taste for cars that looked showroom-normal, or "stock," but that could be souped up to outrun the revenue agents.
Speeding through the piney woods gave way to racing on the sands of Daytona Beach, Fla., and from there racing moved onto dozens of oval tracks, four fast left-turns to the lap, that quickly spread throughout the South and elsewhere.
Now, as auto racing proves its pull at the gate and among television viewers nationally, the promoters are building 200,000-seat superspeedways near Kansas City and Chicago and, soon, in Denver. But New York, the promoters say, would be the crown.
"We'd love to build a track where we could see the New York City skyline," said Jim Talley, a spokesman for the International Speedway Corporation of Daytona, the country's biggest race operator. "That skyline. That would be the ultimate!"
The I.S.C., as it is known, last March signed no less than Donald J. Trump, the real estate developer, as its partner in a search for a New York regional site for a superspeedway, so called because it would be able to handle the fastest cars.
Meanwhile, Speedway Motor Sports of Charlotte, N.C., a pioneer at packaging motor speedways with hotels, resorts and convention centers, has been looking for a place to race around New York City as well. "We are committed to the region, and we've looked at various sites in and around New York City," said Laurie Wilks, Speedway Motor Sport's general counsel.
In New York City?
"In, out and around New York City," Ms. Wilks said. "I really can't be more specific."
The very scent of high-octane gas and burning rubber in the local air has inspired a group of South Jersey elected officials and business people to lobby speedway promoters for a track near a World War II airfield at Millville, in Cumberland County, below Atlantic City. Donald T. DiFrancesco, president of the State Senate, and Jack Collins, speaker of the Assembly, either one of whom could be New Jersey's next governor when Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's term ends next year, have endorsed putting a track in the sandy soil of the state's economically depressed southern reaches.
O. Bruton Smith, chairman of Speedway Motor Sports, has visited the state five times since 1992, officials with the South Jersey effort said, and has met with Governor Whitman and other officials, but without reaching any deals yet.
Mr. Trump, however, has already rejected the South Jersey site, as well as a location in Suffolk County on Long Island, but local promoters hope he will change his mind. Mr. Trump's group, I.S.C., apparently favors a site closer to the New York skyline. The New Jersey Meadowlands offers such a skyline view, and Governor Whitman is said to favor a site that would help the financially ailing Meadowlands Authority, which now requires a huge annual state subsidy.
But a modern superspeedway along with its attractions and amenities takes about 1,000 acres of land, Mr. Talley said, and the Meadowlands, with Giants Stadium, the Meadowlands Racetrack and Continental Airlines Arena already on it, has only 759 acres.
"It's not an appropriate use of the Meadowlands," Mr. DiFrancesco told the New Jersey Conference of Mayors in September. The Meadowlands Authority, after confirming earlier in the week that it had been in contact with race promoters, has since gone mum.
"We cannot comment on whether we had a meeting with Nascar," said Dan Emmer, a spokesman. Asked if there was enough room in the Meadowlands for a Nascar-size speedway, Mr. Emmer said, "What kind of room there is in the Meadowlands is not something that we can speculate on at this point."
An official of the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Authority, which coordinates economic development for a dozen North Jersey municipalities, said: "A thousand acres? Forget about it."
There may be other problems to overcome before people in the region see their first checkered flag. Speedway developers are accustomed to large public subsidies to help build their tracks. But that level of tax support for sports promoters is a tougher sell in both New York and New Jersey.
In 1987, for example, New Jersey voters rejected a $185 million bond issue to build a baseball stadium in Lyndhurst, even when George M. Steinbrenner III, principal owner of the Yankees, was dangling his team before them.
Speedway supporters like Donald L. Fauerbach, executive director of the New Jersey Conference of Mayors and a Nascar racing team owner himself, say that the state that wins a speedway would have to put in no more than the usual access roads and sewer lines, something done for Atlantic City casinos.
Of course, plenty of people could not care less whether Nascar moves in. "I don't understand the mentality of people who pay good money to watch those cars go around and around," said Eric Mihan, a retired Princeton haberdasher. "But then those people will probably say they don't understand the mentality of people who go and watch someone hit a tennis ball back and forth."
But Mr. Fauerbach said people here would pay $50 to $90 for three hours of racing because Nascar racing had grown up. "Nascar racing is not just a bunch of rednecks anymore," Mr. Fauerbach said. "It's champagne helicopter executives who come in and follow this sport. It's Fortune 500 captains of American industry wining and dining themselves and their employees."
Certainly Nascar racing has changed with the boom in television coverage. The sport known for custom-made muscle cars that are festooned with advertising logos used to be nearly entirely dependent on products you had to be 18 or 21 to buy: snuff, cigarettes and beer.
Now, although the Winston Cup series and the Busch (beer) series are still the premier events in Nascar racing, federal and state tobacco suit settlements have reduced tobacco's role in Nascar.
Drivers who are too young to smoke legally may no longer win prizes in race series named for tobacco products.
The tobacco settlement has sharply curtailed the kinds of advertising tobacco companies may do at Nascar events, forbidding, for example, a display of tobacco logos on the race cars themselves. But even as tobacco restrictions increased, Nascar promoters were looking well beyond the Southern males who were the sport's first and most devoted fans.
According to Nascar, 39 percent of the most dedicated fans are women, and more than a third report incomes of more than $50,000.
Now only National Football League games earn a higher television rating than Nascar's premier races, and race attendance has grown 65 percent since 1990, to 6.3 million people last year.
But will they come? There are Nascar-sanctioned tracks in Flemington, N.J., Pocono, Pa., and at Watkins Glen in upstate New York. Neither are the 1.5-mile, steeply banked ovals used for top events like the Winston Cup, however.
Rick Kuhl is the co-promoter, with his father Paul, at Flemington Speedway, in central New Jersey. It is a short-track course, where racing speeds stay below about 85 miles per hour, compared with speeds approaching 200 miles at superspeedways, and Mr. Kuhl has seen his business fall off as Nascar developed its high speed supertracks.
Mr. Kuhl charges $14 admission, with children and parking free, compared with an average price of $90 per admission to a Winston Cup race. But he thinks the promoters have little to worry about in trying to break into the New York market.
"You're talking millions and millions of people in the New York area, and all they need is 150,000 people to be interested," Mr. Kuhl said. "They'll find them."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
GOODRICH MOVES TO DISMISS 24% OF ITS WORK FORCE

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

 BODY:
The B. F. Goodrich Company, the No. 1 United States maker of airplane landing gear, said yesterday that it would dismiss 500 workers, or 24 percent of the business's work force, close one plant and partly close another to cut costs after its purchase of the aircraft-parts maker Coltec Industries. The 500 workers represent the bulk of the job cuts associated with the Coltec purchase, said Kevin Ramundo, a Goodrich spokesman. Goodrich will close a plant it owns in Seattle and close part of another in Euless, Tex., that was owned by Coltec. Goodrich, based in Charlotte, N.C., expects to save about $35 million annually, beginning in 2002, as it eliminates overlapping costs, Mr. Ramundo said. An additional $25 million in savings will come in 2000 from consolidating corporate headquarters, he said.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Debate Between 2 Democrats

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the joint appearance last night of the two candidates seeking the Democratic presidential nomination, Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, as recorded by the Federal Document Clearing House, a private transcription agency. The town hall meeting was held in Nashua, N.H., where members of the audience asked the candidates questions, and its moderator was Ted Koppel of ABC News.
MR. BRADLEY -- I think that the issue really is the health care system is in real distress. There are millions of Americans out there today who have health insurance that are afraid they're not going to be able to see a doctor or to get a hospital. There are millions of middle-class Americans that are really on the brink of losing their health insurance. . . . 
 I think we have to help middle-class Americans also pay for their health coverage, and we have to help cover 44 million Americans who don't have any health insurance. I've offered a plan to do that. It's a plan that will make access to affordable health care available to everyone in this country. It saves billions of dollars in waste and fraud. It provides a prescription drug benefit for the elderly.
And I think that the question that I would ask Al is that the difference, the main difference, between our programs is that I do provide access to affordable quality health care for all Americans and his plan does not.
So my question to you is, Who will you leave out? Will you leave out the part-time worker who doesn't have health insurance? Will you leave out the downsized middle-class industrial worker who loses health insurance? Will you leave out the 40 percent of the people who live in poverty, who don't have any health insurance?
MR. GORE -- O.K., I'll answer the question, and the answer is very simple. I won't leave out anyone. I want to reach universal health insurance.
MR. BRADLEY -- But you haven't proposed universal coverage.
MR. GORE -- I don't think that it's lost on anybody that. Now let me back up. I asked the question about Medicare. Let me tell you.
MR. KOPPEL -- Hold it. Hold it. Hold it just one second, gentlemen. . . .
MR. BRADLEY -- You made a mistake, Al, he asked another question.
MR. GORE -- I don't think it's a mistake at all. . . .
MR. KOPPEL -- I'd like to add a little bit to your question. There's a fellow by the name of Trent Lott. You know him well. Senate majority leader, and likely to be the Senate majority leader next time around, too.
The gentleman's question was, How are you going to get any of these programs your program or your program through the Congress?
Neither one of you answered that question.
MR. GORE -- I served eight years in the House of Representatives and eight years in the Senate. I've got close friendships on both sides of the aisle in both chambers. I happen to think there's an excellent chance that we might see a change in the control of the House of Representatives. . . .
But in explaining to the Congress why this can be done quickly and well, we have to fit it in with the economy.
And the reason why I ask the question that Senator Bradley said is because one of our achievements of the last six and a half years has been to have a strong economy. And that means getting the big questions right. . . .
MR. BRADLEY -- I served on the Senate Finance Committee for 18 years. I defended Medicare for 18 years. It was through my efforts that we prevented premiums from going up on a number of occasions. Medicare is the most important public insurance program on health care that we have.
Medicare is now solid until 2017 in this country. The most rapidly changing area of our lives is health care. There is a great probability that people enter Medicare 10, 15 years from now will be healthier because they have been exercising, not smoking. . . .
But no one should doubt my commitment to making sure Medicare is solid. And I would even suggest that, you know, if we have growth higher than what's been projected, that we could use some of the surplus for Medicare. . . .
MR. KOPPEL -- My question is, It's been said that this presidential election is a battle for the American soul. What is your response to that? . . .
MR. GORE -- If you use the word "soul" in a deeper and broader sense, I think that all elections for president in this country are about our nation's soul. Who are we as a people? . . .
We have to have the wisdom and pragmatism to keep our economy prosperous so that we'll have the resources and the confidence of our people to challenge these problems successfully.
If we look out around us and see that we're in an information age where knowledge and learning is more important than ever before, we have to recognize that it says a lot about who we are as a people if we're willing to say to all the young people: We're going to devote the resources necessary to dramatically improve our public schools.
I've put forward a comprehensive plan for revolutionary improvements in our public schools partly because I think we owe that responsibility to our young people in order to respond to the ultimate challenge that is conveyed in that phrase. Who are we as a people, and do we have the courage to keep on moving forward into the future as we did in the past? . . .
MR. BRADLEY -- When someone says the election's a battle for America's soul, I think of our founding fathers, and I think of what Thomas Jefferson wrote about life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness. And I think about where we haven't measured up. . . .
But I don't view that as related to soul. What I view as related to soul are such things as, Can we cross the racial divide in this country and achieve a deeper level of racial harmony? That's the American soul.
Can those people who have resources turn their eyes toward those that don't and realize that it's in all our interests if everybody moves forward together? And, therefore, we do things like increase the number of people in America with health care. We eliminate child poverty in this country. . . .
MR. KOPPEL -- Let me, if I may, follow-up with a question of my own.
There was an ad today in, I believe it was "USA Today," taken by the Siemens Corporation, which had sponsored a contest. And they had taken out an ad in which there were the pictures of approximately 60 youngsters who were science contest winners. Sixty.
Not one was an African-American, not one was Hispanic, I think about 16 of them were Asian-Americans. A couple of them were Indian-Americans, not American Indians, Indian-Americans.
Which says to me that we are failing somehow in terms of educating young African-Americans, young Hispanic Americans in affording them the same opportunities that white kids and other kids have in this country.
What are you going to do about that?
MR. GORE -- Well, that's why I support affirmative action. Because it's still needed. That's why I support the most vigorous enforcement of the civil rights laws. That's why I think that we have got to turn around failing schools in the communities that don't have them. . . .
And now, frankly, on the science part of this, I think that it is a national disgrace that we are 18th out of 18 nations surveyed in 12th grade math. And the scores are lowest in the schools that serve communities that are large -- that are disproportionately poor and minority. I have put forward a $115 billion plan to bring about revolutionary improvements in our public schools. . . .
Now, I personally always opposed the vouchers. That's been a big disagreement for 18 years between Senator Bradley and myself. And Senator Bradley has not put forward a plan to turn around failing schools, or to lift up our public schools. I think that if you look at that ad, with those young people involved there -- not represented there, I think that it's one of many signs that we simply have to do a lot more -- not to have incremental improvement, not to settle for small changes, but to bring about truly revolutionary improvements.
Treat teachers like professionals. Reduce the class size. Have higher standards. Have teacher testing for new teachers. Make it easier within due process to get rid of the teachers who are not doing a good job. . . .
MR. BRADLEY -- Well, certainly I support affirmative action. I support strong enforcement of the civil rights laws. I also, though, think the issue turned to education, and Al said that I hadn't offered an education program.
I think that shows the difference between us. If your staff had checked the proposals I've made, they would have found that there's an education component of almost each one of the proposals.
The difference is, I view education as integrated into the lives of people where they're living their lives, not as a program that comes from Washington. I believe in a strong federal commitment to education.
And I believe in education from birth through lifetime and for everyone. And in this campaign I've laid out a program that would begin with early childhood education, that would provide funds through the states to the localities where child care could be decided by the local -- localities as to what's the best way to have child care in that community.
I proposed a doubling of Head Start, 400,000 new slots.
I've proposed that, in a world where we're going to lose over the next decade 2.2 million teachers, that we need to infuse our school systems with 60,000 new teachers a year, many of them aimed specifically at the categories that you said were low performances, in terms of math, science, computer education and foreign language.
The full text of the debate is available from The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com/politics

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
BANKS, J. EUGENE

 BODY:
BANKS-J. Eugene. A limited partner of Brown Brothers Harriman & Co., died on December 16, 1999 at Hightstown, New Jersey. He was 91 years old. He maintained homes in St. James, New York and Hightstown, New Jersey. Mr. Banks had been with Brown Brothers Harriman & Co. from 1942 until his death. Shortly after he joined the firm, Mr. Banks went into service in the U.S. Coast Guard. At the time of his discharge in 1945, Mr. Banks was a Lieutenant Commander. Upon his return to Brown Brothers Harriman & Co., Mr. Banks worked as an economist until he was named head of its institutional investment department in 1950. He was appointed a manager of the firm in 1957, and became a general partner in 1962. A leading authority on investments, Mr. Banks was the author of the "Guide to Stock Market Policy" in 1949, "Institutional Investment Guides" in 1955, and "Guides to Growth Stock Investing" in 1959. Mr. Banks was born in Kirksville, Missouri on January 26, 1908. After his graduation from Washington University in 1930, Mr. Banks joined the Boatman's National Bank in St. Louis. From 1932 to 1938, he managed the funds of a St. Louis family. He worked as an analyst with Fenner & Beane, one of the forerunners of Merrill Lynch, from 1938 until he joined Brown Brothers in 1942. Long active in civic affairs, Mr. Banks served for many years as a warden of Trinity Church, as a trustee of the Trinity Church Association, and director of St. Margaret's House. He was also a trustee of Teachers College at Columbia University, a member of the American Economic Association, the Military Order of the World Wars, Theta Ki, the Church Club, the University Club and the Down Town Association. Mr. Banks is survived by his wife, the former Barbara Hall, his stepdaughter, Mrs. Gardner Mundy, and two stepgrandchildren, Philip Mundy and Catherine McKee. Services will be held at Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall Street, on Saturday, December 18 at 11:00 A.M. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. James Episcopal Church, 490 No. Country Road, St. James, N.Y. 11780, or Teachers College at Columbia University, 525 W. 120th Street, New York, New York 10027, would be appreciated.

HEADLINE: E.P.A. IS ORDERING 392 PLANTS TO CUT POLLUTION IN HALF

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
The Environmental Protection Agency today ordered 392 plants in a dozen states, mostly electric generating stations, to cut in half emissions of chemicals that drift with the wind and add to smog along the Eastern seaboard.
The federal regulators acted under the Clean Air Act, at the request of New York, Connecticut, Massachusetts and Pennsylvania, which said they needed help to meet national smog standards. 
 The plants are in states as far west as Indiana and as far south as North Carolina. Agency officials said they might soon issue similar orders for plants in Illinois. Most of the plants met federal limits on the chemicals, nitrogen oxides, and are in areas that do not exceed smog standards, but now the E.P.A. is tightening the limits.
The states that requested the action are among a group on the East Coast that had already agreed among themselves to impose the stricter standard on nitrogen oxide emissions within their borders. The areas that would for the first time be forced to take action under today's order are in the South and Midwest.
The areas covered by the action today must reduce emissions by 2003 by about half a million tons a year, all in the summer smog season, the federal regulators said. Compliance would cost polluters, which include Ford, General Motors, the Dow Chemical Company and most power providers in Ohio, West Virginia and Pennsylvania, about $950 million a year, the E.P.A. said.
Carol M. Browner, the E.P.A. administrator, said the order would raise the cost of electricity by about 1 percent above what it would otherwise have been, but that because of deregulation of the industry, costs to consumers are still expected to decline.
Officials in several industries said today, though, that they were not sure what compliance would cost. Many executives and state officials from areas covered by the order denounced the act, saying they already met strict standards, that Eastern smog was little affected by Midwestern emissions and that the E.P.A. would ultimately be rebuffed by the courts.
In fact, the action today is in part a response to two recent court losses by the agency.
The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit ruled earlier this year that the agency could not enforce a stricter standard on smog levels, one calculated over an eight-hour period instead of the current one-hour. If that rule had taken effect, more areas would have been out of compliance, and more states would have had to take steps to cut emissions within their borders.
In a separate decision the court blocked the E.P.A. from requiring 22 states in the East, Midwest and South to order a new round of reductions in nitrogen oxide emissions from sources within their borders.
So now the E.P.A. is using a different provision of the Clean Air Act that gives states a way to reduce pollution blowing in from other states.
Ms. Browner said today in a conference call with reporters, "Our commitment is to solve the long-distance ozone transport problem."
"We're going to get there, one way or the other," she said. "We are going to get there; we are going to get people clean air."
The order to the states to cut nitrogen oxide emissions -- now blocked in court -- would have gone to 22 states and cut emissions by 1.1 million tons a year; today's order affects 12 of the 22 states and covers 500,000 tons.
The E.P.A. did not rank the plants cited on its list today. David Cohen, a spokesman for the E.P.A., said the four states that filed the petitions provided information based on computer modeling and "we looked at the broad categories to verify the fact that the sources were contributors."
In Michigan, one of the states with plants covered by the order today, Russ Harding, director of the Department of Environmental Quality, said that the appeals court was due to issue a final ruling this winter or spring on the E.P.A.'s effort to have the states order reductions. "I think it's highly inappropriate for the administrator to be doing this," Mr. Harding said. "It may make good headlines, but it's not going to solve clean air issues. She's just creating more lawsuits, wasting more taxpayer dollars."
In fact, owners of some of the plants cited today are already in court against the agency. Earlier this year, the E.P.A. was drafting an order similar to the one Ms. Browner issued today that was based on the need to cut emissions to meet the eight-hour rule. After the eight-hour rule was blocked, the E.P.A. stopped work on the petitions, but the lawsuits are still pending, an industry lawyer said.
At First Energy, the parent company of Ohio Edison, Ralph DiNicola, a spokesman, said, "The E.P.A.'s own studies have indicated that under heavy ozone loading days the Midwest plants contribute to less than 5 percent of the problem in the industrialized Northeast cities."
Mr. DiNicola said that in the East, people could see stone statues eroding, another effect of nitrogen emissions, as they stood next to roads with "12 lanes of stalled traffic."
"It is a little hard to then take a look at plants 500 miles away and claim they are the cause of it," he said.
Ms. Browner was not able to say today how many fewer days of ozone violations the East would record with the new controls in place.
In their petitions, New York, Connecticut and Pennsylvania cited vast swaths of states near and far, and categories of plants within those areas; Massachusetts, the other state whose petition was approved today, named individual plants, some as far away as Michigan.
Another four jurisdictions -- New Jersey, Maryland, Delaware and the District of Columbia -- filed petitions later that are still under review and that cover an area partly within the 12 states covered by today's order and partly outside.
Officials in the complaining states hailed the order. "The E.P.A. has come to the realization that we have come to a long time ago, that trans-boundary pollution exists, and that there are specific facilities outside New York's borders that are seriously affecting quality of air here in New York," said William Cahill, the state's commissioner of environmental conservation.
In 30 years of determined work, government regulators have forced extensive changes to cars, fuels, power plants and even hairspray to reduce emissions of chemicals that cause smog. But paired with 30 years of economic growth, they have not succeeded in eliminating violations, and, as Ms. Browner pointed out today, asthma, a respiratory disease made worse by air pollution, is rising rapidly.
At the Clean Air Task Force, a nonprofit group, David R. Wooley, a lawyer, said that the federal limit for smog was 120 parts ozone per billion parts of air, and that often in the summer, air drifting into densely populated areas of the Northeast was already at 90 parts per billion. Health damage occurs even below 120 parts, Mr. Wooley said, so any reduction would be helpful.
Others were skeptical. In Marshall, Mich., a town of less than 7,000, situated 100 miles west of Detroit, Maurice Evans, the city manager, said he doubted that his town's municipal electric plant could be affecting air in New York.
"We have a small electric utility," Mr. Evans said. "We've got very little pollution that's coming out of that plant."

HEADLINE: Bradley, in Debate With Gore, Goes on the Attack

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

DATELINE: NASHUA, N.H., Dec. 17

 BODY:
Displaying a calm persistence and aggressiveness, former Senator Bill Bradley tried to poke holes tonight in Vice President Al Gore's health care, education and gun control proposals in their second televised encounter. Mr. Gore, in turn, questioned his rival's commitment to education, health care and managing the economy.
Nearly two months after the first debate, when he declined to engage Mr. Gore, Mr. Bradley tried a strikingly different approach in their 90-minute encounter at Daniel Webster College here, which was televised tonight on the ABC News program "Nightline." 
 Speaking in his usual low voice, Mr. Bradley again and again badgered Mr. Gore with a refrain that his health care plan would extend insurance to all Americans while Mr. Gore's would not: "Who will you leave out?"
"I won't leave out anyone," Mr. Gore replied at one point.
But Mr. Bradley would not stop asking the question.
"No one," the vice president said once again.
"That's not true," Mr. Bradley said.
While Mr. Bradley homed in on health care, Mr. Gore said his opponent lacked a comprehensive education plan and scolded him for supporting a school voucher program while he was in the Senate. This week, Mr. Gore unveiled an plan that would spend $115 billion over 10 years to increase teacher salaries and improve public education.
"Every single time vouchers came up in the Senate, Bill, for 18 years, you voted for them," Mr. Gore said.
Mr. Bradley defended his education proposals, saying: "If your staff had checked the proposals I've made, they would have found that there's an education component of almost each one of the proposals. The difference is, I view education as integrated into the lives of people where they're living their lives, not as a program that comes from Washington."
At one point, Ted Koppel, the moderator, cut in as both men tried to talk over one another on health care. "Hold it. Hold it," he said. "Hold it just one second, gentlemen."
"You made a mistake, Al," Mr. Bradley interjected. "You asked another question."
"I don't think it's a mistake at all," Mr. Gore said.
Despite such clashes, the rivals for the Democratic presidential nomination agreed more than they disagreed. In fact, they agreed so much -- on everything from maintaining an even-handed relationship with China and Taiwan to calling on the entertainment industry to better police itself to advocating gay rights -- that Mr. Koppel noted that their differences did not seem significant. He asked them to contrast their leadership styles.
The political terrain has changed significantly since the first debate. As Mr. Bradley moved up in the polls here in the state that holds the first primary on Feb. 1, Mr. Gore has repeatedly, and aggressively, attacked his programs. Mr. Bradley only began fighting back in recent weeks. But his climb in the polls has stopped, and the two men are in a dead heat in this state, according to several surveys.
Mr. Bradley's assertiveness tonight seemed intended to respond to criticism that his campaign was too passive.
While Mr. Gore was less combative than in the first debate, he was still far more aggressive than Mr. Bradley. More than once, he cut off Mr. Bradley in midsentence.
Strategists for both candidates had predicted far more fireworks tonight because of an open format in which an audience of local residents and Mr. Koppel could ask questions -- and the contenders could quiz each other. The only requirement was that the candidates had to sit on their stools and could not roam around the stage (as Mr. Gore did last time.)
There were barbed comments, however, such as when Mr. Bradley sought to portray his agenda as more sweeping on gun control. "I'm the only candidate in this race who's called for mandatory licensing and registration and of all handguns in this country," he said.
The evening became particularly heated when the questions turned to health care, the major point of contention between the two candidates.
Asked what he would do to get his proposal to expand health care coverage to more Americans through a Republican-controlled Congress, Mr. Gore instead talked about how his plan could be paid for without raising taxes or jeopardizing other entitlement programs, like Medicare, the government health care program for the elderly.
Mr. Gore has frequently asserted that Mr. Bradley's more expensive health care plan might require raising taxes and would leave none of the federal surplus for other programs, including Medicare. The vice president asked Mr. Bradley what he would do to bolster Medicare as the number of senior citizens rises sharply over the next two decades.
But rather than answer Mr. Gore's question, Mr. Bradley threw a question back. Mr. Bradley asserted that his plan would extend health insurance to almost all Americans, while Mr. Gore's would not.
Then Mr. Gore focused on another part of Mr. Bradley's health care plan that he has frequently criticized: his proposal to replace Medicaid, the government health care program for the poor, with subsidized private insurance.
Mr. Gore touted his role in the Clinton administration's management of the economy, saying that protecting Medicare and Social Security would keep the nation strong.
"One of our achievements of the last six and a half years has been to have a strong economy," Mr. Gore said. "And that has been to get the big questions right," including protecting Medicare. "Bill does not set aside a penny" for bolstering Medicare, he added.
Mr. Bradley responded by saying he considered Medicare "the most important government program on health care that we now have" but said that it was not yet essential to set aside money to bolster the program.
There were no direct mentions of President Clinton during the debate. And neither contender directly mentioned the Republican front-runner, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.
But the candidates did respond to a question about how Mr. Bush and two other candidates mentioned Christ when they were asked about their favorite philosopher-thinkers in a Republican debate this week.
Mr. Bradley said he considered religion a personal subject that he did not want to discuss. But Mr. Gore said, "I affirm my faith when I'm asked about it." He added that "atheists have just as much of a right to the public discourse as any -- as people of any religious faith in this country."
Mr. Gore seized on a question about terrorism to embrace a Republican presidential candidate, Senator John McCain of Arizona. On Thursday, Mr. Bradley made a joint appearance in New Hampshire with Mr. McCain to call for overhauling the campaign finance system. Polls show Mr. McCain is very popular among independent voters in New Hampshire, a group that Mr. Bradley is also trying to court.
Asked what he would do to fight terrorism, Mr. Gore noted that he had sponsored with Mr. McCain a bill to control nuclear weapons.
The forum began with Mr. Koppel asking both about their wives and what sort of first ladies they would be.
Mr. Gore responded that his wife, Tipper, would be active and pointed out how she had "worked hard on the issue of health care" and had a graduate degree in psychology. He also said Mrs. Gore "spends a lot of time on the plight of the homeless."
Speaking about his wife, Ernestine, Mr. Bradley said, "In this case people will find Ernestine a unique human being; she would be the first immigrant first lady, having been born in Germany." He added: "She's real; she's dynamic. She will chart her way."
One of the first questions from the audience involved the issue of drug use and the questions about whether Mr. Bush had or had not used cocaine. Mr. Bradley has openly acknowledged that he has smoked marijuana in the past, and pointed out that Mr. Gore had made a similar acknowledgment, but said, "I think people have an understanding of the nuances of life."
Both candidates also spoke forcefully about the responsibility of the news media and the entertainment industry in policing the amount of violence and sex that young people can see. Mr. Bradley recalled the high school seminars he gave in New Jersey and mentioned how he once asked the students if they had seen someone killed. He related how two youths said that they had and then he offered a graphic description of someone being shot in the head. Speaking of one student, Mr. Bradley said, "Then he said, 'You know senator, it was nothing like it was on TV.' "
Mr. Gore called for "self-restraint in the media" and said, "Some kids are vulnerable to having seeds planted that bear bitter fruit."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 16; Column 2; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1520 words

HEADLINE: Raising Gotham

BYLINE: By James F. O'Gorman; James F. O'Gorman is the consulting editor of Nineteenth Century, the magazine of the Victorian Society in America. He teaches art history at Wellesley College.

 BODY:

NEW YORK 1880
 Architecture and Urbanism in the Gilded Age.
 By Robert A. M. Stern, Thomas Mellins
 and David Fishman.
 Illustrated. 1,164 pp. New York:
 The Monacelli Press. $85. 
 Over the past two decades the New York architect Robert A. M. Stern, in collaboration with various other authors, has engineered a monumental series of books on the physical history of the city from the late 19th century to the present. "New York 1880," chronologically the earliest volume in the collection, is the fourth to appear (a final tome, "New York 2000," is promised). It covers the architecture and urbanism of the post-Civil War era, with backward glances to the origins of contemporary developments.
You will want to spend some time in the gym building your upper-body strength before picking up this mammoth. "New York 1880" contains something under 1,200 pages and something over 1,200 mostly vintage photographs printed on highly reflective paper. It is 2<4> inches thick and weighs 7 pounds. Since these specifications are typical of the other volumes, we are looking at an aggregate of roughly 6,000 pages and 38 pounds for the series. A Kong-sized production indeed, but one justified by the richness of the subject, and well worth the price for muscular historians of architecture and urban design.
Given the number of illustrations, one might think this a picture book, and it would not be a surprise if more people scanned its illustrations than read its text. There is a long introductory essay, densely packed sections on building types (or, in current architecture-speak, "places") and a hundred pages crammed with footnotes. This is an amazingly thorough work of synthetic scholarship. All that is missing is systematic data about whether or not a building still stands, and if not, when it was demolished. Cryptic captions fail to give this important information, and the vintage photographs themselves offer no help.
"New York 1880" includes an expansive period of architectural change, from red brick and brownstone to buff brick and white terra cotta, from medieval to classical styles, from the filling of the island to the spread of the suburbs. It covers the years in which New York outstripped Boston and Philadelphia to become the great commercial center of the United States. In these years it began to pile office floor upon office floor to create the splintered skyline that heralded the profile of the 20th-century American city; and a mounting inflow of peoples, the newly rich from inland and the "huddled masses" from without, transformed the city's population from largely homogenous to multicultural and fed the widening gulf between the very wealthy and the miserably poor, expressed architecturally in the unbridgeable gap between the mansions of Vanderbilt Row and the "rookeries" of Five Points.
There are major architects here, but they are not the center of attention. Stern and his co-authors, Thomas Mellins and David Fishman, detail the architectural history of the era building by building, from churches and museums, through hotels and tenements, libraries and armories, to theaters and restaurants. The era saw not only the rise of the skyscraper but the flowering of other architectural types: the apartment house, the full exploitation of cast-iron building in the warehouse district and what the authors happily call "the art gallery of the streets," by which they mean the civic embellishment created by the competitively grand facades of high-end town houses. But the book is equal-opportunity history. It covers not only ornamental architecture but also the uptown shanties (which the reigning architectural magazine thought had "a nave charm peculiar to themselves"), Central and Prospect Parks and the infrastructure that made the dense urban complex possible.
Some observations here are economical, graceful and telling, as when the authors write that the dangerously crowded conditions of the tenements led to requirements for fire escapes that "dramatically altered the city's street architecture and to an extent its street life," or when they recognize different social implications for great Fifth Avenue houses, "in which the rivalries of established hostesses and the ambitions of parvenus would not only be played out in private drawing rooms and ballrooms but also in the architecture of the city's principal streets." Such characterizations point up the equally important private and public roles of urban architecture.
There is also the occasional nugget of human interest. It dramatizes the magnitude of Boss Tweed's corrupt reign to learn that his courthouse, begun in 1862, cost twice what America paid for Alaska. That the very rich and their retainers lacked touch with reality is graphically demonstrated by a journalist's description of William H. Vanderbilt's 58-room, $2 million Fifth Avenue brownstone as "a typical American residence." Misplaced confidence shines forth in the story of George B. Post's betting Joseph Pulitzer that Pulitzer's World Building would cost no more than a million -- and losing $20,000 when it did. And how many universal architectural sins are implied by one observer's remark that an early apartment building proved "far more impressive to the beholder than profitable to the owner"?
Much of the value of this history lies in quotations from contemporary social and architectural critics. Perhaps even more than the buildings, these demonstrate the gulf between then and now (although the vast abyss between rich and poor remains a constant). George Templeton Strong, whose diary is mined by every historian of the 19th-century city, noted that the "unventilated, undrained, sunless rookeries" that housed the masses gave rise to epidemics that were "God's judgment on the poor for neglecting his sanitary laws" and "on the rich for tolerating the neglect." When an architect died at the completion of a hotel ill favored by the critics, American Architect and Building News recalled Shakespeare's musing "upon the evil which is not interred with men's bones." And what popular critic now would write about an apartment house, "Of the two temptations of architects of many-storied buildings -- the Scylla of monotony and the Charybdis of miscellany -- the architects have steered clear of the latter"?
But such quotable passages are buried in a dense verbal mass. The aficionado will find the prolixity difficult to negotiate, and even the student of architecture and urbanism will open "New York 1880" more for the occasional fact than for extended reading. After the introductory narrative, the writing takes on the characteristics of a nonjudgmental catalog. One building after another is paraded, its architect and client introduced, its history detailed, its appearance described and contemporary criticism quoted. One building begins to blur into another; page after page of detail makes no concession to the reader's fatigue. Some of this is unavoidable; some is not. Much is the stuff of footnotes. We are told the definition of incandescent lighting, the name of the ship that brought Cleopatra's Needle to the city and the name of every known competitor in a competition, whether his design survives or not. For every building we are given the names, and in some cases biographical sketches, of owner and architect, and complete coordinates ("at the northern end of the block facing Greeley Square, bounded by Broadway, Sixth Avenue and 32nd Street"). Some paragraphs are mere lists of names and dates, addresses and adjectives (among which "pavilionated" grates the most).
But, all that aside, the thoroughness that numbs the casual reader is, paradoxically, the book's great strength. It may leave much to be desired as belles-lettres, but it is architectural history with a capital H. The method is multidimensional; architecture is connected to the rest of life. Buildings are tightly locked into the urban, technical, social, political, economic, demographic, stylistic and other conditions of the place and period. They appear to have been extruded out of the historical pressures of the age, and that is what architectural history should achieve.
All architecture is the result of the call of social need and the response of design solution. In the 1880's, as now, not even the great signature architects could work without reference to demands of urban society that buildings be economical and safe and that they follow some formal expectation. Building programs, technology, designers and stylistic bent may change, but the process remains constant. We gain perspective on our own work by studying processes of other times and other places. When urban architectural history is written, as it is here, as a series of social problems solved, rather than current celebrities praised, it is a valuable educational tool for professionals and persevering laypeople alike. "New York 1880" captures the complexity of architecture as design response. It is too bad it is not better literature, but it is difficult to imagine a better reference work in urban architectural history.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 10; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1390 words

HEADLINE: Brain Trusts

BYLINE: By Robert B. Reich; Robert B. Reich, the former secretary of labor, is university professor of social and economic policy at Brandeis University and national editor of The American Prospect.

 BODY:

The Rise of the Virtual State
 Wealth and Power in the
 Coming Century.
 By Richard Rosecrance.
 287 pp. New York:
 Basic Books. $26. 
 RECENTLY I woke up to discover that I'm working part time for a German company named Bertelsmann A.G. While I wasn't looking, Bertelsmann bought Random House, which published several of my books and still occasionally sends me tiny royalty checks. Bertelsmann is now the largest publisher of English-language trade books in the world. Who's "us"? Who's "them"? Does it matter?
Richard Rosecrance thinks it still does, although not the way it used to. Nations still compete with one another, and they still have different interests, but the terms of the competition have radically changed. During the first centuries of modern history (roughly 1500 to 1900), power went to countries with large amounts of land and key natural resources like iron, coal and copper. They enlarged their power by taking over lesser nations and their land and resources, adding to their military prowess. But roughly a century ago, and again after a pause for the Great Depression and World War II, the terms of competition shifted from territory to trade. Between the 50's and the 80's, the growth of trade easily outpaced the growth of national economies. With goods more mobile than capital or labor, the key resources became state-of-the-art equipment and well-trained workers. Thus were nations like Japan and Germany able to gain large shares of global commerce and indirectly exert significant influence on world events.
The central idea in "The Rise of the Virtual State" is that power is shifting once again, this time to nations whose people are most adept at summoning global financial capital and turning it into conceptual insights for sale around the world. Rosecrance calls these new centers of power virtual states, because their wealth and influence depend on intangible flows of money and ideas. They don't need a lot of exports to finance their imports and their investments in plant and equipment. They need a lot of brains, with which to generate research, software designs, entertainment, engineering concepts, advertising, marketing, styling, legal and financial innovations and information-based inventions. And it is brains -- not land, not armaments, not capital equipment -- on which national wealth and power will depend in the future.
In Rosecrance's view, all nations are evolving toward virtual states, but some are becoming "head" nations, specializing in ideas, and others are becoming "body" nations, making tangible products on the basis of those ideas. In the former category are the United States, the nations of Western Europe and some of the nations of Southeast Asia; among the latter will be China, Eastern Europe, South Asia and the African countries. Rosecrance concedes that the world may grow further divided, yet, like Jesse Ventura, body nations can transform themselves with enough emphasis on training their people's minds.
Indeed, this is an unremittingly cheerful book. Rosecrance expects the planet to become steadily more peaceful because nations no longer need additional territory in order to thrive. And under the new terms of competition, one nation's gains don't come at another's expense. Countries endowed with a lot of capital don't have to conquer countries with a lot of labor; they can just admit more immigrants. Nations with a lot of well-trained but poor workers don't have to pillage their neighbors for capital; they can rely on global capital markets to transfer money to them from capital-rich places, so long as nations on the receiving end remain open and friendly. Developing countries no longer nationalize foreign plants, because that would stem the flow of foreign capital, and flow is more important than any physical plant. The rise of the virtual state will inaugurate "a new epoch of peaceful competition among nations, promising a cooperative transition to the new millennium."
There's no room here for doubters predicting a collision of cultures between a capitalist West and a fundamentalist East or fretting about tribalism. Yet if Rosecrance's sunny forecast is not entirely persuasive, he offers abundant evidence for it. More than a decade ago, he wrote "The Rise of the Trading State," to which this book is something of a sequel. There's a bit of overlap, because much of the history is the same. But in "The Rise of the Virtual State," he ventures more daringly into a new digital economy whose products move through space at the speed of light, and offers some useful insights. Rosecrance, a professor of international and comparative politics at the University of California, Los Angeles, points out that Hong Kong, which used to be known as a cheap place to make things, now earns almost all its money as a center of business services. Moreover, as land continues to decline in value, population density is now positively correlated with a nation's wealth. Consider tiny Singapore.
Rosecrance also makes an admirably strong case for education and job skills as the keys in determining a nation's wealth and influence. A virtual state, he argues, must invest in its people, not worry about amassing expensive production capacity. "At the ultimate stage," he writes, "competition among nations will be competition among educational systems." Nations in effect choose their comparative advantage through the prowess of their graduate schools. But deciding to be an engineering center and not a biotechnology center will have little practical effect, he reasons, if too few citizens have the basic education to specialize.
But there's a paradox at the heart of Rosecrance's argument that he never quite addresses. Who exactly are the citizens of a virtual state, and what exactly are its businesses? Rosecrance refers in passing to a "new type of international crisis" apt to occur as virtual states compete, citing "a frantic two weeks" in December 1994 when, according to his account, the White House and the French vied over a $1 billion deal to manage Brazilian rain forests and air traffic; Washington won it for the Raytheon Company. But it's not at all clear what America's interest was in securing the deal for Raytheon in the first place. After all, Raytheon is fast becoming a global corporation whose employees and shareholders span the world. It's only "virtually" American. Presumably most of the people it would hire to work on these projects in Brazil would be Brazilians. A few years ago my home state of Massachusetts gave Raytheon a lot of money in return for its agreement to keep thousands of jobs in the state. A few weeks ago, Raytheon announced it was pulling the plug on many of them.
I like Rosecrance's idea of investing more money in the education of Americans, especially poor children who are now in lousy schools. But his idea neglects the central question. Whom does he expect to fork up the money? The money Massachusetts gave Raytheon could have been used for public schools, as could all the money states around the country are spending to bribe companies to stay put or move in.
What about individual citizens? By Rosecrance's logic, the citizens of a virtual state will, like corporations, be virtual citizens of the world. They'll be selling their services globally and investing their savings wherever they can get the best return. A growing proportion of the American work force is already employed by companies with headquarters outside the United States. A chief executive of General Motors once said that what was in G.M.'s interest was in the interest of the United States, but G.M. has now gone global. And what about DaimlerChrysler? America bailed out the old Chrysler; the new one seems to have moved its headquarters to Stuttgart. Meanwhile, the fund manager of my 401(k) plan is investing my pension dollars in Europe and Asia as well as America. And don't forget about my part-time job with Bertelsmann.
At the core of a polity are bonds that unite a people and give them a sense of belonging to a common culture. But a virtual state, by its very nature, generates few such bonds and snaps the ones already in place. Rosecrance may be right about the coming of the virtual state. But he hasn't explained why we or anyone else should care about it.
