HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Bankrupt Jersey City Co-op Returns to Stability

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
WE were hanging by a thread and now we have a cable to hold on to," said Howard LaMell, a board officer of Metropolis Towers, a 770-unit limited equity co-op apartment complex in Jersey City that recently emerged from bankruptcy and is about to enter the next stage of its revival.
Under a bankruptcy reorganization plan that became effective in May, the 21-story twin-tower complex was restructured as a free-market co-op, allowing its shareholders to sell their units at a profit. Previously, they could only sell a unit for what they paid for it, plus their contributions to the building's underlying mortgage. 
 This month Metrovest GPNJ L.L.C. -- an affiliate of Metrovest Equities, a real estate services company in Astoria, Queens -- will take over 350 apartments that owners walked away from in the last decade when conditions progressively worsened.
Metrovest GPNJ will also take over the lease for the 40,000-square-foot retail plaza that links the two buildings. The development, formerly known as Gregory Park, is on eight acres bounded by Marin Boulevard, Montgomery and Warren Streets and Christopher Columbus Drive, not far from the city's reviving Hudson River waterfront.
In exchange for the units, Metrovest has a commitment from a bank to refinance its underlying mortgage and restore the co-op to financial health. In July the company started to improve the buildings, including renovating its studio- to two-bedroom units, with 520 to 930 square feet on average, and in September it began leasing the 180 vacant apartments. The remaining 170 of the 350 apartments that had been abandoned by their owners are now rented.
As part of the plan the company will pay for most of the more than $10 million in planned improvements and the Metropolis Towers Apartment Corporation will contribute $1 million that it collected in back maintenance payments over the last year. As a result monthly maintenance fees will remain relatively stable.
"The complex is viable for the first time in its history," said Mr. LaMell, who is the outgoing secretary of the co-op board.
Metrovest said it also plans to switch to selling the units in the future. That prospect is helped by signs that the co-op market, hard hit by the real estate recession when values fell by as much as 50 percent, has rebounded.
"Co-ops are in concert with the rest of the market and values are back to where they were at the '86 peak, at least in Fort Lee," said Charles Oppler, a partner at Oppler-Ketive Realtors in Fort Lee, which has about 4,500 of the state's estimated 25,000 co-op apartments, according to Mr. Oppler's office.
Values have also risen in the state's north and central communities, said Marc Solomon, a partner in the Solomon Organization of Mountainside, which owns or manages buildings in 13 developments with 4,500 co-op unitsin that part of New Jersey. He said at six of his company's projects where unsold units are available nearly 200 were sold this year, the highest number since 1989, and prices have risen. For example, at his company's 702-unit Mountain Club in Parsippany, a one-bedroom that sold for $89,900 in 1988 and dropped to a low of $39,900 in 1994 is now selling for $74,900.
Mr. Solomon said factors stoking the activity include a lack of reasonably priced housing in good locations, a strong economy and rising rents.
Those involved in Metropolis Towers say the tight rental market helps the co-op, as does its location -- close to a PATH station and the riverfront, where rental towers continue to sprout. The activity is now spreading inland with a rental building rising on Montgomery Street, across from Metropolis Towers.
Those factors were part of Metrovest's decision to get involved in the project, said George Filopoulos, its president. "Given its size and the number of unsold apartments we felt the complex had potential," he said, noting that the monthly maintenance fees are also high enough to cover operating expenses.
Allen M. Turek, a lawyer at the Manhattan law firm of Hartman & Craven who represents the co-op corporation, added: "The co-op, once a liability, is now an asset."
BUT getting to this point has not been easy for the co-op, which was burdened with problems almost from the time of its tenant-sponsored conversion in 1986. The federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, which took back the complex through foreclosure when the original developer defaulted, sold the property to the tenants and provided the underlying mortgage. Tenants bought their units for under $10,000.
Then the recession hit and the co-op faced some of the same financial woes that affected many developer-sponsored conversions in the state, where the co-op form of ownership has struggled to gain acceptance. Those woes included defaults on loans by sponsors, nonpayment of monthly maintenance by shareholders and foreclosures by lenders.
New Jersey did not see the same level of co-op defaults as in New York City, and industry analysts agree that the worst problems are over. How many buildings are still under financial strain is unclear because the state does not monitor them.
The key problems at Metropolis Towers, said Mr. Turek, were that nearly half of the shareholders did not pay their maintenance fees and the co-op's structure did not allow it to collect those payments effectively. Also, the shareholders were undermined by a "lack of leadership and unity," he said.
Over time the co-op stopped making repairs and eventually 350 of the 770 shareholders walked away, only to be replaced by tenants, many of whom stopped paying rent. With its monthly income cut in half to about $250,000, the co-op defaulted on its $10 million mortgage, ultimately owing nearly $25 million, including accrued interest.
In June 1998, HUD, after several unsuccessful attempts to save the co-op, which defaulted on its mortgage in 1989, scheduled a foreclosure auction for August. Since shareholders in co-ops must keep up payments on an underlying mortgage on their building as well as on their monthly charges, a foreclosure would have meant that the apartment owners would have lost their investments.
Days before the auction, the co-op, which by then was negotiating with Metrovest, filed for bankruptcy to stay the foreclosure, said Mr. Turek. But HUD argued in United States Court that a stay could not prevent a foreclosure sale. Ultimately, Mr. Turek said, the matter was settled by the current reorganization plan, which 90 percent of the unit owners approved.
Under it HUD agreed to lower the debt $16.35 million. A new $20 million mortgage loan Metrovest negotiated with Dime Savings Bank, which it is to close on this month, will be used to pay off the old mortgage and pay for some capital improvements.
To convert Metropolis Towers to a free-market co-op the shares were reallocated based on the location and size of the units, some of which had been combined. While that led to an adjustment in monthly maintenance fees -- with some of the existing 420 unit owners paying more and others paying less -- the overall amount generated from the fees stayed the same, at $442,000 a month, or a range of $445 to $800 a unit.
Mr. Turek said that the co-op's bylaws had been amended to give it "the ability to enforce its rights against shareholders who do not pay their maintenance, and help it avoid past mistakes."
Mr. Filopoulos said that by trimming operating expenses, rebuilding value and "with everyone paying maintenance fees, the building can operate with a surplus."
Renovations at Metropolis Towers, now 70 percent complete, include installing new elevators and windows as well as giving the 180 vacant apartments new kitchens and baths. In the three months since leasing began, 100 of the units have been rented for $975 to $2,000 a month including utilities, which Mr. Filopoulos said was 30 percent lower on average than riverfront rentals. The complex has such amenities as parking and views of downtown Manhattan and the Statue of Liberty.
While the HUD financing was in place the units were not governed by Jersey City's rent regulations, but rents were low and had not been raised since 1991. Now that the rents on the unoccupied units have been raised to market levels they will be subject to yearly regulated increases. In addition, Metrovest said it also intends to do some renovation on occupied units and raise their rents after their leases expire.
For example, Mr. Filopoulos said, the rent on a typical studio will go from $540 to $900.
Though such a move is expected to be challenged by existing tenants, Mr. Turek said the city supported the increase.
Mr. Filopoulos said he had put off selling the units "until the renovations are complete and the building is stabilized." The goal is to get full-market value for the units, he added, estimating that sales could begin by the spring of 2001.
While encouraged by the recent progress Mr. LaMell, the outgoing co-op board secretary, said he knew there were challenges ahead. "We have a good chance to build equity, but time will tell," he said. "We must be alert to safeguard the foundation we have built and continue on a path of recovery."

LENGTH: 863 words

HEADLINE: OUT OF ORDER;
A 'Carol' Updated For Today

BYLINE: By DAVID BOUCHIER; E-mail address: liorder@nytimes.com

 BODY:
HEADING for dinner in Port Jefferson a couple of weeks ago, we walked into the annual Dickens Festival. The sidewalks were full of costumed characters: chimney sweeps, bobbies, ragged urchins, characters with names like Thomas Beg Alot, an Lord Dudley Butterworth, and, of course, Ebenezer Scrooge. There was a pretty Dickens stage set, the sound of bells and carols was in the air, there were candles in the windows, and even some real reindeer to be petted and photographed.
Charles Dickens has a lot to answer for. He more or less invented the modern Christmas, with all its excesses. When the Puritans were in charge, Christmas festivities were banned, along with plum puddings. In Puritan New England, Christmas was just a regular working day. Even up to the 1840's, Christmas was not much more than a date on the church calendar. 
 Then along came Dickens and his book "A Christmas Carol," and Christmas was never the same again.
Now Christmas is forever burdened with the ambiguous figure of Ebenezer Scrooge, the miser who was scared into becoming a kind of Father Christmas figure himself.
And it was Scrooge, that made me think that it was time for a change. We need a new moral story for our time. Therefore, in the helpful spirit of the season, I offer this updated, brand new version of Dickens's classic.
Consider the opening words of "A Christmas Carol."
"Marley was dead..."
This won't do for a modern story. We can't have elderly businessmen dying in the late 20th century, not with all the benefits of scientific medicine, and the prospect of a long retirement beside a golf course in the earthly paradise of Florida.
No, in my story Marley was on his way back to Palm Beach, after doing some Christmas shopping in New York. He took a trip to Long Island to see his old business partner Scrooge, whom he found relaxing in his huge house in Glen Cove, listening to his home theater system and sipping single malt Scotch whiskey.
"It won't do, you know, Ebenezer," said Marley, "All this high living, spending money like water. Why, I bet you've even been giving money away to charity you sentimental old fool, just because it's Christmas."
Scrooge laughed. "Of course," he said, "Spread a little happiness, that's my motto. After all, you can't take it with you. Anyway, it's all on credit. Have a drink"
"Credit!" shouted Marley. "That was always your weakness. When I get back to Palm Beach, I will send three spirits to haunt your dreams, and teach you the wisdom of financial planning."
That night the first spirit came, the Ghost of Christmas Past. He took Scrooge back to the Christmases of his miserable childhood. No heat, no television, no video games, no entertainment at all, except singing out-of-tune carols around the out-of-tune piano, homemade decorations, not much food and very few presents. Scrooge was depressed.
"I'd forgotten how awful Christmas Past was," said Scrooge to himself, "What a terrible dream."
Next night the second ghost came, The Ghost of Christmas Present in the unmistakeable form of Donald Trump. He was much more fun. He took Scrooge on a tour of London, Paris and Las Vegas, where they watched people buying $4,000 Hermes handbags, $850 Mont Blanc pens, Armani suits, Gucci shoes and Hermes ties, and yet more people throwing away yet more money in casinos. Scrooge cheered up and started counting his credit cards.
On the third night came the third ghost, shrouded and dark.
"I am the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come," he said. "Do you know where the stock market closed on Friday night?"
"Yes, 17,429," said Scrooge. "Do you have any good tips?"
"Repent," said the ghost. "Buy bonds, Buy government securities, buy gold, pay off your debts, stop spending on yourself, stop giving it away. The end of the world is at hand."
And he took the skeptical Scrooge and showed him the horrors of Christmas Yet to Come -- the Dow Jones down below 4,000, last year's Armani suits visibly being worn on Wall Street, Scrooge's platinum credit cards all canceled, and his limited-edition Jaguar repossessed.
"Oh ghost," cried Scrooge, "Who art thou that shows me such terrible things. Show me no more."
The ghost threw back his hood and revealed the bespectacled face of Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve.
"God help us every one" cried Scrooge. "I will repent," and so he did. He gave up day trading, opened a low-interest savings account, moved into a small apartment, bought a Honda, turned the heat down to 68, and drank blended Scotch. When gift catalogs and credit card offers came in the mail, he cried "Bah, humbug!" and tore them up. Scrooge was a changed man.
The Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come kept an eye on him for a while, and was satisfied. Indeed, the transformation of Scrooge was, as it was intended to be, a lesson to everyone. Four thousand-dollar handbags lay unsold in the stores, and people went back to wearing Timex instead of Rolex. The Dow Jones Index deflated, interest rates stayed down, the trade gap was reduced, and they all lived happily ever after.
Except for Scrooge, who always had the uneasy feeling that he had made the wrong choice.

HEADLINE: Companies Take the Clutter Out of the Office

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
WHO among us has not hopelessly shuffled through piles of paper, searching for an all-important document?
Paper clutter, a major office problem, is not only frustrating but also counterproductive, and the best way to deal with it is aggressively, said Celia Wakefield, whose business it is to move her clients from clutter and chaos to control and calm. 
 Ms. Wakefield, a professional organizer, works with both paper and people, helping clients to become more productive by gaining control over their papers, their projects and their time. She started Wakefield & Company in 1990 to fill a niche created by corporate downsizing.
She is among a number of similar businesses in the county, which were started in response to an increasing need to organize work space.
Louise Cristina, who started Organizing, Etc. by Louise Cristina in Mamaroneck 15 years ago, observed that the growing demand for home offices has substantially increased her business.
"I say I came out of the closet, because that's how I began," she said, "by organizing closets in clients houses. Now offices are primarily what I do. Either those in clients' homes or individual offices in offices."
Ms. Cristina, who teaches a course, "How to Organize Your Home, Office and Life" at Westchester Community College in Valhalla, charges clients between $50 and $75 an hour to set up an office. She said that most of her clients are "busy, successful people who don't have the time for such chores as setting up files and organizing space efficiently."
Ms. Cristina who has organized the offices of stockbrokers, dentists and retired executives, said her objective is to leave clients with a system that works easily, which she says is the mark of a good organizer.
Ms. Wakefield saw a need for new organizing techniques in corporations that were making do with fewer people working harder, and she also saw that the new breed of home entrepreneurs had the same needs.
"My goal is to help individuals and groups to improve efficiency and increase productivity," said Ms. Wakefield, who charges $80 an hour. "How do I do it? In a number of ways, such as time-management training, systems for filing, desk management, inventory -- all dealing with clutter control."
Ms. Wakefield calls herself a born organizer who as a child liked to keep lists and build systems into her life.
Eventually, Ms. Wakefield, who grew up in England, went to work for International Business Machines in London, where she met Victor Wakefield, an I.B.M. economist and statistician and the man she later married. When he took a temporary two-year assignment at I.B.M. World Trade Organization in New York, the couple came to America.
"That was 32 years ago, and we're still here, but now we're Americans," said Mr. Wakefield, who joined his wife's company after taking early retirement in 1988 from I.B.M. after 28 years.
The Wakefields share an office in their home in Chappaqua, where they have lived for 30 years.
Mr. Wakefield provides support for the company through research, by designing computer programs for clients to help them manage inventory and data and, he said, "as chief financial officer, I run the numbers tracking our growth and health."
That health, he added, is good. "We've always been in the black, with clients coming to us mainly by word-of-mouth referrals," he said. If the Wakefields help out their clients, "they don't need us any more," Mr. Wakefield said, "so we need a constant stream of new clients in the pipeline."
A surprising number of clients are working for Fortune 500 companies. "They are the executives who have been left behind after downsizing," Mr. Wakefield said. "Some are handling two jobs and yet they have no backup administrative staff available to them. Even secretaries are in a pool or nonexistent. They want to learn how to organize their offices for maximum efficiency."
The other group, the entrepreneurs with home offices, need much the same coaching.
A third group retains Ms. Wakefield for advice on managing employees and increasing their sales.
When Rolf Krauss, the owner of Graphics, a printing and copying shop that has been in Mount Kisco since 1977, wanted to get his employees more involved in the company, he called Ms. Wakefield.
"She spotted what was lacking -- communication -- and helped us with it," Mr. Krauss said. "And when I needed to hire a key employee, she helped me with the job description and the search. And the transition. Actually, she reorganized our staff so we work together more productively." And when Dr. Nancy Schiffman, an optometrist, found that the office paperwork she did at home was getting out of hand, she called Ms. Wakefield. "It was chaos," Dr. Schiffman said. "I work on a lot of claims at home, and I needed a filing system I could rely on. Celia set one up for me and helped me organize my papers properly, making it easier for me to get through the work. We're not finished yet, but already it's easier for me to get through the work."
How do you find a good organizer? Ask for references and ask questions, said Elizabeth Maffucci, who runs the Clutter Warrior in Tarrytown.
"Since it's a team effort between client and organizer, you have to have rapport," said Ms. Maffucci, who charges $50 an hour. "Many of my clients who own small businesses are buried under obsolete ledgers and records, and a large part of my job is convincing them to keep the taxable records and toss the others."
The demand for organizing home offices is such that Stephanie Schur of Space Organizers in White Plains said she could be busy seven days and seven nights a week. Instead, Ms. Schur has produced a video called "Secrets of a Professional Organizer," available from the Video Learning Library in Scottsdale, Ariz., for $19.95 at (800) 383-8811.
"There is so much paperwork generated by daily life, that everyone, not only people running businesses, needs an office today," Ms. Schur said. "Even one that is carved out of the corner of the kitchen, which is something I frequently do for clients."
Ms. Schur, who charges $65 an hour with a four-hour minimum for her services, also charges prospective clients $65 for an hourlong consultation.
Ms. Wakefield, who has taught time and management skills to students in the Westinghouse Science program at Byram Hills High School, is currently training students at the Women's Center at Westchester Community College in Valhalla how to work with mentors.
Yet, the Wakefields, who have helped many clients expand their businesses, are not applying the same strategy to their own.
"We deliberately keep our client list small," Ms. Wakefield said. "Balance between life and work is what we're after. If we want to take off and go to Maine for a long weekend, we do it."

HEADLINE: Skyscraper Museum/'Big Buildings';
Large Models of Accuracy

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
HOW to illustrate an exhibition on really big buildings? Start with a model that is no small structure itself: four towers up to seven feet tall on a landscaped base of about 125 square feet.
That is what Carol Willis did for "Big Buildings," the current show at the Skyscraper Museum, in the soaring former banking hall of 16 Wall Street, at Nassau Street. 
 The exhibition is rich in photographs, renderings and construction drawings, but nine architectural models really give it heft; appropriately enough, since the show concerns itself with large volumes.
Indeed, a model helped spark the show in the first place.
Ms. Willis, the founder and director of the museum, was offered the loan of a very large model of the World Financial Center at Battery Park City by Brookfield Financial Properties, owners of the full-sized buildings and of the plastic ones in which one inch equals eight feet.
As a scholar who views architectural form as an outgrowth of economic forces, Ms. Willis was already thinking about what she calls jumbo and super-jumbo structures -- buildings two to four times larger than the prevailing average for the period.
These categories include two World Financial towers, which qualify as jumbos with more than 2 million square feet of space each.
With theme and centerpiece in hand, Ms. Willis set out to explore the world's 70 largest tall buildings. (This being the Skyscraper Museum, the show excludes such horizontal land-grabbers as the Pentagon.)
She found that oversized buildings doubled in size every era -- 500,000 square feet for super-jumbos in the 1900's, 1 million square feet by the 1920's, 2 million by the 1950's, 4 million by the 1970's, when the World Trade Center was built.
The World Trade Center is represented by a wind-tunnel model that includes the towers, about three feet high, and much of the financial district. The point was to study how surrounding buildings would affect the force of the wind. It was lent by Leslie E. Robertson, the structural engineer for the project.
Easily the most exquisite model is a 51-inch version of 1 Chase Manhattan Plaza, its aluminum curtain wall facade rendered with crystalline precision, its open windows revealing the structure within, including the core. It was made by Theodore Conrad and lent by Chase.
The World Financial Center model was built in the 1980's by Awad Models of Manhattan to help Olympia & York, the developer, promote the complex to prospective occupants.
George Awad, the model maker, said he worked closely with the buildings' architect, Cesar Pelli. The most challenging element, he said, was the thousands of mirrored windows.
It is not the largest model Mr. Awad has made. That distinction probably goes to the World Trade Center of Tokyo, which is a towering eight feet -- but not in the exhibition.
"Big Buildings" runs through Dec. 30. The show is open Tuesday through Friday, noon to 6 p.m. There is a suggested admission fee of $2. More information may be obtained by calling (212) 766-1324 or at www.skyscraper.org.

HEADLINE: State's Social Health Ranks High, but Not in All Areas

BYLINE: By MAURA CASEY 

 BODY:
A STUDY released last week by Fordham University that measures the social health of Connecticut found that life is improving for the majority of citizens, but becoming increasingly stressful for some young people and the working poor.
The report, "The Social State of Connecticut '99" and prepared by the university's Institute for Innovation in Social Policy in Tarrytown, N.Y., studied how Connecticut is faring in 11 social areas and found that the state is performing at its highest level in nine years. The study said the state is providing the most affordable housing and the highest average weekly wages in nearly 30 years. The state also recorded good marks in infant mortality and high school completion. 
 Peter Gioia, economist for the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, cited the booming economy and the subsequent demand for workers as major factors in rising pay levels. He also said that the jobs gained in the last several years have resulted in a more diverse economic base than Connecticut had before the recession. No longer do the defense and insurance industries dominate the state; now there are many different industries and businesses competing for workers.
"A lot of people are getting their first shot at a job," Mr. Gioia said. What's more, he said, the demand for workers won't go away. "We are going to face a shortage of workers for more than a decade."
But the state did not do as well in unemployment, teenage births and violent crime and ranked very poorly in areas such as child abuse, youth suicide and health care costs, all near their worst recorded levels. There was also a sizable gap between rich and poor, which the study found has never been greater.
Although this is its sixth annual report on Connecticut, the institute uses data going back to 1970 to measure the state's progress over nearly three decades. Dr. Marc Miringoff, director of the Fordham Institute and a coauthor of the study, said that analysis of almost every topic in the new report is based on data from 1997, the last year that statistics are available.
He said that the institute also commissioned a survey of state residents. The survey showed that, while most people feel good about their jobs, 50 percent feel overworked; 35 percent had difficulty paying their mortgage or their rent and nearly 20 percent didn't know where their next meal was coming from at some point during the year.
"That tells you something about an island of trouble in a sea of prosperity, and that the island is rather larger than we thought," Dr. Miringoff said. "I thought it was high that one out of five people didn't know where the next meal was coming from. That's kind of scary. There's pressure on people."
Dr. Miringoff said that when examining these social issues, one-year fluctuations are less important than overall trends over the course of several years. He said that, based on a total possible score of 100, Connecticut earned a social health index of 49 -- 4 points higher than last year and the highest score in the 1990's, but still a lower score than was assigned to any year from 1970 to 1988.
Many people were not surprised by the study, particularly as it measured difficulties faced by the working poor.
"This rising tide of economic prosperity isn't raising all boats," said Michelle Doucette Cunningham, public education director of the Connecticut Association for Human Services.
The study made apparent that, while the cost of buying a single-family house is the most affordable, based on the cost of homes and income levels, since 1970, the cost of rents are higher here than nearly anywhere else in the country. Thirty-nine percent of renters cannot afford fair-market rents for a two-bedroom apartment, the report said; to afford such an apartment, a full-time worker would have to make wages of $14.59 per hour.
"Housing is more affordable for the middle class, but the people who can't afford a down payment for a house are paying more in rent than they would for a mortgage," Ms. Cunningham said.
"Low middle-income people are bearing too much burden," said John Olsen, head of the Connecticut A.F.L.-C.I.O. "We are still heavily dependent on high property taxes, which translates right into high rents. When you start to look at high mill rates in cities, that translates into pushing high costs onto the lowest level of citizens. Then we see four-acre zoning in some towns, which keeps out the poor people.
Others worried about the gap between the rich and the poor that the survey highlighted, showing a gap that is the widest it has ever been in Connecticut. The report said that Fairfield County's per capita income of $50,473 is more than double the $23,765 per capita income of Windham County residents'.
To Mr. Olsen, the gap highlights the higher burden of social services that the cities bear compared to suburbs and towns. "Exclusive communities don't want to bear their fair share of the responsibilities," he said. "They aren't even paying their fair share of taxes, because their taxes are so low the taxes are disproportionately higher in the cities."
Yet, given that the state's 1997 average weekly salary, at $551.73, was the highest ever recorded, does it really matter that the rich have gotten richer -- as long as everyone is better off?
Some said yes. "I think we need to worry about the income gap," said Shelly Geballe, president of Connecticut Voices for Children, a nonprofit education organization that focuses on children.
"We are in danger of perpetuating a permanent underclass," she said. "When you have that, the health of everyone suffers. When you are poor in a sea of enormous affluence, it's difficult emotionally as well as financially.
"The challenge Connecticut faces is the new economy. A person with a good mind and good training does well. But for kids who don't graduate from high school, the lack of an education is a death knell," she added, explaining that children of high-income parents are 21 times more likely to graduate from high school than offspring of low-income parents.
For the graduating class of 1997, the cumulative high school dropout rate stands at 15.7 percent, an improvement for the third year in a row and lower than any year since 1973. The cumulative rate is the dropout rate a class experiences over four years, as opposed to the dropout rate from just one year.
Mr. Gioia of the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, agreed that education is critical, but said, "The wage gap is not a Connecticut phenomenon. It is nationwide and worldwide.
"The problem is that we still have citizens who drop out of high school who don't get training and don't get an education," he said. "These people are really at an extreme disadvantage in our work force right now."
Mr. Gioia disagreed with those who said that Connecticut has replaced the jobs lost during the recession of the early 1990's with poorly paying service jobs.
"The replacement of jobs has been in the service industry," he said, "One service industry is computer software. Another is financial services. They don't pay poorly. We didn't have casinos before the recession and didn't have enough retail stores. Some jobs are more basic. Some jobs, though, have been very high paying."
For evidence of families under stress, others pointed to the rate of suicide among young people -- 10.2 deaths per 100,000, lower than the national average but still 36 percent higher than it was in 1970. The report quoted a recent survey by the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which found that more than one-fifth, 21.6 percent, of Connecticut high school students had seriously considered attempting suicide during the previous 12 months.
"That's a number that is just amazing," said state Sen. Toni N. Harp, cochairwoman of the Joint Committee on Public Health. "It is critically important that we address it."
She said the state's mental health system for children is inadequate and the role of drugs and alcohol plays a part in youth suicide. "We do very little in the way of prevention. We need to do that," she said. "We recognize in this state that we need systems for children, but not for adolescents. We need social support for kids."
Peter Shutheis, head of the Youth Service Bureau of the Norwich Department of Social Services, said adolescents are under a lot of stress.
"Substance abuse is a fairly high predictor of suicidal ideation," she said. "We're living in very accelerated and amplified times and you are seeing kids who are not well-connected with their parents, kids who are marginally engaged with society," he said. "I don't need to add that adolescence is a big time of change for kids."
Dr. Miringoff said that the report on the social state of Connecticut two years ago was responsible for highlighting the issue of child abuse when it detected a 20 percent increase in abuse in just one year. The latest report said that the child abuse rate had gotten marginally better, but was still high: 45 out of every 1,000 children have been referred to the state for abuse.
The impact of the study that year helped pass a state law mandating that social indicators be compiled every year and reported to the legislature, making Connecticut the only state in the nation to do so, Dr. Miringoff said.
"What we need to do in social policy is to get it out of partisan politics and treat it like interest rates," he said, allowing policy makers to rationally measure society's problems and consider what needs to be done.
To some, certain difficulties appear to be perennial, such as those faced by poor families and children, just as solutions continue to be elusive.
"I've been in Connecticut for 30 years," Ms. Geballe said. "The state is so small and so rich, it drives me nuts that we can't seem to fix this."

HEADLINE: Another Train Track in the Backyard?

BYLINE: By TOM CALLAHAN 

 BODY:
RESIDENTS opposed to a third Metro-North track in their backyards in southern Westchester are pinning their hopes for delaying the project on the federal government, which could block an environmental statement supporting a plan first put forth by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority in 1993.
Federal officials should soon begin reviewing complaints about the plan, which calls for upgrading an existing track bed on the Harlem Line between the Mount Vernon West and the Fleetwood stations and putting in a third track between the Fleetwood and Crestwood stations. The Harlem Line operates on two tracks from Woodlawn in the Bronx to the end of the line at Dover Plains in Dutchess County. 
 Metro-North and the Federal Transit Administration issued an environmental impact statement in May. The public had until the end of July to comment on that report. The federal agency is waiting to receive those comments from Metro-North, along with the railroad's response. "We expect to begin the process shortly," said Bruce Frame, public affairs director of the Federal Transit Administration, in a telephone interview from his office in Washington.
The agency will then either issue a final environmental statement or ask Metro-North to do more work. Because the railroad is seeking federal money to help pay for the project, the agency must issue a final report before construction can begin. Officials of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Metro-North's parent agency, estimate that the project would cost more than $40 million.
Mayor Nancy D. Hand of Bronxville, where opposition to the plan is strong, said she spoke to Federal Transit Administration officials on Dec. 7 to remind them of the village's contention that there are deficiencies in the environmental statement. She said the F.T.A. told her that it had questions and issues for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to address on the proposal.
Residents and local officials say the railroad is ignoring their fears of increased noise levels and the possibility of graffiti on proposed retaining walls and noise barriers. But the railroad says the project is essential to meet increased Harlem Line ridership.
Eloise L. Morgan, the Bronxville village historian, said, "Besides cutting the village in two, a barrier of this size will irrevocably change the character of the village."
Patty Dohrenwend, the Eastchester town clerk and a resident of Bronxville, said: "Noise barriers will be a visual eyesore. Why destroy a beautiful village that is the gem of Westchester?"
Claire Esposito, 69, who has lived at 38 Parkway Road in Bronxville since 1943 and refuses to move, said, "People who claim that we're just not-in-my-backyard complainers should come down here and imagine what it will be like with a giant wall behind your house."
Other critics contend that the project is just the first step in extending the third track farther north. "If the project terminates at Crestwood, logic tells me that it will have to be eventually extended north to Scarsdale or White Plains," said Jim Cavanaugh, supervisor of the town of Eastchester.
Metro-North strongly denies that, although the possibility has been raised in some capital planning documents in the past.
The greatest impact of the proposed construction would occur in the Parkway Road section of Bronxville, where the railroad bed rises up to 15 feet above residential property in places. The new track would be 12 to 16 feet closer to homes than the existing track. This track would be separated from the backyards of residents by a new retaining wall extending between 4 and 13 feet above ground level. If any noise barriers are added, they will be put on top of the wall.
The controversy over the proposal was renewed by the 674-page environmental statement, which took the railroad two years to complete. A summary says, "No significant unmitigable adverse impacts are expected as a result of the proposed project."
Many who live in the area, like Mayor Philip A. White of Tuckahoe, disagree. "The biggest problem for Tuckahoe is noise," he said. "Their environmental study agreed that the noise here is above where it should be. This project will just create more noise."
The railroad has offered to install noise barriers "only if the community wants them," said the summary. But that offer has been met with skepticism.
"We are concerned about the graffiti problem involving a wall," Mayor White said. "The railroad seems to take care of the graffiti at the stations. But along the right of way, they have left all sorts of equipment that they don't take care of. This equipment gets filled with graffiti."
Mayor Hand said the completed project would result in the construction of a 3,000-foot-long noise barrier through Bronxville, rising from 4 to 17 feet.
"It will be as if you took one of those giant barriers you see along the highway and put it in the center of a village," she said. "This project deserves to be derailed. The railroad is a public service corporation that does not feel responsible to the people they serve."
On the other hand, Mayor Ernest D. Davis of Mount Vernon supports the project. "I have no real problem with it," he said. "It might be beneficial for us. You cannot be myopic about it. It takes a regional approach to planning." He observed that the additional track might ease road congestion.
E. Virgil Conway, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, called the third track absolutely critical. In a telephone interview from his Manhattan office, he said, "In order for the economic growth of Westchester to continue, there has to be adequate transit in that corridor of the Harlem Line."
Mr. Conway added that the third track is needed to remove a bottleneck between Mount Vernon West and Crestwood in Eastchester.
During a typical morning rush in the first 10 months of 1999, 25,132 people rode southbound Harlem Line trains to Grand Central Terminal, with 17,613 boarding from the 9 stations in the mid-Harlem branch. This branch includes the stations from North White Plains to Mount Vernon West.
"Crestwood is a point of origin where more trains are fed into the system to go south," Mr. Conway said. This means that six trains an hour make their journey to Grand Central Terminal in the morning and must then return empty to Crestwood in order to pick up more southbound passengers.
Adding to the problem, railroad officials said, is the growing number of riders from Dutchess and Putnam Counties, as well as an increased number of reverse commuters who take trains north from New York City to jobs in Westchester. This year there were 3,546 reverse commuters on a typical morning and a total of 1.8 million for the year. In 1997, there were 3,200 reverse commuters on a typical morning. Northbound morning trains often must wait until the southbound express trains go around local southbound trains.
If completed, the third track could put an additional 6 to 14 trains in service during the morning rush. "We have been hugely supportive of this proposal," Lawrence Dwyer, president of the Westchester County Association, said. "It will mean an additional 14,500 more riders accessible to the city and Westchester each day, if just six trains are added. Corporations in the county are dependent on the reverse commute, especially for mid-management positions." Mr. Dwyer took this number from the draft environmental impact statement.
Opponents question the accuracy of Metro-North's ridership numbers. They contended that existing capacity and operational changes could meet all of the Harlem Line's ridership needs for the next 20 years. They recalled that in 1994, the railroad projected a yearly average growth rate of 19 percent on the Dover Plains branch, which consists of the four stations at the northernmost part of the line.
But railroad statistics show that the number of peak riders in the morning from the Dover Plains branch increased by 1.5 percent from 1998 to this year, from 320 passengers a day to 325. Total yearly ridership on that branch rose to 298,000 in 1998 from 258,000 in 1994, an increase of just under 16 percent.
Officials of the municipalities say it would be impossible for the construction to be completed, as the railroad contends, entirely on the right of way without infringing on private property. Residents say the railroad has never approached them about the possibility of buying their property.
Emily Papageorge, who has lived at 20 Parkway Road with her husband, Vel, for 30 years, said the distance from the back of their house to the railroad right of way is exactly 22 feet.
"I can't trust Metro-North," she said from her back porch on a recent weekday, as a train rushed by. "I don't believe anything they tell us. A third track will put these trains dangerously close as far as I'm concerned. No one can tell me that a train derailment is impossible. If a derailment happened here, the train would probably land in my house." While she has thought about moving, she has no desire to do so, because she is happy in Bronxville.
Bob Yaro, executive director of the Regional Plan Association, a Manhattan-based organization that supports the project, said: "This is a classic case of a public work that should proceed despite the concern of immediate homeowners. I understand the concern of Bronxville homeowners, but this is a situation where tens of thousands of people will benefit."
Bronxville officials say they have not ruled out the possibility of a court challenge if the railroad obtains permission to start the project.

HEADLINE: Tiptoeing Into the Millennium

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
IN Darien, First Selectman Robert F. Harrell Jr. jokingly observed that his chief fear about the so-called Y2K computer bug is that the Metro-North trains will stop running on their way through town during the morning of Jan. 1, stranding hordes of people recovering from a night of partying in New York City.
In most other respects the town is well prepared, he said, because it has replaced or upgraded its computers and software, and checked areas such as the 911 emergency dispatch system. It also meant that he got acquainted with just how many computerized controllers there were in town offices, such as chips in the elevators. The myriad of systems that had to be checked, he said, made him appreciate that the town does not operate something more complicated, such as a water or electric company. 
 "It's been an interesting, albeit long, exercise, but I expect a smooth transition," Mr. Harrell said. "As an elected official, it's certainly one date I'll be happy to see go by. We've spent a lot of time worrying about this, and a lot of money fixing our older computer systems."
Throughout the state, most people dealing with the Y2K problem feel that for the most part, computer glitches are not going to cause Connecticut to come crashing down on Jan. 1, but, just in case they're wrong, officials want to be prepared. The state will be operating an emergency command center in Hartford a few days before New Year's and the Red Cross is prepared to open additional shelters. Hundreds of state and local government employees who would normally be off duty on New Year's Eve also will be working this year. Municipalities have been preparing throughout the year for this event, but officials are still wary over how such everyday things as traffic lights, elevators and e-mail systems will work in the new year.
"We will have all 25 of the state armories staffed from Dec. 29 through Jan. 1 with at least two people, just in case something happens and we need to bring people in," said Major John R. Whitford, a spokesman for the Connecticut National Guard. Some states are putting their National Guard units on active duty for the date change, but in Connecticut the 5,400 members of the Guard are just on notice to be ready to come in if called, he said.
Private organizations are preparing for problems as well. The Hartford chapter of the American Red Cross has trained 50 extra shelter managers in its 58-town area, giving it the ability to open as many as 300 shelters in schools, churches and other large buildings, said Lori L. Caligiuri, a spokeswoman. The Red Cross is not, however, going so far as to stock up on large quantities of food and water.
"That question comes up time and time again, but we think there might be disruptions here and there, though we don't expect they will be long enough that we should be stockpiling food," Mrs. Caligiuri said. "We don't expect Armageddon, but we will be here if the communities need us."
The state said it had spent about $95 million to address the problem.
At the State Armory in Hartford, John J. Wiltse, the acting director of the Office of Emergency Management, is readying the banks of phones and radios for the morning of Dec. 29, when top officials from 25 state and federal agencies such as the State Police, Corrections and the Department of Transportation will move into a command post for state operations just in case something goes wrong.
"This is not something special that we've devised just for Y2K," Mr. Wiltse said. "If we go into an operational mode for anything from a winter storm to a hurricane, this is how we do it. There's an entire structure, a protocol, that's already in place."
The Y2K problem is the result of early computer programmers shortening the year in all dates to two digit -- 60 for 1960, 65 for 1965, and so forth -- because early computer memories were so limited. When the clock rolls over as Dec. 31 comes to an end, some computers will read the new date as 1900, instead of 2000.
Peter M. Gioia, an economist with the Connecticut Business and Industry Council, said 53 percent of businesses surveyed in October had completed their Y2K preparation plans, and almost 25 percent said they expect it will have no substantial effect on their operations.
But he acknowledged that some businesses have been surprised. One major bank updated the dating protocols on its desktop computers, only to find that noncompliant screen-savers would lock the systems up, Mr. Gioia said.
"In most companies, we've been hearing that the information services staff and management people in critical mission areas will be on-site or on call New Year's Eve," Mr. Gioia said.
Some federal e-mail systems are designed to delete the oldest messages first when memory gets low. That could mean messages arriving in January (coded 00) will be deleted when they arrive, when the computer reads the new message as being 100 years old.
In other cases, the change can cause problems with calculations. State corrections officials, for instance, don't want confused computer systems spitting out early release dates for inmates.
"There's no one answer, because every device is going to react differently," said Rock Regan, the chief information officer for the state Department of Information Technology.
"In some cases, it will just stop. In other cases, it will just give you the wrong date when you try to access the system," he said.
But just because a computer has a wrong date is not necessarily devastating, Mr. Regan said. "How many VCR's in people's homes are blinking 12:00 all the time because no one wants to figure out how to program the right time?"
But sometimes the date does make a difference. In New Haven, Timothy J. Scanlon, the Y2K manager, said the computer system that controls traffic lights had to be replaced, after they discovered the main control and chips in the lights were not compliant.
After Jan. 1, the internal calendar would have been off by 100 years. Routines such as allowing main thoroughfares a longer green at rush hour on weekdays might have been disrupted when the system read it as a weekend or a holiday; lights that were supposed to blink at low traffic time might have gone to blinking during heavy traffic.
Software and hardware in New Haven schools, finance and accounting departments, and other areas have all been checked.
New Haven has spent months coordinating with hospitals, nursing homes and ambulance operators about how to handle any contingency. Representatives of the telephone and light companies that serve the city have assured him they are ready for the transition, but even if there are breakdowns, the systems will be so closely monitored, Mr. Scanlon said, "People won't know there's a problem before it's fixed."
Still, the city's 500-page emergency operations plan calls for him and other department heads to begin staffing a 24-hour-a-day emergency center, as well as 10 police substations and 10 fire stations, at midday Dec. 31.
"We expect a nonevent," Mr. Scanlon said. "But we'll be there just in case."
Most municipalities have been promoting Y2K awareness. In Newington, there have been cable television shows, press releases, and notices on the city's World Wide Web page about the preparations, said Roy C. Zartarian, director of information systems.
"In most cases, our heating and air conditioning and elevator controls are so old, they're analog rather than digital, so we're not having a problem," said Mr. Zartarian, who confesses to using notepaper instead of a personal digital assistant for his own planning purposes. "Where we needed them, we have new computers or software. I'm sure people don't want to hear that we'll be able to print tax bills after Jan. 1, but we will, and more important, we'll be able to collect them."
The only known problem remaining as of early December was the town's voice-mail system, he said.
"It does not mean the system is going to crash, only that some dates might not be stamped correctly, but to tell the truth I'm not sure what it's going to say," Mr. Zartarian said.
In Hartford, Nancy M. Mulroy, a spokewoman for Mayor Michael Peters, said the needed repairs to computer systems presented an opportunity to merge the financial management and payroll systems of the schools and city government offices, which should make both more efficient, as well as incorporating some modern practices such as electronic invoicing.
"We thought it was an opportunity to move forward, rather than just repair the old," Ms. Mulroy said. "We needed to get into the 21st century anyway, and this was a good time to make the investment."
Mr. Regan of the State Department of Information Technology said many state systems have already had a real-life test.
"Our first big challenge on Y2K was almost a year ago, with the Department of Labor systems that do a one-year look-ahead," Mr. Regan said. "They ran fine."
And the problem won't necessarily end on Jan. 1, Mr. Regan noted. There are a number of computer functions tied to the end of the month, or the end of the calendar quarter, that could trigger new rounds of problems.
"There are a whole series of dates that we look at in our testing, not just one test to see if we can get it to roll over without any trouble," Mr. Regan said. So his office has been testing systems all over the state, and fixing computer code that relied on two-digit dates. Mr. Regan said his staff will watch what happens around the world beginning Dec. 30.
"You want to have some insight into what problems might be cropping up for us eventually, you watch New Zealand, and Asia, and Europe, because the clock will hit midnight there hours before it does here," Mr. Regan said.
Of more concern to state officials is all the buildup that the problem has received.
Ice storms or high winds often cause power outages in January. Are people going to panic if there is a random power failure minutes after midnight.
And how many people are going to rush to their telephones to see if they are working at one minute past midnight, triggering failures in the switching gear because it is overloaded.
"I'm pretty confident that when midnight rolls over we're all going to be looking at each other and saying, 'Is that all?' " Mr. Regan said. "The biggest issue now is going to be the people issue -- how is everybody going to react? I just worry that people are going to blame any problem on the year 2000."

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
At Discount Harry's Ultimate Closeout

BYLINE: By ROBERT STRAUSS 

DATELINE: PENNSAUKEN

 BODY:
The Barbies line the shelves, just like they have at Christmas for decades. Hard by are dozens of boxes of Barbie knockoffs, hot pink trim packaging around the glassine windows showing the Kelly Day Care School Set ($14.99 marked down from $24) or the Backpack Club Fashion Mall (only $7.79, down from $13).
There are Toy Story figurines and Elmo this and Elmo that and electronic dart games and, in the oddment section, crates of hampers and digital alarms and comforters and wooden two-person rockers. 
 No one who has shopped at Discount Harry's, a rambling you'll-buy-what-we've-got store along a chaotic section of Route 130 here, over the last 50 years would notice anything different this December. Except that it is the last Christmas for Discount Harry's, yet another victim of consolidation and chain discounting, a piece of business nostalgia as the millennium turns.
"We had our day, but we can't compete any more," said John Lancaster, who bought the business from the original Discount Harry, Harry Kaufman, in 1976. "The biggest thing that got me is that I no longer have the ability to support a building of this size with closeouts and toys like we'd like to."
Discount Harry's has long been the anchor on a strip of warehouse-like discount stores just off the busy Airport Circle. There is the Forman Mills clothing discounter and Jo Skymer, the discount lighting store, among others. But Harry's, well, that was always something else.
At Harry's vast 100,000-square-foot store, you could buy pools and patio furniture, bikes and Halloween decorations, paint and kitty litter, just about everything imaginable, in or out of season. One day several years ago, a man showed up with a truckload of Maxwell House coffee.
"We checked it out to see if it was legitimate and it was," remembered Mr. Lancaster. He bought the lot for $1.50 a pound, went to a couple of supermarkets and found Maxwell House was selling for $2.99 a pound, and piled it on pallets for sale at $1.99 a pound. He sold it out in days, with even diner owners buying it by the case.
"We put up a sign, 'This store sells more Maxwell House coffee than any other toy store in the world,' " he said.
Ah, toys. That's where Harry's made its nut and its name. In the 1980's, as more and more mom-and-pop toy stores faded from the scene, Harry's thrived by selling inexpensive, often close-out toys. For a time, it was the largest independent toy buyer in the United States. Mr. Lancaster loved the art of the deal, which he learned as a salesman at Kiddie City before buying the store from Mr. Kaufman, one of his idols, at the age of 32.
"Harry was the best," said Mr. Lancaster of his mentor, who now lives in Florida and, until this year, came back every Christmas to help out on the sales floor. "He'd take stuff no one could sell off a truck or from an old warehouse and sell the heck out of it."
There were never any frills at Discount Harry's, so in its final days, it looks no different than it ever has. It has always been a mecca for the masses. Items are piled, sometimes even neatly, in little particular order. The hampers, for instance, are right by the comforters, which are up against the digital clocks.
The black-and-white tiled floors have been scuffed for a generation. The exposed ceilings are not of architectural fashion, but of ease to fix wiring and plumbing. Some of the cinder-block walls got the advantage of white paint; others have chipped-but-still-effective peg board. Utility poles and heating ducts block aisles willy-nilly.
But there always bargains to be found, and still are, so long as Mr. Lancaster has merchandise left in his warehouse. That electronic dart game can be in someone's den for $40. Huffy bikes are down as low as $70. Dozens of Tinkerbell Fragranced Bubble Necklaces will go for $1.99 each.
Then there are the really odd items. One peg board has "Timeless Legends" sports figurines, timeless if you think of Steve Owens, the 1969 Heisman Trophy-winning running back from the University of Oklahoma, or the Milwaukee Bucks semi-star Vin Baker as legends. Another spinning holder has mini-Pennsylvania license plates with names imprinted; what's left are Wesley, Clint, Heidi and Clay.
This is no longer enough in the late 1990's economy. About 40 percent of Discount Harry's annual profits have been tied to Christmas toys. But since Mattel and Hasbro have in recent years bought up second-tier toymakers like Tyco and Galoob and non-toy retailers like Wal-Mart and KMart started using toy staples as Christmastime loss-leaders, independents like Mr. Lancaster have been heavily squeezed.
"If I'm in Bentonville, Arkansas, or Paramus, New Jersey," said Mr. Lancaster, referring to the headquarters cities for Wal-Mart and Toys R Us, respectively, "and I, say, want a million Monopoly sets, I'm going to get a deep discount. So then someone like me buys it for $9.99 and they can run it at $8.99 and make a little money. I lose a dollar just to get people in the door.
"It has also taken the distributors out of business," added Mr. Lancaster, taking a deep breath and thinking back to the old days of dealing. "Twenty years ago, there were 200 toy distributors I could deal with. Now I only know of two. I can't make it in toys any more."
And that means the end of Harry's.
This month, Mr. Lancaster put his building up for sale with Mertz Realty of Mount Laurel. It is a huge place on three acres with 140 parking spaces in a relatively hot real estate market. Mr. Lancaster hopes it goes quickly, so he can move on to his next business.
"I'll do just pools and patio furniture in a smaller place nearby," he said. "So far, the independents still rule there because these items require room and service. The Kmarts and the Targets don't want to deliver and set up pools and they don't want to make room for a lot of patio sets. When I go to the outdoor furniture show in Chicago, there are 2,000 independents there."
Mr. Lancaster hopes to be out of Discount Harry's and into the unnamed new business by spring, when people will be out looking for patio sets and pools and filters. And deals.
"Oh, I feel sad, sure, because of the fun I had doing it every day," he said. "A new deal happened every day. Who knew each day? Kitty litter. Tables. Whatever. But I made all my friends in the business and I don't play golf. Got to do something."

HEADLINE: Bookstores Take On The Mouse

BYLINE: By WENDY GINSBERG 

DATELINE: PRINCETON

 BODY:
AS Joey Shapiro sat on the floor of Micawber Books here, he insisted that he would never shop online.
After surveying the display books, his eyes focused on a brightly colored binding on a nearby shelf. 
 "I didn't even want to come here today," said Mr. Shapiro, classical literature major at Princeton who was clutching a bag of books he had bought. "My friend dragged me. But I get here and find things I didn't even know I wanted."
But Margaret G. Knapp, who owns Micawber Books, knows that the growth of online commerce can be ignored only at her own peril. While she says the virtual bookstores can never replace cracking open a new novel, she maintains a Web site nonetheless.
Miles away, Jeremy L. Schaefer relaxed at home in New Brunswick, reveling in finding the computer book he needed on the Web.
"For Christmas gifts, you go to the mall and it's a madhouse," said Mr. Schaefer, a computer science major at Rutgers University in New Brunswick. "It's like football. You have to run through people to get where you're going. Granted, you don't get the warm fuzzies from a Web site like when you walk into an independent bookstore, but at least you can be in your pajamas."
This holiday season -- more than any other that has preceded it -- the shopping battle is pitting the ring of the cash register against the click of the mouse, and the competition will determine if independent bookstores can weather the war of attrition.
The explosion of online shopping, known as e-commerce, has forced many small business owners to rethink their tactics. Economic survival for independent stores is especially acute in the book industry, where online sales have almost doubled since last year, according to several major booksellers.
Indeed, the rapid growth of online shopping cost the state a projected $21 million in lost tax revenue this year, according to the State Treasurer. By 2003 that figure is expected to reach $130 million.
Nabil R. Adam, a professor of computer information systems at Rutgers in Newark, said that the independent bookstore who will have to join the online trend to survive.
"If you don't have a Web site, people might think there's something not quite right about your operation," Professor Adam said.
Smaller bookstores will also have to spend more to make sure they have an easy-to-use Web design and a quality search engine, he said.
"Small businesses will not be able to survive if they continue business as usual," Professor Adams said. "Local bookstores will have to profile their customers and become familiar with their area."
National Small Businesses United, a coalition of small businesses, released statistics estimating that 41 percent of all small businesses had Web sites in 1998, and that the number was expected to jump to more than 60 percent by the new year.
Representatives of Amazon.com and Borders.com say their Web sites are not intended to replicate a visit to the local bookshop. Amazon.com is unique in that exists only on the Internet. "People that shop at Amazon.com are looking for ease and convenience,' said Paul P. Capelli, a spokesman for Amazon. "It's being able to shop at 11:30 at night in your bunny slippers."
Could a solution be for everyone to go to the local bookstore in pajamas and bunny slippers?
Rich Fahle, the editor of the Borders.com Web site, said the answer was sort of.
While Mr. Fahle said that e-commerce was a vital complement to the 290 Borders bookstores nationwide, nothing could replace them. "The Web site is just a piece of the puzzle for Borders," he said.

LENGTH: 1282 words

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
The Restaurant as Leading Economic Indicator

BYLINE: By COREY KILGANNON 

 BODY:
IS there life after two-for-one sushi specials?
The owners of Henry's, a new restaurant at Broadway and 105th Street, think so, especially if the area proves prosperous enough to support the relatively upscale 140-seat restaurant they opened two months ago. 
 It is the latest culinary incarnation in a large corner site that has had two others since the early 1980's, and where a bargain Japanese restaurant, Tofu, closed about eight months ago.
The five small shops that had long been there were converted to the jazz club Birdland in 1983. In 1995, Birdland's owners moved the club to Midtown. Then the owners of a chain of Chinese restaurants on Long Island opened Tofu, which offered inexpensive sushi. It drew few customers, and closed in less than two years.
So why open Henry's, where entrees start at around $15, in a neighborhood where the idea of eating out has often been a good $3.50 falafel or some tasty arroz con pollo for $6.75 at one of the inexpensive ethnic restaurants that line Broadway?
Well, the owners have a quick answer: to get an early foothold in what some see as a neighborhood on the cusp of gentrification.
The dozen blocks of Broadway north of 96th street, historically known as Bloomingdale, have long been lined with small groceries and shops. Nearby residents range from working-class Hispanic families, most of whom live east of Broadway, in a neighborhood known as Manhattan Valley, to wealthier residents in the large apartments along Broadway, West End Avenue and Riverside Drive, on the northern fringe of the Upper West Side. The stretch lies between the increasingly prosperous Columbia University area to the north and the Upper West Side to the south.
It is being called SoCo, or South of Columbia, by local real estate brokers, who say the two adjacent neighborhoods are expanding, and predict that the blocks in between will follow a familiar pattern of gentrification seen in neighborhoods like TriBeCa and the East Village.
Marguerite Pearson, an executive vice president for Douglas Elliman, the large real estate broker in Manhattan, called the area one of the city's fastest growing.
"You've got the absolutely gorgeous prewar apartments, and the service businesses are already there," she said. "Families are moving there, because it is just so 'neighborhood.' "
Henry's five owners have focused on that trend. Luigi and Mauro Lusardi and Elio Guaitolini, who own six restaurants on the Upper East Side, joined with Henry Rinehart and Robert Devine, who ran the Lusardis' restaurant, Luke's, at 79th Street and Third Avenue. Mr. Rinehart said the group just had to cultivate a local following. What Henry's provides, he said, is the large gathering place that the "Upper Upper West Side" sorely needed.
"To me this is a no-brainer," he said. "We did our homework. It's ours to fumble."
And there's no confidence like cash. The partners signed a 10-year lease, with a monthly rent of close to $20,000, and have invested more than $1 million in interior work. They have created a warm, old-time feel, from the checkerboard tablecloths to the Frank Lloyd Wright-style wood interior made of Honduran mahogany to the stained glass lamps that hang from the high ceilings. The expansive interior is larger than any other restaurant down to Carmine's on Broadway near 91st Street.
Henry's classic American fare leans toward comfort food. It has a list of 38 wines and serves 14 kinds of beer. Mauro Lusardi maintains that the price range is commensurate with the budgets of local residents, especially newcomers.
"It's a neighborhood that's really being transformed," he said. "It's up and coming. We considered six other areas in Manhattan before choosing this site. We felt we had to get in now, because waiting a year or two, the rent would be much higher."
Faith Hope Consolo, a senior managing director of Garrick-Aug, a large commercial real estate company, said many large retailers saw Henry's as a test of the spending power of a neighborhood she called "the next big growth area."
"In the past, it was a strip of bodegas," she said. "It had no image and was kind of lost in limbo. Now, you're getting very well-heeled singles and couples moving in."
"You have strong anchors on both sides," she added, "and what was once no man's land is becoming viable for -- and I wish I could give it a new word -- gentrification."
Andrew Albert, executive director of the West Side Chamber of Commerce, compared the area to the stretch of Amsterdam Avenue north of 79th Street, which, by being between two thriving streets, Broadway and Columbus Avenue, became dense with bars and restaurants during the last several years.
"There's always pressure on an area between two prospering neighborhoods," he said, "and people up there are really hungry for a greater choice for places to eat and shop. We hear all the time, 'Why can't this stretch be like the rest of Broadway?' "
It is starting to. Other sophisticated spots have opened nearby. Several doors north of Henry's, in the space that was long Augie's, a jazz bar with cheap beer and a late-night student crowd, a new owner opened Smoke in March. It is a more upscale jazz lounge with red velvet sofas and a cover charge.
A coffee bar that opened last year on 107th Street just west of Broadway recently expanded this year to become the Underground Lounge and Cafe, a campy grotto-style restaurant. Alouette, a French restaurant, opened last year on Broadway between 97th and 98th Streets.
Gothic Cabinet Craft, a furniture maker, opened a large showroom on Broadway near 100th Street in July, and Gristede's supermarket on Broadway near 100th Street recently expanded. Gourmet Garage opened its 4,000-square-foot fine foods store on Broadway north of 96th Street in 1997, after a marketing study showed that the population density, income level and percentage of college graduates were increasing near Broadway above 96th Street.
Along Amsterdam Avenue between 96th and 110th Streets, meanwhile, a spate of new bars and restaurants have opened recently, including Pampa, an Argentinian steak restaurant, near 97th Street.
But John Valenti, who owns Birdland, remains skeptical. He never got the business he hoped for uptown, he said, and he said Henry's might not, either.
"When I first opened, it was tough to walk around there at night," he said. "I thought the gentrification would go above 96th Street the way it did from 86th to 96th, but the traffic was never there like it was down in the 70's and 80's. Also, people up there don't spend big money. If they do, it's to eat downtown." Other disadvantages, he said, include few lunch customers, scant parking, and perceptions. "When people hear 105th Street, they think they're going into no man's land," he said.
Alan Rubin, who has owned RCI Discount Appliances, at Broadway and 98th Street, for 25 years, called business the best it had ever been.
"From 96th Street up has always been way behind, but we're starting to catch up," Mr. Rubin said. "The developments we saw in the West 70's 10 years ago are creeping up here, but there are people who still tend to look at above 96th Street as getting into Harlem. We have more and more young people, or nannies coming in with children. They weren't here 10 years ago. The level of spending and disposable income in this neighborhood is going up all time." But Mr. Rubin said he feared that the influx of chain stores would drive out smaller businesses.
"Commercial rents are doubling and tripling," he said. "Any merchant around here that doesn't have a really strong business and long, low-rent lease is going to be driven out of this area."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
When ThisParty Ends, More Will Feel the Pain

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
WITH all the excitement of the approaching millennium, it is understandable that a different anniversary has been largely ignored. December was the month, in 1996, when Alan Greenspan made his famous warning about "irrational exuberance."
He was uncertain then whether stock prices had become "unduly escalated." But three years later and 4,800 points higher on the Dow Jones industrial average, doubt is gone. The market is clearly exuberant and irrational. 
 That might not be so terrible if this were 1987 or the mid-1970's, when bubbles burst and stock prices took famous plunges. Fewer shareholders counted so much on their paper wealth in those days, and fewer executives relied so heavily on a rising market to sustain their entrepreneurial spirits.
Maybe the selloff that now seems inevitable will do only passing damage. But the odds of getting off easily this time are fading. The national economy and the market have become too intertwined. "Every optimistic forecast about the economy is based on the premise that stock prices will either go up or change very little," said Henry Kaufman, the Wall Street economist. "Not since World War II have we been so dependent on the market."
Economists count the ways. Some items on the list are already well known, the most familiar being the "wealth effect": rising stock prices encourage consumers to spend more and borrow more, activities that almost certainly will come to a halt, shrinking the economy, if the Dow Jones average falls by 30 percent or so and stays down for at least six months.
Even people who don't own stock hear all the glad tidings on the evening news. They see in the rising market a signal that the economy is O.K. and that their jobs are safe, noted Edward McKelvey, senior economist at Goldman, Sachs. So they, too, spend beyond their incomes.
 A MARKET selloff would throw the effect into reverse. The spenders would pull way back. Companies would, too, in response. Job growth would halt; the unemployment rate would rise and incomes would fall. But debt would not, and everyone -- companies and households -- would pull back more in the scramble to pay debts and restore savings that evaporated in the market decline.
"A selloff would bring us the first stock-market-induced recession since before the Second World War," said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
Still, he does not surrender optimism. Although he anticipates a selloff, he does not forecast a recession. When the downfall comes, Mr. Roach and many others will count on Mr. Greenspan's Federal Reserve to lower interest rates quickly enough and to take other steps to prevent the anticipated chain reaction of belt-tightening from happening.
The potential for damage, however, is spreading in small and perhaps uncontrollable ways. Many corporations, for example, no longer have to add cash to their employee pension funds. Because the funds have invested in a rising stock market, they are fully funded. As long as stocks keep their value, the corporate money that would have been needed for pension contributions augments profits instead, or is invested in new products and equipment, activities that keep the economy humming. If the stock market falls sharply, that money would again have to be channeled into the pension funds to keep them whole.
Grants from foundations would also decline after a selloff, and they finance thousands of projects and considerable research and employment. Grants are geared to a foundation's wealth, and foundations invest heavily in stocks. Grant money has risen in step with the market. A selloff would produce a reversal of this trend.
ON a different level, corporate mergers, particularly those in which one company pays for another with stock, would become more difficult. "We have a sense in this booming stock market that there is no deal we cannot do," said Peter L. Bernstein, an economist and author.
And then, of course, there is the spreading use of stock options as pay in place of cash, a practice that is marching down the hierarchy to lower ranks of workers. A market fall that lasted for a while would render many of those options worthless. "Obviously, a lot of people will be angry," said Dean Baker, co-director of the Center for Economic and Policy Research in Washington, "and some will try to get paid retroactively in cash."
Finally, there are all the flourishing Internet companies. They float new stock and watch it soar in value even as many companies fail to make a profit. The market wealth covers the shortfall. Or it makes possible borrowing and expansion in pursuit of success in a new technology that is vibrant and promising.
Or is it? Is it the technology that kindles the entrepreneurial spirit in the Internet billionaires, or is it the stock market?
Probably both. But we must wait for the market selloff to get a more sober fix on the lasting changes wrought by the Internet, the star technology in the much-proclaimed new economy.
