HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SOUTH BRONX;
A Group Named 'We Stay,' A Garden That Must Depart

BYLINE: By DAVID CRITCHELL 

 BODY:
Their apple tree is now bare and the grape and tomato vines have shriveled. But the people who gathered last week in the wooden shanty, or casita, at Rincon Criollo, a community garden on 158th Street and Brook Avenue, were talking about the other fruits of their labors.
"This garden and the culture it represents has inspired me to do better," Samuel Cordero, 29, said. "I've learned about my roots and been able to teach others about them." 
 But Rincon Criollo -- the name means down-home corner -- and other gardens on city-owned lots in the neighborhood will eventually have to make way for residential and commercial development. An urban renewal project called Melrose Commons, financed by city, state and federal agencies and in the works for several years, calls for the redevelopment of 35 blocks in the Melrose neighborhood.
This month a local community group, We Stay/Nos Quedamos, received an $8.2 million federal grant to develop housing for low-income elderly people on 157th Street and Third Avenue. The project is part of the Melrose Commons development. Currently there is a community garden on the site, which is a block away from Rincon Criollo.
Last Thursday, about a dozen gardeners held a small rally at the casita to protest the anticipated loss of their green space. Some said they were disappointed that Nos Quedamos would be shutting down gardens. "Nos Quedamos was formed because they didn't want to move, but now they've become just like the city," said Francine Rogers, who runs a garden on 151st Street and Brook Avenue. "It's their plan now."
But the executive director of Nos Quedamos, Yolanda Garcia said, her group intended to include green space in its project. Yet not every garden could be saved, she said.
"The gardens are very important, and we are planning on open space," Ms. Garcia said. "But the way the city looks at gardens, the bigger lots will have to be converted for housing."
The Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, who has brought visiting Puerto Rican dignitaries to visit Rincon Criollo in the past, said that although he would be saddened to see it go, housing and community renewal had to take precedence.
"This is a community based-project," Mr. Ferrer said of the Melrose Commons plan. "It was an inclusive and democratic process and in the end will add garden acreage to the area. This is something we should feel comfortable with and sets the pace for the kind of planning we need to do everywhere."
But the local gardeners say that they have had little input in the garden's future. "We have not been consulted, and we don't want to move," Pedro Figueroa, Rincon Criollo's president, said. "You can move the casita, but how do you replace an apple tree or the vines that have been here for so long?" DAVID CRITCHELL

HEADLINE: COPING;
The Body Beautiful, In Diverse Guises

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
THE girls were as young as 8, but already they knew what parts of their bodies they liked and what parts they didn't. They knew the pressures to be "pretty" in a society where the definition of female splendor is whimsical. One era you're in, the next era you're out.
The difference in the little room where the girls sat talking the other day is that they also asked questions. Why is thin beautiful? Who says that yellow hair or big breasts are desirable? What role do ethnic and racial bias play in definitions of beauty? 
 That's the way it goes at the Sista II Sista Freedom School in Bushwick, Brooklyn, run by the Sista II Sista Collective. It meets on Saturdays, with anywhere from 8 to 20 girls or young women in attendance. They talk about their values, they attend workshops on health and sexuality, they write poetry and develop theater projects, they identify issues in their community.
It's a struggling community, under the elevated train tracks, where about 40 percent of the people, who are mostly African-American or Latino, meet the federal definition of poor. The neighborhood has less open space and fewer parks than almost any other in the city.
What it does have, in Sista II Sista, is a place that values matters of the heart and the spirit: the female spirit. The Freedom School, a name that purposely recalls the "freedom summers" of the 60's civil rights struggles, is run out of the office of Make the Road by Walking, a community group that provides legal support to the working poor, the unemployed and the undocumented.
On a recent Saturday, the teenagers who usually come were off taking college entrance exams, so the younger girls, 8 to 13, had the place to themselves. Most were Puerto Rican or Dominican.
The girls watched a music video of "Unpretty" by the group TLC, in which an overweight woman peruses fashion magazines, cutting out photographs of thin women and putting them on her wall before indulging in a frenzy of overeating. A woman is shown lying on an operating table before undergoing plastic surgery; another woman sits with her boyfriend in front of a computer, where he electronically enlarges the breasts of the women's bodies on the screen.
"The girls are getting the message that they're not pretty," said Adjoa Jones de Almeida, a Sista II Sista founder and a discussion leader. "Where are they getting that message?"
"If they don't have no makeup, they're ugly," one girl said.
"The guys want the women their way, with big breasts," another said. "In my opinion, that don't matter."
The discussion then veered into eating disorders and the pressures to look a certain way. People talked about their hair, their behinds, their lips, their breasts.
"I don't like my hair because it turns into an Afro," one girl said.
"My uncle said to my sister: 'You're fat. You're going to explode,' " another said. "My sister said: 'I don't care. I'm the right size for me.' "
The little women jumped with excitement at that bit of sass.
"Why are we talking about all this?" asked Jennifer Calderon, another founder of the school, leading the discussion. "We have to look at why I want to have a flatter stomach or longer nails or different hair. Every time you look at a magazine or a video, think about the images."
The Freedom School, for all the intimacy and spontaneity on display the other day, is the carefully cultivated brainchild of four young women who looked around and saw many programs for young Latino and African-American men, but few for women. Not to mention few images reflecting women like them who are doing transforming things with their lives, from raising their families to doing research on women's lives.
Indeed, the four women who brought the sisters together reflect the energy and beauty of countless African-American and Latina women who are quietly turning their communities around. They are Nicole Burrowes, a graduate student in history at City University; Ms. Calderon, a writer and a staff member at El Punte, a youth organization; Ms. Jones de Almeida, an English teacher at El Punte; and Paula Rojas, who has been a full-time community organizer since graduating from Smith College in 1992. They are in their 20's. It's all volunteer work, after school and children and full-time jobs to pay the bills.
Now, at year's end, they are hoping to raise enough money to buy their own space and to expand the program, which began in 1996 with eight Saturday sessions. Help comes from foundations, businesses, fund-raising events like poetry readings and, triumphantly, a $50,000 award from the Fund for the City of New York, which rewards outstanding community groups.
"It was a different vision from most programs that deal with youths as a social service model or a crisis state that young people are in," Ms. Jones de Almeida said.
"People are always putting women of color into categories," Ms. Burrowes said. "Here, they can just be."

HEADLINE: THEN/NOW: REFLECTIONS ON THE MILLENIUM;
A New Way of Living With Nature

 BODY:
A century that will be remembered for material and scientific progress may also be remembered for something more modest -- as a moment when mankind, realizing that the earth's resources were not finite and perhaps seeking expiation for years of predatory behavior, struck a truce with nature. For the first time since the dawn of the industrial age there was, at least in the West and certainly in America, a rough armistice between the forces of economic growth and the forces of preservation.
The big question on the eve of the next century is whether this armistice will hold. The earth's six billion people will grow to nine billion by 2050, creating new pressures on natural resources, food and habitation. There is also the related question of whether what can loosely be called the environmental ethic, now largely confined to the industrialized world, can be extended to poorer nations that believe it is their turn to industrialize. 
 America, for example, seems to have settled on a policy of preserving its national forests and adding incrementally to its protected wilderness. By contrast, countries like Brazil, Malaysia and Indonesia are chewing up their forests at a ferocious clip. Similarly, the industrialized West is actively seeking alternatives to the carbon-based fuels that are contributing to potentially disruptive changes in the earth's climate. Yet unless the big developing countries like India and China do likewise, what the West does will make very little difference.
Still, it is worth celebrating the attitudinal changes in this country that have cast nature, once seen as an unruly force needing discipline, in a more congenial light. Early in this century, for example, federal sharpshooters hunted wolves for bounty. Today, the federal Fish and Wildlife Service is orchestrating the wolf's revival. Sixty-five years ago the Hoover Dam, rising 70 stories above the bed of the Colorado River, was hailed as the greatest engineering feat in American history. Today, dams are increasingly seen as enemies of the natural order and are actually being dismantled. Only 30 years ago the Hudson River, once among America's most majestic waterways, was little more than a 350-mile sewer stretching from the Adirondacks to Manhattan, choked with untreated municipal waste, industrial chemicals and agricultural runoff. Today, the Hudson pulses with life.
Wolves, dams, wilderness, forests, lakes, rivers, estuaries -- all are seen differently now than they were less than 50 years ago. Of course if reparations were to be made at all, the century now ending was surely the proper time to make them. For it was not until the 20th century that we began to develop the technology that enabled us to destroy nature on a truly grand scale -- the implacable machinery that in a heartbeat (measured in millennial time) could foul the air, clear-cut the forests and strip-mine the oceans.
It was thus fitting that this same century would eventually produce a citizens' revolt against environmental degradation. This revolt -- symbolized by the first Earth Day in 1970, and defined by the creation of an astonishing body of environmental laws -- not only gave the nation the tools with which to heal itself but conferred upon ordinary citizens the indispensable right to take even the government to court if it failed to carry out these laws.
There are many who believe that the technology that got us into trouble will get us out -- that fuel cells will replace the internal combustion engine, that microbes will dispose of the waste stream. But of course technology is neutral. What will matter in the future is what has always mattered, namely the values and political will of those at the controls. The truth is, people can accomplish mighty acts of repair. If they can destroy the Everglades with levees and canals, as they did in the 1940's, they can help save the Everglades by replumbing it. If they can decimate the world's swordfish with factory ships, they can replenish the swordfish by keeping those ships in port.
Therein lies one answer to the environmental pessimists who believe that the world is past recovery, that the battle to preserve open spaces and biodiversity is already lost because there are simply too many people coveting too much land and demanding too many resources. What they overlook is that we are not at the same point on the learning curve that we were 70 or even 30 years ago. Having discovered that we can actually change the way nature operates, we have also discovered that with this power comes a sacred obligation to restore what we once nearly ruined.

HEADLINE: The World;
Asia Moves In on the Big Ditch

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PANAMA

 BODY:
EVER since Balboa sighted the Pacific Ocean from a hill here in 1513, this has been one of the world's great geopolitical battlegrounds. The competitors may have changed, as the colonial rivalry of Spain and England gave way in the 1800's to a struggle to build the Panama Canal that pitted France against the United States, but the link between control of the isthmus and dominance in world trade has remained constant.
Now, with the United States having formally handed the canal over to Panama last week, a new phase of that Great Game is beginning. This time it is the trading powers of East Asia who are emerging as players -- reflecting the waterway's diminishing importance to American commerce and its growing strategic value to export-dependent economies on the far side of the Pacific. 
 Before the canal was built, a United States emerging as a world power envisioned it as the best way to get people and goods between its Atlantic and Pacific coasts, and to unify a new two-ocean Navy. But today, not only are aircraft carriers too big to fit through the Canal (and missile submarines normally too secretive to use it), but American companies increasingly prefer overland routes or air freight for shipping goods between their two coasts.
For Asians shipping exports across two oceans, however, the canal is now indispensable. The United States remains its largest user, but the big trading nations of Asia are catching up fast. China, Japan, Korea and Taiwan are all in the top ten, and a typical cargo nowadays is likely to be soybeans from Brazil or oil from Venezuela on their way to East Asia in exchange for automobiles or electronic goods destined for the Colon Free Trade Zone here.
The result has been a conspicuous burst of Asian investment here. Taiwanese and Korean consortiums are building separate industrial parks, and a pair of Chinese shipping tycoons with competing political loyalties are now solidly installed in the ports that command both approaches to the canal: Chang Yung-Fa, a Taiwan loyalist, and his Evergreen Maritime Corporation in Colon at the Caribbean entrance and Li Ka-shing of Hong Kong's Hutchison Whampoa Ltd., who is cozy with Beijing, in Balboa at the Pacific entrance.
"Panamanians have an easier time relating to U.S. businessmen than Chinese or Japanese because culturally they feel more at ease with Americans," said Roberto Eisenmann, a prominent business leader here who advises President Mireya Moscoso. "But the governments of Asia have been much more aggressive than the United States" in seeking opportunities here.
In Washington, only the conservative Republicans who opposed the Panama Canal Treaties in 1977, and who now fear that the People's Liberation Army is sneaking in as the Southern Command moves out, seem interested in Panama these days. Former Secretary of Defense Caspar Weinberger warned this month that China is seeking "a foothold in one of the world's three major chokepoints," while the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, fears that "U.S. naval ships will be at the mercy of Chinese-controlled pilots and could even be denied passage through the canal." Supporters of the turnover counter that such a focus on the military ignores the fact that the United States is the only country with a treaty right to intervene should such an unlikely scenario occur.
More interestingly, perhaps, a narrow emphasis on the military plays down the underlying mercantile factor; it is, after all, by expanding its economy that China has the best chance of becoming a global power in the next few decades, rather than by challenging the United States militarily in the Western Hemisphere.
Perhaps the most significant contest developing here, according to Ricardo Arias Calderon, a former vice president of Panama, is "an intense competition between Taiwan and the People's Republic of China to advance a broad array of interests" that are fundamentally political and economic.
"I think the Chinese have learned the lesson of 19th-century England, which understood that it had influence in the Mediterranean to the extent that it commanded the entrance and exit" at Gibraltar and Suez, he added. "China and Taiwan are already competing in the South China Sea, and now both are seeking a presence at the exit on the other side of the Pacific."
Of course, power and influence today can be exercised in a more subtle manner than by establishing colonies or sending in the fleet, as the British so often did. Neither Chinese state is in a position -- or even appears to want -- to supplant America's role as protector of the canal. So their rivalry has centered on the commercial facilities in and around the canal and on penetrating Latin American markets.
Japan, too, is bidding for influence and profit here. It has underwritten a feasibility study for construction of new canal locks, and is offering to finance a new bridge on extraordinarily generous terms.
YET neither Panama, which abolished its armed forces following the American invasion to overthrow Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega 10 years ago, nor the Asians can guarantee the security of the canal. That has historically been an American responsibility -- just as it is America that guarantees that the sea lanes remain open in Asia. But defending the canal is a role that has changed enormously in the last century, if only because the nature of war has changed.
Panamanians say there is virtually no possibility of building a foolproof military shield these days, a point American military planners concede privately.
Flying over the canal in a helicopter with Nicolas Ardito Barletta, the director of the Inter-Oceanic Regional Authority, the Panamanian government agency that oversees the former Panama Canal Zone, and looking down on the network of dams and locks that hold back the man-made Gatun and Madden Lakes, the waterway's vulnerability in the missile age is evident. If they were to be blown up, "the canal would be shut down for two years," Mr. Barletta acknowledged. That is why, he added, "the best guarantee for the canal is its neutrality."
These days that solution may be as attractive to the United States as it is to Asian users of the canal. But it begs another question: the instability in Latin American countries that are neighbors of the canal, and the fear that terrorism or sabotage there could spill over.
Outfits like the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia are not likely to be restrained by any declared neutrality. As if to underline their capacity to make trouble, that group last week overran the Colombian Navy base closest to Panama. There have also been incursions by Colombian guerrillas and paramilitary death squads into Panama's Darien province, and Mr. Eisenmann said Panamanians "have to be very cautious" about how they respond, lest they come under foreign pressure to revive a national military that has always proved corrupt and repressive.
At the canal, the favorite buzzword of its new masters these days is "diversification." Amid the profusion of new Hyundai cranes and Mitsubishi locomotives as modernization of the canal is planned, it is not clear whether the United States will emerge as first among equals or something less.
"We owe a lot to the United States," Ricardo Martinelli, the Panamanian government's minister of canal affairs, said in an interview. " We'd like American companies to offer the best terms. But we are living in a globalized world that is very competitive. That's the new reality, so welcome to the jungle."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
The Sounds of Silence

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
THAT deafening silence you hear is the sound of presidential hopefuls debating whether government should intervene in the wage-etting process to help people afford a better life. Today, it seems, everyone agrees that the market does this best.
In the past, American politicians have split, often rancorously, over the issue. Still more profoundly, they were divided over tax cuts and social programs such as welfare, food stamps, child care, education and health insurance. Now there is broad agreement that whatever the specifics, government should limit itself to help families get along until the market finally raises their incomes. 
 President Clinton came into office in 1993 in the old style: primed to use government to raise workers' wages. With the country still struggling to shake off the effects of a recession, he proposed a substantial increase in the minimum wage as well as billions on public works to raise the demand for workers. A presidential commission was also set up to study ways to make unions more effective.
In time, however, the public works spending was dropped in favor of deficit reduction. The union commission's recommendations were shelved, and the 90-cent increase in the minimum wage that Congress did approve in 1996 brought the minimum to only $5.15 today. That leaves it well short of its peak in 1968, when its worth was $7.49 an hour in today's dollars.
Since the Reagan years, a gradual metamorphosis has taken place. It appears to be culminating in the current presidential campaign, in which Republican and Democratic candidates alike bow to the efficiencies of the markets, even while acknowledging that income inequality remains a problem.
Wage-setting and labor power, once deeply divisive election year issues, are barely mentioned. The only question is what is the right tax incentive or social program when the markets require a helping hand.
"Where conservatives and liberals might differ, and it is a nuance difference, is in how each of us would tear down the obstacles to getting ahead," said Lawrence B. Lindsay of the American Enterprise Institute, who is George W. Bush's chief economic adviser.
Mr. Lindsay notes that Republicans emphasize tax cuts, which are intended to increase the incentive to work and to hasten the day that a worker takes home adequate pay for a materially decent life . Both sides favor the earned income tax credit, a tax rebate. And while the Democrats endorse a variety of social programs, including food stamps and subsidies for child care, health insurance, education and job training, they are careful to avoid any suggestion that they are interfering in the workings of the marketplace.
"I think the beauty of the earned income tax credit is that it raises living standards and incentives to work," said Gene Sperling, director of President Clinton's National Economic Council and a top adviser to Vice President AlGore. These programs, he explained, avoid "the kind of constraints on markets that in Europe has hurt the dynamism and job growth."
One reason for this convergence between Democrats and Republicans is the remarkable strength of the American economy, which has boomed since the 1996 election, while the more interventionist economies of Europe and Japan have floundered. Moreover, in 1996, wages finally began to rise faster than inflation, across the board, the first time that has happened since the early 1970's -- although well-to-do Americans have pulled further ahead of low-income families.
THIS inequality has hardly escaped notice, and no candidate has been more outspoken on the subject than Bill Bradley, Mr. Gore's rival for the Democratic nomination. But he, too, stays within the free market framework.
"Bill feels that open markets are a strength of the American economy, but he has also indicated that someone who works year-round, full-time should not end up being poor," said Marcia Aronoff, who advises Mr. Bradley on economics issues.
Mr. Bradley'ssolution, like Mr. Gore's, is social programs, including national health insurance and an expansion of the earned income tax credit, which now provides up to $5,000 a year for 17 million families earning between $9,000 and $30,500.
The Democratic candidates would raise the minimum wage again, but modestly, along the lines proposed by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, who tried unsuccessfully to win passage this fall of an increase in the minimum to $6.15 an hour over two years -- still well short of the old peak.
Mr. Gore and Mr. Bradley propose a similar modest increase in the minimum wage. And Mr. Sperling says that $1 over two years strikes a balance between "higher wages for low income people and potential harm to job growth."
Mr. Bradley would go a few steps further, banning striker replacement, for example, giving unions more power to organize workers and denying government contracts to companies that violate labor law. But those proposals, set forth in a mid-August speech, lack details. "He has not proposed specific remedies," Ms. Aronoff said. "He is open at this point to a variety of ideas."
The market-oriented approach to wage setting has the support of most mainstream economists, who argue, among other things, that government intervention discourages companies from hiring unskilled workers and puts the increased wage cost disproportionately on companies that hire the unskilled.
Business, by and large, seconds this view, arguing that tax cuts and social programs are preferable to higher mandated wages, which come directly out of their pockets.
But this view is by no means universally accepted. Some economists believe that the market demand for workers is only part of the reason for the rise in low-end wages in recent years. Small as it was, the 1996 increase in the minimum wage also nudged up hourly wages at the low end of the pay scale.
Today the federal minimum wage is so low that several states have increased their minimums since the mid-1990's, and more than 40 city and county governments have passed "living wage" ordinances. These in effect are minimums, often $7 an hour or more, imposed on companies that do business with local governments. Less job turnover and more worker efficiency help to offset the cost, some studies have found.
All this is fodder for an old-style campaign debate over wages and labor power in the months ahead. That is certainly the hope of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., which has endorsed Mr. Gore. David Smith, director of public policy for the union, said, "We continue to be disappointed that there is not more broad public attention, in the campaign discourse or the public discourse, about the problems of low wage workers and slow wage growth."
Mr. Smith's disappointment may last through November.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Ayes of Texas;
If There's a Lone Star in the State, It Isn't the Governor

BYLINE: By JIM YARDLEY 

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
GOV. GEORGE W. BUSH of Texas likes to remind voters and his rivals for the Republican presidential nomination that he runs one of the largest states in the country, a state so vast that if it were a country -- it once was one -- it would rank as the 11th largest economy in the world.
Bragging, of course, is a favorite sport in Texas, especially if the bragging is about Texas, but Mr. Bush's oft-repeated boast has a serious purpose. 
 In a race in which both his intellect and his experience have come under attack, Mr. Bush is reminding voters of two things: that he alone among the Republican contenders holds executive office, and that governing Texas is a big job, not unlike governing the nation.
Yet for all its mystique and undisputed national stature, Texas actually has one of the weakest gubernatorial offices in the country, a legacy of a Reconstruction-era constitution that was written to curb executive power.
According to political scientists, Texas stands anywhere from the bottom third to dead last among the 50 states, when ranked by the constitutional powers granted its governor.
"The imagined office is much greater than the real office," said Richard Murray, a political science professor at the University of Houston.
The result is a quirky paradox: the job offers a bully pulpit with national reach, yet it has fewer institutional powers than, say, the governor of Maryland.
The Texas governor has no formal cabinet because those positions are held by elected officials with their own political bases. The governor controls appointments to powerful state regulatory boards, but often the appointments are staggered from previous administrations.
And the governor is far less influential in the writing and administering of the budget, which is dominated by the Legislature and the lieutenant governor, compared to governors like Christine Todd Whitman in New Jersey and George E. Pataki in New York. (The New York governor's office is considered the most powerful in the nation.)
Unlike New York, where governors have risen to the presidency (Franklin D. Roosevelt, Theodore Roosevelt), tried and failed (Al Smith and Nelson Rockefeller), or thought about it a good bit (Mario Cuomo), the Texas job has not served as springboard, at least not yet.
John Connally, regarded as the state's most successful modern governor, sought the Republican presidential nomination but lost badly. The state's two presidents, Lyndon B. Johnson and George Bush, did their apprentice work in Washington, not Austin.
The job's inherent restrictions have always made it hard for even an ambitious Texas governor to accomplish the sort of big things that can launch a presidential run.
Mr. Connally managed to pass sweeping reforms and improvements to the state's higher education system in 1965. But he benefited from flush times and widespread public sympathy (his arm was in a sling from injuries he suffered while riding with John F. Kennedy on the day he was assassinated).
Governor Mark White later passed reforms to public schools, but with significant help from Ross Perot, who spent untold amounts of money lobbying for the measure.
What, then, of George W. Bush?
Does a weak office mean that Mr. Bush has been a weak governor?
Few academics or lawmakers in Texas would argue that.
In fact, the nature of the office has in many ways helped shape what some observers regard as the split personality of Mr. Bush's style of governing.
Upon taking office in 1995, Mr. Bush seemed to understand that he could succeed only with the goodwill of the Legislature.
He established a chummy, back-slapping tone, paying unexpected courtesy calls to flattered legislators in both parties and ingratiating himself with the two leading Democrats -- Lt. Gov. Bob Bullock and House Speaker Pete Laney.
"It seems to be more of a lovefest with Bush," said State Representative Steven Wolens of Dallas, one of many Democratic legislators who speaks warmly of the governor. "He is very, very accessible. And he is pal-sy."
The result was that the 1995 Legislative session was regarded as a ringing success for the new governor.
He had set out four broad issues during the campaign -- juvenile justice, welfare reform, tort reform and education -- and legislation was enacted on all four.
None of it represented seismic change, and some observers complained that Mr. Bush hadn't led so much as jumped, in Clintonesque fashion, in front of a parade that was already underway.
In fact, all four issues were popular with voters and in the legislative pipeline before his election. But Mr. Bush was seen as effective.
"You have to coerce, cajole and convince these people to do what you want to do," said Mr. Bush's close friend, State Senator David Sibley, a Republican from Waco, in explaining the influence exerted by the governor.
Two years later, emboldened by his popularity and eager to burnish his legacy and his presidential ambitions, Mr. Bush proposed a sweeping overhaul of the state's unwieldy tax structure. Doing so might have ranked Mr. Bush with John Connally, who is credited with significantly improving the state's system of higher education.
But Mr. Bush failed.
His plan promised to lower property taxes and stabilize school funding while raising sales taxes, but an alternative bill was passed with the governor's blessing, only to die in the Senate at the hands of his fellow Republicans.
Mr. Bush did win a $1 billion tax cut that many regarded as a consolation prize.
Back in 1995, Mr. Bush was taking the Legislature where it was already heading. But his tax plan in 1997 represented a political risk for lawmakers, and he could not muster the support to get the deal done.
More important, in the eyes of some observers he failed to effectively use his bully pulpit -- perhaps the greatest tool of his weak office -- to rally public opinion.
Mr. Bush could have spoken out for his program before it was killed in the Senate, said Bruce Buchanan, a political scientist at the University of Texas.
"That would have been the point where he could have gone public and mobilized the public, and he chose not to," Mr. Buchanan said. Others credited the governor for taking a huge political gamble, even if he did fail.
Political observers were interested to see which Mr. Bush would greet the 1999 legislative session: The more cautious, if more successful, governor of 1995 or the bolder, if less successful, model of 1997.
There was no clear answer; Mr. Bush was widely regarded as playing defense as friendly lawmakers killed any bills that might present potential embarrassments during the presidential campaign.
The lessons that Mr. Bush has taken from his office seem mixed. Legislators describe him as flexible and hardly an ideologue. Several lawmakers, including Democrats, credited the governor for projecting a genuine sense of non-partisanship in his dealings with legislators.
Whether this talent is transferable to the presidency is uncertain. President Jimmy Carter's problems with the Georgia Legislature during his years as governor there seem now to have foreshadowed his later struggles with Congress.
President Clinton, however, had apparently learned the art of massaging legislative egos as governor of Arkansas, yet his relationship with Congress has often been poisonous.
"Does the ability to reach across party lines and work with people translate to Washington?" asked State Representative Paul Sadler, an influential East Texas Democrat. "The answer is, 'I don't know.' "
But others said Mr. Bush's collegial approach does not always work for a leader, even a popular leader, as seen in his tax failure.
"His approach has kept him from being bold because it's an approach that depends on the goodwill and friendship of others," Mr. Buchanan said. "It means not stepping on toes."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Saddam Does Vegas

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
Because of rising oil demand from Asia, and the OPEC cartel's limiting of its production, the oil market has been very tight for the past six months. In this tight market, Saddam Hussein's Iraq became the enormously powerful swing producer -- the only country willing and able to suddenly turn on or off its oil tap. When Saddam was pumping his two million barrels a day, prices stayed steady or fell. But if he suddenly stopped, oil prices could skyrocket. On Nov. 23 Saddam suddenly stopped, sending prices soaring. He said he was doing this in protest of continuing U.N. sanctions. Don't believe it. Here's my guess at what Saddam and his oil minister were really saying to each other:
Saddam: So, how did our strategy work out? 
 Oil Minister: Great Leader, it worked like a charm. Last March OPEC agreed on production cuts in order to soak up world oil inventories and tighten up the market. After all those years of OPEC countries' cheating on their production, they actually did cut back. Just as we expected, that pushed prices up, from about $10 to $20 a barrel, and made our swing production that much more important. In July and August we started buying oil futures through our front companies in Europe. We went long on oil futures at an average of $20 a barrel. Over the months we bought 100 million barrels of futures. Then when you suddenly stopped our production in November, and the price went to $27, we picked up $7 a barrel. That's $700 million, Great Leader, in just a few weeks. That's almost as good as buying Internet stocks.
Saddam: And you were ready when I moved last week?
Oil Minister: Of course, Great Leader! As soon as you told me your plan to tell the U.N. by mid-December that you would resume pumping oil for food, I liquidated our oil futures at the top of the market and locked in our profits before the price fell. All the money's been sent to your Beirut bank account -- which is now The Mother of All Accounts. When will the Americans ever figure out how you've been funding yourself?
Saddam: And did you take care of our Chinese friends?
Oil Minister: Just as you instructed, Great Leader. We tipped them off early to our plan. It is hysterically funny for me to read the oil newsletters. They've all been asking why it was that the Chinese oil companies suddenly started buying up all the North Sea oil they could get their hands on in early November. The oil experts don't have a clue it was because the Chinese were in on our plan.
Saddam: You know the Americans keep thinking that Alan Greenspan is the Master of the Universe. But he's not. I am. I have the power to shoot oil prices up or down any time I want. I can create a lot of inflation and maybe even force Greenspan to raise interest rates. That wouldn't be good for the U.S. stock markets. The Pentagon can bomb me, but I can bomb the Nasdaq. They may discover I've got them over a barrel -- hah! Get it? Over a barrel!
Oil Minister: Great Leader, you are so funny. Speaking of jokes, how will you handle the Syrians cozying up to the Israelis and Americans?
Saddam: The Americans think they can isolate me by pulling the Syrians to their side and then by having the U.N. Security Council vote for their imperialist resolution that suspends the economic sanctions on Iraq -- provided I allow U.N. arms inspectors back here. But I don't want U.N. snoops here again, if I can help it. That may mean my people will have to go hungry some more, but hunger is good. It means they have less energy to focus on me.
The Americans should note that the French, Russians and Chinese all abstained from their U.N. resolution. That's because they look at the Syrian capitulation as another sign that the Americans want to run the whole Middle East. France, Russia and China believe that by supporting Iraq they can prevent U.S. hegemony.
There's a bet going on out here. Assad, Arafat, Mubarak, King Abdullah, they're all betting on the old order and the new emperor -- Emperor Uncle Sam. Me, I'm betting that after all these leaders go, a new Arab generation will come of age that will want a new order and will turn to me, Saddam Hussein, King of Kings, to kick out the Americans and regain their independence. I'm flush with cash right now, so, you wanna bet?

HEADLINE: Snake River Study Avoids Decision on Dams

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
Saying the scientific evidence was not conclusive, federal officials have released a long-awaited study but have made no decision on whether to breach four Snake River dams to help restore salmon populations in the Pacific Northwest.
The study of ways to change dam operations on the lower Snake River to help the salmon was released on Friday in Portland, Ore., by the Army Corps of Engineers. It included a recommendation from another federal agency, the Fish and Wildlife Service, that the dams be breached. 
A spokeswoman for the Fish and Wildlife Service, Joan Jewett, said the agency's recommendation did not consider the economic and social effects of breaching the Ice Harbor, Lower Monumental, Little Goose and Lower Granite dams.
Officials have emphasized that the debate was not just about dams and that the region must consider several steps to help the endangered fish.
Government agencies plan hearings early next year on what might be the best options for restoring Columbia River Basin salmon and steelhead trout.

HEADLINE: Living in a Van, Trying to Move Up

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 17

 BODY:
Kathleen Gray bought the van brand new in 1978. It took half a year of waiting tables to make the $1,300 down payment. But it was well worth it. A Volkswagen pop-top camper!
The day she drove it home, she spread her sleeping bag in the cab, popped open the roof and lay under the built-in tent, daydreaming of a life on the road. 
 That life on the road did not work out as planned. Yet now, with its engine as loud as a helicopter when it agrees to work, the musty green van is more precious than ever. Every morning when Ms. Gray leaves for work, she worries that the van will be gone when she gets back. And then where would she be? The van is her home.
She and her boyfriend, David Aquino, began living in the van almost two years ago. Before the van became home, the couple lived for three months in a tent in an encampment at Golden Gate Park. Before that, both unemployed, they had been evicted from the house where Mr. Aquino grew up. Before that seems like a long time ago.
How Ms. Gray became homeless is a complicated story. But in one crucial respect, Ms. Gray's case is like those of many homeless people she meets: She got in a bind and had no way to get out of it. No money. No help.
Even now, six months into working two part-time jobs that together pay her nearly $1,200 a month, she can not say when she will be able to stop using a ratty blanket for a bed or a pickle jar for a toilet. Not with landlords asking for three months' rent up front, her boyfriend still not working and past-due bills waiting to attach themselves to her paycheck.
It is especially hard to be homeless in these days of giddy prosperity. For Ms. Gray, it is like having her nose pressed against the glass of a big party where money flutters in the air like confetti. San Francisco, flush with Silicon Valley professionals, has become so expensive that a six-figure income is considered middle-class, and basic items like a gallon of regular gas ($1.60) cost more than anywhere else in the country.
Ms. Gray has never been rich. Her parents divorced when she was 12. In her senior year of high school, she abandoned plans for college to support herself and her mother, who had cancer.
But she never thought she would have to count pennies at 44, in the prime of life. People she meets who are not homeless are always surprised to learn that she is; she defies the stereotype.
The Census Bureau survey of homeless people, released this month, showed that most were ill, physically or mentally. Ms. Gray is healthy. She does not drink or use illegal drugs. She does not come from welfare poverty. She is not a single mother.
Until three years ago, when she quit a job as a concessions manager at a Renaissance fair in Marin County to attend a school for prospective travel industry employees, she had worked nonstop since graduating from high school in Orange County.
Until she had to do it herself, she says, she always looked at the people living on the streets with something like revulsion.
"Now I know it's a lot harder to get out of the fix than to get in it," she said with a laugh, her usual punctuation, as she stopped at an Anderson's supermarket the other day on her way to work. By 7 every morning, after a round of catch with Kaya, a pit-bull mix she and Mr. Aquino adopted last year, they arrive at the supermarket to wash up. Then they buy the breakfast they can afford: large coffees, light and sweet.
Sometimes, Ms. Gray has no good answer when people ask why she does not go somewhere easier to live.
Living in a vehicle is illegal in San Francisco. Even in a desolate, wind-whipped neighborhood hard by the ocean, the police regularly shine lights into the van in the middle of the night. Once, when the van was towed for a parking violation, it took several days and $700 of scrounged and borrowed money to get it back.
Inside, the van is as dark and crowded as a storage closet. Good clothes, like his pin-striped interview suit and her pink down jacket, hang on a rod. Clean clothes are piled in his and hers stacks. Laundry sits in plastic grocery bags. Kaya's water and food dishes are by the driver's seat. Jars used as portable urinals are discretely lined up on the floor by a stack of boxes.
Ms. Gray, who is tall and broad-shouldered, with a long red braid, a curtain of bangs and wire-rimmed glasses, often laughs, loudly, at her daily tribulations. "We have to use a bathroom where we can find one," she said, laughing, making a beeline for a veterans' hospital near a park where they exercise Kaya.
"It's Ramen noodles for a week," she will say, laughing if she splurges on a $5 lunch.
"The police call me a habitual, known offender for sleeping in the van," she says, laughing. "And it's true: I sleep every night."
On weekdays, she works at the Coalition on Homelessness, a nonprofit advocacy organization. On weekends, she helps run showers for homeless people at the Mission High School. Her job perks include invitations to church potlucks and one long hot shower a week.
No one notices if her hair needs washing or she wears the same turquoise T-shirt two days in a row.
She and the short, bushy-haired Mr. Aquino often borrow the coalition's van, which they use to push Ms. Gray's van from one street to the next when it refuses to run.
They met playing darts at a pub. At the time Mr. Aquino, who will be 46 this month, had recently left an 11-year job as a sorter for the Postal Service. He says he quit in anger over a $20,000 bill he received for interest and penalties on child support (for a daughter, now in her 20's), which he thought he had paid.
Three months after they met, after a falling out with her roommate, Ms. Gray moved in with Mr. Aquino, who was living with his grandfather. Divorced from his daughter's mother, he had vowed he would never marry again, but Ms. Gray said, "We were going to."
But her wanderlust, whetted by six years as a waitress and bartender in Maui (where she bought her van), was not satisfied. She enrolled in the travel school, hoping for a job on a cruise ship. "It had this highfalutin title for what I wanted," she said. "Destination management."
Within months, Mr. Aquino's grandfather died. The house became the property of Mr. Aquino's estranged father and uncle, who evicted the couple so they could sell it. Neither Ms. Gray, with her savings gone and credit cards at their limits, nor Mr. Aquino, with his debts, were in a position to land on their feet.
"Well, of course, I wouldn't have quit my job if I knew all this was going to happen," Mr. Aquino said. "People just have no idea how hard it is to get out of the hole of homelessness. You spend your days surviving. You don't have room for much else."
Ms. Gray is convinced that if she and Mr. Aquino had been getting along at the time his grandfather died, they could have fought the eviction. Instead, they were busy fighting each other. It was so consuming, she said, that she dropped out of travel school, twice. She had Mr. Aquino arrested for assault after he broke a telephone on her head. A judge ordered him to attend an anger-management class.
Mr. Aquino prefers not to discuss that period. One day, when they were retracing their descent to the streets, Ms. Gray, laughing, said, "Well, things got really hairy when I had David arrested."
Mr. Aquino took his baseball cap off, tapped her on the head with it and said, "Hey, you stop that."
The day they were evicted, Ms. Gray invited Mr. Aquino to stay with her in her van until he found somewhere else. Throughout their ordeals, they have never separated.
She says she tried to leave, alone, before they were evicted. With both parents gone and her two brothers (one a minister in Oregon, the other a computer programmer in Southern California), out of touch, she called an old friend of her mother's and asked to borrow $5,000. The friend said she could not spare it.
These days, Ms. Gray and Mr. Aquino get along fairly well. Their dog is their therapy, Mr. Aquino says.
But they disagree dramatically over how to improve their situation.
Ms. Gray says it is best to take any job to begin repairing their broken credit. Mr. Aquino says it is not worth getting a job that pays less than $10 an hour, because it would be impossible to save money making less. He still receives $345 a month as part of a city program that tries to steer assistance recipients into solid jobs. (He once cleaned buses for his stipend.) He says he hopes to become a truck driver.
While Ms. Gray is still not used to being homeless, she says her worst moment occurred at the beginning, when she and Mr. Aquino were living in Golden Gate Park. (Ms. Gray's van was in a friend's driveway in Marin County, refusing to run). Ms. Gray had just started workfare two days a week for the Parks and Recreation Department for $345 a month. One day, the parks department was ordered to sweep all the homeless camps from the park. Ms. Gray, as part of the crew, was forced to dump her own meager possessions.
"I remember at the time, thinking well, I was guilty," she said. "I was living in the park, Now, I see things so differently. With these sweeps, the city was -- and is -- systematically destroying people's personal property. Blankets, prescription medicine, glasses, documents. And I watched as bosses looked the other way while workfare workers were allowed to keep -- to steal -- things."
She and 10 other homeless people sued the city in small claims court for the illegal destruction of their property and won. She received $500 in damages.
Lately she has been worried about how to help a quadriplegic homeless woman in her 30's. The woman spends nights on the ground, crawling to her chair in the mornings. By the end of the week, when Ms. Gray helps the woman take a shower, her body and clothes are soaked in feces and urine.
"I think two things when I see her," Ms. Gray said one morning in the van. "First, I think, How can we allow this to happen?
"Then," she said, letting her head fall back against a tattered window curtain, "I think, Boy, am I lucky. I am just so lucky."

HEADLINE: THE NEEDIEST CASES;
Straining to Keep a Place That They Can Call Home

BYLINE: By AARON DONOVAN

 BODY:
When Constance B., 62, moved into her studio apartment in the Fordham section of the Bronx 19 years ago, she was a freelance writer and English tutor. Since then, she has lost her sight and suffered kidney disease as a result of acute diabetes. And she fears she may well lose her apartment because of rent increases.
"It's a struggle, because I'm on a fixed income," she said. "Every two years my lease expires, and I have to pay the rent increase. Every two years my rent increases, but my income stays the same." 
 In July, Constance's rent rose to $438 a month from the $420 a month in the previous lease. In May, the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, one of the seven local charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, paid $1,000 of Constance's back rent, and she was able to pay $677 of the arrears herself.
As the New York economy continues to thrive, land values and rent are soaring, but the boom is leaving behind those living on a fixed income, or those who are temporarily out of work.
In addition to the economy, there are demographic reasons for the costly rental market, said Michael H. Schill, director of the New York University School of Law's Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy. The city's housing supply, historically tight, is being squeezed even more as the population grows in certain neighborhoods.
"It's a simple case of supply and demand," he said. "You have an increase in demand, and you have a relatively stagnant supply, so what you have is skyrocketing prices."
"The housing shortage in New York is really quite severe," he said. "Approximately a quarter of the city's renters pay over half their incomes in rent, which is a tremendous rent burden."
Mr. Schill said that many New Yorkers are in that situation, but the problem is especially acute for the poor.
"The problems of affordability affect renters across the income spectrum, but they are particularly concentrated among the very poor," he said.
With circumstances so dire, the charities that benefit from the Neediest Cases Fund often have to step in with assistance. That can mean supplying the money for people like Constance, who are on fixed incomes and facing higher rents; aiding families that have been forced from their homes by fires or other catastrophes find new quarters; or helping a family move when one parent leaves, taking much of the household's income.
 
THE RENT
Rescued From Brink Of Homelessness
Constance, who asked that her full name not be used, lives on $587 a month in Supplemental Security Income, and receives $127 a month in food stamps. Her biggest expense is rent.
About five years ago, she lost her sight. More recently, her kidneys began to fail. "When you have diabetes, first the eyes go, then the kidneys," she said.
"Blindness has not destroyed me, because I would not let it," she said. "My memory has increased, my hearing has increased. It wasn't so tragic coming to me in later years. Dialysis has changed my life more than anything else."
Each week, Constance has three four-hour dialysis treatments, a process in which her blood is cleaned by a machine. "That doesn't allow much time to do anything," she said. "The day after dialysis you're usually very weak and drained."
Because she was never in top health, Constance said, she was not able to hold a 9-to-5 job that could have given her a pension. She worked for many years as a freelance writer, she said, and she tutored students in English at her home. For now, she is scraping by.
Constance said she might find more affordable housing, but is afraid to move to a new neighborhood. "If I went into a new neighborhood, I wouldn't know where anything is, I wouldn't know where the street ends," she said. "After 20 years I know all the means of transportation. When I go out, people look out for me, but in a new neighborhood no one would know me. My neighbors know me here; I know their telephones so I can call them if I'm in distress. So I struggle to pay my rent."
Constance's is just one of 451 households the federation was able to assist by Dec. 1 this year with checks for back rent or security deposits for new apartments, said Judy Milone, the federation's director of client services. She said that most of the people the federation helped were able to pay their rent over the long term, but fell behind for a month or so because they had lost their jobs or had to pay medical expenses.
Chelita Coleman, 58, like many people who have been helped by the federation, had worked her whole life when she was laid off from her job as a legal secretary and fell behind on her rent.
In the aftermath of the layoff, she took computer courses to enhance her resume. But after eight months without a job, she found she was unable to pay the $426 rent on her one-bedroom apartment in a Mitchell-Lama building near Amsterdam Avenue on the Upper West Side, and she fell further and further behind.
"It was mind-boggling to think: 'Where am I going to go? What am I going to do? How am I going to pack all my stuff up?' " she recalled. But before she could be evicted, she called the federation, which reviewed her case and issued her landlord a check for $521.
Ms. Coleman now works as the transcripts secretary at Yeshiva University, and with her annual salary of $22,500, she can now manage her rent, she said.
"Requests for diversion from homelessness is the major need that we see," said Megan McLaughlin, executive director of the federation. "The overwhelming majority of the direct cash assistance goes to people who need money to prevent homelessness.
"As we're pushing people to work, we have to look at the relationship between income and rent," she said. "There are people working full time that cannot keep up with their rent, eat, and take care of the basic human requirements."
Ms. Milone said the federation had helped more families stay in their homes with each year, as donations to the Neediest Cases Fund have gone up. Still, the federation had enough money to help only about 13 percent of the 3,366 households that asked for assistance.
The federation is forced to set priorities. "For rental assistance, we need know why they're behind with their rent to begin with," Ms. Milone said. "It has to be something reasonable and something they can document. We also need to see that they have sufficient income right now to pay their future rent."
As important as housing is in itself, a housing crisis can lead to untold related problems, Ms. McLaughlin said.
"When families are disrupted, schooling is a problem, health care is a problem," she said. "You cannot conduct a job search properly without an address and a phone number, let alone plan for an interview."
 
THE FIRE
Children Are Saved, But a Home Is Lost
But being unable to pay the rent is not only way that people can become homeless. A fire can have the same effect, only more suddenly.
Randy Dillard's first thought as he stood in his underwear in front of his Harlem apartment building on the night of July 15 was of his children. He had just been burned out of his apartment, and he recalled thinking, "What am I going to do with these five kids?"
Randy Dillard was already struggling to raise his five children, one of whom is autistic and one of whom is blind in one eye, even before the fire, which destroyed his two-and-a-half-room, seventh-floor apartment on Morningside Avenue.
Mr. Dillard was able to rescue all five of his children as the apartment burned, but he lost everything he owned.
The fire, which was caused by a malfunctioning electrical socket, destroyed the family's furniture and clothes, photographs and a wooden plaque that Mr. Dillard's mildly autistic son, Nathan Taylor, received for doing well in school.
But Mr. Dillard said he had not given much thought to the things lost in the fire, because he spent most of his time trying to find a new apartment that he can afford, while hoping to avoid public housing projects.
Lacking fire insurance, he and his children were placed in a homeless shelter in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, but Mr. Dillard did not like it there. Not only did his children face an hourlong commute to their school in Harlem, but they were treated roughly by the young people in the neighborhood.
Mr. Dillard, who is separated from his wife, left his job as a construction worker in 1994 to raise his children full time. After about a year, he exhausted his savings and had to turn to public assistance for help. He now must feed and clothe his children, Nathan, Romeo and Joseph Taylor, 11, 10 and 8, and Randy Dillard Jr., 9, and Lynn Dillard, 2, with the money he receives from welfare, a check for $150 every two weeks, and a $523 Supplemental Security Income check for Nathan Taylor once a month.
"I stretch it, I squeeze it," he said, but he has also received help from the Children's Aid Society, one of the seven charities supported by Neediest Cases Fund.
"The main thing is that they eat a lot, and she grows out of stuff as soon as she gets it," he said, looking at his 2-year-old daughter as she worked on a pencil drawing.
Before worrying about paying the rent, Mr. Dillard struggles just to give necessities like food and clothing to his children. The Children's Aid Society gave Lynn $100 worth of summer clothing that she desperately needed. The society has also given Mr. Dillard money for Christmas presents for his children, and it paid for a bed and chest of drawers, bed linens and socks.
After the fire, Mr. Dillard made sure that three of his children remained at the same school so that at least one thing in their lives would remain constant.
After that, by placing telephone calls to City Hall, he was able to win a rarely granted transfer from one housing shelter to another. The family now lives in a room at a shelter in northern Harlem, and Mr. Dillard is grateful that he can live there for now.
"We've got a roof over our heads -- it's not our roof, but at least we have our lives," he said.
At the new shelter, Mr. Dillard's children are much closer to their school, P.S. 180 on West 120th Street, than they had been in Brooklyn -- just a half-hour ride on the M7 bus.
Mr. Dillard's children said they were eager to leave the new shelter despite its proximity to the school. "They got rats and mice in the place," said Joseph. "And there's bad kids there. You know they're bad kids, because bad kids light the garbage on fire."
Mr. Dillard was hoping to become a chef, but the fire dashed his plans for the time being, forcing him to focus instead on finding a place to live other than the shelter.
The housing placement office at the shelter has placed Mr. Dillard on a waiting list for an apartment, but he said he was not sure if an offer of housing would come in five months or tomorrow, or if the offer will be acceptable, given his wariness of public housing.
"If they place me to a project, if I turn it down, I go all the way to the back of the list," he said.
The Children's Aid Society is focused on providing stability to the Dillard family, and when Mr. Dillard eventually finds a new place to live, the society will be there to help him furnish it. "When they find a house, if they need beds and a dresser, the only way we can help them is with New York Times money," said Mary Hutson, the social worker who works with Mr. Dillard.
 
THE CALL FOR HELP
Selling Off Treasures To Keep Apartment
 Jerry Leff, 62, lives in an apartment in Rego Park, Queens. In his 25 years there, his rent has risen to more than 70 percent of his income.
When he was 50, Mr. Leff was laid off as a magazine art director after the stock market downturn of 1987. Worried that he was too old to get a new job in his field, he lost confidence. He eventually began working as a clerk at a bingo hall and as a cook at a center for disabled children. He worked 10 more years, until his arthritis became too painful for him to continue.
At the bingo parlor, Mr. Leff cleaned the floor and wiped tables and moved chairs from place to place. "The years at the bingo hall killed my legs," he said.
Now Mr. Leff, who walks with a cane, stays in his rent-regulated apartment most of the time. Paying the $713 month rent and his other expenses is a constant challenge.
And with the tight rental market, it is unlikely that he could find a less expensive apartment, said his social worker, Karen Norden. Then there are his health concerns and the cost of moving.
Three times since 1996, Mr. Leff has gone to the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, a beneficiary of the UJA-Federation of New York, another one of the seven local charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, for help in paying his back rent. The three well-timed checks amounted to $2,000.
"If Jerry had been evicted, I don't think he could even afford a furnished room," Ms. Norden said. "I think he would probably end up in the street or in a nursing home."
Mr. Leff receives $871 a month in Social Security Disability Income, and $127 each month in food stamps. And because of a state program called Senior Citizen Rent Increase Exemption, his rent will remain the same, while his disability income will increase slightly as the years go by, Ms. Norden said. She expects that he will not need help with his rent in the future.
Earlier this year, before he was helped the second time, in October, Mr. Leff wanted Ms. Norden to think everything was fine, so he told her that he was keeping up with his rent. But at the time he selling off possessions that were dear to him: his extensive watch collection, his series of first-edition Sherlock Holmes novels, and some of his furniture, including a love seat, a chair and two bureaus.
Finally, after his cat, Wilson, died, he realized he had to turn to the social welfare agency for help. Crying, he called Ms. Norden and told her that he had been lying when he said he was getting by.
"I hate to feel that I can't support myself," Mr. Leff said. "But it's the truth. I fell on hard times."
Mr. Leff said he wished his arthritis would allow him to return to his last job, as a Marshall's sales representative, which paid slightly more than minimum wage. "It just felt good to be working," he said.

HEADLINE: Experts Wonder if Crime Drop Is Near End

BYLINE: By KEVIN FLYNN

 BODY:
The overall crime rate in New York City declined again this year, but a rise in homicides and several other factors have led some criminologists to question whether the decade-long descent is about to bottom out.
Through Dec. 12, crime has fallen by 8 percent over last year, police statistics show. But during that same period, the homicide rate, which is often viewed as a bellwether for larger trends in crime, surged by 8 percent. It was the first increase in any major crime category in the city in eight years. 
 Although crime dropped last year in every one of the city's 76 police precincts, 4 of them showed increases this year, as local burglary or robbery rates began to rebound. In one neighborhood, the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn, the number of major crimes grew by 18 percent.
Many criminologists believe that crime trends are reliably cyclical, and several predicted that New York, given the patterns in its history, was at the end of the downturn.
"I am leaning toward the conclusion that we have reached bottom," said James Alan Fox, the Lipman professor of criminal justice at Northeastern University in Boston. "The years of double-digit declines may be over."
New York's police officials, whose efforts have helped push crime to 30-year lows, rejected any suggestion that the tide was turning. They said they had battled such skepticism and pessimism since the early 1990's, when many people kept insisting that a safer city was a pipe dream long after the crime rate had begun to plunge.
Although the homicide rate rose this year, the officials said, 158 American cities still rank above New York in crimes reported per capita, including tourist destinations like Orlando, Fla. And, they said, the broad pattern of decreases in other offenses is evidence that the rise in homicides is an aberration, not a portent.
For example, robberies fell by 9 percent and assaults declined by 10 percent this year. Overall, crime remains down 55 percent compared with the rate six years ago, a statistic that many credit with fueling New York's booming popularity with tourists.
"People every year keep saying, 'It's bottomed out. It's over,' " said Edward T. Norris, the Police Department's deputy commissioner for operations. "But we still find areas where we can improve on. I don't know when we will bottom out, but I don't think we have hit the bottom yet."
Nationally, crime is now dropping even faster than it is in New York. Overall, crime was down 10 percent nationwide for the first six months of this year, the latest period for which comparative data is available, according to the Department of Justice, compared with 7.7 percent in New York City. Crime in New York State declined by 9 percent during the same six-month period.
Similarly, homicides are still down nationally, by 13 percent, although they were up slightly in cities with populations greater than one million, like New York. Although criminologists cautioned against making sweeping predictions from a year's worth of data, some suggested that New York's small rise in homicides might foretell a national trend.
"The big cities led the way when the numbers went down, and they also may be leading the way as the numbers plateau," Mr. Fox said.
But several other criminologists said they shared the Police Department's optimism, largely because of a continuing decline in auto theft in the city, which fell by 10 percent this year and is considered a very reliable indicator. "Auto theft is reported well because the insurance company won't pay you unless you file a police report," said Thomas A. Reppetto, president of the Citizens Crime Commission, a private organization.
Experts also noted that the social forces that drove the crime wave of the late 1980's -- a stagnant economy and a raging epidemic of drug use that lured many unemployed young men into the violence of the narcotics trade -- have not resurfaced.
But other criminologists said that even without such social accelerants, crime in the city has historically spiraled up and down in fairly regular cycles. In the last three decades, for example, the crime rate has peaked in 1972, 1979 and 1990, and then slumped for several years before rising again, said Jeffrey Fagan, a criminologist who teaches at Columbia University.
"If we are not at the bottom now, we are likely to hit the bottom very soon," Mr. Fagan said. "You can't have unending crime increases or decreases, and the past is the best predictor of the future."
In neighborhoods where crime has rebounded, it is often the sight of resurgent street-corner drug traffic, not any statistical abstraction, that has local leaders concerned. In the Seventh Precinct, for example, which covers the Lower East Side, serious crime is up 8 percent, including a 16 percent rise in robberies and a 26 percent increase in burglaries. City Councilwoman Margarita Lopez said tenant groups began noticing an increase in street-corner drug sales about 18 months ago.
"We think there is a connection between this activity and the rise in burglaries and the robberies," she said. "There is no question to me."
Predicting patterns becomes particularly difficult when the period being studied is already somewhat unusual, as the last nine years have been. Seldom has crime in the city declined as sharply as it has in the past few years, criminologists said.
"Look at how much difficulty economists have with the stock market," said Eric Monkkonen, a historian of crime who teaches at the University of California, Los Angeles. "And this is much more complicated than the stock market."
Mr. Monkkonen, who is writing a book about murder in New York City, said that the last time crime dropped so precipitously in the city was in 1931, when New York was reeling from the Depression. There were 562 homicides that year, only 17 percent fewer than the number projected for this year. By 1943, when the nation and its young men were fully engaged in World War II, the number of homicides had dropped to 208.
This year, overall crime has declined in every borough, as well as in the subway system and in public housing. Citywide, rapes went down by 16 percent and burglaries declined by 13 percent. Shooting incidents increased by less than 1 percent, even though gun arrests were down by 14 percent.
Certain places grew noticeably safer, like Central Park, where overall crime declined by 30 percent, including a 22 percent drop in robberies and a 52 percent drop in assaults. Crime also dropped dramatically in the 33rd Precinct, which covers much of Washington Heights, where there was a 30 percent drop in assaults.
But the homicide rate rose in both of those places and across much of the city for reasons police officials are still exploring. Officials estimate the homicide count will rise to 680 by year's end, compared with 633 last year, although the number is still nowhere near the toll in 1990, when the city suffered through a record 2,245 homicides.
Commissioner Norris said the homicide rate appeared to have been driven up by an increase in gang activity, a surge in domestic violence and a downturn in aggressiveness by the police after the shooting of Amadou Diallo, which provoked criticism that too many officers were brutish on patrol. The department has tried to address these concerns with initiatives, like expanding domestic violence units in some precincts and forcing more officers to work weekends, when much of the alcohol-related domestic abuse occurs, the commissioner said.
As a result of the initiatives, officials said, the homicide rate has slowed dramatically since June, when homicides were running 15 percent ahead of last year's tally. For the second half of the year, homicides increased by 2 percent.
Several criminologists said one factor that could lead to an increase in crime in New York was the anticipated growth over the next few years in a crime-prone population, young men 15 to 24 years old. To analysts who believe that demographic trends have as much to do with crime patterns as police work, the New York City decline has always been partly explained by a drop in the number of teenagers and young males during the last eight years.
Police officials resist this notion that somehow their efforts -- a crackdown on quality-of-life offenses, a commitment to gun seizures, a re-emphasis on intelligence-gathering and neighborhood drug initiatives -- played second fiddle to the dictates of a particular population decline.
"We take a lot of credit for most of the decline," Mr. Norris said. "As it goes up, I think we would take a lot of the criticism. But we are confident that we can reduce further and certainly maintain the gains we've enjoyed."

HEADLINE: Six Years in the Making, a Reconstructed Metro-North Station Opens in Harlem

BYLINE: By TINA KELLEY

 BODY:
Ruby Parra of the Bronx remembers having to stand under an umbrella as she waited to buy tickets inside the decrepit 125th Street Metro-North station.
"It used to be bad. I tried to stay away from it," she said of the station, which reopened yesterday after six years of reconstruction. The leaking roof has been fixed, the paint on the 1897 building is fresh, but historically accurate, there are refurbished bathrooms and a new elevator, and a heated waiting area overlooks the tracks. 
 Maria Mosca of Manhattan, who was waiting for a train to Katonah, said the station used to be a wreck. "It's just been a pleasure this morning to sit here and look around," she said, relaxing on the waiting room's restored original oak benches.
In the midst of exuberant economic growth along East and West 125th Streets, the station, at Park Avenue, is a small piece of the new Harlem renaissance, made more of steel and concrete than art and poetry.
It is tucked under the tracks above Park Avenue, barely a block from where a Pathmark supermarket opened recently and a movie theater is expected to be built soon, and just a few blocks from Harlem U.S.A., a shopping center under construction at Frederick Douglass Boulevard and 125th Street.
Inside the station, the trim is done in a hearty green, suitably Victorian, selected after research into paint samples of the era. The solid oak tongue-and-groove paneling imitates the original, which dripping water had ruined. Textured quarry tile provides traction underfoot, and a new stairway design lets people move more easily between tracks. At the station, 20-foot-wide steel and concrete platforms replaced 16-foot-wide ones made of timber and asphalt. Six-inch-thick concrete slabs, molded to look like cedar bark, deflect sound that used to reach the street. Aluminum relief sculptures along the bridge over 125th Street, by a New York artist, Terry Adkins, borrow Sphinx motifs from Aaron Douglas, an artist from the Harlem Renaissance.
The Federal Transit Administration paid for 80 percent of the $148 million project, with the state paying the balance. About 90 percent of the cost was not for the station, but for reconstruction of the century-old, mile-long viaduct carrying the tracks from 110th to 131st Streets.
The route through the area has a long history. The tracks extended north to Harlem at street level in 1837, and by 1860 trains struck a person or an animal almost every week, according to news reports of the time. The tracks were then lowered below street level north of 116th Street.
After a navigable connection was cut from the Hudson River to the Harlem River in the 1890's, allowing boats from upstate to travel down the East Side, the railroad bridge across the Harlem River needed to be raised, so the steel viaduct was built.
It now carries 650 trains a day. To reconstruct it, workers had to replace half of its steel girders. They used 6,000 tons of steel and 10,000 cubic yards of concrete. Under the viaduct, at the cross streets, lighting has been improved.
Poor drainage damaged both the station and the viaduct. Often, puddles would cause drips from one rainstorm to another, leaking brown drops of water onto people on the street below. "It was like Chinese water torture," said Walter Sewell, the project manager for Metro-North.
David Givens, chairman of Community Board 11, welcomed the end of the project. "I'm certainly happy that it's finally over, after numerous years of inconvenience," he said. "We are excited by it. The renovated station certainly adds a jewel in our crown here in East Harlem."
He said he hoped more passengers would get off at the Harlem station and take the subway south from 125th Street, avoiding the crowds at Grand Central Terminal.
Joseph Roberts, an employee of the Greater Harlem Chamber of Commerce, said the new station may attract passengers seeking a nonstop ride from 125th Street to Grand Central, for as low as $3.25.
Speaking of the project's planners, he said, "With everything else that's happening in Harlem, they had great foresight."
Sue Glass, who lives in upper Manhattan, was looking forward to trying out the elevator. "This is so much better, to use the elevator to get up, when you have arthritis in your knees, like I do," she said.
Near her, a woman in a fur coat headed to the tracks with her small black-and-white dog, which was wearing a fur-trimmed jacket. A man with a scarf in Burberry tartan hoisted monogrammed leather luggage, and 3-year-old Chloe Campbell waited with her grandmother for a train to Beacon. She pronounced the station beautiful, announced that she speaks English, and lodged one complaint, about a dark television monitor hanging from the ceiling.
"Where's the TV at?" she asked.
