HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Cleveland's Long Road Finally Leads to Finley

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
The Cleveland Indians traveled a long and treacherous road to sign Chuck Finley. It took them over the ruts and potholes of four free-agent markets and an endless number of talks aimed at generating the right trades. They were left behind in the wake of the movement of pitchers like Roger Clemens, Pedro Martinez, Orlando Hernandez and Randy Johnson.
Before signing Finley last week, the Indians had struck out in their pursuit of a string of top-line starting pitchers in the past four years. The only one they succeeded in obtaining was Jack McDowell, whom they signed as a free agent in December 1995, and then he blew out his arm after one season. 
 "It's been a combination of things," John Hart, the Indians' industrious general manager, said. "Some of it is economics, some of it that there were more buyers than players. We just haven't been able to land the guys we wanted."
The Indians wanted Clemens when he was a free agent following the 1996 season. They competed for him with the Yankees and the Toronto Blue Jays. The offers were similar. Clemens said at the time he wanted to play for a team that had a chance to go to the World Series. The Indians went in 1997, the Yankees in '98; Clemens, however, signed with the Blue Jays.
That same winter the Indians also pursued Alex Fernandez and thought they had him. But at the last minute his wife convinced him to play in Miami, their hometown, and the Indians lost him, too.
After the 1997 season, the Indians renewed their efforts to get a top-notch starting pitcher. They discussed a trade with Montreal for Martinez, but the Expos accepted an offer from the Boston Red Sox. The Indians then negotiated with a trio of free agents, Wilson Alvarez, Darryl Kile and Andy Benes, but other teams offered far more than they wanted to pay.
Straying off the beaten path, they looked at another kind of free agent that winter, the Cuban defector known as El Duque. They were one of two or three finalists, but the Indians did not feel they had enough information to warrant the four-year $6.6 million contract the Yankees offered him. Hernandez became just another one who got away.
But the one who really got away was Randy Johnson. It was the day of the 1998 trading deadline, and the Seattle Mariners were ready to trade Johnson, who was three months from free agency. The Indians, thinking they were among the front-runners, were envisioning Johnson at the head of their rotation, pitching against the Yankees in the playoffs.
Only the Houston Astros swooped in at the last minute and snatched Johnson out of the Indians' rotation and placed him neatly into theirs.
"If you look at our club traditionally," Hart said, "we've either developed players or made major trades. Our forays into the free-agent market haven't been big, except for Robby Alomar last year."
Acquiring Johnson would have been a major trade. That the Indians did not get him was a major disappointment. When he became a free agent after he pitched for the Astros in the postseason, the Indians did not make a competitive offer for him. Nor did they for Kevin Brown, although they liked the thought of having him. But then, no one made a competitive offer for Brown. The Los Angeles Dodgers gave him $40 million more than his next highest offer.
Moving back to the trade route last winter, the Indians tried again to get Clemens but lost out again, this time to the Yankees. Then last July they made another deadline stab at bolstering their corps of starters, trying for Finley and Scott Erickson of Baltimore. Neither was traded.
Last month Andy Ashby was traded, by the San Diego Padres to the Philadelphia Phillies. The Indians tried for him, too, but they did not want to relinquish the prospects the Padres wanted.
It was their desire to hold on to their prospects that prompted them to pay more to sign Finley for what will turn out to be $25 million for three years, bringing an end to their four years of failure.
"We were fortunate to land him," Hart said. "I thought we were out of it at the winter meetings. We were reluctant to go beyond where we were. But as we examined our club, we kept coming back to the feeling that Chuck was the guy."
It also became apparent to Hart at the meetings last week that he was not going to be able to trade for a pitcher. The Indians have been one of the best teams in the American League for the past six seasons. But their experience in the opening round of October's playoffs was embarrassing.
Finding themselves short of starters, the Indians used two on three days' rest instead of on the usual four. Bartolo Colon and Charles Nagy lasted a total of four innings as the Indians squandered a two-games-to-one lead against the Red Sox.
Finley gives the Cleveland rotation a stronger look, though how much stronger they will have to see.
"We're not advertising him as Randy Johnson or Pedro Martinez," Hart said. But at least the Indians have Finley, the proverbial bird in hand who is worth the two who never made it to the Indians.
 
A Man for the No. 7 Train
Does Todd Zeile like New York?
"I have always wanted the opportunity to play in New York City," the Mets' new first baseman said. "I've always loved the opportunity to play there when it's been against the Mets or the Yankees. I've been there three different times in playoff atmosphere against the Yankees. In the world of sports there's no place that compares to New York City for an athlete."
But does he really like New York?
"I have teammates who are afraid to go out of the hotel when they get to the city," he said. "I've always loved the city. I think there's so much to do. I have children I'd love to expose to the culture. I have great interest in the city as a whole outside of the game of baseball."
Did he, like some of those teammates, ever just stay in the hotel?
"Absolutely not," he said. "My representatives have been there a number of years now, so I've been able to see the city and the personality of the city for much more than what I initially saw there. Julianne, my wife, who was involved in gymnastics" -- she was Julianne McNamara, 1984 Olympic gold medalist -- "traveled extensively since she was young. She helped introduce me to different things about the city. I figured if she had no fear of the city and there was so much out there to see and experience, I should do it. I grew to love it. Every time there was an opportunity to go to New York City, I couldn't wait, and I often had my family join me there."
Doesn't he even mind the dreaded news media the city features?
"I know that media scrutiny is a great part of what people are afraid of in that city," he said, "but I think if you're honest, if you tell it like it is, if you don't run from your responsibilities, what's the problem? The key to this is stand up and be honest with the people who try to interpret what you do and why. I welcome the challenge. If you can have success there, it's a different feeling than anywhere else, at least in athletics."
 
The Ethics Dodgers
Once upon a time the Los Angeles Dodgers portrayed themselves as the epitome of a well-run, highly efficient, purest-of-pure organization. It was only a fairy tale, it seems.
The Dodgers are not the only organization that has signed Latin players illegally; some others have even been caught. But the Dodgers were nabbed having scouted players in Cuba and spiriting them out of the off-limits island, then lying about where they discovered them, and now they have been caught with a gun that spews so much smoke the city had to declare a smog alert.
Not only did the Dodgers sign Adrian Beltre, their young third baseman from the Dominican Republic, a year before he became legal age at 16, but they kept obviously altered documents in their files for the commissioner's office to find as proof of their illegal behavior.
Commissioner Bud Selig is expected to rule on the matter tomorrow, and he may allow the Dodgers to keep Beltre while issuing a heavy fine and other disciplinary action. And he may extend the foreign-signing ban imposed on the club in the Cuban matter, which was supposed to end next Friday.
But if he allows the Dodgers to keep Beltre, thus avoiding an expensive free-agent pursuit among several clubs, he will almost certainly trigger a grievance from the players association.
"Our current inclination is to file if they don't grant him free agency," said Gene Orza, the union's associate general counsel, "but I want to read the opinion. It may have something in it. But it's going to have to be a very persuasive opinion for us not to file."

HEADLINE: St. Barnabas Won't Renew City Contract

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER

 BODY:
St. Barnabas Hospital, which won a coveted contract almost three years ago to manage Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx, one of the city's public hospitals, has decided not to renew the contract when it expires in June, executives from both sides said yesterday.
St. Barnabas won the contract in 1997 by promising the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation that it would cut costs and improve the medical staff at Lincoln, which has one of the country's busiest emergency rooms and serves a mostly-poor patient base in the south Bronx. The relationship quickly became tense as St. Barnabas dismissed many senior doctors. 
 In the last year, the corporation has pressured St. Barnabas to improve the care at Lincoln Hospital, particularly in its emergency room, which the federal government had cited for deficiencies. And last month, the chief of Lincoln's obstetrics-gynecology department, who was hired by St. Barnabas, resigned.
The Health and Hospitals Corporation contracts with medical centers around the city to provide doctors for many of its hospitals. Since 1995, the corporation has tied its fees for these services to performance. The Lincoln contract paid about $94 million for three years, but could have gone as high as $102 million. St. Barnabas also has a $500 million contract with the city to provide medical services to prisoners at Rikers Island.
St. Barnabas's president, Dr. Ronald Gade, has gained a reputation for aggressively pursuing efficiency by using fewer doctors and other staff members and pressing for shorter hospital stays. Union officials, competitors and many doctors have argued that this has eroded the quality of care, especially in the case of the prisoners. When the contract with Lincoln expired this summer, St. Barnabas was to have been offered a one-year extension, said the corporation's president, Dr. Luis Marcos, but on Dec. 14 he received a letter from St. Barnabas's lawyers saying that they would decline to renew it, in the interest of both parties.
"We were brought in to organize the medical staff at Lincoln," Gerald McKelvey, a spokesman for Dr. Gade, said yesterday. "We feel our mission is accomplished."
Dr. Marcos said yesterday: "I agree with St. Barnabas that this is in the interest of both parties. This gives H.H.C. the chance to move ahead to a higher level by working more directly with physicians. I don't expect any difficulty in the transition."

HEADLINE: Political Briefing;
Iowa's Invisible Man Casts a Long Shadow

BYLINE: By B. Drummond Ayres Jr.

DATELINE: DES MOINES, Dec. 18

 BODY:
For months, Senator John McCain has been insisting that he will not participate in Iowa's first-in-the-nation Republican caucuses next month. He says he has only limited resources for his presidential quest and that in the early going he will concentrate on New Hampshire, South Carolina and Arizona.
He has no organization in Iowa, has run no ads and has been in the state only twice this year, once in April to hold a Congressional hearing on air fares (hardly a campaign appearance) and again last Monday to participate in a debate with the other Republican contenders (it was televised nationally, not just in Iowa). 
 So, as he says, he is not running in Iowa.
And yet he is here.
Despite his physical absence from the state, he was running a strong third in one recent Iowa poll, closing fast on Steve Forbes, who is spending a fortune, literally, to hang on to the No. 2 spot as he chases the front-runner, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.
Further, reports of Mr. McCain's campaigning in other states show up daily in Iowa newspapers and on Iowa television, and McCain bumper stickers and placards can be spotted here and there. Periodically, too, there have been reports that calls have been made around the state on his behalf, though there is no evidence that he sanctioned them.
And then there was that closing remark in Monday's debate after Mr. McCain had pinned a boondoggle lable on the federal energy program that subsidizes production of ethanol, a fuel additive made from corn, a lot of it Iowa corn.
In what was almost an aside, but not quite, he called for a "hardy band of brave souls" to turn out and vote for him on caucus night, Jan. 24.
What's going on here?
A delicate political dance, as many Iowa political pros see it.
The way they analyze the senator's acts and words, he is trying to set up a win-win situation in which he keeps his profile as high as possible in Iowa, but at the same time does not become so involved in the state that he raises undue expectations about how he will fare on caucus night.
Or, as Dennis Goldford, a political scientist at Drake University, put it the other day, if Mr. McCain should finish in the top three in the caucuses without genuinely competing, he would be entitled to "some bragging rights" on the eve of the next crucial nominating test, the New Hampshire primary.
But why the head-on McCain attack on ethanol in the nation's leading corn-producing state?
"Two plausible reasons," says David Yepsen of The Des Moines Register, the dean of the state's political reporters. "One, agriculture accounts for just 20 percent of the new, much-diversified Iowa economy. Two, the Iowa vote is now more diverse too, and a maverick reformer like McCain could have a certain appeal here, as elsewhere around the country."
One thing more:
He'll be back shortly for another debate.

HEADLINE: December 12-18;
Israel and Syria Agree On January Peace Talks

 BODY:
After co-existing uneasily for 50 years in a state of war and the last 4 years in cold silence, Israel and Syria have agreed to agree. President Clinton announced that the two countries would begin intensive and accelerated peace talks Jan. 3 at a site near Washington, to be determined.
"Over the past 48 hours, Israel and Syria have taken critical steps in the journey toward peace," Mr. Clinton said at the White House, flanked by Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel and Foreign Minister Farouk al-Shara of Syria. "The journey will be a difficult one. But with courage and perseverance on both sides, the result will be deeply rewarding to the people of Israel and to the people of Syria." 
 No deadline was set for reaching agreement on issues that include borders, security, terrorism, water rights and economic relations.
 
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: C. Vann Woodward, Historian Who Wrote Extensively About the South, Dies at 91

BYLINE: By RICHARD SEVERO

 BODY:
C. Vann Woodward, whose gifts of scholarship, storytelling and social conscience combined to produce some of the most readable and respected histories of the South, died on Friday at his home in Hamden, Conn. He was 91 years old.
Mr. Woodward regarded himself as an old-fashioned storyteller who was as interested in the literature and culture of the South as he was in its turbulent economics and politics of the 19th and early 20th centuries. 
 He took to heart the lessons of literature. He conceded that his interest in Southern writers would lead to accusations that he was nothing more than "a chronicler with a weakness for history-with-a-purpose and . . . the still graver charge of being a historian, dedicated to fact, who is inspired by fiction."
He had little use for historians who produced tomes that lacked the grace he found in literature. "History as currently written is bland, banal or philistine" and "often morally obtuse, ethically archaic and intellectually insipid," he told the American Historical Association in 1970, as he completed a term as its president.
He argued that history should not be confused with the natural sciences and was not comfortable with it being regarded as a social science. He thought of it as an art form rooted in scholarship. He saw history as a field where "the main excitement of the adventure comes in the writing."
"The historian-detective," he said, "does not really know how it will all turn out until he reads what he has written."
Mr. Woodward said he found much truth in Willie Stark, the central figure in Robert Penn Warren's novel "All The King's Men," and he found it too in such characters from William Faulkner's fiction as Lucas Beauchamp, Sam Fathers, Joe Christmas, Dilsey, Charles Bon, Jim Bond and the Snopeses.
Mr. Woodward's most famous work, "The Strange Career of Jim Crow" (1955), became a best seller and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. called it the "historical bible of the civil rights movement." Some critics regarded it as the single most influential book ever written on relations between the races in the United States. The book documented that segregation, as expressed by Jim Crow laws, did not appear until well after the end of the slavery, at the beginning of the 20th century.
Mr. Woodward also wrote a biography called "Tom Watson: Agrarian Rebel," which concerned itself with a man not so far removed from Willie Stark. Tom Watson, who lived from 1856 to 1922, was a Congressman from Georgia in the late 19th century and the quintessential Negrophobe, representing what Mr. Woodward called "the most ignorant, bigoted and reactionary forces in American life."
The book was first published in 1938, then republished in 1955. Critics credited it with dispelling some myths about the Southern populists who thrived after Reconstruction and demonstrating that the standard image of the South, as portrayed in most books -- somewhere between "Gone With the Wind" and the Uncle Remus stories -- was not to be taken seriously.
Another noteworthy book was "Origins of the New South" (1951), in which Mr. Woodward detailed the negotiations that took place been Southern Democrats and Northern Republicans after the presidential election of 1876, in which an electoral crisis occurred and Rutherford B. Hayes was eventually declared the winner. Southerners agreed to his being seated as the nation's 19th president only after he agreed to withdraw federal troops from the South, where they had been since the end of the Civil War.
Although sharply critical of segregation and of the Southerners who believed in it, Mr. Woodward nevertheless loved the South and gloated in the 1960's when racial problems erupted in the North, resulting in riots and the burning of neighborhoods in certain cities. "It was time those bastards up North had their time," he said.
"Probably no scholar contributed more toward the civil rights movement than he did," said the Pulitzer Prize-winning historian William S. McFeely, who was a student of Mr. Woodward's at Yale University in the 1960's. "Though he lived more of his life out of the South than in it, he remained Southern, and he remained loyal to the South. He always defended it; he just wanted to rid it of its worst problem, its racism."
Sheldon Hackney, a former president of Tulane University and the University of Pennsylvania and another former student of Mr. Woodward's, called him "the most admired historian of my lifetime."
"Even more than for his mammoth contributions to understanding American race relations and the history of the South, or for his graceful prose and subtle thought, Vann Woodward will be remembered for being the model of intellectual integrity," Mr. Hackney said.
Comer Vann Woodward was born Nov. 13, 1908, in Vanndale, Ark., the descendant of a clan that in the years before the Civil War had been a major slave-owning family. His mother was the former Bessie Vann, whose family had come to Arkansas generations before from the Carolinas via Tennessee. They created the village of Vanndale (population 300), which contained a motley collection of Confederate veterans, former slaves, tenants, sharecroppers, a generous supply of creditors who preyed on farmers who were down on their luck, and quite a number of Negrophobes. "The Faulknerian repertoire was all represented," Mr. Woodward would later recall.
His father, Hugh Alison Woodward, was a public school administrator in Arkansas who later ran a small college in Georgia. The family, according to Mr. Woodward, was of "modest status."
Mr. Woodward spent the first 10 years of his life in Vanndale, then moved with his family to Morrilton, about 50 miles north of Little Rock. Among his most vivid memories there were of a Ku Klux Klan gathering at the Methodist church, after which the Klansmen, in full regalia, left a donation with an obliging minister. But no less vivid was his memory of Charles Hillman Brough, a former governor of Arkansas who denounced lynchings, and of his uncle Comer McDonald Woodward, who also spoke out against racism.
Mr. Woodward went to public school in Morrilton, where he was something of an outsider. To win acceptance, he went out for the football team. He did not like the game very much but played it well.
In 1924, after his graduation from high school, he enrolled in Henderson-Brown College in Arkadelphia, Ark., a small institution run by Methodists. It was there that he suffered one of his rare intellectual defeats. He thought that he should concentrate in the laboratory sciences but he failed chemistry. He did rather well, however, in expository writing.
Within two years he tired of Arkadelphia and transferred to Emory University in Atlanta, in part because his uncle Comer Woodward had become dean of students. Emory bored him almost as much as had Henderson-Brown. He took a history course and found it so bad that he decided he would take no more history courses as an undergraduate.
He liked Atlanta, however, because it provided him with an opportunity to meet black intellectuals, among them John Hope Franklin, an educator, and J. Saunders Redding, an actor, dramatist and essayist.
By the time he received his Bachelor of Philosophy degree in 1930, Mr. Woodward had become a social activist determined to reform the South. He wanted it to be understood, but mostly he wanted it to change. He began teaching freshman English at Georgia Tech and reviewing books for The Atlanta Journal.
He had seen New York City once as an undergraduate. But now he decided to go there and study. In 1931 he enrolled at Columbia University and signed up as a candidate for a master's in sociology. After what he described as "two full and shattering days," he transferred to political science "in desperation." He still had no degree in history.
While in New York he met Langston Hughes, whose poetry he admired, and got to know the principals of the Harlem Renaissance. At one point, he thought he might write his thesis on W. E. B. Du Bois. But according to Mr. Woodward, Mr. Du Bois heard his Southern accent and backed off.
In the early 1930's he vacationed in Europe and visited Paris, Moscow and Berlin. A Communist took him to a section of Berlin where he could see the plight of workers, Mr. Woodward recalled, and he gaped and said, "My God, man, they've got electric lights and running water." They were much better off, he thought, than the sharecroppers he knew in Arkansas and Georgia.
Back in Atlanta and teaching at Georgia Tech in 1932, he involved himself in the case of Angelo Herndon, a young black Communist who was accused of inciting an insurrection. Mr. Woodward raised money for Mr. Herndon, but soon found himself without a teaching job. He long maintained that he lost his job because of a budget cut, but others saw his dismissal as punishment for his sympathy for Mr. Herndon.
Mr. Woodward earned his Ph.D. in history from the University of North Carolina in 1937. Before World War II, he taught briefly at the University of Florida and the University of Virginia. During the war, he served as a lieutenant in the Navy. His war experience led to the publication of "The Battle of Leyte Gulf" in 1947.
From 1947 to 1961 Mr. Woodward taught at Johns Hopkins University, and in 1961 he became Sterling Professor of History at Yale, a position he kept until his retirement in 1977. Over the years, he also lectured at the University of London and at Oxford University.
Among his other books was "The Burden of Southern History" (1960). He also edited many books, including "Mary Chesnut's Civil War," which won a Pulitzer Prize in 1982. There were also numerous articles for the American Historical Review, Johns Hopkins magazine, the American Scholar, The New York Times Magazine and other publications.
Mr. Woodward's wife, the former Glenn Boyd MacLeod, and their son, Peter, predeceased him. No immediate family members survive.

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES;
What the New Paradigm Can't Begin to Explain

BYLINE: By MARK HULBERT; Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a newsletter based in Annandale, Va. His column on investment strategies appears every other week.
E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
LITTLE can be said to change the minds of investors who believe in the so-called new paradigm, the idea that today's stocks, for a variety of reasons, should not be judged by historical valuation standards. The believers generally ignore the skeptics, who gamely point out that ignorance of such valuations in the past has almost always been cause for regret.
But the believers' reaction is hardly surprising. Indeed, a historical argument is hardly relevant to people who think that history itself is no longer relevant. "This time is different," they often say. 
 Anyone aiming to convert the paradigmistas, then, must do so without referring to the historical norms of market valuation. Nor should the argument be based on the recent performance of stocks. After all, it is impossible to know whether the recent gains in the overall market are a result of the new paradigm or of extreme market overvaluation.
But some assumptions underlying the new paradigm can be tested -- at least in how they should affect the relative operating performance of small-capitalization value stocks and large-cap growth stocks.
The 1990's notwithstanding, small-cap stocks have historically outperformed the large caps, and value stocks have outperformed growth. But adherents of the new paradigm contend that the market's leadership has changed permanently. Because of technological advances and the economies of scale of a global marketplace, the reasoning goes, small-cap value stocks should no longer be expected to lead the market; only the very largest companies with the biggest investments in technology will survive and thrive in the new millennium -- the very growth companies that, indeed, have led the market higher over the past few years.
But if the theory is correct, one would expect that large-cap growth companies would have enjoyed extraordinary gains in operating performance in recent years, both in absolute terms and relative to small-cap value stocks.
Those ideas were tested recently by three finance professors -- Louis K. C. Chan and Josef Lakonishok of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, and Jason Karceski of the University of Florida. They focused particularly on the period since the end of 1995, when stocks became grossly overvalued by almost all historical valuation measures. They found that the new paradigm was an almost complete failure in describing the recent operating performances of public American companies.
Sales growth is but one example. From the end of 1995 through 1998, sales of large-cap growth companies grew just 6 percent a year, on average. That is not only lower than their historical rate of 10.3 percent a year -- from 1970 through 1998 -- but also lower than the 12.7 percent rate for small-cap value companies over the same three years.
A SIMILAR story emerges for operating income before depreciation. For large-cap growth companies, this line item grew 9.6 percent, annualized, over that period, lower than their historical rate of 10.6 percent and far below the 16.6 percent annual rate for small-cap value companies over the same three years.
The data on net income is only slightly more encouraging for new-paradigm believers. Before extraordinary items, profits at large growth companies grew 11 percent, annualized, over the test period -- higher than the historical growth rate of 9.6 percent. Yet the growth was much slower than the 22 percent annual rate for small-cap value companies.
So if you are looking for evidence of a new paradigm at work, the professors' study furnishes none. The conclusion is inescapable: This time is not different.
While advocates of the new paradigm come in varying degrees of orthodoxy, this should give all of them reason to pause. Rather than representing a brand-new world, the recent outsized gains of large-cap growth stocks simply reflect overvaluation -- which the market will correct in due course.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Slower Growth at Dell Leaves Sour Taste

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
IS Dell Computer a value stock for the new economy? Perhaps.
Not so long ago, many people on Wall Street called Dell a niche player, one whose growth would sputter once it saturated the base of customers who want to buy a personal computer through a toll-free phone number. Now, with the Dell sales running at $27 billion a year, investors are not calling it that anymore. But there is still much doubt about the sustainability of Dell's growth, which is one reason that its stock has languished all year. 
 Dell shares, a mainstay of the 1990's bull market, took a pounding in February, when some analysts predicted that the company's revenue growth would slow. And it turned out the rate had declined, to 38 percent for the quarter ending Jan. 31, from 56 percent, on average, over the previous two years. It has since recovered a bit, to 41 percent in the most recent quarter, ended Oct. 29.
The message to investors, however, was clear: No one should expect a company of Dell's size to keep growing at 50 percent indefinitely. And shareholders have not forgiven the slip. Dell shares, now at $45.5625, are 17 percent below their 52-week high.
Even with that decline, it is difficult to find anybody who questions Dell's strategy or faults its execution. Many people believe that the company could be the world's largest maker of PC's within the next year or two, as it continues to take market share away from Compaq Computer and I.B.M. It has been the No. 1 supplier of PC's in the United States for the last two quarters. And with the introduction this month of the WebPC, a PC geared to the retail consumer, Dell is finally attacking the home market.
Dell's direct-sales model is well-known: The company builds each PC to order and sells it directly to consumers, by telephone, the Web or, for big corporate customers, through a field sales force. There is little money tied up in inventory and no dealer markups, allowing it to undercut rivals on price. By keeping the barest of component inventories itself, Dell minimizes working capital and maximizes return on that capital. It has a negative cash conversion cycle, meaning that it is paid for finished goods before it pays suppliers for parts.
I.B.M., Compaq and Hewlett-Packard have taken steps to mimic Dell's business model and have made some headway at trimming inventories and costs. But they cannot duplicate Dell's model without cutting off their dealers, which they fear to do.
All of this leads some investors to say that Dell stock simply doesn't deserve the punishment it has suffered. "We're starting to believe that the assumptions people have made about revenue growth slowing down could be wrong," said Randy Befumo, an analyst with the Legg Mason Value Trust, a $14 billion mutual fund and a longtime Dell shareholder. "It's not that they increase revenue growth, because the law of large numbers does eventually apply, but most likely they can sustain the current growth rate much longer than people expect." About 4.6 percent of the fund is invested in Dell shares.
Mr. Befumo said that he believed the growth of the Internet would spur sales of servers and other PC-related products, and that Dell would have many chances to gain market share in these categories and overseas. "The market will consolidate around the most efficient player, and that's Dell," he said. "There's no reason Dell can't have 50 percent market share."
Dell has a 15 percent share in the United States and 7 percent overseas, he said.
CHARLES WOLF, an analyst with Warburg Dillon Read, said Dell shares had underperformed for reasons divorced from fundamentals. "Momentum investors pulled out of the name," he said, referring to Dell stock. "They were very big in the name prior to the February announcement, but once that momentum is broken for any reason, they jump ship. The reality is, except for a little blip in the October quarter due to memory pricing, which I ignore, they have delivered every quarter."
Mr. Wolf said that Dell's competitive advantage over I.B.M. and Compaq appeared to be widening, and that the company was exploiting the Internet more effectively than other PC makers, not only to sell its products but also to maintain relationships with customers. He noted that Dell's price-to-earnings multiple for next year was under 45, just slightly above its earnings growth rate of about 40 percent, while many technology stocks trade for two or three times growth. If Dell's stock-price appreciation matched his expected earnings growth rate of 40 percent in 2000, shares would hit $63.7875 in the next 12 months. "Last week, I lifted it to my No. 1 pick for 2000," he added.
It is still possible, however, to admire Dell's model but not the stock. Andrew Neff of Bear Stearns rates Dell "attractive," a level below a "buy" rating. "Dell uses the Internet, but they don't run the Internet the way Sun does," Mr. Neff said, referring to Sun Microsystems. "Sun sells to the core of the Internet. There's a higher focus on companies that own technology, whereas Dell's competitive advantage has a lot to do with supply chain leverage."
Daniel Kunstler at J. P. Morgan is also waiting for a reason to lift his rating on Dell from "market perform." He said Dell had lifted expectations by describing the slowdown for the January quarter as a one-time event, though it has since become apparent that it was not. "The opportunity for them to really exceed numbers on revenues or earnings is not what it used to be," he said. "It's not that the business model has become deficient. It has not. But there's little perceived potential for upside surprises."

HEADLINE: A Standoff at the Corner Store

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT

DATELINE: SUNBURY, Pa.

 BODY:
IN the 1920's, with their corner stores thriving, Harry and Sigmund Weis decided to build neighboring houses on choice land in this small Susquehanna Valley city. The brick homes, one colonial and one Tudor, bordered the riverbank and looked out to the gently sloping Appalachian Mountains. The two brothers shared a garage; their young children -- a son and a daughter for each -- ran back and forth across the driveway when they played in their front yards.
Over the decades, the Weises transformed their small markets into a modern supermarket chain. By owning their own trucks and warehouses, keeping out labor unions and staunchly refusing to take on debt, the brothers, and later their sons, created the most profitable grocery company in the country, with margins four or five times those of their competitors. 
 Quietly, the Weises became one of the wealthiest families in the United States, slowly expanding their central Pennsylvania chain as far as upstate New York and the Virginia suburbs of Washington -- and popping into the public eye only when they appeared on Forbes magazine's annual list of the richest Americans.
Just as Harry's and Sigmund's father had bequeathed his corner store to them, they handed the business down to their sons, Robert and Sigfried Weis (pronounced "wise"). Although Weis Markets Inc. went public in 1965, the family kept control, retaining about four-fifths of the shares. There was little intrigue and a lot of profit.
But in the last few years, profits have been stagnant, and in the last month, intrigue has inevitably developed. Like the Binghams, the Hunts, the Kochs and so many business families before them, the Weises are now locked in an intense fight for control of the company that has given them their fortunes. The two sides of the family that were once divided by only a driveway are now split over one of the central questions in today's economy: Can a small company, even one with a long history of success, prosper in an era of consolidation?
That the debate is taking place at Weis, which has achieved almost legendary status in its industry, illustrates just how difficult it is for family businesses to survive from one generation to the next.
Sigmund's descendants, with one eye on the fast-expanding Wal-Mart Stores and the other on grocery behemoths like Royal Ahold N.V. that have arisen from the consolidation spree of the 1990's, want to look into selling the company. Led by Janet L. Weis, the 80-year-old widow of Sigmund's son, Sigfried, they are mounting a proxy fight for two additional board seats, which would give them four of the seven.
Mrs. Weis, her three daughters and their husbands, who own a 41 percent stake, see declining margins and a company stock that, before the feud burst into the open, was worth less than it was in 1987. They worry that the company risks a long, slow decline if it stays independent. "The handwriting is really on the wall," Mrs. Weis said. On Friday, shares of the 200-store chain closed at $41.25, up 18 percent in the last three weeks amid investors' hopes for a sale.
But Harry's family, which now runs the business after decades behind the scenes, has no intention of surrendering to its cousins or to its larger rivals. Led by Robert Weis, Harry's 80-year-old son, they say the current competition is similar to earlier threats, when better capitalized supermarkets entered but failed to crack their mid-Atlantic markets. Weis Markets still has above-average margins.
"They are reading the facts wrong," said Robert Weis, a soft-spoken man who still has a full head of gray hair. Mr. Weis, who with his three children and his sister, also owns a 41 percent stake in the company worth $700 million. He hadserved as deputy to Sigfried, Janet Weis's husband, for more than 30 years and took over the chairman's slot in 1995. Sigfried's family no longer has anyone in management, and Robert's family has offered to buy out its cousins' share.
THE battle has many trappings of a takeover struggle. Sigmund's and Sigfried's family has hired Salomon Smith Barney and Wachtel, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, a New York law firm, to advise them on how to lobby shareholders, oust the current board and put the company up for sale. Harry's and Robert's family has retained Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, another Manhattan-based law firm.
The dispute, meanwhile, has split the Susquehanna Valley, where hospital wings, arts centers and major buildings at two universities, Bucknell and Susquehanna, bear the Weis name. And it has chilled friendships among the principal players, who used to play golf together and still routinely eat lunch at the same restaurant, though not the same table.
But this is also a family feud with a twist. So far, it is nearly bereft of nastiness. Neither side doubts the other's motive, only their conclusion. Over the last month, Janet Weis and her allies have publicly praised the way Robert Weis and his deputies have managed the company, even as she seeks to oust him. "Everyone respects the job they're doing," said Joseph I. Goldstein, Mrs. Weis's son-in-law and a member of the board.
Rather than trade allegations, the two sides share a sense of melancholy that they are locked in a public squabble likely to end up humiliating one branch of the family.
"When I first thought about this, it was sad," said Michael Morris Apfelbaum, a lifelong family friend and, as a lawyer overseeing some of the stock, the second dissident board member. "But when you cut out the emotion from it, you have to realize this is the way of capitalism. You have to be big to survive in the economy today. That's just the way of the world."
At least it's what the debate is about.
THE Weises have been merchants in these parts since shortly after the Civil War, when Sigfried Weis immigrated from Austria and made his way to central Pennsylvania. To earn a living, he walked from farmhouse to farmhouse in the lush fields of the Susquehanna Valley -- less than 100 miles from where the Battle of Gettysburg had raged just a few years before -- selling jewelry and other goods. Soon, he opened a general store in Selinsgrove, a town across the river from here, and he married a local woman; they would have two sons. When the boys grew up, Sigfried Weis hung up a sign: "S. Weis & Sons."
After his death in 1907, the sons -- Sigmund and Harry -- opened a new store in Sunbury, the county seat, focused on groceries. It was the start of a furious expansion that lasted nearly 30 years and did not end until the Depression, when they had more than 100 outlets.
Already, a division of labor was emerging that would last for almost a century. Sigmund, the more outgoing brother, was the marketer who decided which national brands the stores should sell. Harry, a lawyer, scouted real estate, picking where the next Weis Pure Foods would go, family members say.
The success of the shops enabled the brothers to build their neighboring houses on Front Street, just a few blocks from Sunbury's main square and their first store.
The Depression, however, prompted shoppers to look for more bargains and helped usher in the era of self-service supermarkets. In 1937, Sigmund and Harry Weis started closing many of their stores to create a smaller chain of larger stores.
Weis Markets, which owned more of its stores and more of its equipment than competitors did, thrived. It sold an unusually large number of private-label products. And it fought bitterly to keep unions from organizing its workers, many of whom were part-timers without benefits.
In fact, in a 1965 registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission to take the company public, virtually the only problem that the family noted was a yearlong strike by meat-department employees starting in the summer of 1963. Five years later, the company and a food workers' union fought all the way to the Supreme Court in a landmark case over whether a shopping mall was a public place where the union, covered by First Amendment speech protection, could try to organize. (The union won in court, but Weis has defeated every effort to organize the company's employees, including one by the Teamsters this year.)
In the mid-1960's, the company achieved operating margins of more than 8 percent. Weis was the envy of the grocery industry, where margins of 2 or 3 percent were much more common. When Weis Markets Inc. went public in 1965, the shares made their debut at $21. Each side of the family was suddenly worth more than $20 million.
By then, both Sigmund and Harry Weis had died, and their sons were running the business. Sigfried -- Sigmund's son, named for the family patriarch -- was four years older than Robert, and they had followed similar paths. As children, both worked behind the counter at some of the original Weis Pure Foods stores. Both served in the Army. Both attended Yale.
It was during college that Sigfried Weis met his future wife, Janet. He was a freshman and she was a 15-year-old who lived in the nearby town of Hamden, Conn. He did not win her over immediately. "It was one of those back-and-forth things," she said this month at her home, grinning between puffs on a thin cigarette. Eventually, after they were married at the Carlyle Hotel in New York, she followed him back to Pennsylvania.
Sigfried became president of the company in 1961 without much debate, family members say. He was older than Robert, who became his deputy. Robert ran the company's finances and, like his father, chose sites for new stores, and the two cousins remained in those jobs for more than 30 years.
They had lunch together most days and lived in the same neighborhood, separated only by an alley.
BUT by all accounts, Sigfried and Robert Weis were not as close as their daily proximity suggested. They were business partners, not best friends.
"We were different, but we were friendly," Robert said.
"We just moved in different circles," Janet Weis said.
Like his father, Sigfried was the more social of the two. He and Janet belonged to the country-club crowd and gave their money to large institutions, like a regional hospital. Robert and his wife, Patricia, gave to the small hospital in Sunbury.
Differences in the ages of the two couples' children pushed them further apart. The three daughters of Sigfried and Janet were all at least 10 years older than the two daughters and son of Robert and Patricia. The next generation -- second cousins who shared a last name and a fortune and grew up only yards away from each other -- still do not know each other well. There was never a blow-up, both sides say. The two families simply drifted apart.
That estrangement, particularly in the context of the strong stock market, is dangerous, said John Messervey, president of the National Family Business Council, an Illinois consulting firm that, among other things, runs retreats where wealthy families can get to know one another better. Many families, Mr. Messervey said, "are scared they're never going to see a market this good again." For the Weises in the 1970's and 80's, there seemed to be little reason for worry. Operating margins never fell below 7 percent and, as late as 1987, were above 9 percent. Weis Markets, a 1982 headline in Forbes magazine said, "makes one-third of what Safeway does -- on only 5 percent of Safeway's sales." The same year, the grandsons of the Austrian peddler appeared on the magazine's list of the 400 wealthiest Americans.
In 1998, the year after the Weises fell off the Forbes list, a squat, enormous distributor center began rising just off of Interstate 99 in western Pennsylvania. When completed, it covered more than 800,000 square feet, and it bore the corporate name that strikes fear into virtually every other retailer in the country: Wal-Mart.
There could be no doubt about the building's purpose. Like a massing of troops at an enemy's border, its size was an announcement that an unstoppable invasion was about to begin. Wal-Mart was bringing supercenters, stores that sell everything from milk and bananas to slacks and tires and are three times the size of modern supermarkets, to Pennsylvania.
Supercenters, the first of which opened in 1988, had already transformed the $420 billion-a-year grocery business. To respond to Wal-Mart's efficient distribution network and its money-saving clout with suppliers, supermarket executives were rapidly consolidating one of the few remaining large regional businesses in the United States. Their aim was to cut costs and gain the kind of power over manufacturers that Wal-Mart has.
The five biggest chains now take in 40 cents of every dollar that Americans spend at the supermarket, up from 20 cents in 1993, according to the Food Institute, a trade group in Fair Lawn, N.J.
For Weis Markets, the changes were coming at a bad time. It had been facing tough competition from Giant Foods of Carlisle, Pa., which had expanded in the area during the late 80's and early 90's. By 1996, Giant had actually overtaken Weis in central Pennsylvania with an 18 percent market share, according to Food Trade News, a publication that tracks grocery sales in the mid-Atlantic states. At the same time, inflation was almost nonexistent, leaving grocers little room to raise prices.
Weis's legendary operating margins paid the price. From their high of 9.2 percent in 1987, they fell to 5.5 percent in 1993 and just 4.1 percent last year. Operating margins for the rest of the industry are now 3 percent. The company posted net income of $83.7 million last year on $1.87 billion in sales, about $3 million less than it earned in 1989 on $1.24 billion in sales.
THOSE numbers -- along with the specter of Wal-Mart and the new grocery giants -- are at the core of the argument of Sigfried Weis's family. The chain still has many strengths, like its $400 million in cash, its milk and ice cream plants and its brand's reputation. But the company should act quickly, the family says, to determine whether it should participate in the current consolidation wave.
"Companies rise and fall, and we want to make sure this company keeps rising," said Mr. Goldstein, a director who is a partner at Kirkpatrick & Lockhart in Washington.
For their part, Robert Weis and the president of the company, Norman Rich, say that is precisely what it has been doing for the past few years. In 1995, when Robert took over from an ailing Sigfried, the company began a capital investment push even more aggressive than the one undertaken by Sigmund and Harry Weis in the 1920's. In the last four years, the company has spent $374 million to build 35 large new markets and to remodel 51 others.
The expansion has helped increase revenue by 7.5 percent through the first three quarters of 1999. The company, meanwhile, has begun working with a cooperative of smaller chains, cutting deals with manufacturers similar to the discounts the bigger companies can negotiate, Mr. Rich said.
The proof of Weis's relative strength can be seen in its stock, they added. From Jan. 1 to Nov. 29, just before the proxy fight began, the company's stock fell only 8 percent versus 35 percent for the Standard & Poor's supermarket industry index.
The disparity, Harry Weis's descendants say, undercuts their cousins' main point: that a small chain can no longer hold its own. "Back in 1928, Safeway Stores came with the same story and tried to buy our company," Robert Weis said last week, speaking softly while sitting in the company's modest boardroom here. "Fortunately, we said no."
One afternoon after Thanksgiving, however, the phone rang in the office of Mr. Rich, Weis's president. A native of New York City whose gregariousness stands in contrast to the Weis family's reserve, Mr. Rich had joined Weis Markets in 1964 as a food scientist and climbed up the ranks, reaching his current position in 1994, He runs daily operations and reports to Robert Weis, the chairman. (The company has never used the title of chief executive.)
The phone call, Mr. Rich recalled, came from Mr. Apfelbaum, the director, who said, "Norm, can you come down to my office?" Mr. Apfelbaum said it was an emergency. His father, Sidney Apfelbaum, who oversees a trust that owns Weis stock, and Mr. Goldstein, Mrs. Weis's son-in-law, were also there.
Mr. Rich drove to the law offices of Apfelbaum, Apfelbaum & Apfelbaum, in a converted house off the town square. The three men waiting for him said they believed Weis Markets should seriously investigate selling itself and that they wanted to install directors who agreed.
The proxy fight, and family feud, had begun.
THE decision had come slowly for the dissidents, over a series of informal discussions among themselves and during the occasional cocktail hours that Mr. Apfelbaum and Mrs. Weis have together at her house, a four-bedroom Tudor on 14 acres across the Susquehanna River from Sunbury.
Eventually, Mr. Apfelbaum, whose father grew up playing pool with Robert Weis on the third floor of his Front Street house, and Mr. Goldstein, a former associate director of enforcement at the S.E.C., decided they had to act.
Sigfried's family has asked that the company hold a shareholder vote by Feb. 7, citing company bylaws, on whether to replace the board. Since each family controls 41 percent of the votes, the resolution would need the approval of more than half of the 18 percent of investors who are not family members.
Most outsiders consider the dissidents to be the favorites; in recent years, shareholders have tended to choose whatever path is most likely to bolster a stock price immediately. Salomon argues that the company could fetch $45 to $55 a share. Charles M. LaLoggia, a Rochester fund manager who publishes an investment newsletter, said he thinks the company would sell for at least $45 a share and maybe up to $90, given its strong balance sheet and recent valuations for other chains.
Investors would be unlikely to turn down a deal in that range. "As far as the dissidents work for all the shareholders, they're our guys," said Martin J. Whitman, who runs a $1.5 billion fund that has owned Weis stock since the early 1990's.
But a vote would probably be close. About three-fifths of the independent investors, representing 11 percent of the company's stock, are individuals, Mr. Rich said. They are more likely to focus on the company's long record of paying strong dividends, he added.
Mr. Rich and Robert Weis will also argue that the company would not fetch a fair price now, because many potential suitors are trading near 52-week lows. Albertson's and Kroger, for example, are busy integrating the chains they have already bought, and their recent earnings disappointments show they have a ways to go. "A lot of the retailers have got their hands full right now," said Mark Husson, a supermarket analyst at Merrill Lynch.
FOR the company, the stakes are obviously high. But they seem almost as high for the region and the two Weis families. The chain employs 19,000 people, and its higher-paying, middle-management jobs would be most vulnerable in a takeover. Those positions are concentrated in central Pennsylvania, a coal and agricultural region that has suffered economically over the last three decades.
"The average person thinks this just can't be good," David L. Persing, the mayor of Sunbury since 1989, said of the dispute. "It might be good for stockholders, but I don't think it will be good for this area."
None of the Weises, or their allies on either side, are likely to emerge from the fight worse off financially. But the dispute has already had personal costs. It has effectively ended the friendship of Mr. Apfelbaum's and Mr. Rich, who still see each other at Tedd's Landing, a local restaurant where both have lunch. Only last summer, Mr. Apfelbaum said, the two men smoked cigars together at 4 a.m. at the W Hotel on Lexington Avenue in Manhattan, just hours after Mr. Rich's son had been married.
Janet Weis, meanwhile, has chosen to spend part of her 81st year fighting a public battle over the company her late husband ran for 35 years, a company she helped build by tasting samples of new products and telling her husband which labels looked right. "It's been all of my life," Mrs. Weis said.
The dispute has been most difficult for Robert Weis, said people who know him, though he is reluctant to discuss his personal feelings. As he nears retirement and grooms his 32-year-old son, Jonathan, to succeed him, the family of his longtime boss is trying to depose him. "People's conditions in life change. Their needs change. Their desires change," the older Mr. Weis said, explaining what he sees as the reasons for the fight.
"I guess every time you have a partner, you have a problem," he added, "maybe not with the partner, but with the next generation."

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Long-Stay Hotels Cater To Families

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
WHILE most extended-stay hotels, whether in cities or suburbs, cater primarily to business travelers, many are more than happy to extend their hospitality to families hoping to escape the noisy hordes of contractors who have invaded their real home for a renovation or redecoration project.
"Basically, what we offer is a home away from home," said Jennifer Coleman, marketing services manager for Manhattan East Suite Hotels."We're a very family-oriented company. Kids and dogs are fine with us." 
 Manhattan East. which has 10 all-suite hotels scattered around Midtown, is one of a growing number of companies offering extended-stay lodgings that include all the amenities an individual or family needs to feel at home.
Most of the all-suite hotels in the chain, said Ms. Coleman, have various-sized suites to accommodate families of most sizes. The company's 300- to 400-square-foot studio suites, for example, contain an oversized sleeping room with a dining or sitting area and kitchen facilities. The two-bedroom suites, on the other hand, range in size from 700 to 950 square feet and contain a living room, separate bedrooms and a fully appointed kitchen. In between are "junior" and one-bedroom suites that range from 400 to 650 square feet, including kitchen facilities.
Ms. Coleman explained that while the nightly rates at Manhattan East hotels range from $164 for a guest room to $725 for the most expensive two-bedroom suite, most accommodations range from $200 to $300. Reduced rates are available for stays of more than 30 days.
"The extended-stay rates are negotiated rates that depend on the total length of stay," she said, adding that her company's most "family-friendly" building was the Surrey Hotel on 76th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues.
One of the main draws of extended-stay facilities, particularly for families, is their ability to provide -- quite literally -- soup to nuts services for their guests.
"Yes, we do offer grocery-shopping services," said Gordon Lambourne, a vice president of Marriott International, the Washington-based hotel chain that pioneered the extended-stay concept with its Residence Inn Hotels.
"The first thing people have to know about our extended-stay facilities is the concept of the descending rate," Mr. Lambourne said. "That means that the longer you stay, the less you pay." Generally speaking, he said, rates for the company's Residence Inn suites in the New York City area start at about $99 a night for the smaller units.
"Most of our suites have a sitting area, a separate bedroom, and a fully equipped kitchen with a stove, microwave, full-sized refrigerator and all the china, silverware and glassware you need," Mr. Lambourne said. "Some even have working fireplaces."
And unlike some extended-stay hotels, he said, Marriott does not have a minimum-stay requirement. "The average stay is probably five nights to two weeks," Mr. Lambourne said.
Another company that has extended-stay lodging is Extended StayAmerica, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. "For us, seven nights or more are considered an extended stay," said Monique Damiano, a spokeswoman for the company. "And at our hotels, there's no need to negotiate with the hotel manager over your room rate. Guests pay the same rate as their neighbor in similarly sized rooms or suites."
Ms. Damiano explained that each of the company's hotel brands offered different types of room arrangements and services. For example, she said, Extended StayAmerica's Crossland Economy Studios are generally 227 square feet in size and furnished with a double bed, kitchenette, refrigerator-freezer, two-burner stove, a microwave and all necessary utensils and tableware. Rates for such rooms range from $159 to $199 a week.
The company's Extended StayAmerica Efficiency Studios hotel brand, which are about 300 square feet and similarly furnished, range from $199 to $299 a week.
And the company's StudioPlus Deluxe Studios hotel brand, Ms. Damiano said, has suites of about 425 square feet, generally with separate living, sleeping and eating areas and a pull-out sleeper sofa. The rates for those units, she said, range $299 to $399 a week.
"To keep our rates affordable, our hotels don't have restaurants, bars, meeting spaces or little plastic shoe-shine kits in the rooms," Ms. Damiano said. "But they do have all the things you need for a comfortable stay."
She added that while guests might request daily housekeeping services, extended-stay guests can generally save money by using housekeeping services just once a week. In addition, she said, all of the company's hotels offer on-premises, coin-operated guest laundry rooms, free local phone calls and a room wired with a dedicated computer data port.
For those who prefer the ambiance of a real Manhattan apartment while their own apartment is being torn asunder, there is a company in Manhattan that rents out one- and two-bedroom apartments at rates that are, in some cases, less than what it would cost to rent a similarly sized unfurnished Manhattan apartment on the open market.
"We don't have all the services of a hotel, but when people see our rates, they're usually willing to make their own beds," said Elizabeth Calogero, a spokeswoman for A Hospitality Company, a Manhattan-based company that owns about 150 apartments that it rents out to extended-stay guests.
"Our flagship property is the Hospitality House," Ms. Calogero said, referring to the 36-unit building the company owns on 49th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues. Apartments in the building, which start at $99 a night for a small studio, have all the necessary furniture and furnishings, including a fully-equipped kitchen.
Apartments in other buildings scattered throughout Manhattan, she said, range from small studios to large, two-bedroom units, all similarly furnished. Rates in those buildings range from $99 to $325 a night or, for stays of 30 days or more, from $1,950 to $5,750 a month.
"We obviously prefer longer corporate stays," Ms. Calogero said. "But our two-bedroom apartments sleep six people comfortably, so we're family-friendly, too."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY & MEDIA: TALKING THE FUTURE WITH: Robert W. Taylor;
An Internet Pioneer Ponders the Next Revolution

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

 BODY:
The Internet has many fathers, but few deserve the label more than Robert W. Taylor.
In 1966, as a director of the Pentagon's Advanced Research Projects Agency Information Processing Techniques Office, Mr. Taylor came up with the idea for the Internet's precursor, the ARPAnet. After authorizing money for research to develop a nationwide computer network, Mr. Taylor wrote a white paper in 1968, a year before the network was created, with another ARPA research director, J. C. R. Licklider. The paper, "The Computer as a Communications Device," was one of the first clear statements about the potential of a computer network. 
 Even before coming to ARPA, Mr. Taylor saw the computer's potential as an interactive device. As a research manager at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, he arranged financing for Douglas C. Engelbart, a young researcher who used the money at what was then called the Stanford Research Institute, now SRI International, to invent the computer mouse.
At ARPA, Mr. Taylor's office continued financing Mr. Engelbart's Augment research group, which pioneered many of the most important ideas in today's computer industry. It was Mr. Taylor who financed Mr. Engelbart's legendary demonstration of advanced computer technologies -- including the mouse, windows, hypertext, networking and teleconferencing -- at the 1968 Joint Fall Computer Conference in San Francisco. The demonstration left many of the nation's best computer scientists, then living in a world of punch cards and paper tape, in awe.
Mr. Taylor's contributions did not end there. After leaving ARPA and spending a year at the University of Utah, he was hired to direct the newly formed computer systems laboratory at Xerox's brand-new Palo Alto Research Center. From that laboratory and several others at PARC came the personal computer, computer networking, desktop publishing, laser printers, the graphical user interface and modern word processing.
Mr. Taylor, who never profited personally from the commercial Internet boom, is now retired at 67 and lives in Woodside, Calif. In a recent interview, he reviewed these pivotal events in the computer industry and looked to what the future might hold.
Following are excerpts from that conversation:
Q. -- What led to your ideas about computer networking?
A. -- I discovered computers in the 1950's, and the whole business of punching holes in cards turned me off. I really wasn't interested in computers from the beginning as an arithmetic engine. What struck me about them really came home when I read J. C. R. Licklider's 1960 "Man-Computer Symbiosis" paper. I said, "Yeah! Now we're talking!"
Q. -- How did you come across that article?
A. -- It appeared in an I.E.E.E. Transactions journal that I subscribed to. I was working as a systems engineer at the Martin Company at the time. That's when the power of interactive computing dawned on me. I had other reasons to pay attention to Licklider. I did my thesis on psycho-acoustics and Licklider was world famous in that field, before he started to play around with computers.
Q. -- How did you meet Licklider?
A. -- NASA had approached me to become a program manager in 1961 to look after research areas including flight displays and manned flight-control systems. I told them they needed an area called simulation technology because we were going to have to make huge investments in simulation, and they liked that idea. In late 1962, Licklider moved to ARPA and started this computer research program. I was at NASA and he was at the Pentagon. I had been supporting Doug Engelbart's work.
Q. -- This led to the mouse?
A. -- Yes. You know, it's quite funny -- several years ago NASA began looking for spinoffs that their research had led to in the civilian economy and they never realized that the mouse was developed under a NASA contract. But Licklider, shortly after he took over at ARPA, organized an informal committee of people in the government who were supporting computer research. He invited me to come over and join the committee. I walked into his office and right away he started talking to me about my thesis. It blew me completely away. How would he know anything about my thesis? I was a no-name nobody graduate student. He wowed me from Day 1.
Q. -- What did you set out to do at ARPA?
A. -- I began to think that if I was going to do this for a while, I wanted to find some particular program to measure my performance by. I wanted to put a nail on the wall or whatever the proper metaphor is. I wanted to make a difference. We had in my office three terminals to three different programs that ARPA was supporting. One was to the Systems Development Corporation in Santa Monica. There was another terminal to the Genie Project at U.C. Berkeley. The third terminal was to the C.T.S.S. project that later became the Multics project at M.I.T. We hadn't had these terminals very long. But I had already seen a very interesting thing. As these three time-sharing projects came alive and they collected users around their respective campuses, the only users they had were local users because there was no network to speak of. All communications were local except to ARPA.
Q. -- What did you discover?
A. -- The thing that really struck me about this evolution was how these three systems caused communities to get built. People who didn't know one another previously would now find themselves using the same system. Because the systems allowed you to share files, you could find that so-and-so was interested in such-and-such and he had some data about it. You could contact him by e-mail and, lo and behold, you would have a whole new relationship.
Q. -- Were these first communities built around mailing lists?
A. -- Well, you had a directory, so you knew how to send them e-mail, but you might only know 2 or 3 people, and you would meet 20 or 30 through the computer. It wasn't a static medium. It was a dynamic medium. And that gave it a lot of power.
Q. -- It was all about community?
A. -- There was one other trigger that turned me to the ARPAnet. For each of these three terminals, I had three different sets of user commands. So if I was talking online with someone at S.D.C. and I wanted to talk to someone I knew at Berkeley or M.I.T. about this, I had to get up from the S.D.C. terminal, go over and log into the other terminal and get in touch with them. I said, oh, man, it's obvious what to do: If you have these three terminals, there ought to be one terminal that goes anywhere you want to go where you have interactive computing. That idea is the ARPAnet.
Q. -- When did you get the idea?
A. -- I decided to do that in late 1965. In February of 1966, I was officially the head of the Information Processing Techniques Office. So I went to see Charlie Herzfeld, who was the head of ARPA, and laid the idea on him. The first funding came that month. He liked the idea immediately, and he took a million dollars out of the ballistic missile defense budget and put it into my budget right then and there.
Q. -- Was the idea an immediate success?
A. -- I had to go around and talk to our contractors to see if I could get their cooperation -- and some of them were enthusiastic, and some of them saw it as an infringement on their computing facilities. They said, "I don't want to share my computing cycles with some guy across the country. I don't have enough cycles as it is. Now you're going to build something that allows people to come in and use my machine?" That took a while to bring people together.
Q. -- Did you see right away that this would have an impact broader than just a small group of military-funded researchers?
A. -- Oh, yeah, sure. It was obvious to some of us that interactive computing was here to stay. And by the late 60's, the personal computer was obvious as well. By the time I went to Xerox in 1970, I tried to get the guys to build the Alto one of the first experimental personal computers and they built it two years later, but that's a whole other story.
Q. -- Was there one shared vision?
A. -- The model that some people were pushing in those days for how this was going to spread was that there were going to be gigantic computer utilities. This was the power utility model. I never bought that. By the late 60's, Moore's Law was pretty obvious. It was just a matter of time before you could afford to put a computer on everyone's desk. That was what I came to Xerox to do.
Q. -- How did you arrive at Xerox?
A. -- I left ARPA in late 1969 after I knew that the ARPAnet was up and running, and I went to Utah for what turned out to be only a year. When I was in Utah, I got a call from George Pake, a physicist who was setting up Xerox's Palo Alto Research Center. I had the impression that he just wanted to pick my brain. There was no discussion of a job. He told me that Xerox was going to have a research lab here in Palo Alto and part of it was going to be devoted to computer research. The research group was going to develop technologies that would be used at S.D.S., a computer company that Xerox had recently purchased. I said, "Oh, that's too bad." He said, "What do you mean?" "Well, you won't be able to get anyone who's any good to come work here because there's absolutely no respect for S.D.S. among the best computer folks." They were floored. They said, "What do you think we ought to do?" I replied, "You ought to computerize the office; everything that happens in the office can be put on the computer."
Q. -- If the personal computer has been the foundation for the Internet, where will the next major burst of innovation come from?
A. -- Broadband networks. If you take real-time video and audio and you couple them, and you imagine some kind of a chair that's connected to this system that you sit in and fly around wherever you want to go . . . .
Q. -- How will we use these new technologies?
A. -- You'll also be able to wear -- maybe not in my lifetime but certainly reasonably soon -- an unobtrusive device that will record in full color and sound everything that you see or point your head at, or, depending on how many of them you have, everything that's around you. And share it. Every waking and sleeping moment in your life will be recorded. And you will be able to store and retrieve it and do what you will with it.
Q. -- How will that change the world?
A. -- I don't know, but it will. There are obviously implications for privacy that will have to be worked through. I'm actually more concerned about nearer-term issues. I want the Internet to become a right, not a privilege. I think we need a driver's license to allow you to use the Internet, much like you drive on the road today. If you misbehave on the road, you get your license taken away.
Q. -- Do you have a sense of what the future will look like from a computer network point of view?
A. -- I can't help much about the future, I'm afraid. I was a bad predictor of the future 30 years ago. I was sure that from the early 1970's, all the pieces were there at Xerox and at ARPA to put the Internet in the state by the early '80's that it is in today. It was all there. It was physically there. But it didn't happen for years.
