HEADLINE: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY: FLASHBACK;
Of Crooks and Cons, Scandals and Schemes

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
In the mid-1980's, a Swedish sociologist named Malin Akerstrom, in her book "Crooks and Squares," examined the remarkable similarities between the personality traits of career criminals and those of successful entrepreneurs. Her findings prompted another prominent scholar to reflect that such criminals "have learned the lessons of capitalism too well." 
 The past century is certainly rich in scandals that bear out that conclusion. Indeed, some of the century's greatest scoundrels - Charles Ponzi, Ivar Krueger, Robert Vesco - were originally assumed by their victims to be brilliant capitalists.
 A few of the century's scandals led to social reforms, while others imply revealed new fault lines in the economic landscape. Some involved colorful characters worthy of a story by Damon Runyon or Tom Wolfe, and others were dull, faceless tales of stupidly bad behavior. But taken together, they offer the dot-com generation a timely reminder of what can go wrong.
 Following are some of the most significant scandlas of the century:
 
A SMELL FROM THE JUNGLE
 It is rare novelist who can claim to have almost single-handedly altered business history. One writer with a valid claim to that distinction is Upton Sinclair, who based his 1906 novel "The Jungle" on his investigations into unsanitary conditions in the meat-packing industry. The disgusting disclosures prodded Congress to adopt laws requiring Federal inspection of meat-packing houses, and led - despite intense business opposition - to a broader Government role in ensuring the safety of consumer goods.
 
THE ORIGINAL PONZI SCHEME
 In 1919, a dapper Italian immigrant named Charles Ponzi established the Old Colony Foreign Exchange Company, with offices in Boston and New York. He promised investors a suspiciously high return, 50 percent ormore, on foreign postal coupons, which he claimed could be purchased abroad at a discount and resold in America at a premium. Prosecutors soon found he simple used the money taken in from late comers to pay the promised dividends to earlier investors. For decades, con artists had called this technique the "Peter-to-Paul" swindle; from Mr. Ponzi's time on, it would be known as a "Ponzi scheme."
 
THE SWEDISH MATCH KING
 Some of the smartest investment bankers in America were taken in by the elegant Ivar Kruegar, a Swedish entrepreneur whose supposed wealth was fed by a monopoly on the kitchen-match business in various European countries. In fact, he was running an elaborate fraud involving dubious accounting and forged assets. Facing exposure at last, Mr. Krueger shot himself in his Paris apartment in March 1932, and his empire collapsed on his creditors and investors. It was one of the first great international swindles of the century.
 
HOW THE MIGHTY FALL
 Few business leaders commanded more respect in 1930 than Richard Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange and brother of a partner in the House of Morgan. By 1935, he embodied Wall Street's implacable resistance to the New Deal's market regulations. But in March 1938, he pleaded guilty to charges that he had stolen money, both from his own customers and from a stock exchange fund set up to benefit the widows and orphans of members. As he served his time in a Federal prison in Ossining, NY., Wall Street's resistance to the reform efforts of the Securities and Exchange Commission began to disintegrate.
 
A BIG PRICE--FIXING SCANDAL
 In early 1960, a dozen manufacturers, including General Electric and Westinghouse, were indicted on Fedeal charges that they had conspired for years to fix prices and rig government bidding for several types of electrical equipment. The elaborate conspiracy, which one writer said lacked only sinister music to qualify as a full-fldged spy movie, cost the Government and other industrial customers million so of dollars. The charges and subsequent guilty pleas shocked American consumers and led the courts to impose some of the stiffest antitrust penalties that American business had faced up until that day.
 
THE CORNFELD CONNECTION
 In the late 1950's, a gifted American salesman named Bernie Cornfeld built a foreign mututal fund empire known as Investors Overseas Service,s based outside Geneva and held together by dubious sales practices throughout the world and the questionable use of fund assets.
 When I.O.S. began to falter in 1970, its board dismissed Mr. Cornfeld and brought in an entrepreneur, Robert Vesco, perhaps the only man who couldmake Mr. Cornfeld seem sober and prudent. Accused by prosecutors of completing the looting of the company, Mr. Vesco fled in 1972 to various Caribbean havens, but was later jailed in Cuba on unrelated fraud charges. Although the crimes occurred abroad, the twin scandals smudged the reputation of the American mutual fund industry.
 
PROGRAMMED FOR CRIME
 The computer was already starting to reshpae American business in the second half of the century; with the Equity Funding scandal, it began to reshape American swindles. This once high-flying mutual fund and insurance conglomerate used phony computer records to make it appear that business was booming. In fact, the company was a fraud that collapsed in April 1973 after a controversial analyst named Raymond L. Dirks learned of the scheme and alerted his clients to it. Regulators accused Mr. Dirks of trading on inside infomration, but the United States Surpreme Court exonerated him on the ground that he had not been seeking personal profit.
 
A BUST IN THE OIL PATCH
 After the 1973 Arab oil embargo few Americans could imagine that energy prices would ever tumble. So nobody raised an eyebrow when, in early 1976, some new high-living managers began to transform the tiny suburban Penn Square Bank in Oklahoma City into an agressive oil and gas lender. Behind a boom-town facade, they routinely made new inflated loans to bail out earlier inflated loans - a Ponzi-like shuffle that ended with the bank's collapse in July 1982.
 Two major banks, the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company and Seattle First National Bank, had purchased some of the bank's dubious loans and were nearly destroyed as a result. Penn Square depositors whose accounts exceeded Federal insurance limits lost millions, shaking public confidence in Federal banking oversight.
 
'THE GREED DECADE' ON TRIAL
 On Wall Street, they still call it "Boesky Day" - Nov. 14, 1986, when Federal prosecutors disclosed that Ivan F. Boesky, a trader who had speculated hand-somely on the takeover deals of the decade, would plead guilty to insider-trading violations and testify about them is deeds of others. The most famous defendant he named was Michael R. Milken, whose transformation of the brokerage firm Drexel Burnham Lambert into a bottomless war chest for corporate raiders had ignited a national debate over junk bonds and hostile takeovers. In 1990, with Drexel itself in bankruptcy, Mr. Milken pleaded guilty to a handful of securities law violations, for which he served two years in prison and paid a record fine of $1 billion.
 
THE FALL OF LINCOLN SAVINGS
 It cost American taxpayers $3.4 billion to bail out Lincoln Savings and Loan in 1989. Lincon, which was run by Charles H. Keating Jr., was one of hundreds of savings institutions to fall in the late 1980's as misguided Federal legislation, inadequate regulatory supervision and old-fashioned fraud and greed combined to undermine an entire industry. Mr. Keating, who came to symbolize what Americans ruefully called the "S. & L. crisis," pleaded guilty in April - after years of legal wrangling - to four counts of fraud in connection with Lincon's collapse.
 
BRINGING DOWN BARINGS
 It seemed impossible that one young corrupt trader, Nicholas W. Leeson, could single-handedly destroy Barings Bank, the oldest investment bank in Britain. But in 1995 that is what happened. While working for the bank as an options trader in Singapore, Mr. Leeson embarked on a secret trading spree that left the bank facing fatal losses of roughly $1.3 billion. Mr. Lesson spent more than three years in a Singapore prison before being released in Uly, at age 32, suffering from colon cancer. His crime awakened older bankers and regulators to the risks posed by the esoteric financial products that were traded by their young computer-savvy employees - but that knowledge came too late to save the 233-year-old British bank, which was taken over by a Dutch financial group.
 
A NASDAQ CENSURE
 It began quietly, with an academic study in 1994 that questioned why traders on the Nasdaq market always seemed to sell every share of stock for at least 25 cents more than they had paid for it. Why not 12.5 cents? Guided by the study, class-action lawyers promptly sued the nation's top brokerage firms, accusing them of illegally conspiring to fix the prices of Nasdaq stocks.
 The lawsuits produced a historic $1 billion settlement and led regulators to censure Nasdaq's parent, the National Association of Securitie sDealers, in 1996 for inadequately regulating the marketplace. As a result, Nasdaq prices became fairer and more visible to public investors - but Nasdaq itself is still scrambling to adjus to the leaner profits and tougher competition that followed.

HEADLINE: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY: FLASHBACK;
Poor Judgement, Bad Breaks, Big Blunders

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
It has been a century of success for American business. General Motors grew to be the world's largest car company, Coca-Cola became unbiquitous around the globe, with McDonald's not far behind, and Walt Disney's Mickey Mouse may be known to far more people than any president ever has been. Microsoft, although not yet 25, is already the world's most valuable enterprise. 
 But there were still plenty of missteps over the past 100 years, even by the most successful companies. Some failed to pursue new opportunities and were left to stare jealously as upstarts surpassed them. Sometimes changes looked good to experts, but outraged customers. Company founders underestimated the value of what they had created and sold out before the real wealth arrived.
 What follows, in chronological order, are 12 of the biggest business launders of the past 100 years. It would not be a stretch to bet that similar mistakes will be made in the next century as well.
 
CARNEGIE TAKES BONDS
 When Andrew Carnegie agreed to sel lhis Carnegie Steel in 1901 to the steel trust being assembled by J.P. Morgan - the United States Steel Corporation - he was convinced that the shares being sold to investors in the new company were ridiculously overvalued and sure to fall in price. So Mr. Carnegie demanded, and got, his $250 million payment in 5 percent bonds, thus assuring him a more than ample income for the rest of his life. But he was supplanted by John D. Rockefeller as the nation's wealthiest person. Had he taken the stock instead, he almost certainly would have maintained his status.
 
SEARS SELLS OUT
Richard Warren Sears, one of two founders of Sears, Roebuck, took on Julius Rosenwald as partner after Alvah C. Roebuck left in 1895. But Mr. Sears and Mr. Rosenwald quarreled over how to run the company. Among other things, Mr. Rosenwald insisted that Sears stop selling something called a "Heidelberg Belt," an electrified device that was said to cure a variety of ailments, including impotence, for only $12.
 After Mr. Rosenwald insisted on cutting expenditures in the face of a recession, Mr. Sears quit in 1908. For five years, he held onto his stock, but in 1913 he sold. As a result, his heirs - Mr. Sears died just one year later - were left to watch the company's phenomenal growth from the sidelines.
 
WARD'S PULLS BACK
 As World War II neared its end in 1945, the conventional economic forecast for the United States was gloomy. Perhaps all those soon-to-be-unemployed soliders would plunge the country back into depression; certainly a recession would arrive as the government drastically reduced its spending.
 Sewell Avery, the presidetn of Montgomery Ward and a man known for strong beliefs (he had been arrested by soldiers for deying government edicts to recognize a union during the war), believed the forecast and husbanded cash for the inevitable downturn. Sears, Roebuck, meanwhile, borrowed money to build in the expanding suburbs. Sears' bet proved right as World War II had produced a lot of savings and pent-up demand. Montogmery Ward would never recover from its error.
 
A JOURNAL DROPS STOCKS
 Coming out of World War II, the two largest business newspapers in the United State - The Journal of Commerce and The Wall Street Journal - were neck-and-neck in circulation and influence. Then The Journal of Commerce decided in 1951 to drop stock tables, which it felt were of relatively little interest and costly to produce, and to concentrate on narrow business areas. The Wall Street Journal took off from there, aided in part by a growing public interest in the stockmarket, and it now has a circulation of 1.75 million. Today's Journal of Commerce circulation? About 17,000.
 
RAILROADS' NARROW TRACK
 For the first half of the century, the railroads were the undisputed masters of national transportation. But since they though tof themselves as railroads rather than transportation companies, they never tried to expand into either trucking or airlines at a time when their capital could have given them the edge. In mid-century, many of the rails went through bankruptcy reorganization, and it was decades before they began to make good money through intermodal service- the shipping of goods by a combination of rail and trucks.
 
PEROT'S $60 MILLION LOSS
 Few culture clashes in the world of business have been greater than the one set up when Ross Perot, the Texas-base founder of Electronic Data Systems, was induced in 1970 to come to the rescue of Francis I. duPont & Company, a wall Street firm with a great past and a struggling present.
 Lured by the opportunity to save the company while building the business of the E.D.S. unit that provided record-keeping services for brokerage firms, Mr. Perot yielded to the entreaties, which included pressure form Nixon administration officials worried about the effect a Wall Street bankruptcy would have on public confidence.
What he saw appalled him. Mr. Perot could not believe how badly Wall Street ran its operations; Wall street executives were equally appalled by theinterloper they considered a hick from Texas. Mr. Perot was left holding the bag when duPont's successor firm, duPont Walston, collapsed in 1974. He lost at least $60 million in the fiasco.
 
A BONDED FAILURE
 John R. Bunting, the chief executive of the First Pennsylvania Corporation, the owner of Philadelphia's biggest - and thenation's oldest - bank, putmore than $1 billion of the bank's money into Treasury bonds in 1976, and thus proved that you can go broke lending to a borrower with perfect credit.
 Having suffered losses on real estate loans, Mr.Bunting turned to Treasuries yielding 8 percent. But interest rates rose to previously unthinkable levels, sneidng the valueof the bonds down and causing huge losses as the bank paid more interest to depositors than it was earning on the bonds. Eventually, it had to be baled out by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The bank survived, but its shareholders suffered. Eventually, it was acquired by another bank.
 
SCHLITZ IS PENNY WISE
 In the eaqrly 1970's, Schlitz was the nation's No. 2 beer company, behind Anheuser-Busch. Trying to improve profits, the company changed its brewing process to cut production time to 4 days from 12 and cut costs with a variety of additives.
 When that did not scare off customers, it made one more change, adding a new ingredient known as Chill-grade to prolong the beer's shelf life. Unfortunately, that interacted with a foam stabilizer the company ahd added earlier, making the beer look milky. And that led to a huge recall in 1976 that destroyed the brand's image. Schlitz became a minor player.
 
AMAX SPURNS A SUITOR
 At the height of the oil boom, Chevron looked around for somewhere to spend its windfall profits and settled on Amax, a metals company whose share price had risen on talk that all natural resources would be in short supply. Amax fought off the 1981 bid, calling it too low, and Chevron backed off. Shareholders who could have enjoyed the gains from the sale instead watched Amax's share price collapse as natural resource values plunged in the 1980's. Eventually, Amax merged into Cyprus-Amax and spun off its gold-mining operations to shareholders, who got far less than they could have had in a marriage with Chevron.
 
I.B.M. FAILS TO THINK
 When I.B.M. entered the personal computer arena in 1981, it immediately set the standard for what had been a fragmented market. That led to monopoly profits for the company that controlled the standard - but that was not I.B.M. It was Microsoft, the upstart that developed and owned the computer's operating system. The failure of I.B.M. - which was known for the THINK signs posted throughout its plants - to secure any ownership interest in Mircrosoft or its operating system may have been the most costly mistake ever made by a major American company.
 
RECIPE FOR DISASTER
 Coca-Cola was the most popular soft dirnk int he wordl by a wide margin in the mid-1980's when the company decided to conduct taste tests. Those showed that most people liked a sweeter taste, one more like that of Pepsi-Cola, the company's prime competitor. So in 1985 the company scratched the old formula and, with much fanfare, introduced a new one. So confident was Roberto C. Goizueta, the chairman ofCoca-Cola, of the test results that he called the decision "one of the easiest we have ever made." Alas, most ofCoke's fervently loyal customers did not agree. Only three months later, the company yielded to consumer outrage and brought back the old formula. The new one was supposed to stay around, but it eventually vanished. Coke went on to prosper again, but the New Coke humilation remains vivid to those who endured it.
 
AT&T MISDIALS
 AT&T's attempt to become a major player in the computer business with its $7.4 billion takeover of NCR in 1991 wins the award as worst big merger of the century. NCR faltered under AT&T's control as expected synergies proved envanescent. Five years - and billions of dollars in losses - after the take over was completed, AT&T washed its hands of NCR by spinning it off to its shareholders.
 But AT&T did not merit the dishonor without competition. Other really bad deals include Xerox's 1969 purchase of Scientific Data Systems (a $1 billion investment that ultimately proved worthless); Mobil's 1974 takeover of Montgomery Ward (which lost money until the company was finally sold to a leveraged buyout firm in 1988, nine years before it field for bankruptcy); Sony's 1989 acquisition of Columbia Pictures (which Sony still owns, a few billion in losses later), and Quaker Oats' 1994 purchase of Snapple for $1.7 billion (which the cereal company sold for $300 million in 1997).

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 2000: A CENTURY OF BUSINESS;
From the Princes of Capitalism to the Bread Lines, How Fortunes Fared

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Mirror, mirror on the wall. Who's the richest of them all?
 There is no doubt that the wealthiest American as the century ends is William H. Gates III, the Microsoft chairman and chief executive. His net worth - as estimated by Forbes Magazine in October - was $85 billion, although it fluctuates daily as Microsoft's stock price rises or falls.
 
 But how does that compare with the wealth of John D. Rockefeller, who in 1913 at age 74 was worth $900 million, just after the government forced the breakup of the Standard Oil company he had created? One way to adjust the figure would be to apply changes in the Consumer Price Index. Do that, and it works out to around $15 billion in 1999 dollars.
 But that greatly understates the economic status Rockefeller actually held. The method used here was developed by Michael Klepper and Robert Gunther for their book "The Wealthy 100," published by Citadel Press i 1996. It is baed on estimates of each man's wealth as a proportion to the gross national product in his era. By that measure, Rockefeller had an economic clout that would be equal to about $212 billion now, making him more than twice as rich as Mr. Gates. (Of course, Mr. Gates is only 44 years old, so he has time to catch up.) Andrew Carnegie, the steel haron who died in 1919, also tops Mr.Gates.
 In fact, using the gross national product figures to adjust wealth, only two living Americans besides Mr.Gates were able to crack the top 16 for the century. They are Paul Allen, at No. 7, and Warren Buffett, at No. 13. Mr. Allen had the good fortune to be Mr. Gate's partner in founding Microsoft. Mr. Buffett built Berkshire Hathaway into a giant insurance and investment company.
 Similarly, the value of American companies has grown exponentially. In 1925, reports the Center for Research in Security Prices at the University of Chicago, only AT&T had a market value of $1 billion.
 A quarter-century later, in 1950, four companies were worthmore than $2 billion. Even in 1975, a value of $6.3 billion was enough to put Texaco in the top 10.
 Now, however, there are Internet startups that have meagers revenues but sport market values in the billions. VA Linux Systems, which went public this month with revenues of less than $50 million in its history, had a market value above $8 billion the first day it traded. Microsoft, the company that made Mr. Gates and Mr. Allen rich, is now valued at almost $600 billion. The tenth-largest company based in the United States, SBC Communications, is worth $175 billion. AT&T, having been broken up in 1984, is no No. 11, at $171.7 billion. FLOYD NORRIS

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2368 words

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 2000: TECHNOLOGY & MEDIA: The Economy Transformed, Bit by Bit;
Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
In 1995, Bill Gates of Microsoft wrote an impassioned memo to his lieutenants stirring them to confront the challenge of "The Internet Tidal Wave." That wave hit corporate America as a whole in 1999, when companies large and small recognized that the impact of the Internet would not be confined merely to Silicon Valley or to the proliferating dot-com start-ups.
"Every business now knows that it faces the opportunity and threat of being transformed by the Internet, and this was the year that happened," said Daniel Yergin, a business consultant and author. 
 The Internet has also become a powerful symbol of society's expectations about the future -- a future of fast-moving, disruptive technology that is shifting the terrain not only in business, but also in politics and culture.
The truth, of course, is that it is probably too early to judge whether an Internet revolution is truly under way. Historians say the Internet should be viewed mainly as the latest advance in communications, a successor to the telegraph and the telephone, more a technological step than a leap forward.
Still, whether labeled a revolution or an evolution, the Internet's impact on the economy seems destined to become greater and greater. When people speak of the "Internet economy," they do not really mean that Internet businesses themselves suddenly loom so large in the nation's $9 trillion economy. They are talking of a technology and a pattern of business behavior that feels like the future.
The Internet is seen as a technology of borderless free markets. It is a global network with open technology standards, not owned or controlled by a single company or nation. And it is magic on Wall Street these days, driving the shares of many Internet companies to astronomical heights.
Because it is such a low-cost communications technology, the Internet holds the promise of drastically reducing transactions costs. This opens the door to what Michael Porter of Harvard's business school has called "atomistic competition," as market forces and entrepreneurial ways are driven further down toward the individual level. Organizational bureaucracies of every kind -- corporate, government and union -- suddenly look vulnerable to the Internet's decentralizing powers.
Even the power of nation states, already eroding, seems at risk. Mr. Yergin, the co-author with Joseph Stanislaw of "The Commanding Heights," a history of the rise of the global marketplace, observed: "Nothing so symbolizes globalization as the Internet, a technology with the power to leap across the geographic borders of nation-states and across time zones."
Prediction tends to be a humbling, hit-or-miss endeavor even for the gifted or lucky. In the late 1960's, for example, Sir Arthur C. Clarke, the science fiction writer, predicted that by 2000 a vast electronic "global library" would be developed -- and the Internet and the World Wide Web could arguably qualify as one. Then again, Sir Arthur also predicted that the planets would be colonized by next year.
But technologists, economists and futurists say that some questions are worth asking when thinking about how the Internet economy might evolve over the next few years. What was the mixture of technology and policy decisions that created today's Internet? What key technology and policy issues are likely to affect the Internet over the next few years? And, finally, since the future is usually the past with a twist, what can be learned from earlier technology-driven transitions?
The Internet has been embraced by libertarian free-marketers as the embodiment of their values, but, to be sure, it began with government financing. Yet liberals who point to the Internet to support a pro-government stance -- at least in any conventional sense -- are ignoring certain facts. The early money for the Internet -- as well as for pioneering research in computer graphics and speech recognition software -- came from an elite, the Pentagon's Advanced Research Projects Agency. Its money came from the military's largess, and ARPA's leaders spent it pretty much as they pleased with little accountability. From the mid-1960's to the mid-1970's, the agency's leaders displayed an uncanny knack for backing long-term winners in technology.
For two decades, the Internet was developed gradually in the distinctive milieu of the nation's research centers by scientists who believed in the free sharing of information and in open technology standards. The next major policy pronouncement about the Internet did not come until 1997, when the Clinton administration released its "Framework for Global Electronic Commerce." Written by Ira C. Magaziner, a senior White House adviser, the report called for a market-driven Internet. "Business models must evolve rapidly to keep pace with the breakneck speed of change in the technology," the report said. "Government attempts to regulate are likely to be outmoded by the time they are finally enacted."
So the pattern of policy to date: shrewd government seeding of research followed by benign neglect. But as the Internet increasingly becomes a main thoroughfare of commerce, a host of new policy issues loom -- how to deal with taxation, privacy, security and international trade in a global networked economy.
"The Internet has given us the greatest rate of return on a public infrastructure investment ever," said Robert Litan, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution. "And it has flourished because we have not yet taxed or regulated it to death -- though those are live issues."
Technologically, the Internet is almost an economy unto itself -- a network, yes, but also a complex and interacting set of technologies. Today's Internet is a result of a torrid pace of improvement in recent years in computer networks, processing power, data storage, software, display technology and user interfaces like the Web browser.
The sheer firepower of computers, experts say, is certain to race ahead to startling effect over the next few years. Data storage technology, for example, is advancing at a particularly rapid rate. By 2003, personal computers may well come with terabyte hard drives, which are roughly 100 times the capacity on new PC's today, featuring about 10 gigabytes on average. A terabyte drive would be able to hold every conversation that even the chattiest person has had in a lifetime. Think of a supercomputer on every desktop, in terms of giving individuals the ability to mine personal or business information.
In every field of academic and scientific research, computing will increasingly be used for simulation and analysis. The real payoff from the Human Genome Project, for example, will come not from identifying the complete DNA sequence, but from understanding how these complex proteins work. Such knowledge, medical experts say, will be the basis for everything from developing personally tailored drugs to discovering new ways to treat disease. The main tool for stalking that breakthrough knowledge is computational biology -- microbiological simulations run on powerful computers.
The real technical challenge to the Internet economy will not come from any shortcoming in raw computing power, but from the difficulty of building up the global network to meet demand. The next-generation vision of the Internet is of a high-speed global network to which billions of devices are connected, from TV set-top boxes and hand-held computers to refrigerators and washing machines that would be able to do everything from optimizing fuel use to requesting a repair call automatically online.
But that kind of global nervous system of commerce and communication will require far more than adding computers and laying more wire. The Internet, after all, was originally designed as a computerized "party line" for a small community of researchers -- who knew and trusted each other -- to send e-mail. And network complexity can increase exponentially -- that is, a network with 200 million users is far more than twice as complex as one with 100 million because each user, each computer and each line of code can interact with others in the network in unpredictable ways, just as in a biological organism.
A presidential advisory group of leading computer scientists concluded earlier this year that new research, fresh approaches and more government money were needed to cope with the problem. "Scaling the Internet to handle the expected growth over time is a major challenge," said Irving Wladawsky-Berger, general manager of the Internet division at I.B.M. and a member of the group. "And the current infrastructure can't scale up."
The group's report to the White House warned that there would be "catastrophic failures" in the computer networks that increasingly support the nation's defense and economy, unless those networks were retooled.
Still, Mr. Wladawsky-Berger predicts that the technical challenge can be overcome, provided the government and industry make the needed research investments. "It should not be a showstopper," he said.
Indeed, given the track record of success in computing, the visceral optimism of the technologists seems justified. "Sure there are some tough problems, but it'll work," said Rick Rashid, head of research at Microsoft. "We can do it. We always have. In information technology, that is the way it's always worked."
That information technology is delivering a problem-solving payoff has been an article of faith in the corporate world for years, far more so than among economists. Business investment in computer hardware and software is running at $380 billion a year, up steadily from the annual rate of $110 billion five years ago. And corporate America is expected to keep increasing such spending.. By the end of 2001, Macroeconomic Advisers, a research firm in St. Louis, projects that business investment in computer hardware and software will be running at a yearly rate of $513 billion.
Economists expect the nation's extraordinary growth to continue next year, though at a somewhat slower pace. The consensus among the 50 forecasters in the Blue Chip Economic Indicators survey is that the economy will expand 3.9 percent this year, with inflation at 1.4 percent. For 2000, the consensus is growth of 3.2 percent and inflation of 1.7 percent. In February, the economy should set the record for the longest expansion, surpassing the 106-month record set in the 1960's.
Just what impact information technology has had on the economy's uncommon run of growth, productivity gains and low inflation is a subject of heated debate within the economics profession. It is probably too early to tell, but Mr. Litan of Brookings, who is leading a yearlong study on the issue, sponsored by the Internet Policy Institute, said, "My instinct is whatever we find the economic impact to be, it will be a lot greater five years from now."
The sense of being at the start of a business and economic transformation, of course, has fueled the Internet start-up fever. It seems a speculative bubble, but such periods of investment mania foster a rapid pace of business experimentation. Thomas Eisenmann, an assistant professor at the Harvard Business School, notes that from 1900 to 1925 there were more than 3,300 automobile start-ups in America turning out cars of many types -- some sporting three wheels, some six; one model featuring a shiplike tiller for steering; others trying electricity or steam as power sources.
"We'll see the same kind of winnowing in e-commerce," Mr. Eisenmann said. "Some will succeed, but most will fail. We'll repeat the past again, only faster."
For established companies, the Internet challenge is to adapt to an accelerated technological shift. That was precisely the quandary Mr. Gates was sketching out in his 1995 memo: Microsoft was threatened by the rise of Internet software; yet if it scrambled, he wrote, the company could benefit from the Internet. The speed of Microsoft's response is regarded as an exceptional case of a big company's moving nimbly to change course, but the tactics it used became the subject of the government's sweeping antitrust suit against Microsoft.
The Internet's openness, low-cost use and speed are its distinctive features. The telegraph, historians note, had many of the same qualities -- it was an electronic network that transformed many business practices and was a new medium of informal communication for many. Yet the telegraph was expensive in contrast to the Internet. Sending a message was a household budgeting decision; firing off an e-mail message today is not. "The Internet is the telegraph for the rest of us," noted Paul Saffo, a director of the Institute for the Future.
The speed at which the Internet is spreading across the globe, pushing both the tools and values of high technology onto people, could prompt a backlash. Peter Schwartz, a leading futurist and business consultant, is a technology optimist. Along with Peter Leyden and Joel Hyatt, he wrote, "The Long Boom: A Vision for the Coming Age of Prosperity."
Yet Mr. Schwartz, while predicting that the pace of technological change will not slow, adds that the willingness of people to accept new technology could reverse sharply if companies and governments do not make the right policy choices.
The Internet economy carries the potential for creating "a deep divide between those who have the skills to prosper and those who don't," he said.
"That's why education policy is so important," he added.
The social tolerance for technology, Mr. Schwartz added, could also cool. The advance of nuclear power in the United States, he said, came to a standstill because the public fears after the Three Mile Island accident were not allayed. The recent resistance to genetically altered foods and the protests in Seattle over the World Trade Organization's global influence on environmental and labor protections, he said, are warning signs.
"An inadequate appreciation of either the losers in this new economy or of the people with legitimate concerns could be real problems," Mr. Schwartz said. "If you don't address those groups early on, it will come back to bite you."

SECTION: Section C; Page 2; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2131 words

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 2000: AN EPITAPH FOR THE 20th CENTURY;
A Time of Energy And Enterprise And E-Everything

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON

 BODY:
When eight well-known executives were asked to sum up the most important characteristics of the last 100 years in an epitaph for the 20th century, they invariably talked about the powerful impact of technology in all its myriad forms: the airplane, television, computers and the Internet.
"Before this century, science did not matter to the average person," said Franklin D. Raines, the chairman and chief executive of Fannie Mae, the world's largest nonbank financial services company. "In this century, science is changing our lives fundamentally." 
 But as much as these business leaders, who hailed from entertainment and financial services and industry, praised the huge advances in technology over the last 100 years, they expressed concern about how technology could be used and the double-edged nature of change.
The dark side of the passing century was hinted at by the comic creator Stan Lee's rendition of Mongorr, a despot eager to infiltrate our world to take advantage of the new technology. But, in as epic terms as any battle waged between superheroes, Robert E. Rubin, the former Treasury secretary, also talked about the stark contrasts of the last 100 years: the huge advances made and the devastation wrought by the ability of people to hurt one another. "Human nature has remained a constant," he concluded.
Many of the executives were also quick to note the substantial divide that exists between those who have benefited from the prosperity of the last 100 years and those who have not. "The haves and have-nots are getting further apart," said Lawrence A. Bossidy, the chairman of Honeywell, the industrial giant created by the recent merger of Honeywell, the maker of electronic controls, and AlliedSignal, a diversified manufacturer.
As the chairman of Stan Lee Media, a publicly held company based in Encino, Calif., Mr. Lee is participating directly in the revolution being created by the Internet. "I've been in comics, radio, television, animation, movies and now the Internet," said Mr. Lee, who is one of the people responsible for such memorable superheroes as Spider-Man and the Fantastic Four and plans to bring a new generation of different superheroes and villains to the Internet in short animated episodes.
Television and the Internet, in particular, have achieved enormous global reach, Mr. Lee says. People who once lived in isolation are exposed as never before to what is going on in the rest of the world. "There are no hicks anymore," he said.
But Mr. Lee is genuinely worried about how this technology is used. Like Mongorr, one of Mr. Lee's new characters, there are those who may use the Internet to harness hatred. "I'm hoping that the closer we come together, the more that will fade away," he said.
When Mr. Bossidy of Honeywell thinks about the 20th century, he ticks off the numerous advances in electronics: the cathode ray tube in televisions, the microchip and the various iterations of computers that allow work to be done rapidly, leading to huge improvements in productivity.
The advances in medicine -- the cure of diseases like scarlet fever and new treatments for heart disease and cancer -- are also striking, Mr. Bossidy said. "People feel better; they don't just live longer," he said.
But the role of the corporation has also undergone significant change, he argued, as companies have become much more efficient. "Corporations used to be run exclusively by dictators," said Mr. Bossidy, who spent more than three decades at General Electric before joining AlliedSignal, where he became chief executive in 1991. "Now you have to lead and be prepared to serve," he said, and employees have the freedom to contribute.
Increasingly, governments and other organizations will rely on a corporate model to improve how they operate, according to Mr. Bossidy. He also believes that companies will be asked more and more to address social issues like education, not in privatizing them but in marshaling resources.
But Mr. Bossidy was wary of trying to guess what other innovations the next century might bring. Just as few foresaw the Internet, "most of the changes in the 21st century will not be predicted," he argued.
Mr. Rubin, who is as well known on Wall Street as he is in Washington, takes an even-handed approach in assessing the century. Once a top official at Goldman Sachs, he is now the chairman of the executive committee of the board for Citigroup, the nation's largest financial services company. "It has been a period of tremendous advance," Mr. Rubin said, noting how much of the global population has benefited from technology. But he is quick to point out the last century's episodes of war and violence as well as the use of technology for mass destruction.
Globalization has also remarkably changed how we live, he noted. "I think we are far more interdependent today than we were 100 years ago," economically, environmentally and geopolitically, Mr. Rubin said. He, too, is concerned about the gulf between those who are enjoying this century's tremendous prosperity and those who are not but understand what they are missing.
The challenge, he said, will be to see how the tension between sovereignty and the growing global interdependence is handled, and he believes the United States must decide what role it should play. "There is a tremendous struggle between those who believe that the U.S. should play a major leadership role and those who believe in some fashion that we should turn inward and turn our back," he said.
David H. Komansky, the chairman and chief executive of Merrill Lynch & Company, takes a strikingly more optimistic view. "Be bullish," he argued, not about financial markets but in viewing the strides made in the past 100 years. Despite world wars, the Great Depression and other economic turbulence, there have been significant improvements in the standard of living, medicine and technology, he said.
"I think we are on the doorstep of a truly global life style that will benefit every person in every part of the world," Mr. Komansky said.
The power of instant communication -- the ability to make a telephone call anywhere in the world or tune into CNN to see minute-by-minute broadcasts of war -- has created a world that is linked almost in real time, Mr. Komansky said.
Globalization, he argued, has transformed businesses like Merrill Lynch, which two decades ago was primarily a domestic firm. Today, more than a third of its business is conducted outside the United States, and Merrill employs 65,000 people in 44 countries. Managing the huge variety of people from different ethnic backgrounds becomes more of a challenge, he said.
"I think the phenomenon of globalization is in its very early days," Mr. Komansky predicted. But he said he was confident that civilization would continue to make great progress. "The future is much brighter than the past," he said.
The head of Fannie Mae, the country's largest provider of home-mortgage financing, Mr. Raines is keenly aware of how much more accessible capital -- in the form of mortgages, credit cards and loans -- is today than it was before a variety of government programs created in the aftermath of the Great Depression to help homeowners, farmers and small businesses.
Then, "the Government was involved in pushing capital out into the economy and making it much more available to the individual," Mr. Raines said.
While the private sector has taken over much of that role -- and Fannie Mae is now a publicly held company -- the continuing spread of capital has helped create "a huge wealth effect" in the United States, according to Mr. Raines.
But Mr. Raines, the first black chief executive of one of the nation's largest 100 corporations, also spoke of the "century-long effort" to promote equality and "integrate black America into society." Corporate America has also taken part in that effort, he said, and he pointed to the advancement of several black executives within the last few years. "Ten years ago, you couldn't think about it," he said.
Mr. Raines also talked about those who have been left behind in what is known as the wealth gap. "The democratization of wealth has not been complete," he said, and he voiced concern that the nation could lose its commitment to that goal during the next 100 years.
Michael D. Eisner, the chairman and chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, was reluctant to pontificate, but he, too, emphasized the transforming power of technology. The 20th century "has been a triumph for human expression," he said. Communication has been transformed, he said, from what was once largely face to face to something that is now both instant and universal for people around the globe. No matter how effective books and other printed forms of expression were in creating change, the widespread adoption of television and the Internet has fundamentally changed how we express ourselves, he said.
While the next century may see advances that make such communication even more efficient and ubiquitous, it cannot make communication faster, Mr. Eisner noted. "You can't go faster than instant," he said.
Mr. Eisner, who suggested that philosophers and psychiatrists were more adept at thinking about the implications of this change, shied away from predicting where this instant human expression, allowing anyone to say anything to nearly anyone else, would lead. Either global democracy or totalitarianism could result, he said.
Martha Stewart, the entrepreneur whose sense of style led to the creation of her own media and merchandising empire, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, worries that we are already witnessing the drawbacks of the new speed at which we conduct our lives. While she applauded the advances of the 20th century in technology, science and medicine, "advancement in the study of the humanities, in art and in cultural endeavors, seems to have been less progressive, especially in the second half of this century," she argued.
The result of the widespread adoption of the telephone, faxes, e-mail messages and computers has been the inability to think creatively, Ms. Stewart said. Answering e-mail has taken the place of writing a great novel. Her own life has been consumed by the Internet, she said, and technology has allowed her to do any number of jobs at once. "It's insane," she laughed, but she said she was also saddened by the widespread implications of this speed.
She is also concerned about the social impact of the technology, which she described as taking away physical contact, from seeing someone directly or talking to them on the telephone. "It is much more introverted living," she said.
What she hopes is that the next century will provide more time for people to reflect. As people get used to the technology, they may learn to dominate it. And she hopes that we remain sensitive to the challenge of making technology accessible to all, although she is confident that will happen. "Computers are going to be cheap," she said. "Everyone is going to have them."
As the chairman and chief executive of America Online, one of the best-known providers of access to the Web, Stephen M. Case enjoys a key vantage point on the development of the Internet. The proliferation of telephones and cars, the television, the computer and the Internet created an increasingly mobile society, Mr. Case said. Businesses were opened up, and people could be on the move without losing all ties to family and friends. "Suddenly, anything was possible," Mr. Case said.
The result, according to Mr. Case, has been the American century. "It was a time of unprecedented opportunity," he argued, as technology, coupled with the spread of democracy and the relative prosperity and security of this period, allowed people to explore new areas.
"Technology was a real driver because it created not just whole new industries, but it has also reshaped our lives," Mr. Case said.
But he acknowledged that the challenge faced by society is in making sure everyone has access. "It is not about dropping computers" into places where people have difficulty taking advantage of the technology, he said, but about developing an integrated approach to making sure they have the tools and wherewithal to use the computers.
Mr. Case believes, however, that the Internet journey is only beginning and that there is much to learn yet about how it will affect this country and the world. "I do think the next century is going to be the Internet century," he said, and the next decade or two will be defined by the changes wrought by the new medium. The Internet has the ability to transform all aspects of what we do to gather information, shop, communicate or be entertained.
"It is very, very empowering," he said.

SECTION: Section C; Page 3; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 986 words

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 2000: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
Engineering the Nation's Longest Expansion

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In his nearly half-century as an economist, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, has watched the nature of the American economy change fundamentally.
"The quintessential manifestations of America's industrial might earlier this century -- large steel mills, auto assembly plants, petrochemical complexes and skyscrapers -- have been replaced by a gross domestic product that has been downsized as ideas have replaced physical bulk and effort as creators of value," Mr. Greenspan said in a recent speech. 
 "Today, economic value is best symbolized by exceedingly complex, miniaturized integrated circuits and the ideas, the software, that utilize them," he said. "Most of what we currently perceive as value and wealth is intellectual and impalpable."
Given the continued importance of basic industry to the economy, Mr. Greenspan may have overstated his case a bit. But there is little doubt that sweeping technology-driven shifts are under way in the structure and operation of the economy and that they are forcing Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues at the Federal Reserve to rethink their approach to monetary policy.
In some ways, the Fed policy makers face problems at the beginning of the new decade that generations of their predecessors would have welcomed.
Having forced inflation down to quite manageable levels, they have the luxury of debating whether it is better to allow prices to rise slightly each year, or whether they should aim for absolute price stability.
But with unemployment hovering near 30-year lows, they have been forced to re-examine the assumption that a strong economy will inevitably generate inflation if joblessness falls below a certain level. With traditional forecasting models no longer terribly reliable, they face considerable uncertainties as they try to predict the economy's course.
There is mounting evidence that productivity -- the single most important determinant of the economy's growth potential -- is benefiting from huge investments in technology and is surging at a rate that would allow the economy to retain substantial momentum without igniting inflation.
But no one is certain how long the surge will continue. Likewise, it is anyone's guess whether the booming stock market is a reflection of and contributor to the economy's improved long-term prospects or a bubble that will end in tears.
It is also unclear whether the length of the current expansion -- barring an unforeseen collapse it will become the longest in the nation's history in February at 8 years and 11 months -- means that the business cycle has been tamed or simply that the United States is benefiting from a remarkable string of good luck.
The Fed faces these challenges from a position of relative strength. Thanks to his success in taming inflation and his flexibility in responding to the rapidly changing economy, Mr. Greenspan has tremendous credibility and leeway among investors and political leaders. With both Democrats and Republicans pledging to maintain fiscal discipline, monetary policy is becoming even more important in managing the economy. The Fed's independence from the government of the day and its focus on inflation-fighting have become the standard for central banks around the world, which constantly look to Mr. Greenspan for their cues.
Central banks, led by the Fed, "now find themselves in a position of power and responsibility unrivaled in their history," said Mervyn King, deputy governor of the Bank of England. "A commitment to price stability is now seen as the key to achieving broader economic stability."
Mr. Greenspan still has his critics. Farmers, beset by commodity prices that are low or falling, contend there is little justification for higher interest rates.
Some manufacturers say Mr. Greenspan does not seem to understand how little power they have to raise prices or to appreciate fully how technology and global competition are driving them to become more efficient. And many liberal economists contend Mr. Greenspan seems to have forgotten that the Fed's mandate includes a commitment to achieving full employment.
Over the next year, Mr. Greenspan is likely to face some particularly difficult choices. If the economy continues to defy predictions that it will slow to a sustainable pace, he may feel forced to follow this year's three quarter-point rate increases with additional tightening. Fed policy makers meet tomorrow but are not expected to raise rates then, given their current neutral policy stance. That puts further action off until 2000, an election year, which could create tremendous political pressure on the Fed.
Mr. Greenspan, who will turn 74 in March, has proved willing and able to take the heat when necessary, and so far he has given no indication that he is tired of the job, which he has held more than 12 years. President Clinton seems almost certain to nominate him to a fourth term next year, providing continuity in monetary policy whatever the outcome of the presidential election.
Even so, policy makers in Washington are already speculating about a post-Greenspan Fed. Assuming Mr. Greenspan serves only one more term, the next president would get to choose his successor, a selection that could carry tremendous economic and political significance.
It is too early to think in terms of Mr. Greenspan's legacy. Still, his constant re-examination of assumptions about how the economy works and his focus on technology as a transforming force have already changed the approach to their jobs of officials at the Fed and at other central banks.
"I believe that if central banks are to retain their central position in economic policy making, they must face up to the intellectual and technological challenges that lie ahead," Mr. King recently told a gathering of central bankers, including Mr. Greenspan. "Unless they do so, popularity will turn to disillusion."

SECTION: Section C; Page 3; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1162 words

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 2000: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
As Nature of Money Changes, Will the Dollar Remain Supreme?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Money is a funny thing. Everyone knows what it is. But money is something that can change a lot over time.
A century ago, there was little question about what money was. It was gold, period. Or, to be a little more exact, it included national currencies like dollars and pounds, but only to the extent they were convertible into gold. There was but one real money. 
 Now there are dozens and dozens of national currencies, none of them tied to gold. But there is a hierarchy of currencies that in practice significantly reduces the real number. That hierarchy is based not on relative value, which can and does fluctuate, but on their function in the world economy. The United States dollar is clearly No. 1.
At the same time, the nature of money is changing. With no anchor in precious metals, the task of maintaining the value of currencies has fallen to central banks, few of which even existed in 1900. It was the central banks -- most notably the Federal Reserve in the United States and the Bundesbank in Germany -- that were given credit for slaying the inflation dragon in the 1980's, leading to what might be called the cult of the central banker.
The big questions for the international monetary system in the 21st century will revolve around those points: Will the dollar maintain its supremacy, or will the euro, and perhaps even the Japanese yen, gain comparable status? How will other countries manage the value of their currencies? And, perhaps most important, will central bankers maintain their power and prestige, or will they stumble and take the blame for some economic problem?
The current supremacy of the dollar does not reflect a brilliant record as a store of value. If one uses consumer price inflation as a measure, a 1999 dollar is worth about a nickel in 1900 money. Measured against gold, the dollar is down 93 percent.
Instead, the dollar's primacy reflects the United States's role as the world's largest economy, with capital markets that lead the world. The dollar is the most likely currency to be held as official reserves by other countries. It is the main currency of international lending. Companies from Brazil to Indonesia owe dollars, not reais or rupiahs. When the real and rupiah were devalued in the crises of the late 1990's, local companies that had thought they were in good shape found themselves in financial difficulty.
The euro, the currency of 11 European countries, was created in part to challenge the dollar's supremacy. Its first year has not been a smooth one, and the value of the currency has fallen. But the euro's use in international borrowing has risen.
Some major economies, such as Britain and Japan, can easily keep floating exchange rates with the dollar and the euro, in part because those countries have capital markets that can allow companies to borrow in local currencies.
But for many other currencies, the options are not so clear. Until the Asian currency crisis, many countries opted for a sort of nonbinding fixed rate. Their currencies were tied to the dollar, sometimes with a planned gradual depreciation.
The Asian crisis, however, saw many such currencies plunge in value and led to a growing consensus that countries must choose one of two options. They can choose freely floating exchange rates that rise or fall against other currencies moved by market forces, a plan that gives governments maximum flexibility but can make it hard for businesses to plan their affairs. Alternatively, they can adopt an absolute fixed rate versus a major currency.
That has meant proposals in Latin America for "dollarization," in which the local currency is simply replaced by the dollar. At the extreme, that could lead to the entire hemisphere, and perhaps much of the rest of the world as well, adopting the dollar. Such a policy would give Latin American businesses the ability to borrow at relatively low dollar interest rates, with confidence that devaluation would not devastate them.
The downside to that arrangement for other countries is that the Federal Reserve, in designing its monetary policy, is unlikely to take into account the effect a given policy might have on a foreign country that has dollarized but whose economy is not moving in tandem with Washington.
The role of central banks is the other major issue. A century ago, there were only 18 central banks, 16 of them in Europe, plus Japan and Indonesia. The Federal Reserve was created in 1913.
Now there are 172 central banks, and more and more of them claim some degree of independence from national governments. The European Central Bank represents a new degree of independence since no one government appoints all its members.
The claim for such independence rests largely on the success of tight monetary policies in quelling inflation in the 1980's.
The role of the European Central Bank might prove to be the most controversial of the next decade. While one can argue that the economies of the euro zone, from Naples to Helsinki, are no more diverse than those of the United States, from Boston to Birmingham, this country has a political unity to go along with a common currency. It has much greater labor mobility, aided to no small extent by a common language, and it has a more developed system to allow fiscal transfers -- via welfare and unemployment benefits -- from prosperous regions to struggling ones.
All that means that the challenges confronting the European Central Bank in bad times could be of a different order of magnitude than those that confront the Fed, simply because the nonmonetary means of stabilization are less developed. It is conceivable that a prolonged economic downturn could lead one European country or another to elect a government that blamed the central bank and wanted out of the euro, thereby precipitating a crisis since no exit from the euro is supposed to be possible.
The European Central Bank is not, of course, the only one that could end up being vilified if economies went bad. The most important question for the future of the international monetary system may be what would happen if faith in central banks were damaged so badly that alternative ways of managing currency values were sought. Some think that gold would make a comeback, as the only real money. Alternatively, a currency's value might be tied to a basket of commodities.
One central banker, Mervyn King, the deputy governor of the Bank of England, has even suggested that new computer technologies might end up making it possible for financiers effectively to bypass government-created money, creating their own relative values through trading. The unit of account, he said, might be a commodity standard, leaving central banks out of the equation.
If that were to happen, he said in a speech last summer, "central banks would lose their ability to influence monetary policy" and "the successors to Bill Gates would have put the successors to Alan Greenspan out of business."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 2000: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
CENTURY HIGHLIGHTS

 BODY:

1904: MORGAN MERGER WRECKED
The railroad combination that J. P. Morgan fashioned in 1901 with James Hill and Edward Harriman into the Northern Securities Company was declared illegal by the United States Supreme Court under the Sherman Antitrust Act of 1890. 

1911: STANDARD OIL BROKEN UP
The Supreme Court ordered the dissolution of John D. Rockefeller's Standard Oil Company in a ruling seen as a victory for big business because only "unreasonable" restraints of trade were found illegal. Rockefeller ended up with big stakes in the spun-off companies and his wealth only grew.
 
1913: INCOME TAX ADOPTED
Only people with an income of $2,500 or higher would be taxed -- at a rate of 1 percent -- under the income tax plan introduced by President Woodrow Wilson to enable the government to reduce tariffs on imported goods.
 
1920: MORGAN MERGER UPHELD
The U.S. Steel Corporation, formed by J. P. Morgan in 1901, may have had the power to control the steel trade but, because it did not exercise that power, it was not an illegal monopoly, the Supreme Court ruled.
 
1939: PAN AM FLIES TO EUROPE
A pontoon plane took the first passengers across the Atlantic in 22 hours for $375 each way, flying from Port Washington, N.Y., and landing in Marseille, France, after two stops.
 
1955: TWO UNION FEDERATIONS UNITE
After years of conflict, the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations agreed to merge into the A.F.L.-C.I.O, with 15 million members.
 
1959: BIG THREE MAKE SMALL CARS
Pressed by domestic and import rivals, G.M., Ford and Chrysler began selling their own small cars, the Chevy Corvair, Ford Falcon and Plymouth Valiant. Ralph Nader's attack on the Corvair led to auto safety laws in 1966.
1968: HUGE OIL FIND
One of the richest oil fields ever was discovered on Alaska's frigid Arctic Slope. Nine years later, a pipeline was opened to carry the oil to market.
 
1970: RAILROAD GOES BANKRUPT
Failing to meet the challenge from truckers and airlines, the Penn Central filed for bankruptcy protection. Conrail later took over freight service in the Northeast and Congress established Amtrak for passengers.
 
1984: AT&T BREAKS UP
The giant telephone business spun off its local companies, the Baby Bells, after settling government charges that it had abused its monopoly to keep competitors out of the telephone equipment and long-distance markets.
1988: KKR GETS RJR
In history's largest leveraged buyout, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. beat out managers for control of RJR Nabisco with a bid of nearly $25 billion.
 
1998: TOBACCO COMPANIES SETTLE
Ending the largest legal and financial threat to their business, cigarette makers agreed to pay more than $200 billion to settle state lawsuits filed to recover Medicaid money spent treating diseases related to smoking.
 
1998: CITIGROUP FORMED
Citicorp and Travelers Group merged in a $70 billion deal that challenged the Glass-Steagall restrictions on banking. Those limits were overturned by Congress in 1999.
 
1999: OIL GIANTS MERGE
After agreeing to major divestitures, the nation's two largest oil companies, Exxon and Mobil, were combined in a deal valued at $81 billion, making it the largest industrial merger ever.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 2000: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
As Labor Pool Shrinks, A New Supply Is Tapped

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Five years into a booming economy, America is "depleting its pool of available workers" -- a warning often heard from Alan Greenspan. But beyond the pool of known recruits lies another mass of untapped labor that can supply an expanding work force -- and sustain a robust economy -- into the new decade.
This labor in reserve consists mainly of women and potential immigrants. The women are not so noticeable in the statistics; many hold jobs and are counted as employed. But nearly half the women working in the United States today do so only part-time, and millions are gradually stepping up to full-time schedules -- making themselves available eight hours a day instead of five, or five days a week instead of three, or working through July and August instead of dropping out during their children's school vacation. Nearly a million women a year since 1994 have upgraded their status to full-time from part-time work.
The immigrants in question are not so much the uncounted people here illegally, but the men and women still in Canada or Mexico who move across the border when jobs beckon. "You have a construction contract and the work doubles," said Harley Shaiken, a labor economist at the University of California at Berkeley. "One of your workers makes a call back home, to his village in Mexico or Guatemala, and within a week a cousin shows up, or a cousin and the cousin's friend."
Tens of millions of people abroad are quickly available for jobs in the United States. The Immigration and Naturalization Service says that slipping into America and then working illegally for a year or two is not all that hard.
And suddenly a straitjacket that threatened to strangle a robust economy is not so binding after all. The work force has grown lately by 200,000 jobs a month, but rather than being depleted the pool of people available to fill still more jobs may be growing, or at least holding its own. Few issues in economics are more important than pinning down the size of this pool. A wrong answer could prompt the Federal Reserve to cut off the economic expansion, which started in 1991, gained steam four years ago and in February will become the longest in American history.
"The labor market gets tight, and these people flow in from across the borders, which helps to explain why wages are not rising that much at the low end," said Daniel Hamermesh, a labor economist at the University of Texas at Austin. "The women, quantitatively, are not a big matter. But they represent a different segment of the population. These are skilled people in many cases, and going full-time leads to" less wage pressure in the middle.
Mr. Greenspan, the Fed chairman, and others at the Fed hold in their public pronouncements to a traditional view on the labor supply -- one that suggests the economic expansion must soon be slowed for lack of available workers. When Mr. Greenspan refers, in his speeches and Congressional testimony, to a "depleting pool," he means two groups: those who are unemployed and seeking work and those who are not seeking work but would accept it if jobs they liked came their way. That pool has shrunk to 9.6 million lately from 11.2 million two years ago, Mr. Greenspan notes.
The significance of this calculation is clear. When workers are in short supply, employers tend to raise compensation to get enough people, and then raise prices to cover the higher labor costs. Neither trend has shown up yet. The inflation rate, a big concern at the Fed, is particularly mild. Even so, the Fed's response to a shrinking labor pool has been to raise interest rates, thus slowing the economy and reducing the demand for new workers. The Fed made that point with its last interest-rate increase, in mid-November. "The pool of available workers willing to take jobs has been drawn down further in recent months, a trend that must eventually be contained," the Fed said, in justifying the increase.
There are, of course, already many illegal immigrants working in America or available for work. The Census Bureau puts the number at 5 million or so. The Labor Department -- along with Mr. Greenspan -- includes this calculation in its estimates of how many people are working or available for work. The Census Bureau's estimate undoubtedly falls short of the actual number of illegal immigrants, but the shortfall is not considered big enough at the Fed or the Labor Department to make a difference.
The Immigration Service, though, counts many more heads. "What that 5 million does not include is the significant number of people on our northern and southern borders who come to the United States and work for a year, and return home and then come back," said Robert Bach, the Immigration Service's executive associate commissioner for policy and planning. Crossing the border is not easy, he said, "but there are certainly ample ways to enter the United States without documents or with fraudulent documents or by abusing documents, such as a tourist's visa."
The results are evident even in the official statistics -- the foreign-born hold nearly 12 percent of all jobs, up from about 10 percent in 1995 -- and certainly their numbers are growing in a number of American cities.
Consider Atlanta, Cincinnati, Louisville, Ky., or Indianapolis, where Hispanic immigrants are now well represented in construction work, holding jobs as electricians, plumbers and carpenters. Or visit Malden Mills, a textile maker in Lawrence, Mass., whose best-known brand is Polartec. The company is adding 230 workers by March at wages of about $11 an hour. Most of the existing 2,000 employees are Hispanic immigrants, mainly from the Dominican Republic, already settled in Lawrence, whose population is heavily Hispanic.
"For the first time, we are facing a situation where we might not have as many people already in the Lawrence area as we might need," said Jeff Bowman, the company's marketing director.
Some new applicants are relatives of Malden's Hispanic employees, or immigrants recommended by parish priests. Indeed, immigrants settling in America over the past two decades have created informal networks that facilitate the arrival of new people who, once in the country, have a relative or a friend who gives them lodging and helps them find work. "It is how you get to jobs in Oregon or Minneapolis or New England that makes these networks pivotal," Mr. Shaiken said.
Malden Mills insists on proof that an immigrant is here legally, but even so has had some problems. An applicant must present a Social Security card and a photo I.D., both easily purchased on the street. And catching any falsehood can take the Immigration Service at least a year, often longer, because the Social Security Administration reviews Social Security numbers for accuracy only once a year.
"I have seen Immigration go one or two years before we are notified," said Alan Kraunelis, the company's director of industrial relations. "A lot of times by then, the employee has a lawyer and is trying to get a green card. In some cases you can keep the worker on and in others you cannot. You say this guy is a very good worker, he has excellent attendance, we have trained him in a skill, and for the most part, unless the worker has a problem back in his homeland, Immigration is pretty reasonable."
Or consider Unite, the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees, representing 300,000 low-wage workers in the United States. "Nationally, 20,000 are probably undocumented workers," said Bruce Raynor, Unite's secretary-treasurer. In Chicago, the proportion is higher, probably one-third, among the 1,500 laundry workers represented by the union, he said.
And the union, in its latest contract, tries to protect them. In addition to specifying wages of $7 to $9 an hour, the contract obligates the employers to bar immigration agents from their plants without search warrants. Just going to court for a warrant alerts undocumented workers, who then can disappear, returning home for a while or reappearing, with fresh documents, at another job.
"I think of what is happening as a floating labor pool that kind of floats back and forth across the border," said Jeffrey Passell, a demographer at the Urban Institute in Washington. "Right now, there is some indication that this floating pool that tends to go back and forth is actually here."
Others are also contributing to the pool of potential workers, postponing the pool's depletion. Older people, for example, are working more years, either postponing retirement or coming back to part-time jobs. Supermarkets and telephone call centers, set up by so many companies to handle orders and customer queries, are recruiting more high school and college students and arranging schedules around their schooling. Blacks are taking jobs in greater numbers, and their unemployment rate has fallen sharply. And the number of people holding two or more jobs has risen by 800,000 since 1994, to 8.1 million.
But apart from immigrants, no group has made a greater contribution than women. The shift from welfare to work plays a role. Many new workers are unmarried mothers with at least one child younger than 3 years old. The percentage of these women now in the labor force -- holding jobs or seeking them -- rose to 65.8 percent last year from only 54.3 percent in 1995.
And across the job spectrum -- from high-skilled work to low-skilled -- the percentage of women shifting to full-time work from part-time rose to 56.4 percent last year from 52.8 percent in 1994. These women are adding millions of hours without changing the number of people employed or the nation's unemployment rate, now 4.1 percent.
The chance to increase family income draws some of the women. So does the aging of the work force; the oldest baby boomers have more time now that their children are young adults. And companies like Manpower, the huge temporary help agency, nudge women into working more hours.
Manpower supplies 25,000 people a day, on average, most of them women, as operators at corporate call centers. The percentage of those women working full time rather than part time is rising, mainly for two reasons, says Jeffrey Joerres, Manpower's chief executive. Some are drawn into longer hours by flexible scheduling, which allows them to work while their children are in school or in the evening when a husband is home. But higher pay is also a lure.
"I don't know where the inflection point is," Mr. Joerres said, "but $1 an hour can make a very big difference at this pay level, and pay for call-center operators has gone up by $1 an hour since the beginning of the year, to $10 an hour."
Does that mean wage pressures have arrived, as Mr. Greenspan fears?
Apparently not, judging by the very mild movement in the Consumer Price Index. Wages might be rising for call-center operators and others, but not by enough to force prices up. The pool of untapped labor is still sufficiently untapped.
