SECTION: Section C; Page 6; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1226 words

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 2000: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
Telecommuting to Pick Up as Workers Iron Out Kinks

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT

 BODY:
If ever there was a company likely to take to telecommuting, it is AT&T. The huge corporation has thousands of employees around the world. Many perform white-collar tasks that can be accomplished on computers and sent over the Internet. Even the company's bottom line can benefit when its workers dial into the company's network or pick up the phone to call headquarters.
Yet in 1999, five years after AT&T began a formal telecommuting program, the percentage of managers who worked from home at least once each week dropped to 24 percent, from 29 percent in 1998. 
 Nor is AT&T alone.
Across the country, thousands of people who tried working from home part time during the 1990's have returned to the office full time. Many felt disconnected from their colleagues, became frustrated about slow computer hookups or simply grew tired of trying to be a parent and an employee at the same time.
It is enough to make one wonder whether the workplace of the early 21st century will in fact resemble a traditional office much more than was once thought.
Do not be fooled, workplace experts say, contending that in reality this is the lull before the telecommuting storm. Companies and workers alike are working out early kinks and awaiting new technology, they say.
"It is going to transform the workplace," said John A. Challenger, the chief executive of Challenger, Gray & Christmas, a Chicago outplacement firm. Over the next few years, analysts say, flexible work arrangements will force companies to reassess how they use space and cause more people to take part-time jobs or become independent contractors.
As broadband Internet access begins to enter homes in the next year -- the change AT&T says its telecommuters are waiting for -- the office computer will no longer be so much faster than the home PC. And as the cost of videoconferencing equipment continues to fall, the technology will soon be affordable to many more people.
Demographic forces are playing a role, as well. As the number of baby boomers taking care of elderly parents grows, the ability to stay home will become more attractive. The current tight labor markets, meanwhile, are certainly vulnerable to economic cycles, but they are also a product of population trends that will continue through the first few years of the new decade, forcing employers to look for highly skilled workers wherever they can find them.
Forty-three percent of human resource executives recently polled by Challenger, Gray & Christmas said that telecommuting would be the most important workplace trend of the 21st century -- ranking it higher than any other subject. And while statistics on the subject are notoriously unreliable, most analysts agree that at least 10 million Americans now telecommute regularly, and that number is not expected to fall.
The hiccups of the last few years are not uncommon when new technology is adopted. Such practices often go through three stages, said John Chambers, the chief executive of Cisco Systems, which builds much of the networking behind the Internet. First comes an initial excitement; then skepticism that the trend will truly take off; and, finally, widespread acceptance.
Telecommuting is now moving out of the second of those stages, many workplace experts say.
At the start of the 1990's, telecommuting captured workers' imaginations as a way to hold on to their careers and salaries while removing some of the strain of long weeks at the office.
Managers, for their part, realized it could help them cut down on real estate costs and potentially even improve productivity by making workers happier. Often, however, both sides underestimated the ensuing difficulties.
"Too many companies rushed into telecommuting," said Rick Wald, a principal at the human resource consulting firm William M. Mercer who advises companies on flexible benefits. "It really requires training for managers. They need to manage people differently."
That is precisely the lesson that Merrill Lynch & Company, the brokerage firm, learned, and its response offers a glimpse of what telecommuting could become.
In 1994, it started a pilot program but quickly discovered that neither telecommuters nor their bosses were ready for all the questions that arose: How often should a worker check voice mail? Is day care still necessary? Do telecommuters really work full time?
So two years later Merrill Lynch created an elaborate training program for people who wanted to work at home sometimes, said Janice Miholics, a vice president for alternative work arrangements in the private-client technology group. Employees must write a formal proposal to enter the program. Both they and their bosses then sit through a two-hour training session. Finally, the telecommuters spend their first two weeks in transition, dialing into the office from an on-site laboratory, where they are given a laptop, printer and other equipment to take home.
In Mrs. Miholics' division, 350 of the 1,800 workers now telecommute at least once a week. Only one employee has ever stopped telecommuting for a reason other than a job change, she said. "It's allowed us to retain some critical people who otherwise would have left," she said.
Other companies are learning the same lessons. "We're starting to sift out a lot of the failed programs," said Christena Nippert-Eng, a sociologist at the Illinois Institute of Technology who has studied telecommuting. "The programs that exist now are much better."
The next problem will be deciding what to do with the office when it has fewer people in it, workplace experts said. One solution, called hoteling, involves getting rid of permanent offices and instead assigning full-time workers to a new office or cubicle each day, depending on what is available.
Some of the country's largest consulting firms, where employees are often out of the office on assignment, have adopted hoteling and cut down their real estate costs. But it has failed to catch on elsewhere because employees often find it dehumanizing. "When you play with someone's space, you're playing with 8 to 10 to 12 hours of their day," Robin Szumyk, a principal in William M. Mercer's human resources practice, said.
Consider Lisa Hilbish, an account executive in Charlotte, N.C., for Ceridian Employer Services, which sells payroll software to companies. She works from home about twice each week and said it was a benefit that made her more likely to remain in her job. The one complication, however, is that, when she decides to come into the office on short notice, there are often no desks available, and she must work in a room used for employee breaks.
"It's kind of loud," Mrs. Hilbish said. "You don't get as much done."
In response, some companies are building space for specific departments or teams so that workers can feel at home there, even if they are sharing it with colleagues, said Susan L. Boyle, a managing partner at HLW International, a New York workplace consulting firm.
That, however, does not solve the problem of what to do when everybody shows up on the same day. Such questions will loom over the workplace in the next few years as telecommuting becomes more widespread.
"The technology piece will get itself worked out. The security piece will get itself worked out," Ms. Boyle said. "But there's an emotional piece, too."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 2000: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
Health Care Consumers Can Expect Change, and a Shock or Two

BYLINE: By DAVID J. MORROW

 BODY:
Americans who have complaints about the health care system may soon be in luck -- or maybe not. Many health care professionals expect the medical system in the United States to be overhauled so remarkably during the next two decades that many patients will not be able to recognize it.
While such a notion may excite some consumers -- who hasn't fantasized about the death of health maintenance organizations? -- others will no doubt be riled by new procedures that actually provide less medical care and coverage than before. 
 "The one thing that is sure to happen is a lot of change across the whole health care industry," said Dr. David B. Skinner, the chief executive of the New York Presbyterian Hospital. "A better quality system has started, but it is going to take several decades to develop."
Consumers should brace themselves for a few shocks. Many patient advocates and Democratic representatives in Congress would like a government-sponsored health care system, similar to many of those in Europe. But some health providers -- notably the pharmaceutical companies -- snarl at the mention of more government involvement, given the likelihood of a federally mandated reduction in drug prices.
"The insurance of last resort is the government," said Joseph Zammit-Lucia, the chief executive of Cambridge Pharma Consultancy in New York, which advises drug companies. "But you never know what insurance you may be able to buy in the future."
Even if health care in the United States remains in private hands, change will be dramatic. One of the biggest changes during the next 10 to 20 years is expected to be the increasing role of the patient in choosing his or her treatment. Instead of relying only on their doctors' advice, consumers will also use medical information from the Internet and prescription-drug ad campaigns.
"Currently, health care is professional-driven," Mr. Zammit-Lucia said. "But with the Internet and consumer ad campaigns, I will know about as much about my illness as the doctor does. I'll use him as a professional adviser, similar to how I use a financial planner now."
Patients will also get their medications in new ways. Health experts are confident that drugs will routinely be bought through the Internet, including treatments for serious conditions. Pharmacists, long the prime instructors of how medications should be taken, will dole out more advice in cyberspace, especially as consumers become brand loyal to their health care Web sites.
Medications are also likely to change. Scientists predict that hospital-bound treatments like chemotherapy may eventually be administered as pills that can be taken at home. Patients will also have more choices about how they take their medications, such as through injection, patch, nasal spray or inhaler.
"It's realistic to believe that cancer will become a chronic illness," said Dr. Scot Remick, head of clinical trials at the University Hospitals of Cleveland. "We're not curing all cancers yet, but patients will be able to live longer with a good quality of life."
The increasingly enormous amount of medical knowledge will also change patients' visits to their doctors. Using models of a person's gene structure, scientists will soon be able to tell which infants can be expected to develop certain illnesses -- including some cancers and diabetes -- and what medicines have little risk of side effects.
Doctors say that breakthroughs in genomic technology will allow consumers to know what diseases they are likely to get and what measures to take to prevent them. Yet patient advocates worry that the insurers may use genomic information to deny or limit coverage.
"In a brave new world, it is frighteningly realistic to imagine an insurance industry that knows more than it should about the lifestyle and family history of every American," said Diane Archer, president of the Medicare Rights Center, a consumer advocacy group in New York. "Through health profiling, an insurer can refuse affordable coverage to everyone with a perceived health risk."
Dr. Charles M. Cutler, chief medical officer of the American Association of Health Plans, a trade group representing managed care companies, said that insurers would use genetic information not to deny coverage but to provide better care. He noted that some illnesses can be diagnosed now during pregnancy, but insurers have still provided coverage to these infants.
That's hardly the last of a consumer's worries. During the next 20 years, Americans will have to deal with increasingly large and powerful health care organizations. Almost all of them will demand higher prices.
The consolidation that has swept the drug industry -- with Pfizer and American Home Products battling now to acquire Warner-Lambert, and Zeneca Pharmaceuticals of Britain buying the Swedish drug giant Astra last year -- will continue until there are a handful of companies, each with 10 percent of the global market, double their current share. Only five companies currently have more than a 4 percent share of the worldwide pharmaceutical market, according to I.M.S. Health, an industry consultant. Cambridge Pharma forecasts that, as a result of more costly technology, drug prices will increase to 30 percent of medical expenditures in the United States during the next 20 years from 10 percent at present.
"Consumers are going to have to pay for routine drugs out of their own pockets" as insurers scramble to control costs, predicted Mr. Zammit-Lucia, citing generic painkillers as an example. "What will happen is that insurance will only pay for what is not affordable."
By most accounts, H.M.O.'s will not live long into the next century, but many health care experts are not sure what type of insurance will take their place. Everyone agrees that traditional indemnity plans are history, even though consumers are demanding an unrestricted choice of doctors.
"The problem with managed care is that it became so intrusive in the relationship between patient and doctor," said Dr. Thomas R. Reardon, president of the American Medical Association. "The H.M.O.'s were spending more money than they were saving. We have to find a method to provide appropriate care. But that may not mean all the care the patient wants."
One thing on which health care experts agree is that the insurers of the next two decades will be substantially larger than any of the entities that have preceded them. Several doctors predicted that H.M.O.'s would eventually be replaced by large hospital systems, with local clinics and hospices, that contract with employers to provide medical insurance and treatment.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 2000: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
In the Works: Drugs Tailored to Individual Patients

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

 BODY:
For several years, the big quest in biotechnology has been to determine the complete sequence of human DNA, the genetic code of life. Now, however, that task is nearing completion, and the biotechnology industry is facing an even tougher job -- deciphering that code so that new drugs and diagnostic tests can be developed.
The coming post-sequencing era will bring huge changes to the industry. The causes and mechanisms of various diseases that now defy treatment will become known so that drugs can be developed much more precisely. Drug discovery will rely as much on software and databases of genetic information as it will on test tubes and white mice. 
 Perhaps the most important change could be a shift from the "one drug fits all" approach to treatments tailored to individual patients based on their genetic profiles.
"With the genome being completed, I think we're literally going to move from statistical-based medicine, where we're thinking about entire populations, to personalized medicine," said Kenneth J. Conway, president of Millennium Predictive Medicine, a majority-owned subsidiary of Millennium Pharmaceuticals in Cambridge, Mass. "I think we're going to look back 10 years from now and think of medicine as being in the dark ages."
Of course, many of the predictions made by biotechnology executives in the past proved overly optimistic. Still, as the biotechnology industry nears its 25th birthday in 2001 -- dating from the formation of Genentech in 1976 -- it has finally started to bring to market the promised treasure trove of drugs. Biotechnology companies now have about 300 drugs in advanced stages in clinical trials, according to the Biotechnology Industry Organization, a trade group.
One of the hottest approaches now, for instance, is monoclonal antibodies, which are proteins that can zero in on a disease-causing agent and neutralize it. These were first developed in the 1970's, but only in the last few years have companies succeeded in making effective drugs from them, such as Reopro from Centocor, which fights blood clotting, and Herceptin from Genentech, for breast cancer.
In the next few years, many other antibodies are expected to reach the market, including one from Genentech for asthma and allergies. Imclone Systems is working on one for head and neck cancers. IDEC Pharmaceuticals and Coulter Pharmaceutical are each hoping to sell the first antibodies linked to radioactive isotopes, which would allow radiation to be directed specifically to tumors, with less harm to healthy tissue.
Other drugs besides antibodies, of course, will continue to be developed. One that is expected to be approved soon is Visudyne from QLT Phototherapeutics, which would be the first drug for age-related macular degeneration, a deterioration of the retina that is the leading cause of near blindness in the elderly.
But the biggest opportunities and challenges are expected to come from genomics, the study of the human genetic code. The Human Genome Project, sponsored by the federal government, is expected to finish the "rough draft" of the genome by spring and to be completed in 2003. Private efforts by such companies as Celera Genomics and Incyte Pharmaceuticals are also racing ahead.
The full sequence consists of about three billion chemical bases, amid which are 100,000 or more genes that code for the production of particular proteins, which actually carry out functions in the body. But unless scientists can determine the functions of the genes and proteins and how they work together, the sequence alone is just an enormous overload of information.
"Knowing the gene sequence in many ways tells you where to start looking, but not much more," said James M. Gower, president and chief executive of Rigel Inc., a South San Francisco start-up involved in what many consider the new thing -- functional genomics, which figures out the functions of genes.
A related discipline that could see growth in the next few years is so-called proteomics, which is the study of proteins. And, since the human mind alone cannot keep track of billions of bases and thousands of genes, companies are springing up in the new field of bio-informatics, the melding of computer science and life science.
As the mechanisms of the body are better discovered, biotechnology companies will be better able to develop drugs based on knowledge of how the body functions than by trying random chemicals to see what works.
"The whole drug-discovery business is now a biology-based business and not a chemistry-based business," said Richard A. van den Broek, biotechnology analyst at Hambrecht & Quist, an investment bank. "It's been a chemical business for 50 years."
Progress should be made on diseases for which there is little understanding or treatment, including neurological diseases like Alzheimer's and autoimmune diseases like lupus.
William A. Haseltine, chairman and chief executive of Human Genome Sciences Inc. in Rockville, Md., said genes and growth factors are already starting to be used to grow new blood vessels and, in the more distant future, it will be possible to grow entire new organs.
One approach to trying to determine gene function is to learn which genes are turned on in different types of cells, such as those turned on in cancer cells compared with normal cells. This has opened up opportunities for companies selling tiny chips that can quickly analyze thousands of genes at a time.
Similarly, companies are now racing to figure out genetic differences among people. Differences of a single base -- known as a single nucleotide polymorphism, or SNP (pronounced "snip") -- can determine eye color or make the difference between health and illness.
Such information could lead to personalized and preventive medicine. People found to be susceptible to a disease might take a regimen of pills or change their diet to prevent it. And medicines will be tailored to each individual, a discipline called pharmacogenomics.
"Snips will make a quantum leap toward patient-specific medicine," said G. Steven Burrill, chief executive of Burrill & Company, a San Francisco merchant bank that specializes in biotechnology.
A precursor is Herceptin, the Genentech drug for breast cancer. It works in only 25 percent to 30 percent of cases, those in which the breast tumors produce unusually large amounts of a protein known as Her2. Patients are tested beforehand to see if they qualify.
Millennium plans to introduce a genetic test next year that will predict whether melanoma, a skin cancer, will spread through the body. Patients whose tumors will not spread might be spared chemotherapy or radiation treatment.
Personalized medicine will change the economics of the business, with fewer blockbuster drugs. "There will be a lot of fragmentation in the market," said Jeffrey Casdin, chief executive of Casdin Capital Partners, a biotechnology investment fund. He said, however, that since personalized drugs would be more effective and would have fewer side effects than mass market drugs, they would fetch higher prices.
Genetic profiling of patients raises privacy issues. Should, for instance, a person's susceptibility to a disease be used by insurance companies to raise premiums or by employers in hiring decisions?
That is just one of the ethical and political issues likely to confront the biotechnology industry in the next decade. A huge backlash has already developed against bioengineered crops. There are controversies over cloning and the use of stem cells -- the progenitors of all other cells in the body -- that can come from aborted fetuses or from embryos made in fertility clinics.
Yet another issue could be a budding backlash against rising drug prices, which are commanding an ever-growing percentage of total health care spending. Some drugs offered by biotechnology companies can cost tens of thousands of dollars a year, though companies argue that drugs can save money over all by reducing the need for operations and hospital stays.
Financially, the biotechnology industry enters the new century in modest shape. A severe shortage of financing that plagued the industry a year ago has abated somewhat, but the industry seems to be stratifying into haves and have-nots.
An index maintained by Burrill & Company of stocks of the biggest biotechnology companies, like Amgen and Biogen, the ones with profits and products, has risen more than 120 percent this year. Burrill found that midsize companies, many with products on the horizon, rose more than 70 percent, but stocks of the smallest companies, many in early stages of development, rose, by comparison, only 30 percent.
Private companies are still having trouble raising venture capital or going public. With a biotechnology company typically taking 10 years to show a profit, Internet companies seem like more attractive investments.
A long-predicted consolidation -- through mergers and, in some cases, bankruptcies -- seemed to begin in earnest in 1999, and that is expected to continue.
"We're still dealing with an industry that has too much capacity," said Peter F. Drake, managing director of Prudential Vector Healthcare Group. There are an estimated 300 publicly traded biotechnology companies and about 1,000 private ones.
Some of the acquisitions of biotech companies in 1999 were made by big drug companies. Johnson & Johnson bought Centocor; Merck bought Sibia Neurosciences, and Warner-Lambert acquired Agouron Pharmaceuticals. The drug companies need new products to continue growth and replace products with expiring patents. And tapping into the technology of biotechnology companies looks like one good way to get them.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 2000: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
Rocky Outlook for Genetically Engineered Crops

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Agribusiness leaders are as confident as ever that the need to feed a growing world population makes it both essential and inevitable that biotechnology will play a central role in 21st-century farming. But for now it looks like the industry may be pulled over by consumers and fined by investors for recklessly speeding toward such a future.
Sales of genetically engineered crops soared in 1999, but a sharp slowdown in growth, if not an actual decline, seems likely in 2000, and even industry optimists are saying it may take several years to get rolling again. Crop surpluses, which undermine farmers' willingness to pay for new technology, trade tensions, and antitrust concerns have all contributed to the uncertain outlook. But the biggest jolt to the visions of the multinational giants that dominate agribusiness have come from a surge in consumer fears about the safety of the novel crops. 
 It has made no difference that regulators and major food companies agreed with the industry that there was scant evidence of any significant human health hazard. Nor has it mattered that most researchers contend that critics have wildly exaggerated evidence that biotechnology is likely to create superweeds or widespread destruction of beneficial insects like Monarch butterflies.
Over the last year, governments and the industry's biggest customers began deciding it was better to retreat than to ignore negative public sentiment. The backlash was strongest in Europe, where supermarket chains took foods containing oil from genetically modified corn and soybeans off their shelves, and regulators tabled applications to plant new genetically altered strains of beets and canola despite the opinions of their own science advisers that the crops were safe.
Some of the biggest drug, food and chemical giants have already retreated from the once popular model of becoming "life sciences" companies with strong footings in every sector affected by biotechnology. Early this month, AstraZeneca P.L.C. of Britain and Novartis A.G. of Switzerland, announced plans to spin off and then merge their agricultural businesses into a new company to be called Syngenta. "We went three steps forward in recent years, but we are now taking two steps back," said Sano M. Shimoda, founder of BioScience Securities, a research firm based in Orinda, Calif., that concentrates on agricultural biotechnology. "I don't think we've seen the worst of it yet."
The biggest business beneficiaries of the biotechnology backlash may be the manufacturers of the traditional agrichemicals that have been losing market share and money while battling to slow the move of farmers to new crops that are devised to work best with just one herbicide or, in some cases, to eliminate the need for certain insecticides. Some chemical giants like DuPont, Dow Chemical and Aventis have major commitments to biotechnology as well, but others, like the struggling American Cyanamid pesticides business of American Home Products, have little to lose from a setback for biotechnology.
One development many foresee for next year is the adoption in many countries -- perhaps even the United States -- of labeling standards for food containing genetically modified products. Opponents of biotechnology predict confidently that labels will lead to widespread rejection of modified products, pointing to recent experience in Europe, where retailers have raced to advertise "G.M.O.-free" products, referring to genetically modified organisms.
But analysts say that outcome depends largely on whether both kinds of products remain on the shelves, and the level of fears about health hazards and pricing. In the United States, they point out, milk produced from cows that have not been injected with Posilac, a bovine growth hormone that Monsanto produces in bacteria, is labeled, but it is usually premium-priced and only a very small percentage of consumers seek it out. Monsanto said that Posilac sales expanded 20 percent this year and that its new production plant under construction in Georgia was expected to begin producing the hormone by the end of next year.
Barring stronger evidence that biotechnology poses major new hazards, analysts and the industry's major players believe that any slowdown or decline this coming year is likely to be reversed. The underlying forces that had made agricultural biotechnology such a hit on Wall Street as recently as last year continue to gather strength. The world's population passed six billion and, although the growth rate is slowing, the demand for rice, wheat and corn, the three mostly widely planted grains, is projected by the International Food Policy Research Institute in Washington to increase 40 percent by 2020.
With the acreage of arable land basically unchanged over the last 30 years, there is increasing pressure to use biotechnology to make agriculture more productive. And researchers continue to expand markedly the industry's tools and potential.
Thomas C. Humphrey, president of DuPont's nutrition and health businesses, notes that public and private money is pouring into research on human, animal and plant genetics and into study of their interaction with the environment. "When all that starts to intersect in two or three years, it's going to be incredible," he said.
The most recent breakthrough was a project to alter rice so that it would produce the protein necessary to create vitamin A in its grain. That development is estimated to be five years from commercialization, but it was widely hailed in developing nations as a way to help prevent the deaths of up to three million children annually and eliminate millions of cases of blindness.
"The main risk is that we keep talking and don't move ahead," said Per Pinstrup-Andersen, director general of the International Food Policy Research Institute.
"If we create biotech options, farmers will take them if they like it," Mr. Pinstrup-Andersen added.
That sounds logical enough, but one hot question is whether farmers actually have much choice. Industry critics contend that the new technology has become so concentrated in the hands of powerful multinationals that they have the marketing influence with international aid agencies to force some products on farmers.
Critics also say that blown pollen can transfer traits from genetically modified crops to the fields of organic farmers and others that want nothing to do with the technology. They are pressing for much stronger regulation and a very broad interpretation of what kinds of effects might be classified as damages for which corporate sponsors of biotechnology could be sued.
The groundswell of public fears and opposition came too late to have much impact on what was planted this year, but farmers are watching the futures markets for signals about what seed to buy this winter. With a growing number staring at bankruptcy after two years of bumper crops and low prices, farmers are worried about paying higher prices for genetically modified seed and then finding the next harvest difficult to sell because of opposition to such crops.
Monsanto has the most to lose from such fears, especially in soybeans. Nearly half of the United States soybean crop this year was modified to tolerate spraying with Roundup, the company's best-selling weed killer. Analysts predict market declines in the United States for both the modified beans and the company's modified corn (farmers say the latter's ability to generate a pesticide was not worth the cost in many areas this year because of low insect populations). Monsanto says it remains somewhat optimistic that the market for both will continue to grow both at home and abroad, according to Hugh Grant, co-president of the company's agricultural business.
One key to the year will be Brazil, where approval of Roundup-Ready soybeans has been recommended by the Government but tied up in court. Biotechnology critics say that thanks to the ban, Brazil will have higher exports to Europe, but the real world may not provide a clear test. Reports suggest that anywhere from 5 percent to 15 percent of the Brazilian crop planted this fall has been grown from Roundup-Ready seed smuggled in from Argentina, where the crop is legal and very popular with farmers.
Such percentages could make it too expensive for Brazil to certify its crops as free from modification, since crops from many farms get mixed together during shipment.
For biotechnology backers, such complications are just one more reason to believe that the past year's turmoil will not derail the industry for long. Safety fears may slow growth, they say, but each year will bring new products that make farming easier or consumer products more appealing.
"The genie is out of the bottle with regard to the technology," said Michael Phillips, executive director for food and agriculture of the Biotechnology Industry Organization, a Washington trade group.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 2000: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
Auto Dealers Streamline Operations To Meet the Challenge of the Internet

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: JACKSON, Mich.

 BODY:
When a customer calls Extreme Dodge here, the dealership's caller identification system instantly brings up on a sales representative's computer screen the customer's sales and service record, along with a photo of the customer and her vehicle. For new buyers, sales or finance managers are no longer required to approve each deal, so a sales representative can negotiate a price and arrange a car loan and insurance in just 45 minutes, in contrast to several hours at many dealerships.
Otherwise, much remains the same here as at dealerships across the country. Most customers come in and test-drive the cars before buying one. The prices, although close to factory invoice, are still subject to some negotiation. The dealer, Wesley L. Lutz, is active in the community and tries to sell cars to his friends. And the dealership is sometimes short of popular sport utility vehicles and clogged with unpopular cars, as factories hundreds of miles away keep cranking out whatever their assembly lines are designed to produce, with limited ability to respond swiftly to shifts in market demand. 
 Extreme Dodge is cited by some auto dealers as an example of the industry's future: a computer-using, family-owned business with a lean staff that has earned DaimlerChrysler's top rating of five stars for customer satisfaction. But whether Extreme Dodge really represents the future, or simply a modern version of a century-old way of doing business, is hotly debated within the auto industry. As executives try to envision what automobiles and the auto industry will look like in 2010, the buying process absorbs much of their attention because of rapid changes that are already beginning to take place.
Some industry executives, particularly at the General Motors Corporation and to some extent at the Ford Motor Company, say that many customers no longer have time to visit dealerships or even take test-drives. They contend that in the next few years, millions of Americans will start ordering new cars on the Internet, with a dealer simply showing up at the buyer's home or office to drop off the new vehicle and fill out the paperwork -- and even the paperwork will eventually disappear, too. A decade from now, these executives predict, customers will choose their vehicles on the Internet, specifying options and paint color, submit an electronic order straight to the factory and take delivery in a couple of weeks.
Such predictions are increasingly popular in Detroit, even though the percentage of Internet purchases now is very small. "While today it's less than 1 percent, in 10 years it'll rise to 40 percent, 50 percent; it's going up geometrically," said Mark Hogan, G.M.'s group vice president for electronic commerce.
Some of the most prominent industry analysts share this view. "Consumers will get their information from the Internet, not a salesperson; the salesperson will be just an order taker," said J. David Power III, founder of the J. D. Power & Associates consulting firm.
Yet in Torrance, Calif., where the big Japanese automakers have their North American sales headquarters, a very different vision of the future is taking shape, a future that looks a lot like Extreme Dodge looks today. These executives say that while customers may increasingly check invoice prices and features on the Internet, they will always want to test- drive cars before buying them, and many customers will want to know the dealer or salesman who sells them the car.
James Press, executive vice president for North American sales of the Toyota Motor Corporation, said that the best way to see what a dealership would look like in 2010, is to visit an up-to-date dealership today. "In many ways, it won't be a lot different; the more things change, the more they'll stay the same," he said. "We'll still have people; you'll have relationships; you'll have a place to test-drive a car and a place to have it serviced."
DaimlerChrysler executives tend to agree with the managers at their Japanese competitors rather than with their crosstown rivals in Detroit. They question the feasibility of building huge numbers of cars one at a time, much less delivering them quickly, and they wonder whether customers will be willing to wait once they decide on a model.
The typical customer remains emotional, even impetuous, about car purchases, despite the cost involved, said James Holden, the president of DaimlerChrysler's former Chrysler operations. "Once they see it, touch it, feel it, they want it right then," he said.
DaimlerChrysler has created elaborate Web sites for its divisions, but these sites are mainly to provide information and steer customers to their nearest dealership to make purchases.
While there is an industry consensus that customers will rely more on the Internet in the years ahead to gather information about automobiles, nobody knows for sure what those vehicles will look like. Most auto engineers do predict, however, that ever more vehicles will look like combinations of minivans, sport utility vehicles and cars, and will be assembled like cars rather than pickup trucks to improve safety.
Tom Davis, G.M.'s head of global vehicle engineering, said that today's bulky four-wheel-drive systems, which are designed to let motorists extract themselves from swamps or deep snow, are likely to be replaced on many vehicles with lighter, less expensive all-wheel-drive systems. All-wheel-drive systems, which typically do not have so-called transfer cases with very low gears, are just as effective as four-wheel drives for accelerating on slippery roads, although neither helps for braking.
Environmentalists have called for increased use of hybrid engines that rely partly on electricity and partly on gasoline or methanol. Indeed, Honda and Toyota plan to introduce small cars with such systems next year. But in a report in November, the Energy Information Administration predicted that 14.3 million automobiles would be sold in 2010, but only 560,000, or 4 percent, would be hybrids.
Fuel cells, an even cleaner technology that involves combining hydrogen and oxygen to produce power, will propel only 2,000 or so automobiles sold in 2010, said David Chien, the agency's transportation forecasting team leader. "They'll start making a dent around 2015," he said, adding that automakers were leery of damaging any new technology's reputation by offering it before it had been perfected. "They really don't want to put something out early and blow it."
As hybrid engines and eventually fuel cells do come onto the market, customers are likely to want to test them before buying. Indeed, while Mr. Power predicts that many customers will be willing to buy cars over the Internet someday, his company's research shows that 76 percent of new-car buyers had test-driven automobiles at the dealership where they eventually bought them, down insignificantly from 79 percent in 1996. Many other buyers test-drive a model at one dealership before buying it at another.
Such research heartens dealers like Mr. Lutz, the owner of Extreme Dodge here, 80 miles west of Detroit. By relying heavily on computers, he has cut his sales staff by more than half in the last three years, lowering his costs so he can compete more aggressively with other dealers on price.
But he also contends that, while millions of Americans may now be willing to buy shirts, books and toys over the Internet, they will remain leery of buying $20,000 cars or $30,000 sport utility vehicles that way. He and other dealers here continue to join the boards of community groups and lend used cars free to school athletic teams for out-of-town trips.
"People reciprocate," Mr. Lutz said, "and buy cars from us."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 2000: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
The Real Retail Revolution: It's Wal-Mart, Not the Net

BYLINE: By LESLIE KAUFMAN

 BODY:
The trend that is driving so much change in retailing at the dawn of the new century is as obvious to spot as a Mack truck bearing down on your rear bumper.
It is, of course, the Internet. If you believe the hype, the Internet -- which will generate an estimated $20 billion in United States sales this year and is expected to grow by 200 percent to 300 percent a year -- promises nothing short of a revolution that will change how Americans shop forever. 
 Even so, it is not the biggest challenge on the retail highway.
The changes remaking retailing come not only in the medium shoppers use to make their purchases, but in what they expect their dollars to buy -- which is a lot more than they did even five years ago. In the end, it is less the Internet that is transforming traditional retailing as this century closes, than one giant discounter: Wal-Mart Stores.
Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer -- famous for wringing every excess penny out of product cost -- is expected to report nearly $143 billion in domestic revenue for fiscal 1999, which will end Jan. 31. That is roughly 7 percent of the United States retail market, according to Jeffrey Feiner, an analyst at Lehman Brothers, and seven times all Internet sales combined for this year, as estimated by Forrester Research, the Boston digital consulting firm.
Online retail sales will reach $184 billion in 2004, Forrester predicts, edging closer but still not catching Wal-Mart, which by that year should have $243 billion in revenue domestically, according to Mr. Feiner. He even predicts that Wal-Mart, which sells everything from fresh lettuce to power tools, will produce $1 trillion in revenue worldwide by 2015.
Wal-Mart is, of course, emblematic of a new kind of retailer. Not long ago, consumers on a tight budget expected to sacrifice quality for cost, generally finding mediocre goods in drab environs at the discount chains. But then the discounters remade themselves by offering fashion, brands and great merchandising, all at prices lower than those that rivals, either department stores or independents, could match.
Consider the real revolution: Kmart now offers Martha Stewart 200-thread-count sheets in colors like pewter and eggshell; Target, a unit of Dayton Hudson, has au courant fashion like embroidered jeans and little beaded black purses, and Ikea will customize maple kitchen cabinets.
Consumers of all income levels have quickly become addicted to the new equation of quality and value, and they are handing over market share to chains that provide both -- a trend that is likely to continue. Not only are stock analysts predicting that Wal-Mart will experience staggering growth, but chains like Target, Home Depot, Costco and Kohl's are all expected to expand rapidly, eating up ever-larger chunks of the $2 trillion Americans spend on retail annually.
And it is not just that today's winning merchants will continue to dominate the land masses; it is expected they will use their formidable buying power and brand names to conquer cyberspace as well. Only a year ago, the e-retailers that ran nothing but virtual stores -- like Amazon and Etoys -- were crowing about how their land-based cousins were dinosaurs bound for extinction. Since then, mass merchants -- discounters and specialty stores like Gap Inc. -- have shown the draw of a household name in cyberspace and in some cases catapulted in front of their virtual brethren in Web sales.
Analysts who once predicted that all the online shoppers would flock to the first Web entry into any category of merchandise, like books, now accept that a retailer's tortoise-like thoroughness in the race into cyberspace is not necessarily a bad thing if the company has the financing to outlast early rivals. Wal-Mart, for instance, will not even have introduced its new Web site by this Christmas, but no one is counting it out as an e-retailer in the year 2010.
"Wal-Mart will challenge Amazon for worldwide e-retailing dominance by the year 2005," Burt Flickinger, managing director of Reach Marketing, in Westport, Conn., predicted. "Ultimately, the land-based retailers of size will be able to inflict real pain on their Internet competitors."
This is not to say that some Web-born businesses will not blossom and that the Internet, no matter who is succeeding there, will not have its effects on bricks-and-mortar retailers. It will force them to be better, to entertain, to attract business or to offer a point of view.
"Stores are going to have to be consumers' editors; they have to make big statements on 'this is the fashion,' " Richard Baum, an analyst at CS First Boston, said. "If you go into the store, you will have to know what they think you should be wearing." Already, retailers like American Eagle Outfitters and Ann Taylor excel in such opinionated retail.
Another trend that will intensify as the Internet grows stronger is shopping as family entertainment. Malls across America are putting in entertainment features like Hard Rock Cafes and 20-screen cinemas as fast as they can. But that is just the start.
"People will use shopping as an escape from the technology that will consume their lives," said Laurence C. Siegel, chairman and chief executive of the Mills Corporation, a Virginia-based mall developer that is expanding rapidly. Mr. Siegel is placing big bets on gated attractions to rival the cultural and entertainment venues of the great cities -- Mills, for instance, is exploring partnerships that would let it build concert halls and museums. He sees a future of malls that offer Broadway shows and have community gardens on their rooftops.
While those are pretty grand visions, Mr. Siegel has one even more radical. "Everyone in my business perceives the Internet as a rival," he said. "In five years, the two will be married. The experience of being on the Internet is going to land in the shopping center." He goes on to predict a world of Internet retailers that have actual stores on the concourse that sell actual goods (very pre-Internet). He even forecast the currently unimaginable: "EBay and Amazon are going to have presences in the mall."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 2000: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY: TALKING THE FUTURE WITH: John S. Reed;
The A.T.M. Prophet Is a Late Convert to the Internet

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN

 BODY:
As a young Citicorp executive more than 20 years ago, John S. Reed earned a reputation as a technology guru for his stubborn insistence that automated teller machines -- faceless boxes that spit out money -- would eventually make legions of human bank tellers unnecessary.
After the bank initially lost millions of dollars on his A.T.M. bet, Mr. Reed was vindicated: the gizmos are now as common as corner newsstands. And empty teller windows at many banks attest to the fate of the machines' human counterparts. 
 Mr. Reed is now co-chief executive of Citigroup, the country's largest financial services concern and the creation of last year's merger of Citicorp and Travelers Group. But for all his interest in technology, Mr. Reed admits that the impact and importance of the Internet escaped his attention until recently.
The Internet has now snared the attention of everyone in the banking industry. Companies are rushing to create Internet banking capabilities, either as part of the bank, as in Citigroup's case, or as an entirely separate entity. While no clear leaders have emerged among the banks, Wells Fargo and Bank One have been particularly aggressive competitors.
Mr. Reed said that tackling the challenges of the Internet was now a high priority at Citigroup. Indeed, a job reshuffling in July put Mr. Reed in charge of Citigroup's Internet strategy, while Citigroup's other co-chief executive, Sanford I. Weill, retains most of the other operational duties at the company.
In an interview at his Midtown Manhattan office, Mr. Reed shared his thoughts about the Internet, online financial services and the future of banking.
Following are excerpts from that conversation:
Mr. Reed. -- First of all, this is a revolution. I believe we are living through a sea change. In the next few years, a lot of customers are going to be dealing with their finances over the Internet. Today, about 25 percent of the U.S. population is on the Internet; 75 percent is not. It is growing rapidly. Around the world the numbers are different, but, still, the growth is significant.
Q. -- What regions around the world are growing fastest in Internet usage?
A. -- Japan, Brazil, Singapore are hot spots. The problem right now is, No. 1, the terrestrial competition is pretty good. Sitting down and paying bills with a check, having a checking account and cash machines is pretty easy. So in order to have the Internet be attractive, it has to be better than things that are already pretty effective and efficient.
One of the things that will make a significant difference over time is pricing. Pricing on the Internet will be significantly cheaper. You pay more for terrestrial banking services because of the cost of operating a branch network. The Internet world won't have those costs and, therefore, should be priced more attractively. We need to be able to translate those cost savings to the customer.
Also, there is a difference between being "on the Net" and "of the Net." "On the Net" means someone comes on, they find us, and they find what they're looking for. "Of the Net" means we're embedded in someone else's offering.
Q. -- Why has online stock trading taken off so much more rapidly than online banking?
A. -- If you're happy writing checks and dealing with your bank in the normal way, there is not tremendous motivation to get you onto the Internet. I think one thing that is causing banks to be slow compared to brokers is that banking is a much more complex relationship. In Japan, 20 percent of our customers are coming to us through the Internet or by phone. When they sign up, we send them the forms and they sign. They never see a branch; they never deal with us physically.
The main reason they deal with us is they are looking for the products we offer that are not available from their local Japanese banks. For whatever reason, they are electronically comfortable, and they come in and deal with us. It is an important part of our growth. I think here in the States it will come in time, but it will come when there is a clear price advantage.
We should be able to pay people a lot more for their money. I think we are going to develop a set of people who deal with us differently. They are going to deal with us over the Internet and with cash machines and they will never see a branch. They won't care about a branch. Then the question will be, why did they choose us, and it's going to have to be some sense of "O.K.-ness" with who we are and some degree of the quality of service of the interaction.
I believe that this notion of community is very important in the electronic world. I think the bank will have to establish some kind of community feel. The customer has to enjoy interacting with us, feel good about interacting with us. We are going to have to do a lot of experimenting as to what constitutes that kind of community. Advice is going to turn out to be one of the key issues. I think to a much greater degree than we recognize, people come into the branches of banks because they want to talk to people. That dialogue gives them a sense of how they should manage their lives.
Q. -- Do you think that is broken up demographically -- that younger people may be willing to find their advice in a medium like the Net rather than rely on an adviser in a branch?
A. -- I think that is true. I just don't have the data to support it. I have a feeling most of us are quite ignorant about finance. It's amazing to me -- I have friends who are professors at famous universities who are absolutely naive with regard to money. That's because there isn't any part of the normal education process that teaches you, unless you're raised in a family where your parents talked to you about these things. It's just not a subject you run into.
So I would guess that half of the people who run into difficulties with a credit card never learned the fundamental disciplines of a budget. And it doesn't make any difference how much money you have, whether it's a lot of money or a little money. Actually people with a little money tend to learn a lot more quickly because they get forced by the world to learn how to manage their resources. The good news is I have a feeling that, 30 to 45 years from now, we will have a much better-educated public.
Q. -- Are these things getting increasingly commodified as the consumer is getting more educated?
A. -- If somebody arrived from Mars and you put a Ford and Chevy in front of them, I think they would have a hard time deciding what the difference is. The point is, a car is a car is a car, and big differences are really quite subtle. So from the perspective of a Martian, let's face it, most banks aren't all that different.
Q. -- Will the differences matter in the future?
A. -- It will matter, but we need to form these communities, and we are going to have to be warm and fuzzy and meaningful. Yes, there will be subtle differences with presentation and style and so forth. I was talking to Bob Pitman from America Online. He estimates that 80 percent of the people on the Net are looking for convenience and 20 percent are looking for price. So a feeling of convenience is going to be important. Someone has to know who you are, who they are taking money from and so forth. It isn't as though you can just go in and buy a share of stock with anyone -- you have to set up a relationship. And once you set up the relationship, the likelihood is you'll stick with it. But it is all open space right now.
Q. -- Do you worry about Quicken or AOL getting between you and your customers?
A. -- Yes. I do believe that it will be a revolution. Like all revolutions it will be very easy to get lost. We have not figured it out. You can see the P/E's of these Internet companies, and you say to yourself, "You know what? What the market is saying to you is, 'If you can get your business into the Internet space, it is more valuable.' "
Why is it more valuable? Because your cost of acquiring customers is very small compared to terrestrial stuff. Your cost in serving a customer is almost negligible. If you do want to play, you have to confront the question of "O.K., how do I operate in this space? How do I get from here to there?"
I just spent an extended period meeting with Internet companies. I was probing to see what sort of inner contradictions there were that might bring this all to a screeching halt. I was trying to figure out if this thing is really going anywhere. And I believe it is. Maybe 20 percent of the G.N.P. is highly susceptible to disintermediation by the Internet. That's a lot of money. This will be profound.
Q. -- Who do you worry about the most?
A. -- I don't worry about anybody. The challenge is ours. I admire -- and that's a little different from worry -- AOL. AOL is clearly predominant. I have been in business for a very long time, and there are very few instances where people start from zero and end up with 20 million customers. And they have done precisely that. We did that with our credit cards. Maybe -- and I don't know the facts here -- our friends at Fidelity did that with mutual funds. This idea of being able to gain customers at that speed is more noteworthy than people think.
I am a revolutionary, as you may know, and anytime you give me a fork in the road where the choice is a slow change or a revolution, I will always take the revolution. I am a great believer that that is how changes take place. The Internet is real. It is fundamental. And it is a young person's game.
Q. -- As a manager of this, what are the questions you are not seeing answered that you would like to see answered, or issues explored that are not being explored?
A. -- From my point of view, we have to figure out fundamental economics. We have to worry a lot about privacy, how to treat customers. And we have to get working on some of these expert systems and selling and so forth and so on. We bring some specific knowledge of how our business works, and we are going to have to let people who know a little bit more about the Internet worry about how to do the software.
I don't think this is going to be fun and games. It's going to be quite a big change in the next 10 to 15 years.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 2000: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
Goodbye Cold Calling; Hello Cross-Selling

BYLINE: By PATRICK McGEEHAN

 BODY:
If families continue to sit down together for dinner in the 21st century, they should be able to enjoy their meals with fewer interruptions.
The stream of unsolicited phone calls from sales people and stockbrokers pitching everything from stock tips to credit card insurance should ebb as financial services companies develop more sophisticated ways of selling their products and services, industry executives and consultants say. They see the dreaded "cold call" being replaced with the new industry buzzword, the "cross sell" of services to people who are already customers of another business of a company. 
 In the wake of the historic changes made by Congress this year in laws that separated commercial banks, investment banks and insurance companies, a wave of consolidation is expected among financial services companies, creating more conglomerates like Citigroup, the first company in the United States to combine an insurer with a commercial bank, an investment bank and a securities brokerage firm, the experts say.
"If history and the experiences in other countries are a guide, the structural changes that will follow will be of great significance," said Jerome Kenney, an executive vice president who plots corporate strategy for Merrill Lynch & Company. "Our own internal forecast is, if you go out five years, there will be very few independent securities firms."
Only the biggest firms on Wall Street, like Merrill, Goldman Sachs Group and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company, will be able to avoid being gobbled up by commercial banks and insurance companies, industry analysts predict.
Most small and midsize brokerage firms, especially Internet-based trading firms that are competing on price, will be acquired or will fail, said James Punishill, an online financial services analyst at Forrester Research in Boston. Electronic trading with low commissions will remain commonplace, as it has become in the last several years, but it will not be profitable enough to sustain a big business, analysts say.
The new conglomerates that are expected to compete with Citigroup will look more like what Europeans call universal banks, Deutsche Bank of Germany or UBS of Switzerland, for example. They will provide the full spectrum of financial products and services under one roof, or in the case of Citigroup, under one red umbrella.
But once companies pay huge sums to acquire the heft needed to remain competitive in a global market, they will face the challenge of making those acquisitions pay off by selling more products and more types of products to their growing lists of customers, and they will do so in a market that is being redefined by the Internet.
So far, the track record of cross-selling financial services is spotty, at best, and the growth of the Internet adds to the challenge, as new competitors spring up all over the World Wide Web, offering bargain prices.
Some are well-disguised units of traditional players, like Wingspanbank.com, an online bank created by the Bank One Corporation. Bank One's management has taken pains to hide the connection, hoping to lure customers with higher rates on certificates of deposit without cannibalizing the bank's existing business. That strategy is not a proven winner yet, but online banking is just starting to catch on and analysts expect its use to increase rapidly as more online banks appear and customers of traditional banks switch over to the Internet.
Widespread acceptance of the Internet as a medium for researching and shopping for financial services has complicated efforts to cross-sell. Consumers no longer need to rely on banks and brokers for information about financial services and prices.
Insurance companies have succeeded at cross-selling different types of insurance by offering package deals, like selling auto insurance at attractive rates to customers who also buy a homeowner's policy. Citigroup and Merrill also claim to have had success in selling home loans to customers of their brokerage units. But, over all, there is no convincing evidence that people want to keep all their assets in one place or to buy a wide variety of financial products from a single source.
"A lot of these big deals will fail ultimately because they're not generating the top-line growth," said Peter Davis, a financial services consultant with Cambridge Group in Manhattan.
"They have to start cross-selling, and that cross-selling has to occur around an understanding of their customers. Cold calls and statement stuffers won't cut it."
For examples, Mr. Davis pointed to the comparative records of banks that are the products of one or more mergers and those that are not. Both types of banks, he said, sell about 2.1 products, like certificates of deposit, per customer. "There really is no difference in performance," he said.
Once a merged organization cuts out overlapping costs, the only way to make a merger pay off is to increase revenue. So inevitably conglomerates will seek to do so by trying to get their customers to buy more from them or invest more with them.
The problem is that consumers have easy access to lots of information -- some would say, too much -- about purveyors of financial services, their prices and offerings. In the future, they will be more likely to shop around, mostly online, before buying investing or borrowing money and will be less susceptible to unsolicited sales pitches of any kind.
Wall Street is already adapting to the new times. Merrill Lynch; Salomon Smith Barney; Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and other big brokerage firms are turning their sales forces away from stock promotion and toward money management. Most firms are concentrating their sales efforts on omnibus accounts that charge an annual fee based on an account's assets, instead of on the number of transactions executed.
In theory, the rise of the fee-based brokerage account will allow the brokers to focus their attention on finding new clients and providing them with advice about how to meet their financial goals. The switch should also make the earnings of brokerage firms more predictable and make their stocks more attractive to investors.
"The traditional broker, we think, is a thing of the past," said Ruediger Adolf, senior vice president at the American Express Company. "The way you can add value, in our belief, is through understanding the goals of an individual customer in a holistic way and developing strategies of how they can get there."
American Express and other financial services companies have accepted that a significant number of investors, not just young people with relatively few assets, want to handle at least some of their financial dealings themselves. Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley and others have introduced online trading services, with commissions as low as $29.95, to appeal to those people.
That is the same basic price that Charles Schwab charges, but considerably higher than E*trade's low rate of $9.95. American Express undercut them all when it recently started offering free stock trades to customers with big account balances.
Analysts see those moves as an acknowledgment that the execution of stock trades, once a core offering on Wall Street, is fast becoming a commodity. In essence, brokerage firms are saying, "Let us manage your money for a fee, and we'll throw in the stock and bond trades."
Forrester Research predicts that after the price war that is raging among dozens of online brokerage firms, about 75 percent of them will either be acquired or fail within five years. Now that the most aggressive traders have migrated to the Internet, online brokerage firms are all expected to suffer a significant decline in growth, although overall growth of online financial services will accelerate, Forrester predicts.
Mr. Davis says the execution of simple stock trades is just one of many financial services that can be carried out electronically and yield only slim profits; others are basic term life insurance and the brokering of standard home mortgages. Consequently, he said, the livelihoods of thousands of people who now sell those services are threatened by the Internet.
"Most existing players in personal financial services won't be successful online," Mr. Davis said, citing their expensive networks of offices and salespeople.
Brokerage firms have taken to the Internet largely as a defensive measure. They found they were losing too much of their customers' money to firms that offered electronic trading, such as Charles Schwab, E*trade and Fidelity Investments. John L. Steffens, a Merrill Lynch vice chairman, told Merrill brokers recently that customers had moved $9 billion to eight leading online brokers.
"The big thing becomes choice," Mr. Kenney, of Merrill, said. "What had heretofore been a bundled product until Schwab came along is going to be unbundled and offered in multiple forms."
Mr. Kenney said that wealthy people would continue to demand the personal attention of an adviser, or team of advisers, but they would expect many transactions, such as the paying of monthly bills, to be handled automatically. In exchange for a fee that amounts to a slim percentage of the assets they keep at the firm, they will expect sound advice and guidance delivered electronically, over the telephone and, occasionally, in person, he said.
Other customers will purchase one or more of the firm's services a la carte, paying only for research on certain industries or advice on how to allocate their assets. But firms will offer the best value to people who keep at least $100,000 in a fee-based account.
"That is the cutoff everybody is using, and they're not raising the amount," Mr. Kenney said. "Five years from now, it's still going to be $100,000. For a middle-class income plus some assets, there's going to be an extraordinary amount of services available from the best firms for a reasonable amount."

SECTION: Section C; Page 19; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1223 words

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 2000: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
The Airline Industry May Get a Little Smaller So It Can Get Bigger

BYLINE: By MATTHEW WALD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The next generation of airplanes will be bigger, faster, higher-flying and more comfortable.
But some will also be smaller and might fly at about the same altitude and speed and with the same comfort as airplanes have for the last 20 years. 
 Aviation, which enters its second century in 2003, is still far from a mature industry, and for the next decade it seems likely to move in two directions at once.
One of those is gigantism, a trend that has persisted through 40 years of the jet age, prompted by a belief in economies of scale. Analysts say, however, that it is nearly played out; the only new design still on the drawing board is the Airbus A3XX, which will have about 650 seats on two levels in one configuration and 550 seats, with beds and exercise rooms, in another.
In addition, the ubiquitous Boeing 747, which began flying in 1969 and has from 400 to 550 seats, no longer dominates the skies. The big markets, like the New York-to-London route, that traditionally support the big planes have been hit with competition from smaller planes, like 757's and 767's, flying less heavily traveled routes, say, Pittsburgh to Birmingham, England.
That is the other trend, the movement toward efficient smaller planes for smaller markets, and it might be hitting domestic routes as well; trips that once supported a flight or two a day by a full-sized jetliner that had 130 seats or so are now served by three or four flights of "regional jets" that carry 50 or 70 passengers. The strategy behind the big planes was to sell a few seats at top dollar and give away the rest at anything above cost since an empty seat gives an airline no revenue at all. But some analysts think more airlines will begin making a profit by leaving those seats on the ground and flying a smaller plane with passengers who pay higher fares, ignoring the other travelers, whom airline experts sometimes refer to, slightly condescendingly, as "backpackers."
"Sometimes, less is more," said George W. Hamlin, senior vice president of Global Aviation Associates, a consulting firm here, and an advocate of smaller planes. On a typical medium-haul domestic flight, he said, half the revenue comes from about 20 percent of the passengers, and an airline that could fly only that group would do very well indeed. Already, some new "regional jets" fly long hauls like Chicago to Baltimore; Cincinnati to Bangor, Me.; or Washington to Fort Myers, Fla.
At WP Securities, Wolfgang Demisch, a longtime expert on the economics of aircraft manufacturing, said that with regional jets, "one of the neat things when you have small airplanes that fly direct is you get increased passenger convenience, and you can probably get improved pricing for it."
"The customer," he said, "gets to save time and frequently can do in one jump what might otherwise take two or three."
He called it "the evolution away from mainframe flying, toward almost personal service-type flying."
Boeing rejects the idea that bigger is more costly. Doubling the number of seats does not come close to doubling costs, said Joseph W. Ozimek, Boeing's director for commercial airplane product marketing. "If you fill the airplane the day you bought it, you've bought the wrong airplane," he said. Besides, he said, thousands of airplanes would saturate the air traffic control system; eventually, planes will have to get bigger.
Boeing's approach is to build new big jets that are slightly less than gigantic; it hopes, for example, that the stretch version of its 777 that it is building will be the market's replacement for old 747's.
Big or small, some planes will have a lot more creature comforts. A variety of experts say that JetBlue Airways, a new line that will start operations early in 2000 from Kennedy International Airport in New York, may set the pace. Beginning with Airbus's 162-seat A320's, its planes will have 24-channel live satellite television at each seat. The planes will have a seat pitch, or space between seats, of 32 inches, an inch or two more than the average, and a width of 18.5 inches, an inch more than average. The overhead bins are 80 inches wide instead of 60, recognizing the penchant of business travelers for carrying their bags on board. The airline, which aims to serve markets that the big carriers have not served well, says bin space is about one-quarter greater than on a 737.
Boeing stresses that the 777 has slightly wider seats and aisles than its older planes. Seat pitch is an airline decision, not a decision of Airbus or Boeing, but some analysts see signs that the airlines are beginning to compete on that basis, reversing the trend of minimizing costs, and comforts, too, that began with deregulation in 1978.
The ability to build new and better planes presumes continued health for the industry. For the time being, traffic is galloping ahead, at 643 million passengers in this country last year (although many of them are counted twice as they change planes) and is expected to reach one billion by 2010; as a whole, the industry is profitable. But the government has not been good, historically, at predicting wars and fuel price increases, the two factors that can cut traffic.
But over all, in contrast to certain past decades, the future looks rather boring, a lot like the present. The idea of new supersonic transport planes is dead, at least for the next 5 to 10 years; airlines took options on 70 Concordes in the 1960's but eventually canceled all but 13 of them, and no one sees a market to build more in the near future. The plane is now a quarter-century old. Newer models may fly only marginally faster, say, 85 percent of the speed of sound instead of 80.
There are no futuristic designs, like giant flying-wing planes with no fuselage, on the drawing boards either. For the foreseeable future, passenger planes will have long, cylindrical fuselages sitting atop a single pair of wings, most with engines under the wings, a few with engines attached to the rear of the fuselage, the layouts that were established by the Boeing 720 and 707, which first flew in the early 1950's, and the 727, which entered service in 1965.
"There are no radical planes in the near future," said David Napier, the research director at the Aerospace Industries Association. "They're stretching planes, they're making slightly different models," he said of the airframe builders, "but they're not extreme."
Strikingly, only one plane now in design is not a derivative of something already flying, and that is Airbus's A3XX. (In the airplane construction business, the "X" designates a model whose design is not yet complete.) Airbus has said the plane will cost $11 billion to $12 billion to develop. Earlier this month, the board of the Airbus consortium reiterated that it anticipated that the plane would enter service in 2005 but it postponed several crucial decisions, including where the plane will be built. Boeing officials say Airbus is reducing its estimates for the size of the market for the jumbo airplane.
Darryl Jenkins, an aviation consultant, said, "the planes that we're going to be using for the next 30 years have already been designed, and most of them have been ordered. We basically know what the planes will look like out to 2030; they won't look any different from the ones we have now."
