SECTION: Section C; Page 30; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1657 words

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 2000: MARKETS & INVESTING;
Trading Will Evolve With or Without Wall Street

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
Late one evening, sometime early in the next century, you settle into your lumbar-support leather recliner and tell your wireless voice-activated computer to sign you on to eBay, where you enter the spirited bidding for an antique Nokia cellular telephone, a slightly foxed first edition of "Bridget Jones's Diary" -- and 10,000 shares of United Parcel Service.
Far-fetched? Maybe. But electronic technology is having such an immediate impact on American financial markets that a team of analysts at Lehman Brothers recently suggested that the stock exchange of the future might evolve not from traditional institutions like the New York Stock Exchange, but from e-commerce companies or Internet auction sites. 
 To be sure, that is only one very long-term possibility, the analysts said. And the evolution might work in reverse -- with the Big Board transforming itself into a 24-hour Internet market that could challenge the auction sites of today.
As that speculation suggests, Wall Street is approaching the new millennium the way superstitious pilots approach the Bermuda Triangle -- fearing the worst, hoping for the best but prepared for just about anything.
"The market will be constantly remaking itself," predicted William C. Freund, director of the Pace University Center for the Study of Equity Markets in Manhattan and a former chief economist of the New York Stock Exchange. "The model of today is a scene of creative destruction."
Regulators have tried to create an environment that will foster greater innovation and competition in stock trading. A remarkably long-lived bull market has attracted millions of new investors. But the real engine driving market change today is computer technology: cheaper, faster computers connected by high-speed communications lines and guided by innovative software.
This fast-forward evolution has given rise to a host of bargain-priced online brokerage services that, in turn, have produced an awesome increase in the amount of stock trading Americans do each day. Forrester Research estimates that the number of online brokerage accounts, which stood at roughly three million in August 1998, will reach 5.4 million by the end of this year and more than 20 million in the next four years.
Further, trading volume on Nasdaq increased 28 percent annually between 1994 and 1998, on average, while the year-to-year increase on the Big Board during that period was 23 percent, Salomon Smith Barney reported recently. That compares with average annual growth rates of roughly 19 percent on Nasdaq and 13 percent on the Big Board between 1989 and 1993.
But the same technology that has unleashed this tidal wave of fresh business has also helped Wall Street cope with that flood by fostering the birth of more than a dozen computerized trading networks, called electronic communications networks, or more often simply E.C.N.'s, where buy and sell orders can be matched in seconds. In recent months, some E.C.N.'s have started staying open for trading after the traditional stock exchanges have closed, making it even easier for investors to trade.
Some E.C.N.'s now handle enough trading to pose a competitive threat to the Nasdaq market and, to a lesser extent, the New York Stock Exchange. But those markets are not ceding their territory without a fight. Both Frank Zarb, the chief executive of the National Association of Securities Dealers, which operates the Nasdaq market, and Richard Grasso, the president of the New York Stock Exchange, are working on plans to convert their markets into for-profit corporations. They argue that the new ownership structure would allow them to react more quickly and compete more effectively.
And competition among the E.C.N.'s themselves is rising, prompting widespread predictions that only a few of the current crop will survive very long into the new century.
"But it becomes very quickly clear that this is a business that requires scale and yet it's one in which very little distinguishes the different players -- in short, it's a commodity business," said Guy Moszkowski, a brokerage industry analyst with Salomon Smith Barney.
Moreover, each E.C.N. further fragments the market when customers want the broadest, deepest market possible. "So they face an almost self-defeating business challenge," Mr. Moszkowski added.
Yet, new competitors continue to arrive. By summer, Wall Street expects the debut of Primex, an E.C.N. that advertises itself as an "electronic auction market." Its hefty backers -- including Merrill Lynch & Company, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and Salomon Smith Barney -- account for more than half the trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange.
Nor is the stock market the only place where the ground is shaking. The nation's major options exchanges -- the Chicago Board Options Exchange, the Chicago Board of Trade, the American Stock Exchange, the Philadelphia Stock Exchange and the Pacific Exchange -- are all facing increased electronic competition.
The International Securities Exchange, an electronic options exchange based in Manhattan and sponsored by a group of large brokerage firms including E*Trade and Ameritrade, plans to open its virtual doors in March, if regulators agree. Another electronic rival, backed by the Chicago Stock Exchange and Goldman, Sachs & Company, is on the drawing board.
Regulatory demands for greater public access to the prices at which bonds trade is also likely to push that traditional marketplace toward greater reliance on electronic trading, Mr. Moszkowski said.
The deep, relatively homogeneous markets for Treasury debt will probably be the first to adopt electronic trading broadly, he said, but the corporate and municipal markets will not be far behind. More than a dozen bond trading systems are already operating or are expected to open in the next year or so.
Though European and East Asian markets have been quicker to adopt electronic trading equipment, American markets remain in the forefront of these changes simply because this revolution is being driven largely by the demands of individual investors, who play a much larger role in the American marketplace than they do elsewhere.
Indeed, individuals play a much greater role in American markets than they once did. From the cloudy vantage point of the mid-1970's, the American securities market seemed to be a purely institutional party, with big pension funds and mutual funds pumping in giant orders and elbowing aside the little guy. But last year and into the first half of this year, more than 51 percent of the Big Board's volume consisted of trades of fewer than 10,000 shares apiece.
While some small orders are submitted by large index funds, which constantly adjust their portfolios to reflect the larger market, the growth in small orders also reflects a larger role by individuals, Mr. Moszkowski said.
But as foreign markets catch up, American investors will no doubt push for cheap, fast access to them as well. That will add to the pressure on Wall Street and its regulators to find a way to develop a global electronic market that has adequate regulation, sufficient financial safeguards for all participants and ready access to accurate, comparable information from market to market.
Already, this technological revolution has produced a long "to do" list for regulators. As the new year opens, they must wrestle not only with the competitive and regulatory issues surrounding E.C.N.'s and their traditional stock exchange rivals, but also with some important developments prompted by the new techology.
Most are fairly technical, but one change that individual investors are sure to notice will be the conversion of stock quotes from the traditional fractions into less unwieldy dollars-and-cents prices, a change that is scheduled for next summer. Market experts like Professor Freund expect that this change will put additional pressure on Wall Street profits by reducing spreads, the difference between the prices at which a trader can buy and sell the same stock.
Today, a market maker might buy a stock for $10 a share and sell it for $10 1/16 -- a difference of 6 1/4 cents. With decimal pricing, that gap could shrink to perhaps 5 cents, or even less.
"The conversion can't compare with the Y2K problems, as a technological challenge; this is not like converting to the metric system," Professor Freund said. "But it will change the economics of market making. It will narrow the spreads, and that will put some market makers out of business."
Indeed, for everyone on Wall Street, from the brokerage giants to the newest E.C.N.'s, competing effectively in the new century is going to mean finding the right balance between computers and human beings, according to Mr. Moszkowski, the securities analyst.
"Anything that can be automated must be automated because of the competitive pressures to keep costs low," he said.
The work left for human traders -- using their firms' capital to ease the handling of giant orders from big institutions that will have to pay handsomely for the service -- is going to require far more than routine skills as the difficulty of conducting these trades increases. "Institutional orders will need people much more skillful than ever before," Professor Freund said. "The seat-of-the-pants trader is not going to make it."
Lee Korins, the chief executive of the Security Traders Association in Manhattan, acknowledged that technology was reshaping the life of his members in significant and unpredictable ways. But he cautioned against confusing technology as a means with technology as an end in itself.
"Our markets work so well because we have risk takers in them, not because we have a particular technology," Mr. Korins said. "Electronic systems will do away with certain work experiences. But as long as we make sure the risk taker is included as we go forward, I don't have a big problem with these changes."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 2000: MARKETS & INVESTING;
It's a Bird! It's a Plane! Yes, and It's Also The Latest I.P.O.!

BYLINE: By JOE QUEENAN; Joe Queenan is a writer in New York whose book "My Goodness" will be published by Hyperion in February.

 BODY:
The successful debuts of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia and World Wrestling Federation Entertainment -- enterprises that went public side by side on Oct. 19 this year -- provide indisputable evidence that the stock market has entered a thrilling new era where the old rules do not apply. Twelve years ago on that same date stocks were tanking, but now they are flourishing and everybody wants a piece of the action. Because of this, the early years of the new millennium are sure to bring us initial public offerings far more exotic than any we have witnessed to date.
One reason traditional yardsticks are useless in measuring the prospects of companies like Martha Stewart and the W.W.F. is that each is in the Zeitgeist industry, an enigmatic and very possibly nonexistent segment of the economy where profits are directly pegged not to specific products but to a particular consumer vibe. The Zeitgeist industry may well be the fastest-growing segment of the world economy, a sector that will one day overtake automobiles, drugs and even high technology. 
 Since the industry celebrates a public fascination, it is hardly a coincidence that both Martha Stewart and the wrestling federation are rooted in television, the ultimate arbiter of public taste. So investors should not be surprised when Rosie O'Donnell, mistress of the morning airwaves, goes public with Rosie O'Donnell Living.
Just as Martha Stewart has tapped into the obsessive quest for perfection of the upwardly mobile, Ms. O'Donnell has tapped into the frantic search for adequacy of so many Americans. An adequate stand-up comic herself who has evolved into an adequate actress and a more-than-adequate talk-show host, Ms. O'Donnell is a goddess to her legions of fans. By going public with a company that will market comfort foods, comfortable clothing, functional appliances and a cozy magazine, Ms. O'Donnell should be able to raise billions.
So should @.com. The power of this icon cannot be underestimated. The "@" symbol is perhaps the most vital graphic linchpin of the Internet for without it e-mail messages could not be delivered. Were it mutilated, destroyed, rendered inoperative or even briefly held for ransom, electronic roadkill would litter the Information Highway. Knowing this, the entrepreneurs who take @.com public will be able to use the vast proceeds of their market entry to inflitrate the communications system even more by successfully introducing and copyrighting symbol-words like h@, c@, r@-a-t@-t@ and @mosphere, employing the slogan: "Saving keystrokes each day keeps the ergonomist away."
Not all the I.P.O.'s of the infant millennium, of course, will be rigorously pegged to the amorphous Zeitgeist -- anymore than were this year's roaring successes: Goldman Sachs Group, Delphi Automotive and United Parcel Service. Big offerings like these, along with the ubiquitous dot-coms -- and the biggest success of all, the Internet-related VA Linux Systems -- propelled the I.P.O. market to big bucks, a record volume of $69 billion through mid-December. That's already above the 1996 record of $50 billion, according to Thomson/ Financial Securities Data.
Some new offerings will simply capitalize on any opportunity to attract an ambitious, credulous investing public, whose appetite for I.P.O.'s this decade grew more than fourfold, to $340 billion from $75 billion in the 80's.
Eager investors can be expected, for instance, to snap up Planet United Nations. The U.N. sits on some very valuable Midtown Manhattan real estate and could be a great place to promote a restaurant with the cachet of a sophisticated international clientele. The money it raises would once and for all end the squabbles over nations that have not paid their dues.
Speaking of squabbling nations, with emerging markets once again beating Wall Street, it might behoove the world to brace for an unorthodox I.P.O. or two, like Mujahedeen.com. Traditionally, third world rebels have financed their operations by obtaining covert funds from abroad -- an approach that prevents the insurgency-minded public from directly participating in third world upheaval. In taking Mujahedeen.com public, Afghan guerrillas will generate profits by charging subscribers a monthly rate to watch live Internet footage of clashes in the foothills of Pakistan and allow subscribers to proffer hints on strategy to mujahedeen leaders in interactive chat rooms every evening.
Mujahedeen.com will also offer $65,000 adventure-travel packages to baby boomers who, having found the climb up Mount Everest too old hat, will get their kicks by locking swords in the Hindu Kush.
Speaking of old hat, old is really new in some quarters -- granny glasses are in vogue, and today's close-cropped men could have stepped out of a Jack Webb movie. Recognizing the trend, Irony "R" Us will make a bundle by reintroducing Disco Era bell-bottoms, Nehru jackets, Clark Kent eyeglasses, Day-Glo platform shoes and Louise Brooks hairstyles at the strategic moment. With the funds raised from the I.P.O. of Irony "R" Us, the founders will be able to blanket the nation with a chain of Saturday night restaurants called Trattoria Travolta and a line of Village People casual wear.
As the financial services industry restructures itself, unusual marketing channels will become increasingly popular. That is where the Girl Scouts come in. They are a marketer's dream: Trustworthy, with outstanding brand recognition.
In the past, Girl Scouts have raised money for good causes by selling cookies door to door. In the future, they will earn merit badges for selling annuities, life insurance, emerging-market mutual funds and high-yield bonds door to door.
By going public, the Girl Scouts will not only raise enough money to train young women in the art of financial planning but will also have enough cash left over to get some new uniforms. With their newfound capitalist prowess, after all, the girls will want boardroom apparel.
Speaking of boardrooms, AMEX.com promises to become a real highflier sometime in the next thousand years. Though it may come as a surprise to many, the American Stock Exchange still exists, and, like a bear emerging from hibernation, it may one day become a force to be reckoned with. Like many I.P.O.'s, it will lure investors with the promise of great profits -- the average I.P.O. this year rose 50 percent on opening day, while the average Internet I.P.O. doubled -- and then use the cash raised by going public to attract exciting young companies, build an opulent new headquarters, hire an attention-getting chairman and explain to the public, with the help of a catchy new slogan, what function it serves.
The slogan? "At AMEX, We Make Money the Old-Fashioned Way. We Go Public."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 2000: MARKETS & INVESTING;
Lower Rates Are Tied to an Economic Slowdown

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Inflation is calm. The Federal Reserve is vigilant. And the federal budget deficit has disappeared. So conditions should be right for long-term interest rates finally to fall decisively below 5 percent, a level they have seen only briefly in the final third of the century about to end.
Maybe. Other factors, like the strong stock market, work against any slippage in rates, and many analysts say that only a significant slowdown in economic growth will push rates down any time soon. But just the fact that this decline can be contemplated shows how much the financial and economic environment has changed over the last few years. 
 The overall Consumer Price Index was up a mild 2.6 percent over the last 12 months through November. While that is above the 1.6 percent in 1998, much of this year's rise has come from a jump in oil prices. The core rate, which excludes food and energy, is up just 2.1 percent through November, down from the 2.4 percent core rate for 1998. All of these are far below the 12.5 percent that the overall Consumer Price Index rose in 1980 when long-term government interest rates topped 13 percent.
The Federal Reserve, which now has 20 years of credible inflation-fighting behind it, is trusted to pounce on any inflationary threat. Even with inflation low this year, the Fed raised its short-term interest rate target a quarter of a percentage point three times to slow the economy and take upward pressure off prices.
And with the monetary side of policy secure, the fiscal side has also improved. At least for the time being, the Federal budget has a surplus, which should take some pressure off the government's $5.7 trillion debt.
But even with all that, long-term government interest rates fell below 5 percent only briefly in late 1998 -- and it was panic over the global financial crisis that produced the fall. Money poured into this country as investors sought safety. When foreign markets stabilized, some of that money left, and bond yields in this country rose again.
Now, some forecasters say that even though the conditions for a further rate decline are in place, it will still take a slowdown in the pace of United States economic growth to get long-term interest rates much below their current levels, 6.37 percent for Treasury bonds and 7.59 percent for corporate bonds.
"I don't think we are there yet," said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch, who is forecasting that the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond will be around 6 percent in the fourth quarter of next year. "First, we need to see some significant slowing in economic activity."
With a forecast of 3.6 percent growth from the fourth quarter of this year to the fourth quarter of 2000, he does not expect that, unless "something unpleasant happens."
Such unpleasantness could come in two forms: a stock market crash, which would dampen consumer spending enough to slow growth significantly, or aggressive rate increases from the Federal Reserve. Mr. Steinberg is expecting one quarter-point increase in the Fed's short-term interest rate target as early as February. But three increases, he said, would surely convince investors that the economy was going to slow a lot, bringing interest rates down.
Two factors are combining to make a rate decline less likely, despite the positive environment. One is that real interest rates, which are adjusted for inflation, are high. The other is that higher worker productivity has raised the Fed's speed limit for economic growth. At least for now, the higher real rates and the higher speed limit mean that the demand for capital to invest and to feed a growing economy will keep rates higher.
"Technology investment is driving this," said James E. Glassman, senior United States economist at the Chase Manhattan Bank, explaining the higher real interest rates. "And the opening up of global opportunities," he added, alluding to the chances for new investment in China if Beijing is able to enter the World Trade Organization.
Mr. Glassman said real long-term rates are now around 4 percent, the rate on the 30-year Treasury bond indexed to inflation.
He is not worried, though, about the higher real interest rates, maintaining that they are positive. "The future looks better and people want to invest," he said. "Higher real rates are a barometer for the outlook for the future." He noted that the current level of real rates is about where they were during the railroad boom in the mid-1800's and at the turn of this century.
Chase is forecasting only a small decline in the rate of economic growth next year, to 3.0 percent, from an estimated 3.8 percent this year. Inflation is expected to remain about 2 percent. And long-term Treasury yields, it expects, will change relatively little, perhaps falling below 6 percent by the end of next year.
Mr. Steinberg of Merrill Lynch said the rise in workers' productivity in the 1990's had pushed the Fed's growth speed limit up to a range of 3.5 percent to 4 percent. Fed officials have acknowledged that the limit is higher, but not how much. So analysts can only estimate how much it has been raised from what was thought to be a ceiling of 2 percent to 2.5 percent.
Mr. Glassman judges the speed limit to be slightly slower, around 3 percent to 3.5 percent. But any increase is important because it raises the pace at which the Fed thinks the economy can grow without generating worrisome inflationary pressure.
The faster growth allowed with the higher speed limit means there will be more credit demand to fuel this extra growth before the Fed puts on the brakes, all of which suggests that interest rates will have more trouble falling even if inflation remains low.
Mr. Glassman said that inflation expectations were also making it hard for interest rates to come down. Based on surveys of inflation expectations and on the Treasury bonds indexed to inflation, he said, consumers expect inflation to stay at the 2 percent level for some time. Investors still have "the 1970's inflation bug," he said, noting that it takes just a few hints of stronger growth to make people worry again.
So a slowdown is the answer, right now, for lower interest rates. And that means the stock market will probably determine whether interest rates go lower or not.
If stock prices keep rising, consumers are likely to continue spending, as they feel wealthier every day. And that spending would presumably prevent the economy from slowing enough to satisfy the Federal Reserve. That could force a series of Fed rate increases that could lead to a bigger slowdown, especially if the stock market crumbled in the face of higher rates.
And after that, interest rates could fall.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 2000: MARKETS & INVESTING;
Long Term Appears Turbulent for Oil

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Of all the pressures on the oil industry as the century turns, the one most likely to transform it over the next two decades, industry experts say, will be the fervent campaign to improve the environment.
"If we go 20 years forward, the oil industry at the turn of the 21st century will look like a very antiquated business because the types and use of petroleum products will change dramatically," said Philip K. Verleger Jr., a senior adviser to the Brattle Group, an economic consulting firm based in Cambridge, Mass. 
 "There is going to be a lot of capital that is going to be made obsolete almost immediately," he said.
Much as it has for the last 100 years, however, oil will dominate the fuel industry as the 21st century begins. Even for the next decade or so the effects of recent underlying trends are likely to be incremental rather than seismic.
"There is nothing surprising out there over the medium term," said Lawrence Goldstein, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in New York. "The trends that have been driving and will continue to drive the industry are already in place: consolidation, cost consciousness and technology."
From a public policy perspective, however, "environmental issues will be paramount," he said. And in the longer term, conforming with stricter environmental guidelines will transform the oil industry.
Structural changes are already occurring. Driven by the need to cut costs, 1999 brought the consolidation of four huge companies into two even bigger ones: Amoco's merger with British Petroleum and the combination of Exxon and Mobil. A consolidation wave in the oil services business has been less heralded, but in many respects has been even more sweeping. Among the combinations are Halliburton's takeover of Dresser Industries, Baker Hughes's purchase of Western Atlas, and EVI's purchase of Weatherford Enterra.
A glimpse of the future will be on view next year when Toyota and Honda roll out so-called hybrid automobiles -- cars that combine batteries and electric motors with gasoline or diesel engines. These clean, peppy models can go twice as far as a conventional car on a gallon of gasoline, although analysts say drivers may not rush to buy any new technology until they are sure it works well.
Also on the drawing boards are vehicles powered by a fuel cell and batteries instead of an engine and batteries. Fuel cells combine hydrogen and oxygen to form electric current and water, with high efficiency and no pollution. Even if oil prices do not rise, movement toward the fuel cell cars is virtually inevitable, the experts said, although this technology is still being developed and is not expected to take hold until sometime in the second decade.
"U.S. energy policy today is an environmental policy: cleaner fuels and substitution away from conventional oil moving slowly, inevitably toward alternative fuels," Mr. Goldstein said.
Even as they roll out more and more gas-guzzling, high-profit-margin sport utility vehicles, automobile manufacturers have apparently heard the message.
"I don't talk to anyone in the auto industry who doesn't think that fuel cells are the likely fuel-propulsion mechanism in the future," said Paul R. Portney, president of Resources of the Future in Washington. "Whether it is powered by methanol, hydrogen or something else is up in the air, but 20 years from now fuel cells will begin to propel more and more cars. In the interim, you will see hybrid cars."
For now, however, the internal combustion engine will continue to rule. And while it is possible that an oil shortage may develop this winter, experts said that oil would remain plentiful over the longer term.
The doubling in oil prices over the last year has been painful to the pocketbook, but experts point out that it was unrealistic to assume that oil, which cost $13 a barrel or less in 1998, would stay at those lower levels for long.
"We are going to get large chunks of new supply over the next five years," Mr. Verleger said, "particularly if OPEC keeps prices up. It will primarily come out of the sea, like the Caspian oil field."
OPEC, the cartel that controlled oil prices and had a profound influence on the world economy in the 1970's, lost most of its teeth in the 1980's and well into the 1990's. Alternative sources of supply and a global economy that is less dependent on petroleum have curbed its power.
But this year OPEC managed to regain some of its old dominance by adopting -- and adhering -- to a set of strict production quotas during a time of rising demand. The cartel's re-emergence as a major force, however, is likely to be short-lived.
"Oil prices will remain volatile because no ruling group is in charge," said M. A. Adelman, professor emeritus of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "Conditions are a lot more competitive than they used to be, and the price is a lot lower. That will continue for some time."
Competition is coming largely from sources of new supply that have been made possible by technological improvements over the last decade. Exploration in some previously unreachable places is now economically viable.
Over the last few years, three technological advances have been particularly important: 3-D seismic exploration techniques, which allow ships trawling over the ocean to locate reserves more precisely; the development of deep-water platforms that allow for exploration at much greater depths, and directional drilling, which slants drill bits out like legs on a mosquito as far as 5 or 10 miles, greatly expanding the territory that can be explored from a single ocean-based platform.
"These technologies, which are being fine-tuned to make them more versatile in various parts of the world, allow for much faster exploration and delivery," said James L. Smith, a professor of economics at the Cox School of Business of Southern Methodist University in Dallas.
As an example, Mr. Smith said that new wells in the North Sea could be in production within 18 months to two years from first discovery. Not so long ago, that same process would have taken as much as seven years, he said.
Although OPEC nations sit on vast proven reserves of oil, the rise in recoverable reserves elsewhere has all but silenced the voices that a quarter-century ago were saying that the world would soon run out of oil.
"There is no chance we will run out of oil in the next 20 years," Mr. Portney, from Resources of the Future, said. "We will stop using oil long before we run out of it. A century from now, when we don't use oil for very much, there will be a ton of it around."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 2000: TECHNOLOGY & MEDIA;
Wireless Industry Looks Beyond Phone

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL

 BODY:
Over the last decade, cellular telephones have evolved from oddity to indulgence to everyday accessory. Eighty million Americans now use them. That is not so shabby a track record, but many communications experts now want to move on. They want you to stop talking about wireless phones.
In fact, discuss the future of wireless technology with leading communications executives and the words "phone" and "telephone" may not be used at all. That is because they see the future of wireless technology as having little to do with talking and everything to do with putting the Internet into pockets and purses around the world. 
 To be sure, people's need to talk on the phone will continue to provide the financial lifeblood of the wireless industry. Some wireless executives even see the promises of technological wizardry as overblown. Andrew Sukawaty, chief executive of Sprint PCS, one of the nation's biggest wireless phone carriers, predicts that old-fashioned voice transmission will remain the biggest part of the business, with as many as half the nation's phone calls being made without wires by the middle of the next decade.
Nevertheless, in just a few years, the mere wireless phone may very well seem as dated as a rotary dial. The conventional wisdom -- the orthodoxy even -- in the communications business is that in its place will be a new generation of mobile wireless devices that function not only as telephones but also as Internet terminals, radios that can be customized for personal tastes, and perhaps even customized television.
Call it a smart phone, a personal digital assistant or merely a wireless device. New wireless technologies to be deployed over the next few years promise to pump the flow of digital information to hand-held wireless units from trickles to torrents. By 2002, wireless subscribers could have access to as much as a million bits of digital information each second -- just about enough for a television-quality videophone and about 20 times the 56K connection speed supported by today's fastest home modems.
The idea is to unplug the wired world of computers and phone jacks to allow people to communicate and gain access to information when they want, where they want, how they want. In much the same way that computers that link to the Internet have been credited with releasing people from some constraints of time and space, the next generation of wireless technology may release the Internet from computers themselves.
"Now we will be able to focus on getting the individual his or her own information, no matter how they would like to receive it," said Phillip T. Redman, an analyst for the Yankee Group, a technology consulting firm based in Boston.
"Wireless offers the ability to extend a user's communications, their entertainment system, their commercial transactions to an anytime, anywhere paradigm," Mr. Redman said. "You no longer are going to be tethered to a computer at home or at work or have to plan your shopping around when you're going to be at the mall. All of these will be targeted to you whenever or wherever you want to use it."
This may all sound a bit familiar, of course. The hype about wireless data services has continued almost unabated for years. But the technology to support futuristic wireless services is beginning to be put into place, so those services now seem set to move beyond e-mail on a phone.
"The wireless industry has been promoting this year being the year of wireless data for the last five or six years now," said Scott Goldman, chief executive of the Wireless Application Protocol Forum, an industry group that has developed systems to deliver Internet services to hand-held devices. "Now, if you poll wireless experts you will find people in concert saying, 'Yes, 2000 is the year.' "
One reason for optimism is that the big companies that make wireless systems -- like Ericsson, Nokia, Lucent Technologies and Northern Telecom -- have begun to foster expectations about the data capacities of their products. They have seen start-ups like Neopoint produce revolutionary phones that can link to the Internet.
"The information will be localized, will be personalized and will be timely," said Haroon I. Alvi, director for business development of Nokia's wireless handset operation,
"Imagine you're a soccer parent," he said, "and you spend two to three hours a day taking your kids around town to school, sports events and other sorts of family events. As that soccer parent, you want to know about road conditions, traffic and weather conditions in the vicinity where you're located and at that instant.
"So if you're going to get into your car and take your kids to a soccer match, you may want to look at your phone to see if the venue has been changed. There might be an alert saying, 'We've changed the location because the field was waterlogged.' "
Even e-commerce, the much-vaunted selling of goods over the Internet, could be revolutionized by the next wave of wireless technology, through phones or personal digital assistants, known as P.D.A.'s.
"It's not just important that I can purchase a product through my phone or my P.D.A.," Mr. Redman said. "But my phone or P.D.A. knows where I am, and I can get a deal because there's a special going on near me as I'm driving and I'm alerted to it."
For all the noise around wireless data services, however, voice telephone service will continue to be the fundamental economic driver of the big wireless carriers' business. That is largely because data services may well be priced along the "all you can eat" model of Internet service providers, but phone calls are still likely to be priced minute by minute.
"We're in a technology business, and so people get focused often on the wrong thing," Mr. Sukawaty of Sprint PCS said. "Data is coming, no doubt about it, but the bigger revenue for wireless is that probably 50 percent of the voice traffic is going to go on wireless networks in the next three to five years. Given that it was at 6 or 7 percent two years ago, that's incredible."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 2000: TECHNOLOGY & MEDIA: TALKING THE FUTURE WITH: Robert W. Taylor;
An Internet Pioneer Ponders the Next Revolution

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
The Internet has many fathers, but few deserve the label more than Robert W. Taylor.
In 1966, as a director of the Pentagon's Advanced Research Projects Agency Information Processing Techniques Office, Mr. Taylor came up with the idea for the Internet's precursor, the ARPAnet. After authorizing money for research to develop a nationwide computer network, Mr. Taylor wrote a white paper in 1968, a year before the network was created, with another ARPA research director, J. C. R. Licklider. The paper, "The Computer as a Communications Device," was one of the first clear statements about the potential of a computer network. 
 Even before coming to ARPA, Mr. Taylor saw the computer's potential as an interactive device. As a research manager at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, he arranged financing for Douglas C. Engelbart, a young researcher who used the money at what was then called the Stanford Research Institute, now SRI International, to invent the computer mouse.
At ARPA, Mr. Taylor's office continued financing Mr. Engelbart's Augment research group, which pioneered many of the most important ideas in today's computer industry. It was Mr. Taylor who financed Mr. Engelbart's legendary demonstration of advanced computer technologies -- including the mouse, windows, hypertext, networking and teleconferencing -- at the 1968 Joint Fall Computer Conference in San Francisco. The demonstration left many of the nation's best computer scientists, then living in a world of punch cards and paper tape, in awe.
Mr. Taylor's contributions did not end there. After leaving ARPA and spending a year at the University of Utah, he was hired to direct the newly formed computer systems laboratory at Xerox's brand-new Palo Alto Research Center. From that laboratory and several others at PARC came the personal computer, computer networking, desktop publishing, laser printers, the graphical user interface and modern word processing.
Mr. Taylor, who never profited personally from the commercial Internet boom, is now retired at 67 and lives in Woodside, Calif. In a recent interview, he reviewed these pivotal events in the computer industry and looked to what the future might hold.
Following are excerpts from that conversation:
Q. -- What led to your ideas about computer networking?
A. -- I discovered computers in the 1950's, and the whole business of punching holes in cards turned me off. I really wasn't interested in computers from the beginning as an arithmetic engine. What struck me about them really came home when I read J. C. R. Licklider's 1960 "Man-Computer Symbiosis" paper. I said, "Yeah! Now we're talking!"
Q. -- How did you come across that article?
A. -- It appeared in an I.E.E.E. Transactions journal that I subscribed to. I was working as a systems engineer at the Martin Company at the time. That's when the power of interactive computing dawned on me. I had other reasons to pay attention to Licklider. I did my thesis on psycho-acoustics and Licklider was world famous in that field, before he started to play around with computers.
Q. -- How did you meet Licklider?
A. -- NASA had approached me to become a program manager in 1961 to look after research areas including flight displays and manned flight-control systems. I told them they needed an area called simulation technology because we were going to have to make huge investments in simulation, and they liked that idea. In late 1962, Licklider moved to ARPA and started this computer research program. I was at NASA and he was at the Pentagon. I had been supporting Doug Engelbart's work.
Q. -- This led to the mouse?
A. -- Yes. You know, it's quite funny -- several years ago NASA began looking for spinoffs that their research had led to in the civilian economy and they never realized that the mouse was developed under a NASA contract. But Licklider, shortly after he took over at ARPA, organized an informal committee of people in the government who were supporting computer research. He invited me to come over and join the committee. I walked into his office and right away he started talking to me about my thesis. It blew me completely away. How would he know anything about my thesis? I was a no-name nobody graduate student. He wowed me from Day 1.
Q. -- What did you set out to do at ARPA?
A. -- I began to think that if I was going to do this for a while, I wanted to find some particular program to measure my performance by. I wanted to put a nail on the wall or whatever the proper metaphor is. I wanted to make a difference. We had in my office three terminals to three different programs that ARPA was supporting. One was to the Systems Development Corporation in Santa Monica. There was another terminal to the Genie Project at U.C. Berkeley. The third terminal was to the C.T.S.S. project that later became the Multics project at M.I.T. We hadn't had these terminals very long. But I had already seen a very interesting thing. As these three time-sharing projects came alive and they collected users around their respective campuses, the only users they had were local users because there was no network to speak of. All communications were local except to ARPA.
Q. -- What did you discover?
A. -- The thing that really struck me about this evolution was how these three systems caused communities to get built. People who didn't know one another previously would now find themselves using the same system. Because the systems allowed you to share files, you could find that so-and-so was interested in such-and-such and he had some data about it. You could contact him by e-mail and, lo and behold, you would have a whole new relationship.
Q. -- Were these first communities built around mailing lists?
A. -- Well, you had a directory, so you knew how to send them e-mail, but you might only know 2 or 3 people, and you would meet 20 or 30 through the computer. It wasn't a static medium. It was a dynamic medium. And that gave it a lot of power.
Q. -- It was all about community?
A. -- There was one other trigger that turned me to the ARPAnet. For each of these three terminals, I had three different sets of user commands. So if I was talking online with someone at S.D.C. and I wanted to talk to someone I knew at Berkeley or M.I.T. about this, I had to get up from the S.D.C. terminal, go over and log into the other terminal and get in touch with them. I said, oh, man, it's obvious what to do: If you have these three terminals, there ought to be one terminal that goes anywhere you want to go where you have interactive computing. That idea is the ARPAnet.
Q. -- When did you get the idea?
A. -- I decided to do that in late 1965. In February of 1966, I was officially the head of the Information Processing Techniques Office. So I went to see Charlie Herzfeld, who was the head of ARPA, and laid the idea on him. The first funding came that month. He liked the idea immediately, and he took a million dollars out of the ballistic missile defense budget and put it into my budget right then and there.
Q. -- Was the idea an immediate success?
A. -- I had to go around and talk to our contractors to see if I could get their cooperation -- and some of them were enthusiastic, and some of them saw it as an infringement on their computing facilities. They said, "I don't want to share my computing cycles with some guy across the country. I don't have enough cycles as it is. Now you're going to build something that allows people to come in and use my machine?" That took a while to bring people together.
Q. -- Did you see right away that this would have an impact broader than just a small group of military-funded researchers?
A. -- Oh, yeah, sure. It was obvious to some of us that interactive computing was here to stay. And by the late 60's, the personal computer was obvious as well. By the time I went to Xerox in 1970, I tried to get the guys to build the Alto one of the first experimental personal computers and they built it two years later, but that's a whole other story.
Q. -- Was there one shared vision?
A. -- The model that some people were pushing in those days for how this was going to spread was that there were going to be gigantic computer utilities. This was the power utility model. I never bought that. By the late 60's, Moore's Law was pretty obvious. It was just a matter of time before you could afford to put a computer on everyone's desk. That was what I came to Xerox to do.
Q. -- How did you arrive at Xerox?
A. -- I left ARPA in late 1969 after I knew that the ARPAnet was up and running, and I went to Utah for what turned out to be only a year. When I was in Utah, I got a call from George Pake, a physicist who was setting up Xerox's Palo Alto Research Center. I had the impression that he just wanted to pick my brain. There was no discussion of a job. He told me that Xerox was going to have a research lab here in Palo Alto and part of it was going to be devoted to computer research. The research group was going to develop technologies that would be used at S.D.S., a computer company that Xerox had recently purchased. I said, "Oh, that's too bad." He said, "What do you mean?" "Well, you won't be able to get anyone who's any good to come work here because there's absolutely no respect for S.D.S. among the best computer folks." They were floored. They said, "What do you think we ought to do?" I replied, "You ought to computerize the office; everything that happens in the office can be put on the computer."
Q. -- If the personal computer has been the foundation for the Internet, where will the next major burst of innovation come from?
A. -- Broadband networks. If you take real-time video and audio and you couple them, and you imagine some kind of a chair that's connected to this system that you sit in and fly around wherever you want to go . . . .
Q. -- How will we use these new technologies?
A. -- You'll also be able to wear -- maybe not in my lifetime but certainly reasonably soon -- an unobtrusive device that will record in full color and sound everything that you see or point your head at, or, depending on how many of them you have, everything that's around you. And share it. Every waking and sleeping moment in your life will be recorded. And you will be able to store and retrieve it and do what you will with it.
Q. -- How will that change the world?
A. -- I don't know, but it will. There are obviously implications for privacy that will have to be worked through. I'm actually more concerned about nearer-term issues. I want the Internet to become a right, not a privilege. I think we need a driver's license to allow you to use the Internet, much like you drive on the road today. If you misbehave on the road, you get your license taken away.
Q. -- Do you have a sense of what the future will look like from a computer network point of view?
A. -- I can't help much about the future, I'm afraid. I was a bad predictor of the future 30 years ago. I was sure that from the early 1970's, all the pieces were there at Xerox and at ARPA to put the Internet in the state by the early '80's that it is in today. It was all there. It was physically there. But it didn't happen for years.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 2000: TECHNOLOGY & MEDIA;
Patents Considered Vital To Thrive on the Internet

BYLINE: By TERESA RIORDAN

 BODY:
How important will intellectual property be in the new economy?
"Excruciatingly important," said Glover Ferguson, co-director of the electronic commerce program at Andersen Consulting. 
 A case in point is the victory that the online bookseller Amazon.com scored earlier this month when it obtained a preliminary injunction against Barnesandnoble.com. The injunction prevents Barnes & Noble from using the one-click system patented by Amazon that enables repeat online customers to place orders without having to re-enter mailing and credit card information.
"This is going to put some real boulders in the way of the Barnes & Noble checkout line system," said Kevin Rivette, co-author of "Rembrandts in the Attic," a new book from the Harvard Business Press that proselytizes on the power of patents. "The lawsuit also has put everyone else on the Net on notice."
Walter Hanchuk, a partner at the New York law firm of Morgan & Finnegan, concurred, saying the ruling "clearly highlights the importance of intellectual property in all technologies."
Intellectual property, in Mr. Rivette's view, is what is going to separate many winners and losers on the Internet.
"When it's easy to put up a Web site, when it's easy to get financial backing, this is where some of the shakeout is going to happen," he said.
Much attention so far has been paid to the new wave of so-called business-method patents on the Internet. But Mark Lemley, a professor of law at the University of Texas, points out that the scope of what can be patented is growing every day.
"There's a patent on a method for holding a golf putter," Mr. Lemley said. "There's a patent on allocating assets in a divorce settlement. This is a great expansion of patentable subject matter beyond what has traditionally been the technological arts."
Mr. Rivette, who is chief executive of Aurigin Systems, a patent-strategy consulting company, predicted that "one of the biggest things that will occur in the next three to five years is the proliferation of well-funded patent 'factories.' "
Mr. Rivette said he had heard of about half a dozen such enterprises modeled along the lines of Walker Digital, the controversial -- and extremely successful -- patent-incubation venture that gave birth to Priceline.com. The Priceline.com business is based on a patented method for letting prospective customers propose a price for a product or service, with the online order being filled if the seller is willing to sell at that price. The patent is one of 30 received by Walker Digital, which has another 300 patent applications pending.
Like Walker Digital, which maintained a very low profile until it started Priceline.com, these ventures are stealthily amassing patent empires that will become apparent only when they are ready to start businesses, Mr. Rivette said.
Mr. Rivette predicts that the high mortality rate of Internet businesses will create new opportunities for patent expertise.
"It will be just like what happened in the biotech community in the 1980's," he said. "There's going to be opportunity to buy property rights and turn around and sell them to market leaders."
But Mr. Hanchuk, the patent lawyer, expects this sorting-out period to be tumultuous. As patent portfolios fatten and as e-commerce continues its explosive growth, he said, "we will inevitably see a significant increase in patent litigation involving e-commerce."
And the suits may not come only from competitors. Companies that fail to protect their innovations may face lawsuits from shareholders, warns Charles Eldering, president of Telecom Partners Ltd., a company based in New Britain, Pa., that develops strategic patent portfolios for telecommunications and Internet companies.
Mr. Rivette and others predict that within a few years many companies will have the equivalent of a vice president for intellectual property -- not a lawyer who shepherds applications through the patent office, but rather an M.B.A. who thinks strategically about intellectual property.
"We'll see a chief patent strategist or the equivalent in most corporations in the next three years," Mr. Rivette said. "Intellectual property touches too much of the corporation."
The Internet already has become home to a number of online intellectual property bazaars -- sites where companies can swap technology through licensing deals or sell off trademarks, patents or copyrights that the owner does not need but that another company might find valuable.
Among these new sites are www.yet2.com, which uses technology developed by Mr. Rivette's Aurigin Systems; www.pl-x.com, which specializes in technologies developed by universities, and IPnetwork.com, which is weighted toward trademarks and copyrights.
"We will bring in lots of new players," said Christine Hearst Schwarzman, the president of IPnetwork. "I have hundreds and hundreds of companies from places in the world that are chronically underrepresented areas of the licensing world."
And what will patents themselves look like in the future? Mr. Ferguson of Andersen Consulting predicts that -- instead of consisting of text and drawings as they have for more than two centuries -- patents are likely to become mixed-media affairs.
"We're getting into things that are darn difficult to explain in prose," Mr. Ferguson said. "Imagine the most graphical interface possible," he said, referring to computer screens on which users interact with images instead of issuing verbal commands. "It's almost impossible to describe it in text. But as soon as you see the thing, you say, 'Oh, I get it.' There may be a gap in the way we have chosen to memorialize inventions."

HEADLINE: OBSERVATORY

BYLINE: By HENRY FOUNTAIN 

 BODY:

The Better to See With
Giant squid, those monsters of the deep, are famous for (among other things) having eyes the size of dinner plates.
Now comes word that another sea creature had eyes that could just as easily have graced a table. A researcher at the University of California Museum of Paleontology and colleagues report that some types of ichthyosaurs, marine reptiles that lived 90 million to 250 million years ago, had eyes up to 10 inches in diameter, rivaling those of the largest giant squid. The ichthyosaur eyes are the largest ever found in a vertebrate. 
 Ichthyosaurs, which ranged in size from about 7 feet to more than 30, had fishlike bodies, including fins and vertical tails. Among the fossils studied, those of a genus called Ophthalmosaurus had the largest eyes for its size, about 9 inches in diameter for a body length of roughly 13 feet.
In general, the larger the eye, the better it can see in low light conditions. The researchers, writing in the journal Nature, estimate that the ophthalmosaurs could probably have detected point light sources (like those from photoluminescent prey) in deep water, and suggest that the creatures dived to depths of close to 2,000 feet.
Supporting the idea that ophthalmosaurs were deep divers, the researchers found evidence in the fossil bones that the reptiles suffered from the bends, which occurs when an animal (or human) dives to great depths and rises too quickly, with the pressure changes causing gas bubbles to expand in tissues.
 
Atomic Clock Watch
Strange things happen during a solar eclipse. Twilight falls, the wind can shift, birds stop singing: it almost seems that time stands still.
Perhaps more than almost. Experiments during some eclipses over the last half century have appeared to show strange things happening to atomic clocks and pendulums, attributed to some unexplained feature of gravity.
A set of experiments during four partial eclipses from 1987 to 1992 was particularly odd: it showed a small but significant accumulated time difference between atomic clocks in the same laboratory, where the gravitational effects, if any, would have been the same.
But a new study by German scientists during August's total solar eclipse in Europe contradicts these previous findings. The experiment used four atomic clocks of three different types, and all were placed in an air-conditioned basement laboratory in Wessling, Germany, with a computer recording their time differences every four seconds between Aug. 3 and 23 (the eclipse occurred on the 11th). The results showed no anomalous changes in the relative rates of the four clocks.
 
Haze Over China
Burning of soft coal to feed its growing economy has made China the world leader in sulfur emissions, and its neighbors are complaining about acid rain caused by all that sulfur. But China's economic progress is causing problems at home in the fields as well.
A NASA-financed study by a professor at the Georgia Institute of Technology and colleagues shows that heavy haze in China's chief growing regions may be cutting agricultural production by up to one-third.
The aerosol haze, which the researchers say is most likely a result of the burning of coal and other fuels, acts like a filter, absorbing some of the sunlight that would ordinarily be used by plants for photosynthesis.
The researchers, who reported on their work in a recent issue of The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, said that sunlight was reduced by 5 percent to 30 percent over the roughly 250,000 square miles of hazy areas in China, which include some of the country's most productive farmland.
The scientists also point out that similar haze problems exist in many developing countries.

HEADLINE: NYC;
Santa Aside, Who Believes In Virginia?

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
CURIOSITY led to a row house at 115 West 95th Street, where one of the best-known sentiments of this holiday season was born. The idea was to see if anyone knew that Virginia O'Hanlon once lived there, or even had a clue who she was.
It was a foolish mission. Inquiries produced polite shrugs or don't-bother-me clicks of the intercom from the few people living at No. 115. Their reaction should have been anticipated. After all, this is a city of impermanence; collective memory often lasts about as long as sand castles at high tide. 
 Still, one thought that there just might be a plaque or some other indication that, in this house 102 years ago, an 8-year-old girl wrote a letter that produced perhaps this country's most enduring secular affirmation of hope and faith.
Some of her "little friends" at school had said there was no Santa Claus, Virginia O'Hanlon wrote to the editor of The New York Sun. Could they conceivably be right? In what would become America's most famous newspaper editorial, Francis Pharcellus Church of The Sun replied:
"Yes, Virginia, there is a Santa Claus."
"He exists," the editorial continued, "as certainly as love and generosity and devotion exist, and you know that they abound and give to your life its highest beauty and joy."
Cornball? You bet. Irresistible? That, too. Generations of open-hearted Americans have thought so (their numbers including countless newspaper writers who have taken "Yes, Virginia" and pounded it silly, often on the misguided assumption that they were the first to play with that locution).
You would think that a piece of New York writing of such grace and durability deserved formal acknowledgment. Surely, something creative could be figured out by city officials, whose taste in tributes leans more to renaming streets Senor Wences Way and the like.
Given the absence of any public recognition, you can hardly blame the present occupants of No. 115 for drawing a blank. "Yes, Virginia" doesn't always ring a bell with Mr. Claus, either.
"I never heard of her, to tell you the truth, and I've been doing this a long time," said Bob Williams, a sidewalk Santa for 14 years with Volunteers of America, the helping hand to some of New York's neediest.
Mr. Williams, 66, was at his regular post during the weekend, on Fifth Avenue, facing the Rockefeller Center Christmas tree. He is something of an expert, he said, on little children and their need to believe.
"But I tell them right up front that I'm not Santa," he said. "I'm Santa's helper, and if they tell me something, I'll pass it on to the big guy. I don't make promises I can't keep."
There is wizardry in that red suit, whether you believe it or not, Mr. Williams added. "When I'm in street clothes, I'm nobody," he said. "But the minute I put on that suit, I'm somebody. It changes everything. Even when I go take a break, I can't really take a break. I get mobbed."
But it's not all magic. To steal from Barbara Basler, formerly of this newspaper, being Santa can be a tough row to ho.
CHILDREN today are more jaded than their older brothers and sisters, Mr. Williams finds. And the grown-ups who stuff cash in Santa's chimney are usually tourists, not New Yorkers, who are too busy rushing through the canyons of Midtown.
"The ones that work in those office buildings there, they don't give," he said. "The ones that don't have it, give it. The ones that have it, they walk right by you."
Sad but true, agreed Linda McNeil, Volunteers of America's director of development and communications. Altogether, the Volunteers' eight sidewalk Santas are likely to collect about $45,000 by Christmas Eve. Even though these are heady days on Wall Street, the figure has held steady for several years, Ms. McNeil said.
In general, she said, "the boom in the economy is not impacting on our fund-raising at all. There are maybe a few donors who find it advantageous to unload some stock on us."
What about all the cyber-generated money floating out there? "The new wealth," Ms. McNeil said, "has not necessarily been trained in philanthropy."
Of course, Santa is about more than money and gifts. Church of The Sun knew that, and said so to Virginia O'Hanlon, who died in 1971.
"How dreary would be the world if there were no Santa Claus!" he wrote. "It would be as dreary as if there were no Virginias. There would be no childlike faith then, no poetry, no romance to make tolerable this existence."

SECTION: Section A; Page 30; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 512 words

HEADLINE: Russia's New Parliament

 BODY:
Several distinct messages can be drawn from Sunday's parliamentary elections in Russia, some more encouraging than others. Most hearteningly, voters showed a clear preference for centrists, selecting what may turn out to be the first reform-minded Duma majority since the Soviet collapse. But the main centrist party, Unity, allied with President Boris Yeltsin and Prime Minister Vladimir Putin, built its success on jingoistic exploitation of the brutal Russian military campaign in Chechnya. The results were also skewed by the unequal enforcement of election rules, dirty campaign tricks and the crude bias of television stations allied with the Kremlin. These outlets fed Russians a stream of unproven criminal accusations against the two leaders of a rival party, former Prime Minister Yevgeny Primakov and Mayor Yuri Luzhkov of Moscow.
The allocation of parliamentary seats is still incomplete. But it appears that the Communists just barely remained the largest party. Challenging them closely is Mr. Putin's Unity Party. An allied party of economic reformers did well enough to bring Mr. Putin close to a working majority. When members elected from the liberal Yabloko Party and the Fatherland-All Russia alliance of Mr. Primakov and Mr. Luzhkov are added in, moderates could end up with more than half the total seats. 
 Those gains could help bring economic reform back to life and revive hopes of ratifying nuclear arms control treaties with the United States. But that will require the centrist parties to cooperate on legislative goals even as they prepare to line up behind competing candidates in next summer's presidential elections.
Achieving substantive results from the new parliamentary alignment will largely depend on Mr. Putin, a former K.G.B. officer who has built his popularity mainly on Russian military successes in Chechnya. Mr. Putin's own ideological and political instincts are unclear. Russia's economy has revived somewhat in recent months, but those gains flowed mainly from last year's ruble devaluation and the recent doubling of world oil prices. Continued growth depends on pushing through reforms long stymied by the Communists and their parliamentary allies. The most urgently needed measures are a simplified and enforceable tax system, strengthened legal protections for Russian and foreign investors and a crackdown on corruption.
One of Mr. Putin's strongest opponents for the presidency is likely to be Mr. Primakov, an experienced politician who has coupled promises of strong leadership with a pledge to avoid wrenching economic change. Although Mr. Primakov's party got only about half as many votes as Mr. Putin's this week, the presidential race could be closer. Russia's party system is weak, and sentiment can change swiftly in response to unforeseen events, including possible reverses in Chechnya. What the voters surely deserve is a cleaner campaign than they got this time, with honest media coverage for all sides. Mr. Putin should use his new political strength to assure a fairer presidential race.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Three weddings and a funeral: deals are made and a small specialty agency closes shop.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THREE acquisitions and an agency's closing are making news.
In the largest of the acquisitions, the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York, which owns agencies like Draft Worldwide, the Lowe Group and the McCann-Erickson World Group, agreed yesterday to buy NFO Worldwide Inc. in Stamford, Conn., a leading market research company. 
 The stock deal is valued about $580 million.
Interpublic is the world's No. 2 agency company in revenue, at $4.3 billion behind the Omnicom Group, according to the trade publication Advertising Age, and is No. 1 in billings at $37.7 billion. NFO is to operate as a stand-alone autonomous unit of Interpublic, perhaps as part of its Allied Communications Group division.
The acquisition vaults Interpublic into the front ranks of the market research field, which is booming because of the demand for data related to interactive advertising. In fact, NFO describes itself as the single largest provider of Internet-based marketing research.
"We consider market research an area of opportunity," said Sean Orr, executive vice president and chief financial officer at Interpublic.
"Arguably, it was a bit of a hole in our portfolio of service offerings. We're delighted to have that hole closed."
While Interpublic owns some small market research companies, it has not been as large a force in that field as the WPP Group in London, which has assiduously assembled an array of such operations, primarily through acquisitions.
"We wanted a significantly larger presence, ideally globally," said Barry Linsky, senior vice president for planning and business development at Interpublic. "With NFO, we're gaining the size and scope and a terrific brand."
NFO was originally known as National Family Opinion, after a unit that polls consumers through surveys sent out under the name Carol Adams -- an imaginary woman who could be considered the Betty Crocker of market research. NFO, founded in 1946, has about 4,000 employees in 35 countries providing custom and syndicated marketing information to more than 3,000 clients; annual revenue is estimated at more than $425 million.
"It's a great strategic fit between two global leaders," said William E. Lipner, chairman, chief executive and president at NFO, "reaffirming the convergence of advertising agencies and market research firms."
Terms of the deal call for NFO shareholders to receive $26 worth of Interpublic stock for each NFO share they own. On the New York Stock Exchange, NFO stock closed Friday at $14 and closed yesterday at $22.25, up $8.25. Interpublic shares, traded on the same exchange, fell $2.3125 yesterday, to $55.75.
The acquisition was announced as NFO warned that it expected a significant shortfall in earnings during the current quarter, far below the predictions of Wall Street analysts, and would take fourth-quarter after-tax charges of $15 million to $20 million. Interpublic was aware of those developments before making the deal, Mr. Linsky and Mr. Orr said.
The second acquisition involves Modem Media.Poppe Tyson in Norwalk, Conn., an Internet advertising agency and Web site creator, which agreed to buy Vivid Studios in San Francisco, a Web site creator and consultant, for $64 million in cash and stock. Modem Media.Poppe Tyson is partly owned by True North Communications.
The acquisition of Vivid, which has about 100 employees, is meant to help Modem Media.Poppe Tyson develop e-commerce sites more efficiently and effectively. It will be the third deal in recent months for Modem Media.Poppe Tyson, whose shares closed yesterday at $64.375, down $1.375, in Nasdaq trading.
The third acquisition involves Powers & Associates in Cincinnati, which agreed to buy another agency there, Sive/Young & Rubicam. Terms were not disclosed.
Sive/Y.& R. has 24 employees working on accounts with billings estimated at $42 million from clients like Frisch's Restaurants, Mercy Health Partners and the United States Playing Card Company. Powers has about 26 employees and clients like American Savings and Loan and the Progressive Insurance Company.
The merged agency will operate under the Powers name, with Charles W. Powers, 62, continuing as president. Michael Kitei, 62, president and chief executive at Sive/ Y.& R., will serve as a consultant.
"The new agency will be a long-held dream come true," Mr. Powers said, referring to his attempt in 1977 to acquire the old Sive agency, only to be outbid by Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York. Sive/Y.& R. remained part of Y.& R. until 1994, when five managers bought 90 percent of the agency. Sive/Y.& R. is being acquired from current management and Y.& R., which is selling its 10 percent stake.
Finally, the agency that is closing, effective immediately, is Mulryan/ Nash, a small New York shop specializing in campaigns aimed at gay and lesbian consumers. Clients included Agouron Pharmaceuticals, part of the Warner-Lambert Company, and Subaru of America, a unit of Fuji Heavy Industries.
"There's no one thing" that led to the decision, said Dave Mulryan, president at Mulryan/Nash, adding that he could not comment further.
In a letter addressed to "valued customers, vendors and friends," Mr. Mulryan wrote that "harsh financial circumstances beyond our control" led to the closing. Inquiries were referred to Geron & Corsano, a New York law firm.
"Even though it's a bad situation not typical of other agencies specializing in the gay market," said Sean Strub, chairman of Poz Publishing L.L.C. in New York, 'it's a black mark on the gay market." He estimated that his company was owed about $125,000 for ad space that Mulryan/Nash bought for clients in Poz and Poz en Espanol magazines.
Agouron, which extensively advertises an AIDS drug, Viracept, in publications read by gay men, sent letters to those magazines and newspapers expressing regret over "the unfortunate circumstances of the agency closing." The letter notified the publications that Rivendell Marketing in New York and Westfield, N.J., would take over media duties from Mulryan/Nash.
"We're sorry to see Mulryan/Nash go," said Todd Evans, chief executive at Rivendell, adding that he did not think the agency's difficulties were indicative of the health of the overall market.
"Companies have a commitment to the gay market," said Mr. Evans, who sells ad space in gay and lesbian publications in local markets nationwide. "Our business was up 30 percent this year, and we expect another banner year next year."

HEADLINE: Chief American U.N. Delegate Charts Course for His Month at the Helm

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 20

 BODY:
Richard C. Holbrooke's moment has come, and he intends to make the most of it.
With a long and bedeviled nomination process and the battle to pay American dues to the United Nations now behind him, he has one year left as chief American representative here, one year to put his imprint on Washington's relations with the world and perhaps to emerge again as a leading candidate for secretary of state after the next election. 
 Almost four months after taking office here and picking up a cabinet seat at the White House, Mr. Holbrooke called his first major news conference today to talk about his plans for January, a month when he takes on the rotating presidency of the Security Council and can frame much of its agenda. In a word, it will be Africa. Not Iraq, not Kosovo or Bosnia, not North Korea or East Timor.
"It's not just a gimmick," said Mr. Holbrooke, who is an expert on Europe and Asia. Back from his first extended tour of sub-Saharan Africa, he has been plainly shaken by what he saw: the endless implosion of Angola, a pointless war in the Congo and the social and economic devastation wrought by AIDS.
With Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright now focused on the Middle East, and with events in the Balkans and East Timor largely under United Nations or NATO control, Africa looms as the great unfinished business at the century's end. Mr. Holbrooke plans public Security Council sessions on Burundi, Congo and Sierra Leone.
Many diplomats are skeptical. Council debates on Africa have often turned into speechfests that changed nothing.
But Africans and envoys from developing nations elsewhere are welcoming the attention. At the Center for the Global South at American University in Washington, the director, Clovis Maksoud, said that Mr. Holbrooke might strike the right chord with poorer nations, finding a way to line up their support, much of which has been lost in recent years because of fears of unrestrained American power.
Mr. Holbrooke is more willing than most diplomats to openly criticize African leaders and what he sees as slow-motion responses to crises. To underline the folly of neglecting AIDS in many countries, he said he will set aside a day for AIDS in Africa, particularly southern Africa.
"Some people wonder, why hold a Security Council meeting on a health issue?" he said. "There has never been a Security Council meeting on a health issue. The reason is simple. In Africa, in southern Africa, in countries like Namibia and South Africa, Zimbabwe and other countries, AIDS is far more than a health issue. It is jeopardizing the advances that these countries have made."
Mr. Holbrooke will be a relative newcomer to the Security Council, where he is seen only sporadically, and some diplomats wonder if he will have the patience to live by its peculiar rhythms for a month. He is a fierce critic of United Nations procedure, accusing the organization and many of the diplomats assigned to it with being more fascinated with process than principle.
At his news conference today, he took aim at the organization, which he said still needed a lot of reform -- a theme that Congressional Republicans always like to hear. He is impatient with the chain of command and the complex relationships among United Nations agencies. The Security Council and the Secretary General's office are on different wave lengths, he said.
He made his point with an anecdote: the collision of an event he had personally planned -- probably one of many taking place around the United Nations that day -- with a United Nations news conference to release a long-awaited report on mass killings of Muslims in Srebrenica, Bosnia, in 1995.
"On Nov. 15, we had the three Bosnian presidents here, a historic meeting," he said. "In the exact middle of that event, you were summoned to a press conference to release the Srebrenica report. So I called up the Secretariat. I said why did you do that?" He found it hard to believe that United Nations officials claimed not to have known about his visitors. "It happens all the time," he complained.
In the last American presidency of the Security Council of the Clinton era, there will also be some performance diplomacy. Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who is one of the most intractable critics of the United Nations, will be invited to sit in on the Council, and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, of which he is chairman, will hold a hearing in New York, Mr. Holbrooke said. Half a dozen senators and about 30 representatives have already been his guests.
Politically motivated stunts? Well, maybe, a European said. But if this is what it takes to get a better hearing on Capitol Hill, then everybody might enjoy a little American politics.
"Perhaps we didn't do a good enough job on bringing Congress aboard on policy in the past," Mr. Holbrooke said in one of several careful asides hinting that he is not always in line with the administration's handling of foreign policy issues. He was also asked today why so many war criminals in Bosnia are still at large, in part because NATO officers have said it is not their job to pursue them.
"I will not share my thoughts with you on why they're at large," he told a reporter. "I find it very, very difficult. I've long taken the view that they must be brought to justice."
At the American mission to the United Nations, whose somewhat shabby 1950's style attests to congressional stinginess toward diplomacy, Mr. Holbrooke has assembled his own team of trusted colleagues from the past. A tough taskmaster with a gargantuan appetite for work, he provokes either winces and wounded feelings or a loyalty often couched in black humor. One of his top diplomats recalled at his swearing-in that he had worked for Ambassador Holbrooke "for 10 years, between 1994 and 1995."
Mr. Holbrooke plunged into United Nations activity playing from his own strengths. After checking in at the United States mission here only long enough to claim his new office in August, he left for the Balkans. There, he is well known. Mr. Holbrooke, who was ambassador to Germany in the early years of the first Clinton Administration, later wrote the 1995 Dayton peace agreement for Bosnia, and then browbeat and cajoled three distrustful parties -- Croats, Serbs and Bosnian Muslims -- into accepting it.
He is also remembered for having secured a celebrated cease-fire agreement from President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia last October, only to see it violated, leading to an American-led bombing campaign this year. Mr. Holbrooke was characteristically blunt under criticism in June in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee for having negotiated with the Serbian leader, an indicted war criminal and recipient of much vitriol from Washington.
He criticized the limits of his instructions -- the Clinton Administration did not want to commit itself to ground troops to ensure peace in Kosovo -- and added for good measure that he talks with Mr. Milosevic were hardly fun. "This isn't bridge or tennis," he said.
Back from the Balkans on Labor Day weekend, he stepped off the plane into the maelstrom of the crisis in East Timor following the region's vote for independence. A former assistant secretary of state for East Asia, Mr. Holbrooke was no stranger to the region. Within hours, he renewed as many contacts as he could muster on a holiday, from human rights experts to diplomats in the region. Then he turned his sights on the White House as well as the Security Council to plead for more of an outcry.
A week later, the Indonesians had agreed to international intervention.
