SECTION: Section F; Page 2; Column 5; Science Desk 

LENGTH: 181 words

HEADLINE: Mission in the Rain Forest

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The Scientist at Work profile of Dr. Mark Plotkin was an unfortunately truncated picture of one of the most committed and effective individuals working for indigenous peoples, their cultures and the forests in which they live.
Yes, Mark Plotkin started out as a traditional ethnobotanist working in Suriname and the Amazon seeking indigenous knowledge that could be useful for modern medicine. 
 And, yes, he has ceased that approach. He did that not only because of the problem of low rates of "success" as measured by a drug going to market or because of issues surrounding intellectual property rights for indigenous knowledge but because as much as anyone, he is committed to these people and their cultures. His work has become a full-time effort to help these peoples protect their cultures and their knowledge and simultaneously protect the forests in which they live. That may be distant from his original approach, but it deserves real respect.
 
DR. THOMAS E. LOVEJOY
McLean, Va.
 
The writer is chief biodiversity adviser to the World Bank.

LENGTH: 1657 words

HEADLINE: Adviser to U.S. on Microsoft Likes to Avoid the Limelight

BYLINE: By LAURA M. HOLSON 

 BODY:
After 10 minutes with Robert F. Greenhill, a longtime Wall Street deal maker, it is clear why the Justice Department hired him to advise it on its negotiations with Microsoft.
Ask about his 20-year friendship with Sanford I. Weill, chairman of Citigroup and frequent dinner companion, and his answer is a firm "No comment." Question his role in some of this decade's largest corporate takeovers, like Viacom's bid for Paramount Communications or the restructuring of I.B.M., and he says, "I won't talk about that." And when queried about what it was like to run not one, but two, Wall Street firms, he dodges the question: "You don't really want to know, do you?" 
 After 37 years on Wall Street, Mr. Greenhill has joined the rarefied group of investment bankers who command the ear of America's corporate elite. Not only does he have a knack for wooing the most stubborn executives, but he has the drive to get them to the bargaining table. Still, while he delights in his role as matchmaker, he prefers to negotiate far from the eyes of a curious press and public. So it comes as no surprise to those who know him that the Justice Department sought his discretion in studying the financial impact of various proposals to resolve the antitrust case against Microsoft.
Besides, not many people on Wall Street have the stature to give counsel on the most important antitrust action in recent history. Joel Klein, head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, needs help sifting through the technological and financial implications of each proposal. And if indeed Microsoft is fractured into pieces, Mr. Klein wants a name-brand executive to defend that decision before Congress.
But of the handful of eligible candidates Mr. Klein approached, who would be willing to do it? Almost every leading investment bank with any technology prowess has either worked with Microsoft or does not want to risk making such a powerful enemy. And smaller boutiques could not afford the task.
"Whoever comes forward has to be credible," said Charles Koob, an antitrust lawyer at Simpson Thacher & Bartlett in New York. "Greenhill is credible."
Mr. Greenhill, who now owns a small investment firm, was attracted to the Microsoft assignment, in part, because it was an unusual challenge. And that is in keeping with his driven personality. Mr. Greenhill's recent interest in technology companies comes at an age, 63, when most executives are considering retirement. When he is not piloting one of his three airplanes, including a top-of-the-line jet, between homes in Greenwich, Conn., Maine and Nantucket, he can be found on his satellite phone with clients. (His wife pilots her own single-engine plane.) He took up golf in his late 50's and now boasts a solid 14 handicap. And on vacation, he pushes the limits, too, taking his family canoeing near the Arctic Circle or skiing in untainted wilderness.
But his true passion is negotiating deals. Sumner M. Redstone, Viacom's chairman, knows that firsthand. In the spring of 1993, Mr. Greenhill called Mr. Redstone and suggested that they and Martin Davis, then Paramount's chairman, have dinner. Mr. Greenhill knew Mr. Redstone coveted Paramount's assets but after three years of trying had failed to strike a pact with Mr. Davis. Mr. Greenhill knew Mr. Davis well because he had advised on Paramount's unsuccessful $12 billion hostile bid for Time Inc. in 1989.
"I said, 'If you are asking what I think you are, it's not going to happen,' " Mr. Redstone said in a recent interview. "I didn't want to get involved." Still, the two chairmen agreed to meet and, as Mr. Redstone predicted, the ensuing months' negotiations were tortuous. More than once Mr. Greenhill dragged Mr. Redstone to the bargaining table against his will.
"Bob was absolutely persistent," Mr. Redstone said. "A couple of times I said, 'Leave it alone. It's not going to happen.' I even sent a telegram that said, 'Bob, back off.' " But he never did until the deal was done.
Such forcefulness engenders enemies, too. Wall Street executives are loath to criticize Mr. Greenhill publicly, but privately warn that he can wreak havoc. When he left Morgan Stanley in 1993 to become chairman of Smith Barney Shearson, as it was then named, he relentlessly pursued talented financiers at Morgan, angering old colleagues. His abrupt manner has bruised more than a few egos. And his zeal to win at any cost offends even his most avid supporters. "He can be like a bull in a china shop," said one banker who worked with him.
Mr. Greenhill attended Yale University, graduating in 1958. At first he thought of majoring in physics, then philosophy and finally, painting. His senior thesis, he said, was on Van Gogh's theory of color. And in perhaps his first "hostile takeover," he met his wife, Gayle, when she was on a blind date with his college roommate.
After two years in the Navy, he abandoned his paint brushes and headed for Harvard Business School. In 1962, M.B.A. in hand, he moved to New York and joined Morgan Stanley.
From the outset, his career was blessed. In 1970 he became a partner and set to work creating a mergers and acquisitions department that would become a powerhouse. He later ran investment banking and, in 1989, was made a vice chairman. Two years later he was named president.
But Mr. Greenhill's intensity was not suited for the corner office. In March 1993, after a weekend retreat in Utah with clients, Mr. Greenhill was ousted as president. He left the firm soon after, ending a 31-year career, and found refuge with his good friend Mr. Weill, who named him chairman of Smith Barney Shearson, then part of the Travelers Corporation. That job lasted only three years before Mr. Greenhill -- pocketing tens of millions of dollars in the process -- was again asked to step down, former colleagues said, in a management tussle over how the firm was being run. In 1996, he started the boutique Greenhill & Company.
Mr. Greenhill finds it difficult to reflect on his undistinguished career as a manager. But former colleagues say he lacks an innate ability to lead. When asked about it, he becomes unusually still, his hearty laugh silenced. "One of the pleasures of being in a small firm is you can focus on working with clients," he said, noting that he has only six partners now. "Helping clients is the thing I've liked doing all my life."
Mr. Greenhill got a call from Mr. Klein the week before Thanksgiving asking if he was interested in the Microsoft assignment. Executives from Greenhill & Company then met with Justice Department officials to understand exactly what was expected. They were told, said an executive involved in those discussions, that it would be Greenhill & Company's job to analyze the financial impact if Microsoft were ever split up.
Mr. Greenhill has a limited background in technology, although he advised I.B.M. on its restructuring in 1993 and includes Compaq Computer in his stable of clients. "He doesn't necessarily understand all the technology he is dealing with," said one banker who has worked with him.
Mr. Greenhill, too, wanted a well-defined role, which he accepted on Nov. 28. He will not say what his firm is being paid by the Justice Department, but industry executives say it is a flat fee that is "substantially less" than the millions his firm usually commands. So far he has assigned six bankers to the task.
One is Jeffrey Williams, a long-time colleague of Mr. Greenhill who once headed Morgan Stanley's telecommunications and media group and counseled AT&T. Colleagues describe Mr. Williams, a former architect, as technologically astute and detail-oriented, a perfect foil to Mr. Greenhill, whose strength is distilling mountains of research by subordinates into a coherent action plan.
Mr. Greenhill is not shy about worming his way into the action. Michael Levitt, a partner at the leveraged buyout firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst and a close friend who worked for Mr. Greenhill at Morgan Stanley and later Smith Barney, recalled the summer of 1997 when Hicks, Muse announced it was buying Lin Television for $1.4 billion. A banker from Morgan Stanley had brought Mr. Levitt the idea, which Mr. Greenhill later asked about. "He didn't call up and say 'What role can we play?' " Mr. Levitt said. "He called up and said he wanted to understand the broadcasting industry and why we were interested in it."
Few bankers can get much mileage from a phone call like that. But Mr. Greenhill called Mr. Levitt later and said Hicks, Muse should line up a partner, like NBC, in case another bidder emerged. Mr. Levitt agreed. So Mr. Greenhill called his Nantucket neighbor, Jack Welch, the chief executive of General Electric, which owns NBC, and set up a lunch at his summer home there for Robert Wright, NBC's chief executive, as well as executives for Hicks, Muse.
It was timely. Raycom Media, an Alabama-based company, offered to pay $1.7 billion for Lin. And the lunch meeting at Mr. Greenhill's led to a partnership between Hicks, Muse and NBC that topped Raycom with its own $1.9 billion offer. "That was Bob using his network of relationships to create opportunities for both of us," Mr. Levitt said.
And he is doing the same thing for his firm by advising the Justice Department. Greenhill & Company is increasingly interested in representing Internet companies, having helped counsel Compaq this year on the sale of its 83 percent stake in AltaVista, a Web search engine, to CMGI, a publicly traded company that invests in Internet ventures. And his involvement in the Microsoft assignment suggests that Mr. Greenhill does not want to lose his edge in the new economy.
"Bob wants to make sure the world knows he's not out of the game," said one executive who has worked with him. But do not ask about it; his answer is predictable.
"I'll play golf with you," Mr. Greenhill said, laughing. "But I won't talk about Microsoft."

HEADLINE: Morgan Stanley Exceeds Expectations With Record Operating Profit

BYLINE: By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company reported record quarterly income of $1.63 billion yesterday, up 86 percent from its operating profit in the period a year earlier and well ahead of analysts' estimates.
In the first look at fourth-quarter results from a major Wall Street securities firm, the company said it earned $2.84 a diluted share. The profit was up from $1.49 a share a year earlier, when its operating income totaled $879 million, and was well ahead of the $1.96 a share expected by analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial. 
 "It's hard to argue with anything that they posted," said Richard Strauss, an analyst at Goldman Sachs Group. "It's a blowout quarter." Mr. Strauss raised his estimate of Morgan Stanley's earnings 20 percent last month, to $2.10 a share, only to be topped by 35 percent. Yesterday, he raised his estimate for the firm's 2000 earnings to $9.10 from $8.15 a share.
Morgan Stanley also announced that in January it would split its shares 2 for 1 and increase its dividend, before the split, by 67 percent, to 40 cents a share. The firm said it planned to spend up to $1 billion buying back its stock. Its shares rose 93.75 cents, to $128.9375.
Morgan Stanley, like a rival investment bank Goldman Sachs, which reports its earnings today, is riding atop two powerful trends: a boom in new stock offerings, especially by Internet-based companies, and a wave of mergers and acquisitions involving European companies. Morgan Stanley ranks just behind Goldman this year in money raised through initial public offerings and in the value of announced mergers and acquisitions.
"The I.P.O. boom certainly plays an important role in the results of the quarter," said Robert Scott, Morgan Stanley's chief financial officer. "We also had a record quarter in M & A with lots of activity in the U.S. and in Europe."
Mr. Scott said high levels of trading, especially stock trading, led to a 36 percent increase in commission revenue, to $786 million from $579 million in a depressed quarter a year earlier. Over all, the firm's profit from its securities businesses more than doubled, to $1.39 billion, in the quarter that ended Nov. 30.
The firm's 43 percent jump in revenue, to $5.66 billion for the quarter, surprised even the firm's management, analysts said. That was clear, they said, from how much the firm's compensation expenses shrunk.
Morgan Stanley set aside almost $1 billion less in employee compensation and benefits last quarter than the quarter before. Mr. Scott said the decrease was a result of the firm's practice of accruing money through the year to pay year-end bonuses. Those bonuses, which account for the bulk of annual pay for investment bankers and traders, will be paid in early January.
Traditionally, Morgan Stanley and its competitors pay about half of their revenues to their employees as salaries, bonuses and benefits. But, Mr. Scott said, Morgan Stanley had such a big year that it needed only 23 percent of this quarter's revenue -- 40 percent of the full year's revenue -- to pay competitive bonuses this year.
"They had such a stupendous year, if they had paid out 49 percent of this year's revenue, it would clearly argue that the business doesn't have economies of scale," said Joan Solotar, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
Ms. Solotar said the markets gained strength well into December, confounding most industry insiders, who thought investors would pull back in fear of Year 2000 problems. "Even those who weren't bearish thought it would be significantly slower," she said. "But money is still flowing into the markets."
Morgan Stanley's expenses aside from compensation were higher last quarter, Mr. Strauss said. He said some of the increase went toward technology and marketing for the firm's new iChoice online trading operation.
Mr. Scott said it was too soon to gauge the success of iChoice, but he said the firm was pleased that of the online accounts opened since the October introduction, 70 percent were for new customers and only 30 percent were transfers from the firm's traditional brokerage operation.

HEADLINE: Gore and Kazakh Leader Vow Cooperation

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore met with the president of Kazakhstan today to reaffirm United States support for the former Soviet republic and to sign an agreement covering issues ranging from economic cooperation to nuclear safety.
Mr. Gore also applauded President Nursultan Nazarbayev's investigation and punishment of officials who sold 40 older MIG-21 jet fighters to North Korea, and he said that Mr. Nazarbayev had recommitted himself to democratic reforms. 
 "The relationship between the United States and Kazakhstan is of great importance," Mr. Gore said, welcoming Mr. Nazarbayev to a meeting in the vice president's ceremonial office.
As part of the sixth meeting of the United States-Kazakhstan Joint Commission, the two officials signed a final report calling for greater consular cooperation, bilateral efforts toward decommissioning a Kazakh nuclear reactor, the transfer of nuclear safety technology, more small business assistance across borders, increased military contacts and other issues.

HEADLINE: Russia Votes, Like It or Not

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 20

 BODY:
The West has long seen the development of democracy in Russia as a check against the Kremlin's military ambitions and a way to bridge the political divide between East and West.
But consider the results of Russia's parliamentary elections: millions went to the polls and demonstrated their support for the war in Chechnya, despite its apparent brutality, by voting for candidates backed by Vladimir V. Putin, the hawkish prime minister closely associated with the war. 
 Western governments, especially the United States, have run into many difficulties in trying to deal with the new Russia: corrupt tycoons, die-hard Communists and an enfeebled president. But now they have found themselves squarely at odds with the Russian public.
The widespread backing for the war -- and Mr. Putin's personal popularity, which soared as the situation in Chechnya got more brutal -- not only reduces the already minuscule chance for a political accommodation in Chechnya. It also suggests a broad shift in Russian public sentiment toward a more nationalist, if pro-capitalist, stance.
"Putin will take this as an endorsement of his policy and wage the war even more fiercely," said Andrei Piontkovsky, a political analyst. "Democracy is not a guarantee against many nasty things."
Certainly, many Russians had reason to be concerned that Chechnya had turned into a lawless region of marauders and kidnappers. The trouble in the Caucasus region began in August when Islamic militants stormed into neighboring Dagestan. Later, apartment houses in Moscow and other Russian cities were blown up by terrorists, acts for which most Russians believe Chechen militants are responsible.
Mr. Putin also benefits from the Russian political psyche that hankers for a strongman: a political leader who can bring the country's disputatious regions to heel, force people to work and ensure that pensions are paid on time.
As a former intelligence chief, untainted by allegations of corruption and relatively new to politics, Mr. Putin seems to fit that bill.
But the way in which the current Chechnya campaign was turned into a major election-year asset, with a largely sympathetic Russian press playing down reports of civilian and military casualties while highlighting the army's heroic advances on the battlefield, was not supposed to be in the democracy lesson book.
In the past, Russian and Soviet military operations were perceived by the West as the adventures of secretive cabals, which the public would oppose if only it could.
When the Soviet Union invaded Afghanistan, Western governments assailed the Communist Party's ruling Politburo, and when the Yeltsin government dispatched the Russian Army into Grozny during the 1994-96 war in Chechnya, critics blamed a small Kremlin clique.
This time, whether the Chechnya campaign is considered a just fight against terrorism or a politically expedient war that has needlessly endangered civilians, it is different in this respect: many Russians believe that it is necessary and, as in any democratic society, share in the responsibility.
The election returns indicate as much. The Unity Party, which received 23 per cent of the votes cast for political parties, was established by the Kremlin only months ago. What gave it strength was its endorsement by Mr. Putin.
The Union of Right Forces, a pro-capitalist group, also did better than expected, with 9 percent. Led by Sergei V. Kiriyenko, a former prime minister, it received an enormous boost when Mr. Putin publicly praised its economic program.
Probably few voters knew what the economic program consisted of, but the campaign ads of a smiling Mr. Kiriyenko meeting with Mr. Putin was enough to bring in the votes.
By contrast, the only party that even remotely challenged the wisdom of the war, Yabloko, led by Grigory A. Yavlinsky, fared poorly at the polls, garnering only 6 percent.
"There was a chance to change the situation in 1999," Mr. Yavlinsky said ruefully on Sunday night. "But it did not happen. War, it seems, is a narcotic that can drown out all political problems."
The election results present a mixed message for the West. The good news is that the success of Unity and the Union of Right Forces broke the Communists' control of Parliament. That in turn increased the prospects for legislation to encourage investment and reform the tax system.
The bad news is that Russia's economic reformers are no longer the fair-haired boys they used to be, at least in the eyes of the West. To boost their parliamentary fortunes, they talked tougher than Russia's most hard-line generals and turned a deaf ear to the Western officials they once courted.
"Destruction of terrorism in Chechnya is, of course, the basis of continued support for Putin," declared Anatoly B. Chubais, the former Kremlin aide and architect of the Union of Right Forces' strategy.
And much of the Russian public seems to be hostile to Western opinion, at least if the voting results are any guide. But having urged Russia to embrace democracy, Western spokesmen could only applaud the elections -- if not the message they sent regarding the war.
That will not necessarily stop Washington from complaining about Russian policy on Chechnya. But it left officials in Washington groping for a response today.
"It says something about the system in Russia," said Joe Lockhart, the White House spokesman, "where elections are becoming more common, where the turnout is so strong and the democratic institutions, regardless of, you know, what you think of who won and who lost, have become accepted as the norm, and that's a positive."
Asked whether the election results, and their endorsement of the Chechnya policy, would make it harder for the United States to bring pressure to bear on the Kremlin over the war, Mr. Lockhart said: "Well, I don't know. I mean, obviously the domestic political audience may view it different than the international community does."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

High Bond Yields Hurt Dow, But Technology Shares Rise
Rising long-term interest rates hurt some segments of the stock market as concerns mounted about what Federal Reserve policy makers might do about interest rates at a meeting today. The yield on the 30-year Treasury rose to 6.44 percent from 6.37 percent on Friday. 
 Stocks seen as sensitive to rising interest rates, like financial-services companies, helped to pull down the Dow Jones industrial average by 113.16 points, or 1 percent, to 11,144.27. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 2.94 points, to 1,418.09, but demand for technology stocks remained intense, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 30.81 points, or 0.8 percent, to 3,783.87, a record. Page C10.
 
Putting a Good Face on Profits
The punishment that stocks regularly endure when profits come in shy of forecasts, even by the tiniest amount, has put managements under pressure to deliver upbeat earnings announcements even if the numbers do not support them. The result, according to some Wall Street accounting experts, is that more and more companies are going to extremes to paint a rosy picture of their operations. A1.
 
49% Stake Sold in Virgin Airlines
Richard Branson sold 49 percent of Virgin Airlines to Singapore Airlines for $965 million, giving the airline a global reach and highly profitable partner at a time when his airline is in a heated competitive battle with British Airways for trans-Atlantic passengers. C4.
 
Morgan Stanley Profit Rises 86%
Morgan Stanley Dean Witter posted an 86 percent increase in quarterly income, well ahead of analysts' estimates. The investment bank is riding two powerful trends: a boom in new stock offerings, especially by Internet-based companies, and a wave of mergers and acquisitions involving European companies. C21.
 
Mattel to Change Toy Materials
Mattel plans to eliminate petroleum-based plastics, which have been linked to an assortment of environmental and health problems, from Barbie and many of its other toys. F7.
 
I.R.S. Official Accused of Favoritism
The top Internal Revenue Service official in Northern California repeatedly gave wealthy and politically connected taxpayers unwarranted breaks including reduced tax bills, a refund, and deferred payments in 1996 and 1997, the government's former chief tax collector for the district testified. Peter W. Coons, tax collection chief for Northern California from 1995 until he was removed in February 1998, testified at a hearing where he is trying to get his job back under a federal law that protects whistle-blowers. The Internal Revenue Service contends that Mr. Coons was fired for looking at 253 Web sites on his government computer, five of them featuring images of naked women. Mr. Coons says the allegations are a smoke screen to obscure the real reason for his removal. C2.
 
Los Angeles Times Examines Deal
The Los Angeles Times published a 14-page special section detailing its ill-fated profit-sharing deal on a Sunday magazine section with the Staples Center sports arena. The erosion of traditional lines between the editorial and advertising departments raised questions about a possible conflict of interest. C2.
 
TV Networks to Share News Video
The news operations of CBS, ABC and Fox agreed to form a cooperative service to supply video pictures of news events to the affiliated stations of each network. NBC News was excluded. It was the first time that the three news organizations, which normally compete in news coverage, had gotten together on a formal basis to create a joint enterprise. C8.
 
Coca-Cola Bias Suit May Grow
Lawyers for four former and current employees who have brought a racial discrimination lawsuit against Coca-Cola filed a request to add four new plaintiffs and contended that M. Douglas Ivester, the company's outgoing chief executive, was directly involved in the company's employment policy. C10.

HEADLINE: In Libel Case, Court Rules 'Public Concern' Is a Factor

BYLINE: By DAVID ROHDE 

 BODY:
In a decision that could broaden protection from libel suits, New York's highest court issued a ruling yesterday making it more difficult for people to sue news organizations over articles that disclose details of their private lives provided the articles raise issues of "legitimate public concern."
The unanimous ruling by the State Court of Appeals involved a libel lawsuit filed by Charles Huggins, the former husband of the singer Melba Moore, over a series of articles published in The Daily News in 1993. The articles chronicled the couple's bitter divorce and Ms. Moore's accusation that her husband, who was her manager, had committed "economic spousal abuse" by ruining her career and bankrupting her. 
 Mr. Huggins sued The Daily News and Ms. Moore for $90 million, asserting that her statements were false, his reputation had been destroyed and their divorce was a private matter. Yesterday's ruling focused on what standard Mr. Huggins would have to prove in court to win his libel case.
The case sets a precedent because lower courts had ruled that while Ms. Moore was a public figure, her former husband was not. Under New York law, people deemed public figures must prove that a news organization's account was malicious before a libel suit can proceed, but others must prove only that a news organization was negligent, a lower standard.
In an initial victory for Mr. Huggins, the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court ruled in April that the couple's divorce was a private matter and that to win he only needed to prove that The Daily News had been negligent in printing the articles.
But in its unanimous opinion yesterday, the Court of Appeals reversed that ruling. Judge Howard Levine wrote that because the articles raised an issue of public concern -- what Ms. Moore called "the black-on-black crime of economic spousal abuse" -- Mr. Huggins would have to prove in court that the newspaper was "grossly irresponsible" in printing the articles, a far higher standard.
Lawyers for The Daily News and other New York news organizations hailed the decision yesterday. "The net effect of this opinion is that the flow of information in the state will be protected," said Eve Burton, deputy general counsel for The Daily News.
Sixteen news organizations, including The New York Times, The Associated Press, The Dow Jones Company, ABC, NBC and CBS filed legal papers urging the state's highest court to overturn the lower court ruling.
Bradley C. Rosen, the lawyer representing Mr. Huggins, said the ruling would give the news media free reign to report on people's private lives and then claim that the articles raised important social issues.
"This means that the most private aspects of a person's life can be reported on and arguably declared a matter of public concern," he said. "Whether it is a private person's very private divorce or a person getting a jaywalking ticket."
Mr. Rosen said that Mr. Huggins would still go to trial in the case.
Under the State Constitution and a series of rulings by the Court of Appeals, news media in New York generally enjoy far more protection from libel suits than news organizations in other states. Richard N. Winfield, a lawyer for The Associated Press who drafted the joint legal papers filed by the 16 media organizations, said there was concern that the appeals court could have eroded those protections.
But in his opinion, Judge Levine criticized the lower court with strong language. "Absent clear abuse, the courts will not second-guess editorial decisions as to what constitutes matters of genuine public concern," Judge Levine wrote. "The Appellate Division did not accord the deference to editorial judgment our decisions require."

HEADLINE: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS;
MEXICO LUXURY HOTELS FOR SALE

BYLINE: By Sam Dillon 

 BODY:
Mexico's bank rescue agency said it would try to sell the Camino Real hotel chain, which includes several of the country's best-known luxury hotels. The agency will auction the Camino Real Mexico City as well as others in Cancun, Guadalajara, Puerto Vallarta, Acapulco and El Paso, Tex., in the first half of 2000. The agency seized the hotels along with Banco Union S.A., the failing bank that had owned them, after Mexico's economic crisis five years ago.

HEADLINE: Playing the Field for Phone Service;
With Many Suitors, Customers Turn Fickle to Get Best Deal

BYLINE: By WINNIE HU 

 BODY:
Imelda Marcos picking out yet another pair of shoes. Patricia Duff running through five teams of divorce lawyers. Donald Trump and his succession of leggy blondes. In the annals of the fickle, some people are giants.
But alas, even among ordinary mortals, there has never been a shortage of caprice, whether in matters of the heart or the head, or in these modern times, matters close to the ear and the lips. That is to say, telephone service. 
 Every day, countless people jilt their phone companies and then embrace another in a kind of mating ritual that makes marketing executives stare at their ceilings at night. There are usually few warning signs before the split. It's not as if most callers can complain of egregious lapses like being cut off in midsentence.
Instead, after years of being stuck with one or two choices, telephone customers have suddenly become the belles of the ball. They are courted by dozens of phone companies, each dangling enticements like free calling time, frequent-flier miles and even $100 checks that come unsolicited in the mail.
"It's a kind of game that you play," said Ninon Rogers, 27, an actress in Greenwich Village who has switched phone companies five times in five years. "It is worth it because you get the same service for less money -- and sometimes outright cash."
A quick glance at Ms. Rogers's dance card: She signed up with Sprint in 1995, but was lured away by a $100 check from AT&T. In 1997, she bit at MCI's offer of 3,000 frequent-flier miles on Continental Airlines, but then settled again for Sprint because the international rates were lower. Last year, she was wooed back to AT&T with the 10-cents-a-minute plan for domestic calls.
Ms. Rogers is just the sort of disloyal customer who has helped stimulate a fierce competition in the telecommunications industry and drive the cost of phone calls down to just a few pennies per minute. A recent marketing survey of 12,185 households nationwide by J. D. Power & Associates showed that 31 percent switched their long-distance service at least once this year compared with 26 percent in 1997.
"I think the industry has created its own monster because companies keep topping each other," said Kirk Parsons, director of telecommunications accounts at J. D. Power. "Brand loyalty doesn't matter any more; what drives the consumer is cost. The way the rate is going down, in a couple of years, long distance is going to be free."
Well, not quite. But in this freewheeling buyer's market for telephone service, New Yorkers seeking to play the field have never had so many suitors -- or so many tangled offers that seem to promise one thing and turn out to be quite another.
In the past year, AT&T, MCI Worldcom, Sprint and a host of upstart companies have leased local lines from Bell Atlantic and started offering what is basically the same service. They have dangled sign-up bonuses like two free hours every month for six months (AT&T), a three-hour phone card picturing two cuddly polar bears (MCI Worldcom), frequent-flier miles and a $10 credit at Radio Shack stores (Sprint).
And they have pursued new customers in unlikely places. At the New York City Marathon last month, for example, Sprint banners heralded an unlimited local calling plan while workers passed out cellular phones for runners to make free calls. A local competitor, Z-Line, gave out plastic key chains and glossy cards that read, "Rudy. Hillary. Z-Line. New Yorkers love a choice."
The Web site Priceline.com, after letting customers name a price for airline tickets, hotel rooms and groceries, plans to do the same thing early next year for long-distance rates. Customers will be able to buy blocks of time from companies willing to match their bids.
But all these options leave some consumers simply flustered. They complain that calling plans are convoluted and seem to benefit those who scramble for the best deal rather than those who stand by their plan. Slick advertising campaigns sometimes leave crucial details like monthly fees and restrictions on calling times to the fine print.
"People are busy, and the phone companies take advantage," said Cindy McIntyre, publisher of The Frugal Gazette in Newtown, Conn., who advises her readers to call the phone companies every six months for the latest offers.
Even Jules Polonetsky, the commissioner of consumer affairs for New York City, seemed baffled by it all. He spent 45 minutes last month comparing his phone plan with half a dozen others before throwing up his hands. "It's more complicated than applying for a mortgage," Mr. Polonetsky declared, after ending up where he started: with his current company, Excel.
Some people are just looking for a down-to-earth relationship with their phone company, but that is increasingly hard to find. Lawrence Whiteside, 63, a building consultant in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, was nearly persuaded to switch by a letter from AT&T that promised what it called virtually unlimited local calling -- 75 hours a month -- and 7 cents a minute for long-distance calls, all for $24.90 a month. He had to call the company to find out that charges were rounded up to the next minute and that his fax line would cost extra -- pushing the price to $45 a month.
. "I'm looking for simplicity at the same time that I'm trying to save money," Mr. Whiteside said. "I don't want to spend half an hour going through a bill; that's too much like work."
Like Mr. Whiteside, many phone customers stay faithful to the company they know, if only because switching seems like too much trouble. For instance, Judy Langer, 58, a focus-group moderator in Manhattan, routinely ducks calls from telemarketers. "I'm not a comparison shopper," said Ms. Langer, who spends about $50 a month with MCI Worldcom. "It's a relatively minor expense, and we've been satisfied with the quality of service."
But an increasing number of people, either because they have more time, or less money, or both, are on the prowl for better deals. They scour the mail for the latest offers and compare notes with their friends. Several self-styled phone experts have even set up Web sites comparing the various pricing plans.
"Anything that's over $100 -- whether it's the cost of using it over a year or a one-time purchase -- I'm going to spend time on it," said Rich Sayers, an advertising sales manager from Martinez, Calif., who runs 10-10phonerates.com -- a Web site he created in May to compare 10-10 dial-in numbers that charge by the call and do not require monthly fees. The site logged 80,000 visits last month.
Still, some bargain hunters can be downright bashful about their obsession. John Williams, 32, switched from AT&T to MCI Worldcom in October after calculating that he would save $10 a month, or $120 a year. But he hesitates to brag about it for fear that he will sound like a "cheap date."
"You can really save a lot of money, but you have to sweat the details," said Mr. Williams, a computer consultant on the Upper West Side who also admits to clipping coupons. "It sounds ridiculous, I know, but every little bit helps, especially in this city."
Others offer no apologies for their love-'em-and-leave-'em attitude toward phone service.
Arlene Burgos, 27, a lawyer in Manhattan, said she saved hundreds of dollars by switching phone companies every six months in law school, raking in $100 checks and ever-lower rates. "They've never offered the $100 check right away," Ms. Burgos said, "but the more you held out, the more incentives they threw at you."
She recently saw an opportunity when an AT&T telemarketer offered to waive the monthly fee for the 5-cents-a-minute weekend rate if she left MCI. Instead, Ms. Burgos called MCI and asked for the same deal without having to go through the trouble of switching. Her company now mails her a $5 check every month to cover its fee.
"It doesn't hurt to ask," she said. "Your phone company is not going to call you and tell you that other people pay less for the same service."
Lately, Ms. Rogers, the actress, has been quarreling with AT&T over the $4.95 monthly fee for her discount phone rate. When she complains about it, the company removes it from her bill to keep her from leaving. Several months later, the fee will quietly reappear. And then she picks up the phone again.
When the day comes that AT&T refuses to drop the charge, she knows she will have to make good on her threat. "Ultimately, the reason I'd be switching is to switch back to AT&T at a later date," she said.
Spurned companies, Ms. Rogers confided, always offer the best deals.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Investor Is Accused of Fraud Over Azerbaijan Venture

BYLINE: By STEVE LEVINE

DATELINE: ALMATY, Kazakhstan, Dec. 21 

 BODY:
 An investment promoter who made a fortune from questionable stock dealings in his native Czech Republic years ago has now been accused of fraud in an Azerbaijan venture that has attracted $450 million from foreign investors. Some investors are prominent Americans, including former Senator George J. Mitchell and Leon G. Cooperman, a Wall Street fund manager.
The fraud accusation against Viktor Kozeny was contained in a civil lawsuit filed Friday in London by one of the investors, Marlwood Commercial Inc., a subsidiary of the American International Group, a diversified insurance company. The suit seeks $15 million, the amount of Marlwood's investment. 
 The High Court in London sealed the suit, but some details were disclosed Monday in a routine notification filed with the High Court clerk's office. The filing said there were fraud and breach of duty involving the long-stalled privatization program of Azerbaijan, an oil-rich Caspian Sea nation. 
 The lawsuit asserted that Mr. Kozeny fraudulently convinced investors they could buy, among other properties, part of the extremely valuable Azerbaijan state oil company, a concern that Azeri officials say they never promised to sell. In addition, the lawsuit asserted, Mr. Kozeny grossly inflated the price of privatization ''options'' necessary for bidding on the properties, charging investors $25 apiece when he paid as little as 25 cents apiece.
 In all, the lawsuit said, some of Mr. Kozeny's clients say their investment has plummeted to less than 10 percent of its original value, or a loss exceeding $400 million.
 Richard D'Alessandri, a lawyer for the American International Group, said the company would not comment on its lawsuit, which has also been filed in the Bahamas. Legal action was taken in London and the Bahamas because Mr. Kozeny owns property in those places that plaintiffs could move to seize.
 The group of about 30 American investors also included the real estate billionaire Richard Friedman, who owns a Martha's Vineyard estate where President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton have vacationed, and Frederick Bourke, chairman of Dooney & Bourke, the handbag company. 
 With $180 million in investments from institutional and other clients, Mr. Cooperman, chairman of New York-based Omega Advisors, is thought to have the greatest exposure to the Azerbaijan venture. Mr. Cooperman is not a party to the suit, though he said in a telephone interview that ''it doesn't mean we can't be down the road.'' 
 Mr. Cooperman said he and Mr. Kozeny were no longer working together. Mr. Cooperman also said he was still trying to persuade the Azerbaijan government to proceed with a significant privatization. The Azerbaijan government recently said it would do so, but would not yet include any part of the state oil company. Diplomats have described the company as a lucrative source of cash in a corrupt government that is unlikely to be sold anytime soon.
 ''Viktor brought us the investment through a friend,'' Mr. Cooperman said. ''We were not happy with his deportment. He became a lightning rod of resentment in the country. So we went our separate way.''
 Some of the Americans have described the Harvard-educated Mr. Kozeny, 36, as a gifted, charismatic salesman. He has attracted as much publicity for his spending binges as his investment promotions, including a 1997 London meal on which he spent $20,000, including $8,000 for a bottle of wine.
 Mr. Kozeny owns a mansion in London and a ski chalet in Aspen, Colo., though he usually lives on the Bahamas island of Lyford Cay. Several attempts to call Mr. Kozeny on Lyford Cay were unsuccessful. His lawyer, Jacqueline Miller, did not return three phone calls to her office in Palm Beach, Fla.
 The Azerbaijan affair bears a resemblance to one earlier this decade involving Mr. Kozeny in the Czech Republic, from which he came to the United States as a teenager. 
 Starting in 1991, Mr. Kozeny went on television and promised enormous returns for Czech citizens who turned over their privatization coupons -- every adult was entitled to them -- to the company he then ran, Harvard Capital and Consulting. 
 About 800,000 Czechs eventually did so. By 1996, Mr. Kozeny had earned a fortune estimated to exceed $200 million, while his clients' investment had plummeted. Some press articles called Mr. Kozeny the Pirate of Prague, a title that endures there.
 A Czech government investigation resulted in a finding of wrongdoing by his company, which was fined and ordered to reimburse $6.8 million of investors' money improperly spent on advertising and consulting fees. Mr. Kozeny was never criminally charged with fraud.
 In 1997, Mr. Kozeny shifted his attention to Azerbaijan. That year in Aspen, Mr. Kozeny was host to a party where, according to several accounts, he delivered an extremely vivid account of a coming windfall in Azerbaijan privatization.
 Mr. Kozeny said he intended to buy the gems of the Azerbaijan economy -- the telecommunications company, the natural gas distribution company and, especially, the state oil company, known by its acronym, Socar. With its refineries, pipelines and oil fields, Socar is said to be worth well into the billions of dollars. Those who heard the pitch told friends, and Mr. Kozeny suddenly had much American investment.
 In Baku, Mr. Kozeny's company, the Minaret Group, rented two floors in the Landmark, one of the most expensive office buildings in the Azerbaijan capital, which was then booming. Although Baku as yet had no stock market, he built a ''trading floor'' of computer banks.
 Mr. Mitchell, who invested an undisclosed sum, appeared in April 1998 as Mr. Kozeny's marquee guest at Minaret's catered grand opening at Baku's premier hotel. Mr. Mitchell's Washington law office said the former senator was traveling today and was unavailable for immediate comment.
 Shortly after the Minaret Group established itself, Azeri officials began delaying the privatization. Earlier this year, Minaret abandoned much of its office space, and condensed its operations into three rooms in the Landmark. Correction: January 13, 200, Thursday
 An article in Business Day on Dec. 22 about Viktor Kozeny, a promoter of a foreign investment fund in Azerbaijan, overstated the wealth of Richard Friedman, an American investor who participated in the fund. Mr. Friedman says he is not a billionaire.

HEADLINE: November Budget Gap Rises to $27 Billion

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21

 BODY:
The government recorded a $27.6 billion budget deficit in November, surpassing the $16.9 billion shortfall posted for the corresponding month of 1998, when Social Security checks were sent out in late October because Nov. 1 fell on a Sunday.
The Treasury Department said today that November's revenue totaled $121.4 billion while expenditures came to $149 billion. 
 For the first two months of the 2000 fiscal year, which began Oct. 1, the government is running a deficit of $54 billion.
A budget surplus is still expected for all of the current fiscal year, however. The Clinton administration is predicting a $142.5 billion surplus for the 2000 fiscal year and $168.2 billion in 2001.
For the 1999 fiscal year, the government reported a record surplus of $123.6 billion.
In November, the biggest spending categories were Social Security, $35 billion; Health and Human Services Department programs, $30.5 billion; interest on the public debt, $25.7 billion; and military spending, $21.5 billion.
Government revenue from individual income tax payments in November came to $57.5 billion. So far this fiscal year, individual income tax revenue has totaled $120.9 billion, compared with $111.6 billion for the corresponding 1998 period.
Corporate income tax payments totaled $1.7 billion in November. So far this fiscal year, corporate income tax payments came to $3.8 billion, compared with $5.2 billion for the 1998 period.

HEADLINE: Former Aide To Franco Challenged In Galicia

BYLINE: By AL GOODMAN 

DATELINE: SANTIAGO DE COMPOSTELA, Spain

 BODY:
Manuel Fraga Iribarne, Francisco Franco's propaganda chief in the 1960's, is the only veteran of the old fascist dictatorship who still holds high elected office in democratic Spain.
Mr. Fraga has been president of his native Galicia in northwest Spain for nearly a decade, but as he turned 77 in November a fierce battle to succeed him was brewing here in the regional capital. 
 On the inside track are conservatives in Spain's governing Popular Party, which Mr. Fraga himself founded in 1989 after repeatedly failing to win election as prime minister after Franco's death in 1975.
On the outside are upstart progressives, who for the first time won control of most of Galicia's big cities last June. They say that despite Mr. Fraga's latter-day democratic credentials, which include helping to write Spain's Constitution of 1978, he rules relatively poor Galicia like a fief.
To all, Mr. Fraga's steely gaze and sly grin send a message not to expect a disappearing act. He shows every indication of seeking a fourth consecutive term in the regional elections due by 2001.
"My succession has come up, logically, because of my age and my years of service," Mr. Fraga told Spain's largest-circulation newspaper, El Pais, recently. "But it has been made clear that my succession is not open."
A top aide, Jesus Parga Lopez, put it more succinctly: "He is his own successor."
And Galicia's fiery opposition leader, Xose Manuel Beiras, is convinced that Mr. Fraga "wants to continue and die with his boots on."
Which may not surprise many people in this rainy, hilly corner of Spain near the Atlantic. Mr. Fraga's staying power recalls other leaders with Galician roots. The region produced Franco, who ran Spain for 36 years, and it was also the birthplace of Fidel Castro's father, who emigrated to Cuba, which his son has run for nearly 41 years.
The Communist Mr. Castro and Mr. Fraga may be ideological opposites but they have celebrated their shared Galician heritage during visits to to each other's territories.
As Galicia's president, roughly equivalent to a United States governor, Mr. Fraga has traveled to 28 nations to promote his region and is sometimes treated like a head of state.
His aides say that these trips, criticized by the opposition, have produced huge gains for Galicia's fishing, agricultural and industrial companies. But Mr. Fraga's economic counselor, Jose Antonio Orza, conceded that his department had never actually calculated the financial benefits.
Mr. Fraga is not the longest-serving of Spain's 17 regional government leaders; his counterparts in Catalonia, Extremadura and New Castile have held office longer. But Mr. Fraga is unique for his link to Franco, whom he served as minister of information and tourism and later as ambassador to Britain.
The Franco connection hampered Mr. Fraga's four bids to become prime minister, and the job of moving the Spanish right toward the political center finally went to his protege, the current prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar.
Mr. Fraga retreated to Galicia, a region of 2.7 million people, and has been elected three times with comfortable majorities. He has presided over increasing prosperity for Galicia at a time when Madrid has given it, and other regions, more home-rule powers in areas like education and health.
"Fraga is incredibly efficient at image-making," said Emilio Perez Tourino, secretary general of Galicia's Socialist Party. "He has been capable of making himself the symbol of this changing Galicia."
But the Socialists and Mr. Beiras's leftist Galician Nationalist Bloc have buried their differences recently to form a joint threat to Mr. Fraga, like pooling their resources to wrest control of the big city halls.
Other potential successors come from within the Popular Party, where analysts say that a longtime Fraga aide, Jose Cuina, heads a faction strong in rural Galicia, while Madrid's conservatives are pushing an aide to Prime Minister Aznar, Mariano Rajoy, who represents the urbane, better-educated Galicians.
Mr. Rajoy, the minister of education and culture, announced in November that the national government would soon invest nearly $1 billion for long-sought railroad improvements in Galicia.
Mr. Rajoy's news conference did not include Mr. Fraga, who was preparing to leave for another overseas trip, to Brazil. But the next day, a new opinion poll said Mr. Fraga was still the best-rated leader in Galicia.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Retail-Office Complex Reflects Groton's Rebound

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
When Michael B. Dunn began putting together a 10-acre parcel off Route 1 in Groton, Conn., in the mid-1980's, his initial thought was to put up a self-storage business. But as the region began to experience a renaissance, he reconsidered his plans.
Today, a $14 million development called the Gateway to Groton is taking shape on the site. An Applebee's restaurant has opened on the corner of Route 1 and Colver Court, an 80-room Hampton Inn is under construction on the front part of the property, and land clearing is under way for a 27,000-square-foot office complex at the rear of the property. 
 The region had been sharply affected by defense cutbacks that had an impact on the Navy's submarine base and related contractors like Electric Boat, but Mr. Dunn noted that it had since recovered.
"Ten years ago, this whole region was entirely dependent on defense, from the submarine base to Electric Boat," he said. "The local economy today is a lot stronger, a lot more diverse."
Some developers in the region are saying commercial property throughout the region is experiencing the "Pfizer effect," for Pfizer Inc., the pharmaceutical giant that has its world research headquarters in Groton and is building almost 800,000 square feet of new space in neighboring New London.
Real estate agents say there is considerable interest in retail projects that may benefit from the traffic that the Pfizer development is expected to generate. In addition, office complexes like the 350,000-square-foot Shaw's Cove in New London had vacancy rates as high as 50 percent in the early 1990's, when the defense industry was in decline, and now are fully occupied, with much of the space taken by Pfizer or some of the companies that support it.
"It may be the Pfizer effect, but there are a lot of other things driving the interest in commercial property in that area as well," said James Butler, director of the Southeastern Connecticut Regional Council of Governments and a former Groton town planner. For instance, the rapidly expanding Foxwoods and Mohegan Sun casinos are 20 minutes away, and business at Electric Boat is stabilizing for the first time in a decade.
Kiran C. Parekh, who is developing the Hampton Inn, said there were other benefits to the location of the Gateway to Groton project.
"There are a couple of other big businesses right close by, the Navy base right up Route 12, the Avery Point campus of the University of Connecticut -- all of those are going to be big traffic generators," he said. "We think there was the market for at least 100 rooms, but we couldn't fit that many on the site."
Whatever the reason, Mr. Dunn proposed the right project at the right time, according to those involved.
"That property sat vacant for years and years," said Timothy Londregan of Londregan Real Estate in New London. "It had a history of vacancy, and a reputation that nobody could do anything with it." But when he began marketing the property for a small hotel this year, he said, "we had all the corporate people from a number of the big national chains in here, and there was a lot of interest."
Mr. Butler, the former Groton planner, proposed the name Gateway to Groton because the site is just off Interstate 95 on Route 1, between the town's two main commercial districts, one to the north of the highway, and one to the south.
Mr. Dunn began assembling the property almost 15 years ago, buying several smaller parcels, including some land that had been approved for a shopping center before the developer withdrew from the project, a couple of small residential properties and a former boat sales yard with frontage on Route 1.
"We were worried about the environmental aspects because of lead paint and engine repairs, but we did the analysis and everything was clean," Mr. Dunn said.
He was also busy obtaining the necessary zoning permits, and authorization from the State Traffic Commission to add a traffic light and widen the street in front of the complex.
"We were working on all the approvals at the same time we were marketing the property, and had all the permits in hand by the time everyone came in, so no one was starting from ground zero," Mr. Dunn said. "They all had a running start and were able to get in the ground pretty quickly."
Mr. Londregan said the T. L. Cannon Company in Buffalo was developing the restaurant, "But once we put it under contract to Applebee's, I had a host of restaurant chains tell me that if the deal fell through, they wanted the next chance to develop it."
Stephanie Griffin, a spokeswoman for Cannon, which operates 28 Applebee's restaurants throughout New York and Connecticut, said that the company was looking at a number of Connecticut locations but that the Groton site attracted its interest because of its high traffic counts -- 30,000 cars a day pass by the property -- and its large daytime population of workers at local businesses.
At least one part of the Gateway to Groton is directly linked to the Pfizer development. The Ledge Light Community Federal Credit Union, organized to serve Pfizer employees and their families, has been told that its lease on the Pfizer research campus will not be renewed next year because the space is needed, so it will build new offices in the Gateway project.
Ledge Light will consolidate its customer service office in Groton and its administrative offices in New London into a single location. The credit union hopes to move into the new quarters by next September.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Nasdaq Soars Above 3,900 as Fed Leaves Rates Alone

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Two broad stock market gauges leaped to records yesterday, with the bulk of the gains coming after the Federal Reserve left short-term interest rates unchanged and kept its neutral stance toward future increases.
The gains were particularly pronounced in the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index, which registered its biggest one-day point gain ever. 
 The Nasdaq, which was up early in the session, jumped an additional 30 points after the Fed announced that it was not raising interest rates and that it was remaining neutral about a further increase.
Led by Internet companies like CMGI and Yahoo, the Nasdaq continued to climb, broke through the 3,900 barrier for the first time and closed at 3,911.15, a gain of 127.28, or 3.4 percent. With yesterday's gains, the Nasdaq is now up 78.4 percent for the year.
"We don't have a clue why this is happening, and everyone is amazed by it," said Steven C. Witt, a managing director at Firsthand Funds in San Jose, Calif., which has about $2.3 billion invested in technology stocks.
"We know there will be a correction at some point, but interest in technology has spread to a much, much broader audience than previously. What is going on is more than momentum investors piling into stocks that have worked in the past."
Laszlo Birinyi, who runs his own stock research firm, echoed those comments.
"This is not a mania, because it is so broad and so deep," he said. "This is more than that, even though I don't know how to classify it."
About a year ago, Mr. Birinyi forecast that the Nasdaq would peak at 2,800 in 1999, a prediction that most on Wall Street viewed as wildly optimistic.
The Fed's decision to stand pat also helped to fuel gains in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, the Dow Jones industrial average and the Russell 2000 index of smaller-company stocks.
The S.& P. 500 climbed 15.34 points, or 1.1 percent, to a record 1,433.43, led by Microsoft and General Electric, the two largest companies by market value.
The Dow, which was lower early in the day, rallied after the Fed announcement and closed at 11,200.54, up 56.27 points, or 0.5 percent. And the Russell 2000 index had a solid day, gaining 8.60 points, or 1.8 percent, to 475.79.
CMGI, the Internet holding company, and Qualcomm were two of the Nasdaq's biggest stars.
CMGI catapulted 47 13/16, to 270, after Henry Blodget, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, initiated coverage with an "accumulate" rating.
And Qualcomm, a phone and semiconductor maker, gained 30 1/16, to 496 7/8. The stock was lifted by optimism that Motorola or Nokia would buy its wireless phone unit.
"People are making a bet that analysts are going to be raising fourth-quarter earnings estimates early next year," said Michael Molnar, a managing director in sales and trading at Salomon Smith Barney.
"Rising interest rates will be the catalyst of a correction, and that will become more and more of an issue in the second quarter. But the prospects for the first quarter are great."

HEADLINE: Central Bank's Statement

 BODY:
Following is the text of the statement by the Federal Open Market Committee, the Federal Reserve's monetary policy panel, after its decision yesterday to leave interest rates unchanged:
The Federal Open Market Committee made no change today in its target for the federal funds rate. 
 Based on the available evidence, however, the committee remains concerned with the possibility that over time increases in demand will continue to exceed the growth in potential supply, even after taking account of the remarkable rise in productivity growth. Such trends could foster inflationary imbalances that would undermine the economy's exemplary performance.
Nonetheless, in light of market uncertainties associated with the century date change, the committee decided to adopt a symmetric directive in order to indicate that the focus of policy in the intermeeting period must be ensuring a smooth transition into the year 2000. At its next meeting the committee will assess available information on the likely balance of supply and demand, conditions in financial markets, and the possible need for adjustment in the stance of policy to contain inflationary pressures.

HEADLINE: Vermonters Would Keep Lid on Ben & Jerry's Pint

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: BURLINGTON, Vt., Dec. 17

 BODY:
A poignant cry is rising from many a Vermonter's heart these days, a plaint for local purity in the face of cold cash and the forces of globalization: "Say it ain't so, Ben and Jerry!"
Ever since Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc. announced on Dec. 2 that it had received "indications of interest" from potential buyers and was considering them, the entreaties of "Don't sell out!" have sounded from the Statehouse to the Internet to the streets of this lakeside city where the company began in 1978 as a little ice cream shop in a converted gas station. 
 Perhaps no other for-profit company is so known for its green, community-oriented virtue, typified by the 7.5 percent of pre-tax profits it gives away. It would be hard to name another company as symbiotically synonymous with its state. Ben & Jerry's sweet, dappled-and-tie-dyed image helps market Vermont, and vice versa, says Gov. Howard Dean.
"Anywhere I go in the country or the world," said Dr. Dean, who is fighting the possible sale, "When you say, 'I'm from Vermont,' they say 'Ben & Jerry's!' So it really is a signature corporation for the state."
And the state is reacting in its signature utopian way -- with homemade protests and calls to idealism. A street theater group demonstrated outside the Ben & Jerry's shop here last week, offering suggestions including the introduction of new flavors like Chubby Bureaucrat, Funky Money and Two-Faced Swirl. Despite diligent employees' scrubbing, the outside wall of the shop still bears the faint scrawl, "Don't Sell Out Vermont!"
Peter Clavelle, the Progressive mayor of Burlington, went to the protest, as did Representative Bernard Sanders, the independent Congressman whose district includes Burlington. In an interview today, Mr. Clavelle said that "Vermont is not for sale, nor should Ben & Jerry's be."
Part of Vermonters' concern is economic. Ben & Jerry's, Dr. Dean said, buys 300 million tons of milk a year from local dairy farmers at premium prices, and its ice cream factory attracts more visitors than any other tourist site in the state.
Some also see the battle as a last stand by hippie idealism against capitalism.
But Governor Dean, Mayor Clavelle and Representative Sanders painted the current conflict a bit differently. This fight, Dr. Dean said, is about globalization, and the need to keep companies in the hands of Vermonters. As Mr. Clavelle put it, "Folks on Church Street in Burlington should have as much or more control over our economy as those on Wall Street."
One effort to stop the possible sale tries to use Wall Street in the fight. Garret LoPorto, a Web designer based in Massachusetts who has worked for Ben & Jerry's on social projects, is proposing on a new Web site, www.savebenjerry.com, that people who care about preventing the sale buy shares so they can vote against it.
The site warns that "gigantic multinational companies are trying to take advantage of Ben & Jerry's undervalued stock price," and want to "skin the company alive and use its gentle lambskin brand to fool unsuspecting consumers into purchasing their soulless, profit-driven products."
The Web site, Mr. LoPorto said in a telephone interview, is "a way for the board of directors to see that other people care. Ben and Jerry have been doing this for over 20 years now. They're tired. When you're a prizefighter, you need people to cheer you on to keep going."
Amid all this hubbub, Ben (Cohen) and Jerry (Greenfield) have maintained an atypical -- some would say ominous -- silence. Chrystie Heimert, a company spokeswoman, said that neither she nor they would comment on the possible sale.
The only company word since the announcement came when Mr. Cohen, who was asked about the sale in an interview on New Hampshire Public Radio, said, "It's my strong personal belief that the only way that the company can actualize its progressive values is to remain independent, so within the bounds of my fiduciary duties as director, I am working hard to find a way to remain independent and return adequate value to the shareholders."
It is that "adequate value" for shareholders that is the rub. The Dec. 2 announcement noted that potential buyers had indicated they would pay significantly more than the company's stock value on the Nasdaq. Industry analysts have been speculating that if the company's board did not sell, it could lay itself open to legal attacks from angry shareholders.
That disturbs Mr. Sanders. "The directors of a company could actually be sued because they are responsive to their employees, to family farmers in our state and to the local economy," he said. "That sounds to me to be quite unacceptable."
Seeking to address just such a situation, the Vermont Legislature recently enacted what is widely referred to as the Ben & Jerry's law. It says that a company can consider factors beyond profit when it is deciding whether to accept an offer. But defenders of Ben & Jerry's worry because the law has not been tested in court.
There has been no official word on which companies are interested in buying Ben & Jerry's, but reports, unconfirmed by the companies, have included the giant Unilever and Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream. Roncadin, an Italian manufacturer, told Dow Jones Business News recently that it had been interested at first, but when other big players started bidding, the price jumped too high.
Mr. Cohen and Mr. Greenfield, along with a third director, Jeffrey Furman, control about 46 percent of the voting stock, which gives them effective control. They would thus seem to have the power to reject an offer.
Dr. Dean said he had met with the Ben & Jerry's board to make his pitch for ownership's remaining local. The members heard him out and asked some questions but did not indicate their leanings, he said.
He said he believed this was a time of "deep reflection and deliberation about who they are as a company."
Others close to the company speculate that the board is riven by disagreement, that the founders oppose the sale but others support it, arguing that it needs outside capital to ascend to a new level of growth and competition.
The internal nature of the decision-making has not stopped the Vermont Public Interest Research Group, which organized the Burlington rally, from pushing hard against a sale. Dave Rapaport, the group's executive director, said that perhaps the state should consider buying Ben & Jerry's.
Ben & Jerry's officials have announced no deadline for a decision.
Meanwhile, many Vermonters, when asked about a sale, sounded like Krista Reinhart, a forestry graduate student: "I feel like it's selling out, and it's against the initial mission of what we all love about Ben & Jerry's."
Matt Gallagher, an engineer, said, "It would be a shame -- it's an icon." His wife, Emily, also an engineer, agreed.
"It's like it's gotten too big for those two goofy guys to run," Emily Gallagher said.
Many Vermonters are hoping those two goofy guys will come through.
"I believe," Mr. Clavelle said, "that at the end of the day, the good guys will win. This has always been a good-guys story, and it can't end being just another business sucked by money-grubbers."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Slip a Bit More After Monday's Huge Drop

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Government bond yields rose moderately yesterday, continuing the run-up that has taken them to two-year highs even as the Federal Reserve decided to leave short-term interest rates unchanged and to keep its stance neutral.
The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond slipped 8/32, to 95 21/32; the yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.46 percent, from 6.44 percent on Monday. 
 William A. Hornbarger, fixed-income strategist at A. G. Edwards & Sons, said the bond market's performance on Monday, in which the 30-year bond's price fell 25/32, was the steepest one-day decline since February. He called it an indication the market feared more interest-rate increases by the Fed. The lack of liquidity at year-end has most likely exaggerated the recent weakness.
"It should be noted that the yield spread between the 2-year note and the 30-year bond continues to narrow and is currently at 26 basis points," Mr. Hornbarger said; a basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. "A more restrictive monetary policy tends to produce a narrower yield spread."
"In terms of this week, the biggest event was obviously today's F.O.M.C. meeting," he said, referring to the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's policy panel. "Coming into the meeting it was highly unlikely that the Fed would alter monetary policy" so close to the year 2000.
"The street consensus was that the Fed would adopt a tightening bias, which they didn't," Mr. Hornbarger said. "A change in the bias would not have meant that a tightening was a foregone conclusion. It simply would have meant that the Fed views the risks as unbalanced and that they are more likely to tighten than to ease going forward." He noted that the Fed had adopted a tightening bias, favoring higher interest rates, 22 times this decade and tightened after only six of those moves.
"Despite the recent weakness," Mr. Hornbarger said, "we still feel that bonds represent good values at these levels. Discounting the rise in energy prices, inflation remains well in check and there are signs that the interest-rate-sensitive areas of the economy continue to slow. A Fed tightening remains a big worry, but the flattening of the yield curve leads us to believe that further moves won't hurt long-term rates too much.
"At this point one has to look past the immediate impact of tighter policy and at the long-term effects of multiple moves in the federal funds rate."
Mr. Hornbarger said that if the Fed moved again, it would slow the economy and keep inflation in check, which is ultimately good for bonds. "In the near term, we look for yields to continue to hang around recent levels, but we still feel that looking into the first half of 2000, yields will fall from current levels, to under 6 percent."

HEADLINE: Fed Steady on Rates but Doesn't Rule Out Increase in February

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve voted today to leave interest rates unchanged but warned that it might raise rates early next year to head off inflation if the economy continued to grow at a rapid pace.
The central bank stopped short of adopting a formal policy signaling the likelihood of a future rate increase, saying that it did not want to risk throwing the financial markets off balance in the weeks leading up to the turn of the century given the possibility of fallout from the associated computer software problems. 
 But the Fed's policy-setting committee issued a statement making clear that it was only the potential for Year 2000 disruptions to the markets and the economy that kept it from formally putting investors on notice that a rate increase might come as soon as its next meeting on Feb. 1 and 2. And the practical effect of the statement was nearly the same in any case, emphasizing the Fed's willingness to consider a rate increase if the economy continued to run so hot that it generates inflationary pressures.
"The Fed may formally be neutral, but you don't even have to read between the lines to see that they're biased towards tightening policy," said James E. Glassman, an economist at Chase Manhattan in New York. "A new chapter of Fed tightening is certainly on the table for the February and March meetings."
The Fed almost never raises rates in the weeks before Christmas, and given the added concerns over Year 2000 computer problems, analysts had long ago concluded that the central bank would not push rates up today. On Wall Street, investors read the Fed's decision not to adopt a formal bias toward raising rates as good news, sending stock prices higher.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 56.27 points, closing at 11,200.54. Bond prices fell, sending up interest rates. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose 2 basis points, or hundredths of a percent, to 6.46 percent, its highest level since September 1997.
So far, there is little evidence that inflation might be taking root, despite economic growth this year of about 5 percent, a level that economists once assumed would set off broad-based increases in wages and prices, especially with unemployment as low as it is now -- 4.1 percent in November.
The economy's remarkable performance has led to wholesale re-evaluations among Fed officials and economists generally about the relationship between growth and inflation.
Those who believe the economy is now capable of substantially higher levels of noninflationary growth base their case on the huge investments by American business in computers and other technology and the associated pickup in the growth rate of productivity, or the amount that a worker can produce in an hour.
But in raising its short-term federal funds target rate three times this year, to 5.5 percent -- and through its statement today -- the Fed has stressed that even a more productive economy can bump up against inflationary pressures that needed to be squelched before they can endanger the long expansion.
The Federal Open Market Committee "remains concerned with the possibility that over time increases in demand will continue to exceed the growth in potential supply, even after taking into account the remarkable rise in productivity growth," the central bank's statement said.
"Such trends," it continued, "could foster inflationary imbalances that would undermine the economy's exemplary performance."
The committee said it was nonetheless maintaining its current neutral policy stance to emphasize that its focus in coming weeks "must be ensuring a smooth transition into the year 2000."
At its meeting in February, the statement said, "the committee will assess available information on the likely balance of supply and demand, conditions in the financial markets and the possible need for adjustment in the stance of policy to contain inflationary pressures."
Economists said the economy had retained its considerable momentum as it headed toward 2000. Some of the robust growth may come from companies' stockpiling goods and supplies as a protective measure in case the economy is disrupted by computer problems starting on Jan. 1. But most of it continues to stem from strong consumer demand and a buoyant stock market, heavy levels of business investment and a rebound in many foreign countries.
Many forecasters say the economy is likely to slow next year but not right away and probably not until the Fed pushes the federal funds rate up by at least half a percentage point, to 6 percent.
"I do expect a slowdown, but I don't think it will be sufficient to ward off more Fed tightenings, and I don't think it will be apparent in the first month of the year," said Marilyn Schaja, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "We'll see at least two more Fed tightenings with the potential for a third if the economy does not slow."
As the prospects grow for a series of rate increases next year, so does the likelihood that the Fed will become a political issue in a presidential election year. But the White House reiterated its support today for Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, whose term expires in June. President Clinton is widely expected to nominate Mr. Greenspan to a fourth four-year term.
"The president believes he has done a good job, has a lot of respect for the job he's done and likes him personally, and when we're ready to announce a decision, we'll announce a decision," Joe Lockhart, the White House spokesman, said today.
But Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues are likely to face some difficult decisions about how much leeway to grant the economy, given the absence of inflation, the benefits of low unemployment and robust job creation, and the wealth being created by the stock market.
Robert V. DiClemente, an economist at Salomon Smith Barney, said the Fed might even consider a half-point rate increase in February if domestic demand and the stock market remained strong. The Fed has not raised rates by half a percentage point since February 1995, at the end of a tightening cycle in which the central bank doubled the federal funds rate, to 6 percent, in the course of a year.
Among the problems facing the Fed is that higher rates so far have done little to restrain Wall Street; its continuing rise is seen by most economists as a key driver of consumer confidence and spending.
But there are also indications that even sectors of the economy that traditionally have been most sensitive to rising rates, like housing, have so far remained relatively robust.
