HEADLINE: Space Travel in a Loft

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER MASON 

 BODY:
CLIENTS willing to indulge the futuristic whims of architects are notoriously rare. But Winka Dubbeldam, a Dutch-born architect based in Manhattan, seems to have a knack for attracting patrons susceptible to her visual poetry and her sculptor's passion for combining natural materials to achieve novel effects. Among her fans, the famously demanding architect Peter Eisenman called her "a very talented, highly energetic and motivated person."
"She's the pulse of the moment," he added.
Swinging open a pivoting door at the center of a 50-foot-long wall of translucent glass and steel that tilts at five distinct angles, spaceship-style, Ms. Dubbeldam said, "What I do is so specific, people either love it or hate it." 
 She was standing in the exuberantly minimalist SoHo pied-a-terre she designed for Jonathon Carroll, a British art collector, who recently retired from investment banking at 33. "As my mum says, I'm unemployed," the Birmingham-born Mr. Carroll joked.
A devotee of cutting-edge design, he seemed eager to extol the beauty of his loft, and its sense of play: the space flows freely through three distinct areas, kept in flux by moving parts and transparency.
"I think it's a reaction to the traditional house with chintzy curtains I grew up in -- the kind of house that still horrifies me," he said.
The apartment occupies the fifth floor of a former warehouse, built around 1870, which had been unoccupied for a decade when Mr. Carroll moved in last year. He interviewed three architects before hiring Ms. Dubbeldam, admiring the experimental verve of her portfolio and her imaginative use of wood, polished plaster, steel, concrete and glass.
"I only work with natural materials because they have a subtle, soft effect on the experience of the space," Ms. Dubbeldam said, adding that she developed an affinity for them while studying sculpture. "I love the feeling of spaces that are seamless and fluid, where there's a possibility of transforming the space by pivoting a table, swiveling a TV."
Her passion for design was kindled in childhood in Gorinchem, a seaside town near Rotterdam, where she grew up the daughter of a government official and a fashion stylist. "My parents bought a new house every two years, because my father loved finding new houses and my mother loved doing the interiors," said Ms. Dubbeldam, a sprightly, handsome woman with expressive hands and eyes that are apt to twinkle when she speaks of architecture. "So, I was always fighting with my brother over who got the best room."
Spurred by that early sibling rivalry, Ms. Dubbeldam went on to graduate from the Academy of Architecture in Rotterdam before moving to New York in 1990 to study at Columbia University. From there, she worked for two innovative and internationally recognized architects, Bernard Tschumi and Mr. Eisenman, before setting up her own firm, Archi-Tectonics, in 1994. Fascinated by the challenges of creating sculptural design using computers, she currently teaches Paperless Studio, a course for third-year architecture graduates at Columbia University and the University of Pennsylvania. Her meticulous computer-generated drawings, and a model for a house in Millbrook, N.Y., were included in "The Un-Private House," the Museum of Modern Art's critically acclaimed summer exhibition.
Ms. Dubbeldam has a fascinating way of layering space to create a sense of peacefulness: few interiors can match the tranquillity of Mr. Carroll's apartment. Stepping from the elevator, visitors first encounter a wall of soft-gray plaster interrupted at waist level by a broad horizontal cutaway that offers a peak into an intriguingly spare, ordered interior.
To obscure an unappealing view, windows at the rear of the loft were coated with a translucent, removable film that resembles sandblasted glass, creating the effect of radiant light boxes by day and providing privacy at night.
Ingeniously configured expanses of translucent glass, steel and concrete also dominate the new 24,000-square-foot headquarters on West 23rd Street of Duggal Color Projects, one of the city's largest photographic and computer imaging companies, which Ms. Dubbeldam designed for Baldev Duggal, the owner.
"Our work is all rush and meeting deadlines, but here, you still get a feeling of peace," Mr. Duggal said, contemplating a sweeping circular steel staircase leading to a new 6,000-square-foot cantilevered mezzanine -- a serene, glass-clad office space that appears to hover above the busy main floor "street level." Vintage columns form an arcade. The office has walls of opague glass; clear glass inserts at eye level form a horizon.
For Mr. Carroll, Ms. Dubbeldam produced drawings and models so inventive and assured that Mr. Carroll felt confident about leaving her to execute his project, monitoring progress from London via e-mail, fax and weekend visits once a month. "Winka had to make a lot of decisions for me," he said. "But she actually made better choices than I would have made myself."
Soaring arched windows illuminate the immense main living space, which encompasses three free-flowing but distinct areas, each containing movable elements that contribute to an engaging sense of playfulness, inviting discovery.
In a spacious sisal-carpeted sitting area, floor-to-ceiling raw-linen curtains can be drawn to create an intimate atmosphere for lounging in front of a slate fireplace set into a jutting, right-angled corner. Across the room, a silver flat-screen television suspended from a vertical pole can be swiveled to provide entertainment from multiple angles. Similarly, a poured-acrylic see-through breakfast bar, cantilevered from a tree-trunk column in front of the gleaming stainless-steel kitchen in the center of the apartment, can be swiveled from side to side at whim. "The structural engineer kept saying, 'Are you sure you want this?' " Ms. Dubbeldam recalled. "I guess it was a bit new for him."
Clearly enchanted by all the modernity, Mr. Carroll does not seem at all fazed that his designer has given him a doorless master bedroom. "It is possible to have privacy," he insisted, dragging a giant moss-green Ultrasuede curtain around the room to demonstrate that it can be transformed into a giant cocoon. "It is a bedroom, after all," he said.
Nearby, a suite of more intimately scaled rooms -- a modern walnut-paneled library, two guest bedrooms and the master bathroom -- are nestled behind the apartment's signature bulging steel-and-glass wall. The bathroom, contained in a glass capsule, is the most spectacular.
"If you're naked in the shower and your mum and gran are sitting out there in the kitchen having breakfast, you obviously don't want them going, 'Oh, my God!' " Mr. Carroll said, recalling that he erred on the side of caution when he and Ms. Dubbeldam experimented with glass of varying clarity for the wall.
"I said it should be more translucent, because it would steam up when you take a shower," Ms. Dubbeldam added mischievously, noting that they reached a compromise with semiopaque panels that permit the passage of light but preserve a bather's privacy.
In a striking contrast to the rest of the apartment, where neutral-toned plaster walls complement artworks by Warhol, Christo and Hockney, the master bathroom is a riot of vivid, purplish-blue polished plaster. The floor, washstand, shower and bathtub were created by pouring a thin warm-to-the-touch layer of concrete, mixed with prodigious quantities of pigment over custom-built molds of fiberglass and timber.
The most startling feature is the stainless-steel toilet from Metcraft, a Missouri-based company that supplies prisons. "I said I wanted two, and the guy said, 'Two hundred, right?' " Ms. Dubbeldam recalled, laughing.
Somewhat alarmingly, the all-metal toilet has no raiseable seat (to spare inmates the temptation of prying them off to use as weapons). "When I explained that to Jonathon, he said, 'But it's going to be cold,' " Ms. Dubbeldam said, grinning. "So I told him, 'Get used to it.' "
Working with Mr. Duggal over the last year on his new headquarters in Chelsea, Ms. Dubbeldam found herself dealing with a client no less passionate than Mr. Carroll about innovative design, but with an infinitely more complex and shifting series of spacial requirements. The challenge was to accommodate under one giant roof advances in new technology and operations that had sprawled over 12 floors.
At the company's new headquarters, gracious 1880 cast-iron columns coexist with sleek new forms in an office that is a city block deep.
"The columns are the real sculpture of the space," Ms. Dubbeldam said, recalling that all 18 were invisible under multiple layers of paint, gypsum and grime before Mr. Duggal had them stripped.
"I'm lucky having Jonathon and Mr. D. as clients because they're like me -- they want everything to look perfect," Ms. Dubbeldam said. She withholds such praise for those who labor at Gear magazine, whose offices in Chelsea she designed for Bob Guccione, the publisher, earlier this year.
"As the architect, I can't very well say, 'Clean this up!' " Ms. Dubbeldam noted ruefully. On a recent visit, Gear's spacious blue-and-green river-view offices were strewn with a workaday assortment of sports equipment, stray files and portable coat racks.
"Winka thinks we're a bunch of pigs, I guess," said Lonnie Major, the office manager.
To escape the exigencies of her architectural practice, Ms. Dubbeldam often leaves the city on weekends, driving her 1976 Pacer, with its distinctive oblong hatchback. "I can't tell you how much I love it when people in big Mercedes yell, 'Love your car,' " she said. Ambitiously, she is counting on the Pacer to pull her latest acquisition, a silvery 1967 Airstream.
"Next," she said, "I want to buy a piece of land so I can park my Airstream."
And hopefully, find the time to build a house of her own.

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

EUROPE
 
RUSSIA: TALKS WITH U.S. -- Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott discussed arms control and other issues with Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, but the two appeared to make little headway. The Defense Ministry again ridiculed United States proposals to alter the 1972 antiballistic missile treaty to permit a limited defense against rogue missiles, saying the treaty is the basis of arms control. Michael Wines (NYT)
 
RUSSIA, BELARUS: PACT APPROVED -- Legislators in Russia and Belarus voted to ratify a treaty moving the two nations closer to economic union, but still well short of political merger. The treaty, signed this month by the Russian and Belarussian presidents, calls for a unified tax system by 2001 and a common currency by 2005, but is mostly short on details. It replaces a similar document signed in 1996. Michael Wines (NYT) 
 
BRITAIN: PINOCHET HEALTH CHECK -- Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the former Chilean dictator, will be given an independent medical examination on Jan. 5, the government said. General Pinochet, 84, has complained of poor health as he waits for possible extradition to Spain on charges of torture. Sarah Lyall (NYT)
 
BRITAIN: EASING QUARANTINE -- Starting Feb. 28, cats and dogs entering Britain from European Union countries, Switzerland and Norway will not be subject to the usual six months in quarantine. The government said that as part of a pilot program, pets vaccinated against rabies and that have been fitted with an identity microchip, among other things, will forgo the usual stay in a government-approved kennel. Sarah Lyall (NYT)
 
SWITZERLAND: MORE SLAVES BOUGHT -- A Swiss-based rights group said it bought the freedom of 5,514 more slaves in Sudan last week. Christian Solidarity International said the latest action brought to 20,961 the number of slaves freed through its program since 1995. The executive director of Unicef, Carol Bellamy, has said the practice of buying slaves' freedom "encouraged more trafficking and criminality." (Reuters)
 
UKRAINE: PREMIER APPROVED -- Parliament approved the central bank chairman, Viktor Yushchenko, as prime minister. Mr. Yushchenko, 45, was backed by 296 of 411 members in the chamber, well clear of the 226 votes needed for confirmation. Mr. Yushchenko, who advocates radical market reforms, pledged to reduce government intervention in the economy, consolidate state finances and promote privatization and land reform. (Reuters)
 
AFRICA
 
NAMIBIA: U.S. WARNING -- The American Embassy issued a warning against travel in northeast Namibia, where fighting between Angolan rebels and Angolan and Namibian forces persists. Angolan troops have recently operated openly in northern Namibia, using the area to mount attacks on rebel bases in Angola's extreme southeast. The attacks have prompted rebel strikes against Namibian forces. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)
 
NIGER: PRESIDENT SWORN IN -- The newly elected civilian president, Tandja Mamadou, took his oath of office, marking the end of military rule. Mr. Tandja, a retired army colonel, succeeded Ibrahim Bare Mainassara, who won the disputed 1996 presidential election but was shot dead by soldiers in April. (Reuters)
 
ASIA
 
INDONESIA: U.N. TRIBUNAL RULED OUT -- Indonesia will not allow its top generals to be tried at a war crimes tribunal being considered by the United Nations, President Abdurrahman Wahid said, adding that Indonesia's judicial system would bring those responsible for atrocities in East Timor to justice. He spoke after the former military chief, Gen. Wiranto, failed to appear before a panel investigating East Timor abuses. (AP)
 
CHINA: COMPUTER ALERT -- China has ordered a three-day New Year's holiday and prohibited foreign ships from entering Chinese ports for two days to minimize disruptions from possible computer coding failures, the state-run China Daily reported. The last day of business for 1999 will be Dec. 30. Government agencies and businesses will not reopen until Jan. 3. (AP)
 
TAIWAN: TOP AIDE RESIGNS -- The president's chief of staff resigned after admitting to an affair with a former actress, which he called a "serious error." John Chang, 58, grandson of Chiang Kai-shek and the only Chiang descendant active in Taiwan politics, said that he needed time off to be with his family but that he planned to continue in public service. Mr. Chang is a former foreign minister and deputy prime minister. (AP)
 
INDIA: SEATS FOR WOMEN -- Despite growing opposition, the government will introduce a bill in the lower house today seeking to reserve seats in Parliament for women, Parliamentary Affairs Minister Pramod Mahajan said. On Tuesday opposition legislators held a sit-in against the bill, saying it should also include quotas for lower castes and minorities in general. (Reuters)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
MEXICO: BUDGET IMPASSE -- Congress, meeting in extraordinary session to vote on next year's budget, defeated the bill offered by President Ernesto Zedillo's party as well as an alternative bill from the opposition, which includes slightly more spending for health and education. Lawmakers renewed negotiations, with some urging a second session after Christmas but before the New Year, when the budget must be approved to avoid a constitutional crisis. Sam Dillon (NYT)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
ISRAEL: GOLAN RE-EDUCATION -- Education Minister Yossi Sarid sent a letter to school principals urging them to open up classrooms to discussion of a possible withdrawal from the Golan Heights. Calling it "a controversial and burning issue on the national agenda," he said viewpoints supporting and opposing withdrawal as a condition of peace with Syria should be presented. Deborah Sontag (NYT)

HEADLINE: Pataki's Cigarette Tax

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "New York Raising Tax on Cigarettes to Help Uninsured" (front page, Dec. 18): As a smoker, I feel robbed. 
 First, while extending medical care to all who need it is a program worthy of any Democrat, paying for it is the responsibility of all of us. There is no fiscal justification for exempting non-smokers from financing the program's cost.
Second, Gov. George E. Pataki's economic calculation is iniquitous. Habituated smokers' demand for cigarettes is price inelastic. Exploiting inelasticities along a demand curve is called price discrimination and is outlawed in civilian applications under many of our antitrust laws. Third, the smugness with which nonsmokers believe that raising the price will reduce the number of smokers is as offensive as it is wrong-headed. Smoking is not a crime and should not be penalized.
MICHAEL ADLER
New York, Dec. 18, 1999

HEADLINE: U.N. Panel Agrees On Two-Year Budget

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 22

 BODY:
A General Assembly committee reached agreement today on a two-year budget for the organization that American diplomats hope will fall within the "nominal no-growth" spending demanded by the United States Congress in return for releasing money to pay overdue American debts.
The budget is expected to be approved by the full General Assembly on Thursday. 
 The two-year budget for the headquarters -- not including money to be spent on agencies like Unicef or the World Heath Organization, which raise their own funds -- has been held to $2.535 billion, $2 million more than the previous budget, diplomats said.
The American demand for a no-growth budget, which some United Nations officials see as hamstringing the organization for domestic political reasons in Washington, was one of many conditions that Congress attached to payments to the United Nations. The United States is now more than $1 billion in debt, a sum close to the United Nations operating expenses for one year.
The most difficult Congressional condition remains to be settled, a demand to lower American payments to the organization. The payments are linked to the proportion of the world economy in the hands of the United States. That issue will be taken up in the new year.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
G.M. and Ford Expected to Compete for Daewoo Motor

BYLINE: By SAMUEL LEN 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 22

 BODY:
The Daewoo Motor Company became the object of a potential bidding brawl between the world's two largest automakers today after the South Korean government decided to solicit offers instead of negotiate with a single buyer.
The government, which is overseeing Daewoo Motor's sale as part of a broader dismantling of the Daewoo Group, the insolvent conglomerate, decided to auction the automaker after the Ford Motor Company expressed interest in buying it. Earlier, the government had indicated it might bargain exclusively with the General Motors Corporation, which said last week that it wanted to buy Daewoo Motor. 
 It is unclear how much buyers ultimately would be willing to pay for Daewoo Motor, which carries more than $16 billion of Daewoo Group's estimated $78 billion in debts. But G.M. reportedly had offered as much as $7 billion for Daewoo Motor's assets, and the assumption of an unspecified amount of the debt.
For both Ford and G.M., the acquisition of Daewoo Motor would offer an instant expansion of their manufacturing and marketing in Asia, which has rebounded from a 1997 economic crisis and is now considered a most promising region for increased vehicle sales.
The Financial Supervisory Commission, the government agency responsible for the sale of Daewoo Motor, said it would "take place through a method where an investor with the best advantages, selected from their letters of intent, will be given exclusive negotiating rights."
G.M. declined to comment on the government's decision, but it is clearly a setback for the automaker, which had hoped to reach a deal without rival interference by negotiating an exclusive contract quickly.
Ford said it intended to step up negotiations with Daewoo Motor's South Korean creditors. Jim Bright, a Ford Motor spokesman in Detroit, said that Paul Drenkow, a senior Ford manager in the Asia-Pacific region, would lead a group meeting in early January with Daewoo Motor's main creditor, Korea Development Bank.
"Projected growth in the global auto industry is going to occur in other places than in North America and Europe, and most of that growth is going to occur in Asia," Mr. Bright said. "We're definitely interested in Daewoo Motor."
Ford and G.M. have jostled before in trying to acquire a South Korean automaker. When Ford began a serious bid for the Kia Motor Corporation, G.M. flirted briefly with that bankrupt company until the Hyundai Motor Company beat Ford in October 1998.
South Korea has spent the last year recovering from the Asian economic crisis and car sales this year have doubled since the peak of the recession in 1998, nearly catching up with levels seen just before the crisis began in 1997.
Combined domestic and overseas car sales by Daewoo, Hyundai and Kia totaled more than 300,000 vehicles last month. Ranked by automobile sales, South Korea is second only to Japan in the Asian market.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Kodak has given its Times Square billboard a face lift to keep up with the neighborhood.

BYLINE: By Courtney Kane 

 BODY:
ONE of the original extravagant signs at the crossroads of the world has undergone a face lift to keep up with its glitzy high-technology neighbors.
After 15 years, the Eastman Kodak Company recently renovated its billboard, which has been a fixture in Times Square since it was designed as part of the exterior of the Marriott Marquis Hotel on Broadway between 45th and 46th Streets. 
 The gigantic billboard -- which outdoor-advertising executives refer to as spectaculars -- has always featured an illuminated image of stunning photography accompanied by the Kodak logo. Now, the new sign, which is 52 feet high by 70 feet wide, is not only 20 percent larger than its predecessor but is brighter and features a state-of-the-art Sony Jumbotron screen.
"Signage in Times Square has been changing dramatically over the past several years," said Mike Ianzito, director for marketing communications at Eastman Kodak, which is based in Rochester. "It was really our goal to bring it up to current times. With all the advances in technology, we decided to recreate the Kodarama with a completely new concept in lighting and imagery."
The new 1,800-square-foot Kodak image area, which the company refers to as the Kodarama, is divided into three areas: a 15-by-60 foot primary display that takes up the lower half featuring eye-catching photographs like those its predecessor displayed over the years. In the upper right portion is the Sony Jumbotron video screen. And the other section is either used as an extension of the main display or to show images of Kodak products and promotions.
"With the new video capability, we can show our commercials or do live telecasts from the Olympics or other venues," Mr. Ianzito said. In addition, Kodak will be able to create direct links to its Web site, displaying Web pages like Kodak Photoquilt, where consumers send in their most meaningful photos.
The content of the billboard, created by the New York office of the Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide unit of WPP Group, will ideally change every few months or so, Mr. Ianzito said. But through January the display will feature Kodak's "millennium gallery," which will cycle through images of the 20th century.
The entire image area features a black-and-white aerial view of a construction worker waving from a girder above the Manhattan skyline in the 1930's. The picture remains for five seconds, then the screen dissolves into a three-minute slide show of images from famous to everyday moments in this century. At various times, title cards state: "A picture speaks so loudly . . . just listen."
One image, for instance, is Winston Churchill flashing his "V" for victory sign, fading into Mickey Mantle with his four fingers up in the air signifying a grand slam home run, to former President Richard Nixon bidding farewell in front of a helicopter. Those famous moments in history, which are in no particular order, are interspersed with ordinary moments like people at the beach in the 1920's or a picture of a family having dinner.
The renovation of the sign is indicative of the ever-changing Times Square landscape. The Kodak sign is the second spectacular to be revamped, after the transformation of the Coca-Cola billboard eight and a half years ago. In the mid-1980's, those two were the only major American companies with billboards in the square when the neighborhood's bleak, seedy appearance discouraged tourists and New Yorkers alike.
But, over the years, the improvements in Times Square's economic and physical health transformed the lineup of marketers planting, or replanting, their brands on billboards there. And the square is now bursting with electronic spectaculars that feature huge video screens, message centers, electronic strips or ribbons, printed vinyl that changes and, of course, flashing neon.
Michael Forte, chief executive of Spectacolor Communications Inc. in New York, which specializes in Times Square signs and is handling Kodak's job, said: "Everybody gives the credit to Disney as the turning point to Times Square. But Times Square has always been Times Square. It was always an entertainment mecca. Although it had its slow days, I think people always wanted Times Square to come back."
The "great signs" in the square now have three components in common, Mr. Forte said. "They all have something that is permanent for the corporate name. They all have something that is spectacular, and something that is changeable."
Neither Kodak nor Spectacolor would disclose the cost of the Kodak sign or discuss the multiyear contract to lease the space. However, leases usually cost millions, plus millions more to build, operate and maintain the billboards.

HEADLINE: Strengthening Mr. Castro's Hand

 BODY:
Forty-one years after he came to power and a decade after the end of the cold war, Fidel Castro maintains his repressive rule over Cuba, in part with the unwitting collusion of the United States. The resolution this week of a hostage standoff with Cuban detainees in a Louisiana jail and the unresolved custody battle over 6-year-old Elian Gonzalez in Florida are examples of how an outdated American attempt to isolate Cuba and weaken Mr. Castro's regime accomplishes just the opposite.
Both of these events are symptoms of an obsolete and increasingly counterproductive American estrangement from Cuba. In Louisiana, United States officials ended the six-day standoff by striking a deal with the Cuban government that permitted six of seven Cuban inmates at the center of the uprising to be deported back to Cuba. The inmates had come here in the 1980 Mariel boatlift, during which Mr. Castro sent thousands of criminals to the United States. The inmates had completed prison sentences for crimes committed in this country but were being held indefinitely because their deportation had been blocked by Mr. Castro. 
 The agreement by which Mr. Castro dropped his opposition would appear to be a laudable example of all-too-infrequent cooperation between the two countries. But it should not have been necessary. Because the United States lacks normal diplomatic relations with Cuba, some 2,400 Cuban inmates are languishing in local jails across America under similarly combustible circumstances. Instead of deporting them routinely, the United States has to rely on Mr. Castro's political calculation that he can play the statesman, thereby enhancing his stature at home and abroad.
Similarly, the unseemly custody battle over Elian Gonzalez was partly a symptom of the embargo and related laws. The boy was rescued off the Florida coast on Nov. 25 after surviving a boat capsizing that claimed the lives of his mother and stepfather. The United States ban on all exports to Cuba, including food and medicine, fuels the very hardships that drive Cubans to flee the island. The Cuban Adjustment Act of 1966, in turn, which enables Cubans to circumvent immigration requirements that apply to all other nationals, has become a strong incentive for the kind of smuggling enterprise using overloaded powerboats that nearly cost Elian his life.
The act also made it possible for the boy to be immediately turned over to relatives in Miami, who have allowed him to be cynically exploited by exiles bent on discrediting Mr. Castro. Now we are confronted with the spectacle of Mr. Castro, whose police state has ruined countless families, demanding that Elian be returned to his father and grandparents. The case must be resolved in a manner that best serves the boy's needs, not those of Mr. Castro or his opponents.
With his Soviet benefactors long gone and his state-controlled economy on its knees, Mr. Castro has little left with which to mobilize popular support beyond his stature as defender of the homeland against American economic aggression. The Clinton administration has moved in the last year toward a slight thawing on the margins, allowing cultural exchanges and increasing travel opportunities, for example. But on the larger issues of trade and diplomacy it remains trapped in a futile policy from the cold-war past.

HEADLINE: U.S. Economy Kept Surging In 3rd Quarter

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
The nation's economic performance in the third quarter was its strongest in almost a year, Commerce Department figures showed today.
The gross domestic product, the sum of all goods and services produced in the United States, rose at a 5.7 percent annual rate in the three months ended Sept. 30 because of upward revisions in consumer spending on services and business inventories. The pace, previously estimated at 5.5 percent, was the fastest since the 5.9 percent rate in 1998's fourth quarter. 
 Analysts are forecasting a 4.7 percent expansion rate in this year's final quarter, which ends a week from Friday. "The economy is going gangbusters and inflation remains muted," said Joel L. Naroff, president of Naroff Economic Advisors Inc. in Holland, Pa.
A separate University of Michigan report released today showed that consumer confidence in the economy rose to 105.4 this month in the index the university maintains, up from the preliminary reading of 104.2. That suggests that rising stock values and the lowest unemployment rate in 29 years will most likely fuel additional gains in spending.
The economic expansion, already the longest in peacetime, is on track to become the longest ever in February. It would surpass the 1961-1969 expansion that coincided with the Vietnam War, according to the National Bureau of Economic Research, a private nonprofit research group.
The consumer spending spree, even before the start of the holiday shopping season, drove most of the third-quarter increase in G.D.P. Spending rose at an annual rate of 4.9 percent, up from a previous estimate of 4.6 percent; the revised figure put spending on course to rise 5.2 percent for all of 1999. That would be the largest annual rise since a 5.4 percent gain in 1984. Consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of overall economic activity.
The revision was paced by an increase in spending on brokers' commissions and other services; it grew at a 5 percent pace, up from a previously estimated 4.5 percent rate. Spending on services is also on track to top last year's 4 percent increase, the largest gain since 1988.
The G.D.P. report offered fresh evidence that inflation stayed subdued. The G.D.P. price deflator -- a measure of price increases followed by many investors -- grew at a 1.1 percent annual pace in the third quarter, the same as previously reported. That is lower than increases of 1.4 percent in the second quarter and 2 percent in the first.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Nasdaq and S.& P. 500 Ride Technology to Records

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks rose yesterday, led by technology companies like Microsoft, lifting the Nasdaq composite index and the S.& P. 500 to records.
The Nasdaq gained 26.15 points, to 3,937.30, its 57th record closing high of the year. The index has risen almost 80 percent this year. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 3.06 points, to 11,203.60, with gains in Eastman Kodak and Procter & Gamble offsetting declines in banks.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.70 points, to 1,436.13, a record high close.
The broad market, however, turned negative, as declining Nasdaq issues outpaced those advancing 2,257 to 1,920; on the New York Stock Exchange, 1,698 stocks fell compared with 1,426 gaining.
"The pattern remains the same, and that pattern is continued strength by individual issues that dominate the averages," said Donald Selkin, chief market strategist at Joseph Gunnar & Company.
"In the broader market, the new highs versus new lows is a disaster," he said. "But the stock market is not a democracy."
Eastman Kodak and Procter & Gamble raised the Dow. Kodak rose 4 11/16, to 62 1/16, after the company named a new chief financial officer.
P.& G. gained 4 1/2, to 109. Analysts said they saw strength in the entire consumer products sector. Also on Tuesday, the company won a court battle against a rival citing false advertising.
Insurers and drug stocks also traded higher. American International Group gained 2 7/16, to 107 13/16. The company, the world's largest insurer, may be interested in acquiring the Trust Insurance Company of Massachusetts, according to a report in The Boston Globe.
Pharmacia & Upjohn and Monsanto, which have agreed to merge, inched higher after offering skeptical investors a set of upbeat earnings forecasts to gain some support for their deal. Pharmacia gained 2, to 46 5/8, and Monsanto was up 9/16, to 36 13/16.
"They have been undervalued relative to their growth prospects," said Phil Orlando, chief investment officer at Value Line Asset Management, in reference to the drug stocks.
Bellwether technology names shifted higher with Microsoft, a Dow component, rising 1 11/16, to 117 9/16, after reaching a new intraday high of 118. Dell Computer also rose, by 9/16, to 50 5/16.
On the negative side, AT&T lost 1 1/4, to 52 15/16 7/8, after Bell Atlantic received clearance from the Federal Communications Commission to offer long-distance phone service in New York. AT&T said it expected to file a court challenge to the ruling. Bell Atlantic lost 1 1/16, to 64 1/2.
Among financial stocks, American Express declined 2 7/16, to 155 3/8.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Israel's Shame

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Li Peng, China's hardest-line Com munist leader the man famed for ordering the Tiananmen massacre -- was feted in Israel this month.
After a visit to the Holocaust memorial, Foreign Ministry officials took him to the Israeli Aircraft Industries facility near Ben-Gurion Airport. He inspected a Russian-built plane, owned by the Chinese, on which Israel is installing an advanced AWACS battle-management system called the Phalcon. 
 Israel is charging a quarter of a billion dollars for the aerial reconnaissance radar installation, and has a contract for three more. It's a lucrative deal. It may also be the biggest geopolitical blunder any Israeli government ever made.
Free Chinese on Taiwan have no such high-altitude early-warning system. Combined with the new long-range and surface-to-air missiles being installed by China in Zhangzhou, its Israeli purchases will give it a "qualitative edge" in any military confrontation in the Taiwan Strait. That would include, of course, new ability for China to look down on and target any U.S. warships sent to discourage invasion.
Why is Israel, a small democratic nation threatened by powerful neighbors, helping to menace Taiwan, another small democratic nation threatened by a nearby tyranny?
Prime Minister Ehud Barak has been ducking me on this (Shimon Peres and Yitzhak Rabin were more courageous about facing embarrassing questions), but here are the reasons behind Israel's amoral policy:
1. Arms exports enable Israel to improve its own defenses. Besides, America's Boeing and Loral have done more to build Beijing's military than all other nations combined.
2. China offers a huge market for Israeli technology; moreover, its position on the U.N. Security Council offers big-power diplomatic engagement long limited to the U.S.
3. Israel has avoided the transfer of technology it received from the U.S. to any third party without clearance; Phalcon avionics were Israeli-developed. And the U.S. for years did not object to Israel's efforts to follow the U.S. into the Chinese arms market.
4. China's vast network of human intelligence agents can, better than U.S. satellites, relay secret information to Israel about North Korea's sales of missiles to Iraq and Russia's nuclear development of Iran.
That's the case for Israel's supply alliance with China against Taiwan. Here is the case against:
This flies directly in the face of United States security interests. When China last threatened Taiwan, President Clinton was forced to put two U.S. aircraft carriers into the strait. When that happens again, American forces will be directly threatened by Chinese air, naval and missile forces emboldened by Israel's Phalcon battle management.
That's why the Senate Foreign Relations chairman, Jesse Helms, long a supporter of Israel, wrote to its government privately on Nov. 17: "The Pentagon has informed me that this system may be more advanced than the U.S. AWACS and will definitely enhance China's power projection capabilities. . . . United States security will be put at risk by the Phalcon and other Israeli sales to Beijing."
Though candidates for U.S. president today are fearful of raising this question, American supporters of Israel want to know: If Israel tips the technological military balance against a democratic American ally in Asia, why should the U.S. guarantee that Israel continue to have a "qualitative edge" in the Middle East?
Throughout the cold war, Israel and America were together on the side of freedom. In the coming superpower rivalry in Asia, will Israel choose neutralism? And when the multibillion-dollar bill comes in to subsidize a settlement with Syrians and Palestinians, will Israel's prime minister seek economic aid from his big new Asian customer?
Let's talk tachlis, Yiddish for "brass tacks": If the freedom of an island with 22 million souls is of no concern to Israel, the world will care even less about 6 million Jews getting pushed into the sea. Israeli survival has one dependable guarantor, and the powerful U.S.-Israel alliance is nothing without its moral dimension.
That's why some of us hope that after being shown around the Holocaust museum and the Phalcon plant, the "butcher of Beijing" did not get an idea for the final solution to the Taiwanese question.

HEADLINE: For Baby Sitters Around Nation, New Year's Eve Is Best of Times

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

 BODY:
On New Year's Eve, many of the 1,000-some couples attending the Memphis Junior League's charity ball at the Peabody Hotel will take their children along. So the parents can be free to cavort, they have corralled 40 baby sitters from the Annie's Nannies agency. Each sitter will be paid $330 for the 11-hour affair, triple the agency's usual rate.
So it will be in most big cities and their affluent suburbs this New Year's Eve. Baby sitters, whether teenage amateurs or professional adults like those from Annie's Nannies, stand to earn up to $100 an hour for one night's work, or more than many a partygoer's champagne. 
 In New York, the demand for sitters is "high, high, high," said Heidi Davalos of the Baby Sitters Guild placement service. She is charging a minimum of $250 for five hours for up to five children.
"We're fully booked," Ms. Davalos said, with 100 sitters assigned.
In spite of reports of a more tranquil millennium-crossing than first forecast, with many hotels and restaurants hoping for guests and chopping prices, placement services say they are running short of the nation's sitters -- baby sitters, pet sitters and building sitters, or security guards -- who free others to celebrate.
By most accounts, demand for sitters and guards this New Year's Eve far exceeds that of previous years. More people plan to go out, and more businesses want protection against vandalism and system and power failures if computers go awry. Meanwhile, the supply of sitters is lower than usual, with more taking the night off themselves. Many an agency's answering machine says its sitters are booked through New Year's.
"I'm getting more requests than I've ever had," said Nate Wood, a senior vice president at Blackhawk Inc. in Suitland, Md., near Washington, which places security guards. Blackhawk has exhausted its reserve supply of guards filling the swollen demand of regular clients.
"Everyone wants security," Mr. Wood said, "for cabarets, for special events. All of our banks want extra coverage. All of our retail clients. We've been driven all the way to the end of our means."
To feed and tend pets, Sit-a-Pet in Arlington, Va., normally charges $17 for a half-hour visit with one pet once a day and $2 for each additional dog or cat. But to induce more of her 70 sitters to stay on the job, the agency's owner, Debbie Hollander, said, "We have a millennium policy. For anyone using us the 31st or the 1st, it's an additional $25 a day."
But in terms of the pay, the cream of this crop is entrepreneurial teenagers and adult women who care for children.
Fifteen-year-old Ingrid Aguero of Miami and her cousin, Amy Rejaian, 14, will watch children in Ingrid's home. They have lined up three children so far, ages 8 months to 7 years to spend the night. For the three, they will earn $135, and they are advertising on the Internet for more.
"We thought it would be too much to charge at first," Ingrid said. "But, really, almost everyone is going out, and they would pay anything for a sitter on that night."
In the New York suburb of Ridgewood, N.J., 13-year-old Alex Ortiz, whose father will be at work on New Year's Eve and whose mother will be at home, plans to have two or three children ages 3 to 6 come to his home around 7 p.m.
"They'll eat dinner here," said Alex, who has honed his sitting skills watching two younger sisters. "And I'll entertain them. They'll spend the night, and their parents will pick them up around 10 or 11 in the morning."
Alex plans to ask $150 per child and has already signed one up.
In New York, Susan Tokayer, owner of Family Helpers in the Westchester County town of Dobbs Ferry, said she had not had many requests for sitters, but in defiance of the law of economics that says low demand means low prices, "I keep hearing of people who will be making hundreds and hundreds of dollars."
Rather than quote a price, Ms. Tokayer refers callers directly to sitters to negotiate one.
In Boston, Priscilla Garnache, owner of Boston's Best Baby Sitters-Nannies, said, "We're obviously very booked. We have placed about 20 for New Year's Eve. If I had 200, I'm sure I could place 200." Ms. Garnache is charging a family with three children $225 for five hours.
In the Sherman Oaks section of Los Angeles, Buckingham Nannies usually charges $10 to place a sitter and then pays the sitter $10 to $12 an hour. But for New Year's Eve, the manager, Steven Lampert, said the agency is charging a $150 placement fee, $180 for a sitter, for a total of $330, and an additional $30 an hour after six hours.
"I want the nannies to make a worthwhile amount of money to give up the night," Mr. Lampert said.
Still, as Las Vegas has discovered, the sky is not the limit. Anticipating a high demand from high rollers at the casino hotels there, the Nannies and Grannies agency set a charge of $500 to watch one or two children in the hotels' bedrooms for four hours, or more than 10 times the usual $45 fee. But parents have been balking, and as in other big cities, hotel bookings have been fewer than expected.
"So we have readjusted that down to $350," H. D. Hale, the agency's general manager, said.
In all these cities, security guards are in high demand. Agencies say that calls for guards have soared, less in response to a need for crowd control and crime deterrence than to worries that buildings' computer-controlled locks, elevators and other systems will go berserk when the clock strikes midnight.
"Mostly, people are concerned about access control," said Michael Julian, New York City regional vice president for Spectaguard. Banks, for example, link their vaults and doors to clocks that could misread the debut of the millennium and open after midnight, and apartment buildings could lock out returning revelers.
"What we're talking about is locks more than anything else," Mr. Julian said.
Spectaguard will have 600 guards on the job on New Year's Eve in New York, 200 more than on a typical weekend night.
The guards, most of whom normally earn less than $10 an hour, can expect big rewards for giving up their night on the town.
"You have to give them some inducement to work," said Richard Hamilton, president of Watson Security Agency of DC, who said he had more than doubled his guards' pay, to $25 and $30 an hour.
Mark Calvery, manager of the Burns International office in Vienna, Va., said that for a lack of extra personnel, he had turned down a customer who offered $80 an hour. In Chicago, Mike Ragnanese, district manager for Pinkerton's there, declined to disclose how much he charges. But he said that some agencies would charge as much as $100 an hour for one guard.
At its offices nationwide, the Wackenhut Corporation is paying bonuses to off-duty guards who stay home. Then, if the guards are called in, they will receive holiday pay and an additional bonus.

HEADLINE: U.S. Banks Report Sharp Rise in Profit

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
United States banks earned $19.4 billion in the third quarter, a 29.1 percent increase from a year ago, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today.
Banks have rebounded from a year ago, when Russia's default on its debt created market volatility that trimmed third-quarter 1998 earnings to $15 billion. More recently, banks earned $17 billion in the second quarter and a record $18 billion in the first quarter of this year. 
 "The domestic economy remains strong," said Ross Waldrop, senior financial analyst for the F.D.I.C. "Overseas markets remain stable."
Banks' profitability as measured by average return on assets rose to a record high 1.42 percent from 1.15 percent. The profitability yardstick measured 1.25 percent in this year's second quarter, and 1.32 percent in the first quarter.
Income from fees and other areas that do not include interest payments continued to rise to $36.9 billion in the third quarter, from $29.6 billion a year earlier, according to the agency.
Banks' trading profits of $2.9 billion in the quarter reversed results from 1998's rough third quarter, when the industry lost $4 billion.

HEADLINE: Port Authority And 2 States Discuss Lease For Terminal

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Dec. 22

 BODY:
Top aides to the governors of New York and New Jersey met today with Port Authority officials in a step toward ending a long impasse over a new lease for a cargo terminal at Port Elizabeth.
At issue is a 30-year lease with Maersk Sea-Land to operate a terminal to handle up to 25 percent of the port's container cargo. The deal was negotiated by the staff of the Port Authority months ago but has not been acted on by the agency's board amid persistent disputes over its terms and economic impact. 
 New York representatives say the deal amounts to a subsidy that disproportionately benefits New Jersey. They boycotted last week's board meeting after New Jersey representatives insisted that the lease be voted on as part of a package of long-pending actions affecting operations on both sides of the Hudson River.
New Jersey insists that the lease deal, with the jobs throughout the area and increase in cargo it will generate, benefits the entire region and not just one state.
Lewis Eisenberg, the chairman of the port agency board and an appointee of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, confirmed that a meeting was held today as part of his and others' attempts to resolve the disagreement between the two states. Present were Brad Race, chief of staff to Gov. George E. Pataki of New York; Michael Torpey, chief of staff to Governor Whitman; Mr. Eisenberg; and Charles Gargano, Port Authority vice chairman and head of the board's New York delegation.
"We had a productive meeting and have determined that we will meet again early in the next year," said Mr. Eisenberg, who would not discuss any details.
Others officials, however, said that what was emerging as a possible solution to the impasse was the creation of pools of money or "development banks" drawn from agency revenues, from which each state could draw to finance pet projects that were not clearly regional priorities for the port agency.
According to Port Authority staff, such banks have been created twice in recent years. On both occasions the money was drawn from tolls or fare increases that, over time, were expected to take in more money than needed to pay for operations.
Officials said that there were currently no toll or fare increases envisioned, but that there was nothing to prevent the agency from setting up such banks using other regular revenues from port and airport operations.
Ronald H. Shiftan, deputy executive director of the port agency, said that New York representatives were advocating a bank that would finance only New York projects, while New Jersey representatives were pressing for funds available to both states.
Mr. Gargano contended that in recent years New Jersey had benefited from more subsidized development than had New York. He cited agency subsidies to the PATH system that had held the fare at one dollar, and improvements to Newark Airport that had outpaced improvements at La Guardia and Kennedy Airports.
"We need a more principled approach to these projects and we have to look at them and determine if they are subsidizing New Jersey then say, 'What about New York?' " said Mr. Gargano, who is also chairman of New York's Empire State Development Corporation.
Mr. Gargano said the lease arrangement with Maersk Sea-Land and the capital improvements it required amounted to a $55-million-a-year subsidy for the New Jersey-based operation over the 30-year lease.
Mr. Shiftan disputed those figures. He acknowledged that the first 10 years would mean net losses for the agency, but said the remainder of the term would be profitable, resulting in a $412.5 million gain over time.

HEADLINE: $20 Million in Pay Deferrals Prevents Union Layoffs in Nassau

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER 

DATELINE: MINEOLA, N.Y., Dec. 22

 BODY:
After a tense bargaining session that lasted through the night, Nassau County's unions averted 500 threatened layoffs today by reluctantly agreeing to make $20 million worth of concessions to help the fiscally challenged county close its persistent budget gap.
The union presidents agreed to a plan in which county workers would be paid for only 50 weeks next year. The county would hold on to the extra two weeks' pay until the employee quits, retires or is fired. By doing so, county officials said, they expect to save $20 million next year. 
 In return, the unions got much more than simply avoiding the 500 layoffs that County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta had threatened to make if they refused to make the concessions. The unions extracted a pledge from the county that there would be no layoffs at all in 2000 and won agreements that would make it almost impossible for the county to lay off any workers until 2003.
The agreement brought an end to an anxious week in which county workers feared the loss of their jobs. After a night of negotiations, a tentative deal was reached at 6:30 a.m. but was not signed. One union, the Civil Service Employees Association, made a late attempt this morning to get a court order blocking any threatened layoffs. When that failed, the plan was presented to the unions' boards and signed.
The plan, which was signed by presidents of the unions representing Civil Service employees, police officers, police detectives, police sergeants, police superior officers and sheriffs, still needs the approval of rank and file members.
Mr. Gulotta, the embattled Republican county executive, said that these concessions brought the county significantly closer to closing the $60 million budget gap that was created last month when the Republican legislators repealed a real estate transfer tax that they themselves had passed.
"We have cut government spending by $41 million to date, and we are working on cutting the final $19 million," Mr. Gulotta told the Legislature this evening. So far he has cut human services contracts in half; cut roughly a third of the county's subsidy to Long Island Bus, a part of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority; cut $4 million in overtime; and halted a number of the county's capital improvement plans.
Anthony Giustino, the president of the local chapter of the Civil Service Employees Association, said it was hard to believe that the county has been forced to take such austere measures in healthy economic times.
"What's so incredible is that in a time of the greatest economic boom probably in American history -- certainly in my generation -- that we had to come to this point that we have to have threats of layoffs and furloughs," he said.
The deal was announced at what was expected to be the last session of the Republican-controlled Legislature. When the Legislature convenes in January, it will be led by Democrats, who were swept into power last month by an electorate unhappy with the county's fiscal condition and upset by tax increases.
It was the Republicans' decision to repeal one of those new taxes -- the transfer tax -- that unraveled the county budget and set off a frenzied search for further cuts in the few weeks before the 2000 budget takes effect.
Asked whether he regretted his Republican colleagues' repeal of the tax last month at a meeting he did not attend, Bruce A. Blakeman, the outgoing presiding officer, said, "I'm not going to comment on that -- that's ancient history."
Mr. Gulotta first proposed the union concession, known as a lag payroll, when he made an extremely rare appearance before the Legislature on Monday. This evening he returned to tell the legislators that the deal was accepted. The Legislature voted unanimously to ratify it.
Under the deal, the unions agreed that sometime after April 1 the county, which pays its employees every two weeks, will begin delaying its paychecks one day for 10 successive pay periods. Employees who are normally paid on Mondays would be paid two weeks later on a Tuesday, and then two weeks later on Wednesday, and so on for a total of 20 weeks.
The county would be giving workers 10 days of pay for every 11 days they work. At the end of the 20 weeks, the county would save $20 million, or two weeks' pay for each worker. The county would return the money when employees leave their jobs, and at their later pay levels.
On Monday Mr. Gulotta had proposed a similar plan in which workers would be given nine days' pay for every 10 days worked; this plan, essentially the same, was considered more acceptable because the total amount on each worker's paycheck will remain the same.
Workers were mixed in their reaction to the plan. "The county is basically borrowing money from its employees," said one union worker who asked not to be named. She said some people lived from paycheck to paycheck.
But Jane D'Amico, a union vice president, said, "Anything is better than layoffs."

HEADLINE: Gore, in Iowa, Duels an Absent Bradley

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: AMES, Iowa, Dec. 22

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore stumped through central Iowa today and sparred at long distance with former Senator Bill Bradley's campaign organization over farm problems and preschool education.
Before speaking here at a forum sponsored by the Iowa Farmers Union, Mr. Gore used half a dozen radio and television interviews to complain that Mr. Bradley had declined to debate him on farm issues here today or next month in Cedar Rapids. "Senator Bradley," he said, "has refused to have a specific debate on farm policy." 
 Mr. Bradley's spokesman, Eric Hauser, replied from West Orange, N.J., that there were other forums where the two Democratic presidential candidates would appear together. "We'll be talking about agriculture a lot with Al Gore in Iowa," Mr. Hauser said, "and we look forward to it."
Mr. Bradley also said through his campaign staff that "for seven years the Clinton-Gore administration has presided over a farm crisis of historic proportions" and that "we've needed strong leadership for fundamental changes in our farm programs, and the administration has not provided it."
At the Farmers Union forum, the vice president renewed his criticism of Mr. Bradley's absence and promised that in a Gore administration, farm policy would be "explicitly directed at saving the viability of family farms." Among other things, he vowed that the Packers and Stockyards Act would be enforced to prevent price discrimination by packers against small farmers.
Much of his criticism was directed at the Freedom to Farm Act of 1996, passed by a Republican-controlled Congress but signed into law by President Clinton. The vice president said it had an inadequate safety net to protect farmers when prices slumped.
Mr. Gore, the only presidential candidate who had not already stopped stumping for Christmas, began his campaign day at 6 a.m. at a Des Moines school, where he appeared at a "town meeting" sponsored, and briefly broadcast, by ABC's "Good Morning America." There he sketched a 10-year, $50 billion proposal for a "universal preschool initiative that will make high-quality preschool available to every 4-year-old in America and expand coverage to 3-year-olds."
"Most learning takes place in the first few years of life," he said, "and if kids get off to a great start before they ever get to kindergarten, the chances for them to succeed in life, to have good jobs, to lead fulfilling lives, is greatly enhanced."
Under the Gore proposal, federal matching grants to the states would allow 4-year-olds greater access to preschool. With some parents sure not to take advantage of the opportunity, he said, the leftover money could be used for programs for 3-year-olds.
The Bradley campaign promptly criticized the proposal as one that would deliver less than it promised. Pointing to a Gore campaign estimate that 75 percent of 4-year-olds would be enrolled if the initiative was adopted, the Bradley camp noted that 64 percent were already in preschool.
"Al Gore," the Bradley organization said, "would spend $50 billion to enroll an additional 11 percent of the nation's 4-year-olds in preschool."
The Bradley campaign also described the approach envisioned by Mr. Gore as a voucher program, since it would allow parents to use public money to place their children in private-school programs. Bradley aides suggested that the vice president was being hypocritical, because he has criticized Mr. Bradley for having supported an experimental school voucher program when he was a senator.
But Mr. Gore's campaign said that what he proposed was different from a voucher system, because it would give money not to individual families but to the states, which would run the program.
The sniping proceeded. A Gore spokesman, Chris Lehane, issued a statement saying Mr. Bradley was launching "misleading attacks on Gore's bold plan."
"Since Bradley has failed to offer a comprehensive education plan and is running from his 18-year record of supporting private-school vouchers and tax credits," the statement said, "all his campaign can do is divert and attack."
In a more general campaign appearance at a breakfast meeting with Jewish supporters in Des Moines, Mr. Gore stressed his experience, saying that he knew how to "keep the economy going" and that he had once maintained a 100 percent pro-Israel voting record in the House, "compiled on the basis of inner instinct," despite having almost no Jewish constituents to lobby him.
He noted his 1991 vote in the Senate favoring authorization for President George Bush to make war on Iraq, a position Senator Bradley opposed. But for Congress's voting to support the war, he said, Saddam Hussein "would still be in Kuwait."
His spokesman, Mr. Lehane, said that after Mr. Gore returned to Washington tonight, he would not campaign again until the new year, although he might issue some statements next week.

HEADLINE: A Cadre of Familiar Foreign Policy Experts Is Putting Its Imprint on Bush

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
Gov. George W. Bush of Texas is counting on a small group of conservative experts steeped in the intricacies of arms control, military budgets and geopolitical security to counsel him on a subject that has caused him the most trouble in his presidential campaign: foreign affairs.
The task of helping Mr. Bush translate his core principles for the United States' role in the world into concrete policies lies largely in the hands of eight hawkish advisers with broad experience under President Ronald Reagan or Mr. Bush's father, President George Bush. 
 Like Mr. Reagan when he ran for President, Governor Bush has no broad foreign policy experience. But unlike Mr. Reagan, who had a long history of preaching against communism, Mr. Bush had no similar guiding philosophy. As a result, his foreign policy stumbles, like flubbing a pop quiz on world leaders, have only amplified the role his advisers play.
After months of briefings and informal discussions, the advisers' influence over Mr. Bush has become more evident with every speech, news conference and debate. Indeed, perhaps even more than the other candidates in the field, it is not unusual to hear the advisers' words coming out of Mr. Bush's mouth.
This kitchen cabinet is a tight-knit, strong-willed group led by Condoleezza Rice, a Russia specialist in President Bush's National Security Council, and Paul D. Wolfowitz, a senior Pentagon official in the Bush administration and former ambassador to Indonesia.
Mr. Bush also consults with two unofficial senior advisers, Richard B. Cheney, President Bush's secretary of defense, and George P. Shultz, Mr. Reagan's secretary of state. Conspicuously absent is the elder Mr. Bush, who has not sought a foreign policy role, largely to give his son a degree of independence, aides said.
Most of the advisers have known each other for more than a decade, forging close ties as cold warriors combating the Soviet Union, as mediators helping to reunify Germany, or as Pentagon strategists leading the allied victory over Iraq in the 1991 Persian Gulf war.
Advisers bristle at the notion that they are tutoring a novice, arguing that Mr. Bush surprised them by articulating a set of broad foreign policy principles and priorities -- from missile defenses to free trade to what he calls The Big Ones, Russia, China and India -- that need refining, not revamping.
"What this drill has involved is fleshing out the sense he has about things, rather than introducing things he didn't know anything about," said Dov S. Zakheim, a former deputy under secretary of defense for Mr. Reagan.
But Mr. Bush's words have a familiar ring, at times echoing his advisers' public pronouncements as well as their private counsel given in hours of free-wheeling, rapid-fire discussions in conference calls and in meetings at the governor's mansion here over the last year. Advisers say he has yet to overrule them on any major issue.
In August, for example, Ms. Rice, the governor's top foreign policy adviser, described to The National Journal how a future Bush administration would curtail the Clinton administration's penchant for dispatching troops on far-flung humanitarian or peacekeeping missions.
"We would be more selective in our military involvements," she said. "One downside of having this extraordinary power, relative to the rest of the world, is that you can easily become overextended. That risks erosion of domestic support for America's global role and international resentment of what many see as an arrogant and reckless power."
Six weeks later, in Mr. Bush's defense policy speech on Sept. 23, he issued a similar warning: "We must be selective in the use of our military, precisely because America has other great responsibilities that cannot be slighted or compromised."
Several advisers, including Richard Perle, an assistant secretary of defense under Mr. Reagan, have advocated that the United States withdraw from the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Treaty if Russia refuses to negotiate changes to allow both countries to field national systems to protect against limited long-range missile attacks. The governor heartily embraced that position.
Mr. Bush rarely has to choose between stark divisions in his advisers. Last spring, his aides split over whether the United States should support NATO military action to protect Kosovar Albanians. Mr. Zakheim publicly opposed it. Mr. Wolfowitz supported it. Mr. Bush reluctantly backed Mr. Clinton's decision to intervene, persuaded that broader European interests were at stake.
His aides insist that they are often reinforcing and fine-tuning Mr. Bush's gut instincts, making it difficult to single out any one adviser's influence.
"It's like making sausage," Ms. Rice said in an interview at Bush campaign headquarters here. "We get in there, slog through together, and ideas emerge."
The foreign policy team sprang from a meeting in August 1998 that President Bush set up at his summer home in Kennebunkport, Me., between his son and Ms. Rice.
Within a few months, Ms. Rice, who stepped down in June as provost of Stanford University, agreed to head the governor's foreign policy team. Together with Mr. Wolfowitz, she chose a seasoned cadre of experts who, like Mr. Bush, champion internationalism, voice a tougher security approach to dealing with China and Russia, and promise an overhaul of Pentagon spending and strategy.
But surprisingly for a candidate who preaches the virtues of the global marketplace, the Bush team has only one expert in international economics -- Robert B. Zoellick, an undersecretary of state in the Bush administration -- and no specialists in Africa or Latin America. The campaign has a separate team of economic aides, with whom Ms. Rice and Mr. Zoellick coordinate.
"If there's a weakness in the team, it's that it's heavy on security issues," acknowledged Ms. Rice, who said she was seeking to diversify the group.
In their dealings with Mr. Bush, the advisers rely on a familiar working model.
"This operation runs a little bit like we'd run the N.S.C., with the daily briefing he gets, making sure there's press guidance, and worrying about speeches where your policy gets honed," said Ms. Rice, who studied international relations at the University of Denver under Josef Korbel, the father of Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright.
"But in some ways, the most important thing in a campaign is to try to keep focused on the fact that there are a lot of audiences reading what you're saying, including foreign audiences, foreign governments," Ms. Rice said.
To keep that message sharp, the team has a routine. At nine o'clock every Monday morning, the advisers hook up by phone to swap diplomatic gossip, dissect world events and polish Mr. Bush's approach to international affairs.
Each Sunday evening, Ms. Rice, Mr. Wolfowitz, Mr. Bush and a few other top aides here hold a conference call to review global hot spots and talk about issues that have caught the governor's eye.
"It's a little bit more relaxed opportunity to discuss foreign policy, and a chance for him to talk directly to us," said Ms. Rice, who shuttles between here and Stanford, where she is a senior fellow at the Hoover Institution.
Ms. Rice periodically reaches outside the foreign policy brain trust for insights. Gen. Colin L. Powell, the former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, has met with Mr. Bush and critiqued his defense policy speech.
Senator Paul Coverdell, a Georgia Republican on the Foreign Relations Committee who is Mr. Bush's point man in the Senate, briefed the governor's top aides on Senate Republicans' strategy to oppose a global treaty banning underground nuclear testing. The Senate rejected the pact in October.
 The musings of Mr. Bush's advisers are also important because they give a glimpse into who will undoubtedly fill the top ranks of the Pentagon, State Department and National Security Council, if he is elected.
When tensions in Asia ran high last summer over the rejection by Taiwan's president, Lee Teng-hui, of the longstanding "one China" formula, Richard L. Armitage, a senior Pentagon official in the Reagan administration, caused a stir in Australia when he told The Australian Financial Review that Australia "must stand ready to give military support to the U.S. if Washington goes to war with China" over Taiwan.
Mr. Armitage emphasized that Washington did not want to go to war with China, and that there was a low risk of conflict. But if a misjudgment triggered fighting, he said, the United States would expect Australia to help with "the dirty, hard and dangerous work."
In the Persian Gulf, Mr. Wolfowitz has not ruled out using American troops to support Iraqi insurgents in toppling Saddam Hussein.
"It will take American forces to create a protected area in which opposition forces can organize and to which units from Saddam's army can defect," Mr. Wolfowitz wrote in The New Republic in December 1998. "This policy is risky. But it is less risky than the present course, which is leading us to the day that we are obliged to face Saddam ourselves, when he is armed with weapons of unparalleled destructiveness."
Unlike his father or President Clinton, Mr. Bush is not likely to immerse himself in the arcana of policy, leaving more running room for his advisers.
"He's not a policy wonk and he never will be," Mr. Perle said. "But he's going to convey a sense of who he is and how he'd exercise authority."
 
New Tack In Ad Campaign
 AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 22 (AP) Facing a tightening race in New Hampshire, Gov. George W. Bush will try to convey a sense of immediacy by having some television commercials broadcast on the same day that they are produced, his campaign says.
Mark McKinnon, creator of the advertising campaign, said it was intended to show how aggressively Mr. Bush was campaigning in the state.
Mr. McKinnon said he knew of no campaign that had sought to get same-day advertisements on the air.
The first "crash ad," filmed on Monday at a Manchester, N.H., high school, showed Mr. Bush talking about leadership and his tax-cut plan.
The goal was to get the 30-second spot on the air around Monday evening newscasts, but it did not run until Tuesday, Mr. McKinnon said.

A CLOSER LOOK: 10 Bush Counselors
 
RICHARD L. ARMITAGE: 54. Assistant secretary of defense for international security affairs, 1983-89. President, Armitage Associates L.C., a consulting firm.
 
ROBERT D. BLACKWILL: 60. Specialist on European and Soviet affairs with the National Security Council, 1989-90. Lecturer in international security at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University.
 
RICHARD B. CHENEY: 58. Secretary of defense, 1989-93. Chief executive of the Halliburton Company, a worldwide oil industry supply corporation in Dallas.
 
STEPHEN J. HADLEY: 52. Assistant secretary of defense for international security policy, 1989-93. International lawyer with Shea & Gardner.
 
RICHARD PERLE: 58. Assistant secretary of defense for international security policy, 1981-87. Resident fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, a research organization in Washington.
 
CONDOLEEZZA RICE: 45. Specialist on Soviet and East European affairs with the National Security Council, 1989-91. Affiliated with Stanford University since 1981 as professor of political science, serving as provost from 1993 until last June and currently a senior fellow at the university's Hoover Institution.
 
GEORGE P. SHULTZ: 79. Secretary of state, 1982-89. Fellow at the Hoover Institution at Stanford University.
 
PAUL D. WOLFOWITZ: 55. Assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, 1982-86. Ambassador to Indonesia, 1986-89. Under secretary of defense for policy, 1989-93. Dean of the School of Advanced International Studies at Johns Hopkins University.
 
DOV S. ZAKHEIM: 51. Deputy under secretary of defense for planning and resources, 1985-87. Heads a company dealing with defense technology.
 
ROBERT B. ZOELLICK: 46. Under secretary of state, 1989-92. Fellow at the German Marshall Fund of the United States and research scholar at Harvard University.

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 40; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 320 words

HEADLINE: ALBUM OF THE WEEK: RODNEY WHITAKER QUINTET;
"Ballads and Blues: The Brooklyn Session" (Criss Cross).

BYLINE: By BEN RATLIFF 

 BODY:
The first two albums by Rodney Whitaker, the bassist for the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra, were valentines to his hometown, Detroit; he surrounded himself with players he had known before moving to New York, mixing them in with his new colleagues. The albums were ambitious and a little unwieldy and often lost focus and balance with so many different kinds of players.
But his third, "Ballads and Blues," has a streamlined, economized sound, the benefit of players who know one another. It includes some of the best young musicians in jazz: the saxophonist Ron Blake, the vibraphonist Stefon Harris, the pianist Eric Reed and the drummer Carl Allen. Although Mr. Whitaker has included a number of songs by bassists -- three by Paul Chambers, one by George Duvivier -- it's not a thematic record. The album has the ring of the late 50's and early 60's, when great jazz musicians were under contract to produce several albums a year, and a huge number of high-quality records that weren't particularly high-concept were recorded, thus creating the mainstream. 
 The jazz mainstream has two aspects: there's the flat and the dull, and then there's a form of comfort within traditional language that allows musicians to let themselves go, which is what happens here. Mr. Allen fills his sound with cymbal-heavy swing; Mr. Blake plays long, connected, rapid lines that accrue an intellectual weight as they go along; Mr. Harris steps out of rhythm to play dots of sound in strange intervals; and Mr. Reed, an alert player, gets into tumbling waves of rolled chords.
The trombonist Wycliffe Gordon shows up on a few tracks, too, chattering his solos and using a mute to sound like a singer. The current anxiety emanating from jazz records -- the need to make a new sound stick, the dips into stylized retro, the nervous desire to connect with pop -- is, to our pleasure, nowhere to be found here. BEN RATLIFF
