SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 38; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 4813 words

HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 14. 

Now Playing
 
* "ALL ABOUT MY MOTHER," starring Cecilia Roth, Marisa Paredes, Antonia San Juan and Penelope Cruz. Directed by Pedro Almodovar (R, 101 minutes). A whole new order of Almodovar extravaganza. The antic fizz and theatrical exaggeration of this filmmaker's earlier work have blossomed into a newly sophisticated style, one that is far more wise and deeply felt. Lovingly dedicated to actresses who have played actresses, this film weaves its own soap opera around "A Streetcar Named Desire" and tells of splendidly resilient women; Mr. Almodovar has aptly described his material as "screwball drama." Rich and entertaining, this story celebrates the power of artifice and impersonation to transcend ordinary truth. The irrepressible Ms. San Juan, a Spanish nightclub performer, plays a transsexual named Agrado and is the film's biggest treat (Janet Maslin).
 
* "ANY GIVEN SUNDAY," starring Al Pacino, Cameron Diaz, Dennis Quaid, James Woods and Jamie Foxx. Directed by Oliver Stone (R, 160 minutes). Mr. Stone's brawling, hyper-macho professional football film has enough in-the-thick-of-it playing-field action to satisfy the fantasies of most armchair players. In the style of Mr. Stone's "Wall Street," the movie is also a crude morality play that pits the old ways versus the new with the veteran coach Tony D'Amato (Mr. Pacino) embodying tradition and a young hot-shot quarterback Willie Beamen (Mr. Foxx) the new. Although the acting is uneven (Ms. Diaz is disappointing as a tough team owner), and the final scenes are shamelessly "Rocky"-ish, the movie delivers a credible, action-charged vision of the frenzied world of professional sports as a metaphor for the volatility of American culture (Stephen Holden).
 
* "AMERICAN BEAUTY," starring Kevin Spacey, Annette Bening, Chris Cooper, Wes Bentley and Thora Birch. Written by Alan Ball. Directed by Sam Mendes (R, 116 minutes). With heavenly finesse Mr. Spacey plays a buttoned-down 42-year-old suburbanite who flips his lid for a teenage cheerleader. And he never gets it back on. The midlife crisis motif is familiar, but the stage director Sam Mendes brings terrific visual flair and dry humor to this barbecuing of the bourgeoisie. All the actors display coolly expert timing, especially Ms. Bening as the antihero's grasping wife. Although the story spreads itself thin among many characters, the film coalesces for a devastating finale (Maslin).
 
* "AMERICAN MOVIE," featuring Mark Borchardt and friends. Directed by Chris Smith (R, 104 minutes). An insightful, funny, not-to-be-missed documentary about a no-budget Wisconsin filmmaker who makes a horror film as if his life depended on it. And as Mr. Smith so affectingly reveals, Mr. Borchardt's hopes really do hang in the balance. This knowing and often hilarious look at try-anything indie filmmaking becomes a moving portrait of one man's uphill struggle and finds Mr. Borchardt often describing success and prosperity as his goals. Meanwhile, his own life is eloquently presented as a very different, no less authentic kind of American Dream (Maslin).
 
"ANNA AND THE KING," starring Jodie Foster and Chow Yun-Fat. Directed by Andy Tennant (PG-13, 140 minutes). The same story that inspired the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical "The King and I" is the basis for this movie about the British schoolteacher Anna Leonowens (Ms. Foster) who travels to Bangkok in 1862 to educate the 58 children of King Mongkut (Mr. Chow). Although the story has been given a contemporary multicultural perspective that's critical of British imperialism, the picturesque film tells essentially the same story but without the beloved songs, which are badly missed. Ms. Foster's Anna is another of her nobler-than-thou ice queens, and Mr. Chow's king is authoritative but less than thunderous (Holden).
 
* "BEING JOHN MALKOVICH," starring John Cusack, Catherine Keener, Cameron Diaz and (of course) John Malkovich. Written by Charlie Kaufman and directed by Spike Jonze (R, 112 minutes). Welcome to the fun house: in this exhilaratingly quirky first feature by a stellar video director, the reigning fears and obsessions of a technology-crazed, voyeuristic culture are given an even wilder workout than they got from "The Truman Show." Mr. Cusack plays a discouraged puppeteer who accidentally finds a way into Mr. Malkovich's mind. While the ordinary science-fiction plot might go downhill after revealing its gimmick, this one's inspired craziness goes on and on. Originality and cleverness abound (Maslin).
 
"BICENTENNIAL MAN," starring Robin Williams, Embeth Davidtz, Sam Neill and Oliver Platt. Directed by Chris Columbus (PG, 132 minutes). This year's gushy Christmas card from Robin Williams follows the 200-year quest of a household robot named Andrew to become human. Directed by the schmaltzmeister Chris Columbus, who steered this star through "Mrs. Doubtfire," the movie is a joke-strewn sentimental man-machine allegory determined to make us feel good about being human and is punctuated by corny speeches exalting freedom, the joys of sex and the mystery of mortality. Except for Mr. Williams, the acting is strictly of sitcom caliber (Holden).
 
* "BOYS DON'T CRY," starring Hilary Swank and Chloe Sevigny. Directed by Kimberly Peirce (R, 114 minutes). This stunning debut feature tells the strange and resonant story of Brandon Teena, who despite being born Teena Brandon went on to create a charismatic identity as a young man. Brandon's ultimately wrenching tale may sound tabloid-ready, but on screen it turns into Theodore Dreiser's idea of American tragedy. The film makes it hauntingly real and even tenderly romantic, with the astonishing acting needed to make it work. One of the year's best (Maslin).
 
* "THE CIDER HOUSE RULES," starring Tobey Maguire, Charlize Theron and Delroy Lindo. Directed by Lasse Halstrom (PG-13, 125 minutes). Radically downsized in scope, and its examination of the issue of abortion greatly softened, John Irving's sixth novel (with a Dickensian screenplay by the author) has been turned into a lovely World War II-era fable about a young man venturing out into the world. Mr. Maguire is Homer Wells, a doleful innocent raised in an orphanage by Dr. Wilbur Larch (Michael Caine), who performs abortions. Fleeing the institution with a golden young couple (Ms. Theron and Paul Rudd), he becomes an apple picker. Sentimental but smart, the movie has the sweetness and narrative drive of a 40's "David Copperfield" (Holden).
 
"CRADLE WILL ROCK," starring Emily Watson, John Turturro, Ruben Blades, John Cusack, Joan Cusack, Bill Murray and Vanessa Redgrave. Written and directed by Tim Robbins (R, 132 minutes). This huge Depression-era story features well-known figures from Orson Welles to Nelson Rockefeller to Diego Rivera, and it works them into an ambitious "Ragtime"-like tableau. Though too many figures in this landscape are reduced to naive caricature, Mr. Robbins and his impressive cast bring strong passions to bear upon this (mostly) true story of a legendary event: the trouble-fraught production of the banner-waving 1936 agitprop musical "The Cradle Will Rock" by Welles and John Houseman. Mr. Robbins and his cast play out all sides of this event with the certitude that its importance lives on (Maslin).
 
* "DOGMA," starring Matt Damon, Ben Affleck, Linda Fiorentino and Chris Rock.and Salma Hayek. Directed by Kevin Smith (R, 130 minutes). Mr. Smith's idea of angels in America is the notion of two cool dudes who take a hair-splitting, legalese approach to Roman Catholic doctrine and think it would be amusing to nullify all existence. And nothing in this wildly brazen, unexpectedly devout comedy is any less outrageous than that. Mr. Smith again shows off a rare gift for fusing his comic-book sensibility with serious debates and big, big laughs, even if some parts of his film (Ms. Fiorentino's performance, Mr. Rock's and semirepartee from the ubiquitous Jay and Silent Bob) work better than others (an excrement monster). Making a gutsy leap into matters of faith, Mr. Smith miraculously emerges with his humor intact and his wings unsinged (Maslin).
 
* "THE END OF THE AFFAIR," starring Ralph Fiennes, Julianne Moore, Stephen Rea and Ian Hart. Directed by Neil Jordan (R, 105 minutes). Mr. Jordan's intoxicating version of Graham Greene's 1951 novel, in which an illicit affair becomes a far greater gamble than either lover could have imagined. For this fearlessly eclectic filmmaker, this is one more intelligent, brooding love story with a secret twist. Mr. Fiennes and Ms. Moore breathe life into this story with a dreamy, erotic intensity that in no way trivializes the film's underlying ideas about religious faith. Period detail (the setting is London in the mid-1940's) is sumptuously heightened by the inspired costume designer Sandy Powell ("Shakespeare in Love") (Maslin).
 
"END OF DAYS," starring Arnold Schwarenegger, Robin Tunney, Gabriel Byrne and Kevin Pollak. Directed by Peter Hyams (R, 118 minutes). The star modestly tackles the role of a new savior who may just keep mankind free of Satan for the next thousand years. And that's not even the worst thing about this pointlessly nasty would-be thriller. The material is so derivative that it amounts to a tag sale of used parts from better apocalyptic films, with special credit owed to "The Exorcist" for grisly sacrilegious tricks. Mr. Hyams favors a jack-in-the-box approach to delivering shock value. The star dutifully protects a nice young woman from demonic forces. But Mr. Byrne plays the swaggering embodiment of pure evil and has the better role (Maslin).
 
* "FELICIA'S JOURNEY," starring Elaine Cassidy and Bob Hoskins. Directed by Atom Egoyan (PG-13, 116 minutes). In the brilliantly realized surreal thriller, adapted from William Trevor's popular novel, Felicia (Ms. Cassidy), a pregnant Irish girl searching for her boyfriend in the English midlands, is befriended by Joseph Hilditch (Mr. Hoskins), a catering manager who also happens to be a serial killer. Mr. Egoyan, Canada's most gifted filmmaker, elevates this cat-and-mouse game into a film that transcends genre by entering the characters' consciousness and implying a world of half-discernible connections in which the weather, the landscape and the chance encounters of strangers suggest the sense of a grand design (Holden).
 
"FLAWLESS," starring Robert De Niro and Philip Seymour Hoffman. Written and directed by Joel Schumacher (R, 110 minutes). Mr. De Niro is a retired New York City policeman recovering from a stroke and Mr. Hoffman the drag queen upstairs who gives him speech therapy in the form of singing lessons in this stridently campy comedy. Their flashy performances can't add dimension to a movie that is a message-laden duet for two caricatures, a homophobe and the angry, self-loathing drag queen who gets him out of his depression (Holden).
 
"GIRL, INTERRUPTED," starring Winona Ryder and Angelina Jolie, Directed by James Mangold (R, 120 minutes). Except for being several years too old for the role, Winona Ryder, an actress who oozes high-strung intelligence, is ideally cast as Susanna Kaysen, a pre-college-age girl who lands in a Cambridge mental institution in 1967 after a halfhearted suicide attempt. (The movie is based on Ms. Kaysen's memoir.) The period details are perfect, and Ms. Ryder has the courage to make her character a pain in the neck. But the small, introspective movie is nearly stolen by Ms. Jolie as a charismatic, brutally truth-telling sociopath who becomes Susanna's best friend (Holden).
 
"THE GREEN MILE," starring Tom Hanks, Michael Clarke Duncan, David Morse, Doug Hutchison, Sam Rockwell and Bonnie Hunt. Written and directed by Frank Darabont (R, 180 minutes). In adapting the death row drama that Stephen King wrote in multiple installments, the director of "The Shawshank Redemption" could have managed more economy and fewer talky bits of business around the cell block. Still, this lengthy film is vivid and well played. Smooth ensemble acting builds up to the discovery that a gigantic condemned man (Mr. Duncan) is a prisoner with very special abilities, which gives the film its mixture of religious overtones and mild horror. Mr. Hanks, as a wry Southern prison guard, is so unaffectedly good that it's redundant to say so (Maslin).
 
* "THE INSIDER," starring Al Pacino, Russell Crowe and Christopher Plummer. Directed by Michael Mann (R, 155 minutes). Mr. Mann directs this taut thriller about the tobacco industry whistle-blower Jeffrey Wigand with pulse-quickening panache. And he illustrates why, in the corporate climate of the 90's, truth-telling is a riskier business than it was circa "All the President's Men." While Mr. Pacino delivers galvanizing moral outrage as a producer for "60 Minutes," and Mr. Plummer wickedly mimics Mike Wallace, Mr. Crowe movingly captures the complexity of Mr. Wigand's situation. Shaky docudrama ethics cloud the film's take on "60 Minutes." But this is an inordinately well-played thriller, with Mr. Mann's stylistic brio at its best (Maslin).
 
* "LIBERTY HEIGHTS," starring Adrien Brody, Bebe Neuwirth, Joe Mantegna and Ben Foster. Directed and written by Barry Levinson (R, 134 minutes). This semiautobiographical comedy-drama remembering teenage life, anti-Semitism and racism in mid-1950's Baltimore is the fourth movie by Mr. Levinson to be set in his native city. A deeply felt nostalgia trip, the movie adroitly captures the look and social attitudes of the city 45 years ago. But the screenplay and performances are too muted for the movie to come to terms with growing pains cushioned in the nostalgic haze (Holden).
 
* "THE LIMEY," starring Terence Stamp and Peter Fonda. Directed by Steven Soderbergh (R, 89 minutes). From a director for whom the quirky stylistic exercise is standard style, this is a handsome throwback to the salad days of its two iconic stars. Mr. Stamp, in a stony, magnetic performance punctuated by flashbacks to his early career, plays an ex-con seeking revenge for the death of his daughter. He becomes the nemesis of Mr. Fonda's slick Hollywood hipster, in another role that's piquantly tailor-made. Mr. Soderbergh resurrects the lean, hard-boiled look of John Boorman's "Point Blank" as he dissects and considers these two tough customers from every conceivable perspective (Maslin).
 
"MAGNOLIA," starring Tom Cruise, Melinda Dillon, Philip Seymour Hoffman, William H. Macy, Julianne Moore, John C. Reilly and Jason Robards. Written and directed by Paul Thomas Anderson (R, 180 minutes). In "Magnolia" the colossally talented Mr. Anderson has set up an artfully orchestrated symphony of intersecting L.A. stories, with many of the cast members from his "Boogie Nights" assembled to form a charismatic ensemble. The movie is saved from its own worst ideas by the intimacy of the performances. Its single biggest surprise is Tom Cruise in the role of a strutting, obscenity-spouting cult figure named Frank Mackey (Maslin).
 
"MAN ON THE MOON," starring Jim Carrey, Courtney Love, Danny DeVito and Paul Giamatti. Directed by Milos Forman (R, 118 minutes). Mr. Carrey delivers an electrifying homage in Mr. Forman's vivid re-creation ofAndy Kaufman's too-short and enduringly strange career. In a film that summons its subject's most memorable creative inventions as a series of greatest hits, Mr. Carrey makes a flawless, uncanny impersonator. But what is missing here, though it might have been the first thing expected from an ostensible film biography, is an answer to the simplest question: Who was Andy Kaufman, and how did he get that way? (Maslin).
 
* "MANSFIELD PARK," starring Frances O'Connor and Jonny Lee Miller. Written and directed by Patricia Rozema (PG-13, 105 minutes). In Ms. Rozema's skillful screen adaptation of Jane Austen's third novel, the protagonist Fanny Price (Ms. O'Connor) has been sharpened into a proto-feminist heroine who triumphs over the materialist, patriarchal values of her wealthy relatives through a combination of wit, beauty and daring. Without bearing down too heavily, the screenplay (which incorporates fragments of Austen's letters and diaries) equates early 19th-century slave trading with the oppression of women. The message is leavened with smart humor and warm three-dimensional performances (Holden).
 
"MUSIC OF THE HEART," starring Meryl Streep, Aidan Quinn, Angela Bassett and Gloria Estefan. Directed by Wes Craven (PG, 110 minutes). Not many of us enjoy being lectured by dressed-down Hollywood stars in gritty classroom situations. But the true story of Roberta Guaspari, a music teacher in East Harlem and a single mother surviving a nasty divorce, has been given a blunt, no-nonsense tone that works. Ms. Streep gives a down-to-earth performance that is sheer award bait. The story is inspirational enough to take Ms. Guaspari from no job prospects to watching her proud students play alongside Itzhak Perlman, Isaac Stern and other violin stars. Not a bad reason for Mr. Craven to have sidelined the claws and hatchets for a while (Maslin).
 
"ONEGIN," starring Ralph Fiennes, Liv Tyler and Martin Donovan. Directed by Martha Fiennes (not rated, 106 minutes). As the directorial debut of Mr. Fiennes's sister Martha, "Onegin" diminishes Alexander Pushkin's epic 19th-century novel "Evgeny Onegin" into a cramped little soap opera whose two stars are painfully mismatched. While Mr. Fiennes acts up a fine storm as the arrogant, cynical title character who doesn't believe in love, Ms. Tyler, who plays his romantic nemesis, is an inert cipher. Somehow, even the grand ballrooms of 1820's St. Petersburg look drab and chintzy (Holden).
 
"POKEMON: THE FIRST MOVIE," with the voices of Veronica Taylor, Philip Bartlett, Rachael Lillis, Eric Stuart, Addie Blaustein and Ikue Otani. Directed by Kunihiko Yuyama (G, 90 minutes). Parents don't have to know all 151 monsters to understand "Pokemon: The First Movie," but they can observe several in action, including Pikachu, cutest of them all. The magic doesn't bridge the generation gap; whatever makes "Pokemon" such a huge pop-culture phenomenon is still a secret of the grammar school set, but the film is energetic and the animation is fun to watch. The plot is about a bioengineered Pokemon who lures young Pokemon trainers (including 12-year-old Ash of the television series) into a showdown. Characters spout pacifist profundities while pairs of monsters punch each other silly (Anita Gates).
 
"ROSETTA," starring Emilie Dequenne. Directed by Luc and Jean-Pierre Dardenne (R, 90 minutes). This grim quasi-documentary, filmed with hand-held cameras (it's almost as jiggly as "The Blair Witch Project"), picked up the Palme d'Or (the top prize) at the Cannes Film Festival earlier this year. Ms. Dequenne was also chosen best actress for her portrayal of a miserable 17-year-old Belgian girl living in a trailer camp with her alcoholic mother. Her desperate quest for a job and what she calls a "normal life" leads her to betray her only friend, who works at a waffle stand, by stealing his job. Unlike the Dardenne brothers' last film, "La Promesse," the movie's social realist angst feels contrived, and its main character never fully comes to life (Holden).
 
"SLEEPY HOLLOW," starring Johnny Depp, Christina Ricci, Miranda Richardson, Michael Gambon, Jeffrey Jones, Michael Gough and Christopher Walken. Written by Andrew Kevin Walker and directed by Tim Burton (R, 110 minutes). This ornate visual fantasy, artfully concocted using a palette that suggests nuclear winter, has little to do with Washington Irving's story and everything to do with Mr. Burton's macabre vision. Mr. Depp makes a dashing hero as the film's shy detective, but the story (by the writer of "Seven" and "Fight Club") is determined to put the ick into Ichabod Crane. A first-rate cast and extraordinary technical talents are attention-getting here, but so is the film's penchant for sardonic beheadings. It's possible to admire Mr. Burton immensely for the secret tenderness and rich imagination of his work without wanting to peer at the exposed brain stems of his characters (Maslin).
 
"SNOW FALLING ON CEDARS," starring Ethan Hawke, James Cromwell and Max Von Sydow. Directed by Scott Hicks (PG-13, 130 minutes). This director's follow-up to "Shine" is the cinematic equivalent of an arty coffee-table book. It is so busy illustrating the story (with elaborate flashbacks and montage sequences) that it forgets to be dramatic. Set in the Pacific Northwest in 1950, the movie looks back to World War II and the charged relationships between Japanese-Americans and whites on an island north of the Puget Sound. Mr. Hawke is the brooding reporter covering the trial and Mr. Von Sydow the defense lawyer who is the film's official conscience. Robert Richardson is responsible for the gorgeous cinematography (Holden).
 
* "THE STRAIGHT STORY," starring Richard Farnsworth and Sissy Spacek. Directed by David Lynch (G, 110 minutes). As the least likely filmmaker on the planet to pull off a G-rated miracle, Mr. Lynch rises to the challenge with exhilarating vigor. It may not sound like much, but this account of an old man making a long trip on a riding lawn mower turns out to be a slow-moving, folksy-looking, deeply spiritual film with the power to hold audiences in thrall. And as Oscar may well note next spring, it would not have been possible without Mr. Farnsworth's terse, no-nonsense honesty at its heart. Mr. Lynch's famously unwholesome imagination crosses a new frontier to explore simple virtues and natural beauty. The result: a supremely improbable triumph (Maslin).
 
* "STUART LITTLE," starring Geena Davis, Hugh Laurie and Jonathan Lipnicki. Directed by Rob Minkoff (PG, 92 minutes). E. B. White's 1945 children's classic has been adapted into a lovely family film about a little mouse (the voice of Michael J. Fox) who is adopted by humans but runs afoul of their fluffy white Persian house cat, Snowbell (Nathan Lane). The movie creates an enchanted storybook version of New York and has what may be the most exciting toy boat race (in Central Park) ever filmed. Thanks to Mr. Lane's sly, wise-guy vocal impersonation, Snowbell nearly steals a movie that is funny and sweet but never cloying (Holden).
 
"SWEET AND LOWDOWN," starring Sean Penn, Samantha Morton and Uma Thurman. Directed by Woody Allen (PG-13, 95 minutes). In homage to the kind of jaunty 1930's jazz that has been heard on many of his other films' soundtracks, Mr. Allen imagines a consummate jazz character: Emmet Ray (played with gusto by Mr. Penn), who can play the guitar as gorgeously as Django Reinhardt but lacks certain interpersonal skills when it comes to his private life. Borrowing attributes of various real musicians, the film turns Emmet into another one of Mr. Allen's cad-geniuses and gives him a long-suffering mute laundress as a sweetheart. (Ms. Morton works miracles in her wordless role.) But on the storytelling level, the film remains flimsy. It's the musical interludes, frequent and lovingly presented, that keep it alive (Maslin).
 
* "TOPSY-TURVY," starring Allan Corduner and Jim Broadbent. Directed by Mike Leigh (R, 161 minutes). Mr. Leigh's grandly entertaining "Topsy-Turvy" is one of those films that create a mix of erudition, pageantry and delectable acting opportunities, much as "Shakespeare in Love" did last year. Instead of a love-struck young playwright, it presents the curiously matched personalities of the librettist William Schwenk Gilbert and the composer Arthur Sullivan in the midst of a robust, knowing, frequently hilarious look at the musical theater over which they held sway (Maslin).
 
"THREE KINGS," starring George Clooney, Mark Wahlberg and Ice Cube. Written and directed by David O. Russell (R, 105 minutes). The prodigiously talented writer-director of "Spanking the Monkey" and "Flirting With Disaster" has made a much more ambitious film, with mixed results. His gimlet-eyed Persian Gulf war film has a "Catch-22" absurdist edge, but it also has an oversupply of visual affectations. Vertiginous music-video camera tricks jazz up the otherwise straightforward story of American soldiers who have larcenous designs on Saddam Hussein's captured gold and then develop conscience pangs about their own roles in Iraq. There are many clever peripheral touches, but there's something tamely conventional at the film's core (Maslin).
 
* "TOY STORY 2," with the voices of Tom Hanks and Tim Allen. Directed by John Lasseter; a Pixar Animated Studios film (G, 98 minutes). A wonderfully playful sequel, sustaining the first film's wit and novelty while bringing new sophistication to computer-generated animation. And here is welcome proof that Hollywood can still make movies to please audiences of any age or persuasion. From its opening (a perfectly adorable "Star Wars" parody) to its Capraesque conclusion, this is seamless work with more metaphorical cleverness than that usually found in the toy bin. Colorful new characters and more adventurous action enhance the story of how Woody falls into the clutches of a sleazy toy dealer, experiences new-found celebrity and needs to be rescued by his fabulous old friends (Maslin).
 
* "TUMBLEWEEDS," starring Janet McTeer and Kimberly J. Brown. Directed by Gavin O'Connor (PG-13, 100 minutes). An astoundingly vital performance by the British actress Janet McTeer makes this small, beautifully acted slice of contemporary Americana a must-see film. Ms. McTeer is Mary Jo Walker, a sexy, free-spirited woman with four marriages behind her who travels across the country with her 12-year-old daughter, Ava (Ms. Brown). Like few other films, this one captures an intimately loving (though not conflict-free) relationship between a parent and child without becoming saccharine. The director plays Mary Jo's trucker boyfriend, who is only the latest in a series of romantic disasters (Holden).
 
* "THE WAR ZONE," starring Freddie Cunliffe, Ray Winstone, Tilda Swinton and Lara Belmont. Directed by Tim Roth (not rated, 99 minutes). Mr. Roth is an actor known for roles in tough films, but never for anything quite as raw as this. In this searing first feature, the title battlefield is a rural English home where a teenage boy looks upon his own family with helpless rage and astonishment. Sensing the incestuous relationship between his father and older sister, the film's wordless, baleful young hero struggles to come to terms with this household horror. Understated but extremely graphic at times, and shot with mournfully expressive simplicity by Seamus McGarvey (Maslin).
 
"THE WORLD IS NOT ENOUGH," starring Pierce Brosnan, Sophie Marceau, Dame Judi Dench, Robert Carlyle and Denise Richards. Directed by Michael Apted (PG-13, 128 minutes). This director is much admired for his "Up" series chronicling the lives of former schoolchildren as they mature. And he has managed to make James Bond grow up a little, too. Mr. Brosnan has grown much more comfortable with the role of Bond, and most of the other characters are also more interesting than might have been expected. Ms. Marceau slinks memorably through the role of a treacherous oil heiress. Ms. Richards seemed a lot smarter playing high school vixens than she does as a brilliant scientist here. The itinerary roams from Scotland to Central Asia. And Mr. Apted handles the action as well as he does the talk (Maslin).

"COLUMBIA 75." With more than a month behind it and three weeks still to go, Film Forum is past the midpoint of its 75-film festival celebrating the 75th anniversary of Columbia Pictures. But there are still plenty of cinematic riches to come. Today's double feature consists of two Kim Novak starring vehicles, Joshua Logan's "Picnic" (1955), with William Holden, and Richard Quine's "Bell, Book and Candle" (1958), with James Stewart, Ernie Kovacs and Jack Lemmon. For Christmas Day and Sunday the attractions are George Sidney's "Bye Bye Birdie" (1965) with Ann-Margret and Dick Van Dyke, and Elliot Silverstein's "Cat Ballou," with Jane Fonda as an outlaw and Lee Marvin in an Academy Award-winning dual role as a drunken gunslinger and his tin-nosed evil twin. The series continues through Jan. 13 at Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, in the South Village. Admission is $9; $5 for members. Screening schedule and information: (212) 727-8110 (Lawrence Van Gelder).

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
A Canvas of Concerns: Race, Racism and Class

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER; "Adrian Piper: A Retrospective" remains at the Fine Arts Gallery, University of Maryland in Baltimore County, 1000 Hilltop Circle, Baltimore, through Jan. 15. It will travel to the New Museum of Contemporary Art in Manhattan (Oct. 4 to Jan. 13, 2002) and then to the Weatherspoon Art Gallery in Greensboro, N.C.

DATELINE: BALTIMORE

 BODY:
For art, the 1990's started in a mood of agitation. The market went down the drain. AIDS was rampant. The 1993 Whitney Biennial, the most important American contemporary showcase of the decade, was a full-voiced chorus of long-excluded voices, black, Latino, gay and feminist among them.
What a difference a few years make. The 90's are ending on a complacent, upbeat note. Economics are back on track. AIDS has become the scourge of the silent poor at home and abroad. The art world has joined the rest of the world in dismissing politically concerned art as "politically correct." 
 All of this provides an interesting context for the traveling midcareer retrospective of work by the American artist Adrian Piper, making its inaugural appearance at the Fine Arts Gallery of the University of Maryland, Baltimore County, a half-hour drive from the center of Baltimore.
Her work is about consciousness-raising. Her primary subjects are race, racism and their links to class and gender. Her forms are spare, unsensual, but for the most part attention-holding. Her method is interrogatory: she asks unsettling questions to evoke revealing responses. Sugar-coating isn't her style.
The retrospective, organized by the art historian Maurice Berger and accompanied by a solid catalog, covers roughly 30 years. A few crucial pieces are missing, notably the photo-and-text-based drawings of the 1970's known as the "Mythic Being" series. (They will join the show at a later venue.) But the show is still as complete a view of this influential artist's career as we have had.
It begins with paintings from 1966, when Ms. Piper was barely out of high school. One, titled "LSD Self-Portrait From the Inside Out," is period-piece psychedelia: an image of a black woman surrounded by an aura of high-color, splitting-apart geometric shards. The other, "Multichrome Mom and Dad," is a snapshotlike portrait of her parents, done in shades of gray except for the faces, which are biscuit-brown.
Although little more than juvenilia, the pictures point up essential aspects of Ms. Piper's work as a whole. The human figure and abstract forms play interactive roles. Autobiographical data recurs but is kept impersonal, always about something else, ideas as well as emotions. For example, the artist uses the fact that both her parents were of mixed-race heritage as a strategic point from which to attack essentialist concepts of race itself.
In the late 1960's Ms. Piper aligned herself with the nascent Conceptual art movement, attracted to its intellectual rigor and speculative logic. At the same time, her political convictions were growing acute and specific. She brought these strands together (she was among the first artists to do so) in performance pieces executed in private and in public.
"Food for the Spirit" (1970) was among her early private solo pieces, done when she was finishing a degree in philosophy at City College in New York. She approached an intensive study of Emmanuel Kant as a kind of yogic discipline, fasting as she worked. She recorded her appearance during this hermetic period in a series of remarkable photographs in which her body seems to be gradually dematerializing.
Her public performances, by contrast, were often assertive and disruptive. For the "Mythic Being" series, she disguised herself as a black or Latino teenager in an Afro wig and acted out stereotypes of antisocial behavior, cruising women in the street, even staging a fake mugging. A single piece in the show catches the spirit: it is a head shot of the bewigged artist with a thought balloon that reads, "I embody everything you most hate and fear."
Ms. Piper repeatedly appears in her own work, assuming different personae (she's a skilled and witty performer) and changing her looks as if she were herself a kind of malleable conceptual object.
Sometimes she is just a voice, as in the installation titled "Art for Art World Surface Pattern" (1976). The piece consists of a walk-in white cubicle resembling an abstract sculpture. The interior is papered with photos of calamitous third world events for which Ms. Piper supplies an exasperated-sounding taped commentary that begins: "Oh, I get it. O.K. Got it. This is social conscience art. Right. O.K. You know, I mean, I don't need this when I come to an art show."
Most of her role-playing, however, is visual. In a 1981 pencil drawing titled "Self-Portrait Exaggerating My Negroid Features" she gives a cosmetic makeover the grim and haunted look of a mug shot. Elsewhere she plays with the educational aspects of her career as both didactic artist and professional academic. (She teaches philosophy at Wellesley College in Massachusetts.)
In a terrific, funny video titled "Funk Lessons" (1983), she earnestly uses diagrams and personal demonstrations to instruct students in the how-to's of popular music and dance, generating lively class participation in the process. In "Cornered" (1988), she is filmed sitting behind a desk and explaining with unflappable, schoolmarmish composure that most Americans are, like her, genetically black, even if their physical appearance seems to say otherwise.
This information also forms the basis for performance pieces she executed in social situations in the late 1980's. Their occurrence was spontaneous, their format simple: when she overheard casually dropped ethnic slurs at parties or dinners, she offered the offending speaker a business card printed with the words: "Dear Friend. I am black. I am sure you did not realize this when you made/laughed at/agreed with that racist remark."
Ms. Piper has placed a supply of these cards in the Baltimore show under the words: "Join the struggle. Take some for your own use." The implication is that any viewers, whatever their preferred racial self-identity, are eligible to pass them out. And that assumption gets to the radical core of what Ms. Piper's work is about.
On the most obvious level, her mission is to reveal racist attitudes and behavior, overt or hidden, and call them by their right name. But she also provocatively suggests that such attitudes and behavior actually create race as a perceptual category and that that category, however illusory, reinforces hierarchies of socioeconomic power and exclusion.
The idea of race as a construct, one producing tightly scripted and limiting roles, is being closely examined these days, with important implications for art.
Although increasing numbers of young artists of African-American descent are forging careers, their number is still small and most are faced with "ethnic" expectations in terms of subject matter (colonialism, spirituality) and materials (elephant dung, for example), as were artists before them, including a whole generation of abstract painters.
But the issue of ethnicity and post-ethnicity, intrinsic to the multiculturalist thinking of the 1990's, is far from being resolved and may stay that way. Racism, meanwhile, remains a fact. The black middle class is growing, but so is the black prison population. American consumerism is more and more an equal opportunity affair, but the hard-won benefits and protections gained by blacks during the civil rights era are now being legally dismantled.
And so Ms. Piper's role as agent provocateur is as valid as ever. Her persistence in exposing the mechanics of prejudice, her insistence on the double-edged dangers inherent in the perception of difference, and her passionately instrumental view of art as a mind-altering and expanding substance make her just as much an artist of the moment today -- a stimulating and prophetic one -- as she has been for the last 30 years.

(University of Maryland Fine Arts Gallery)

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
Stealing a New Life, Carnal, Glamorous And Worth the Price

BYLINE: By JANET MASLIN 

 BODY:
A FLOOD of adjectives bursts onto the screen at the start of Anthony Minghella's glittering new thriller, considering ways to describe Tom Ripley before settling on "talented" as le mot juste. This is only a minuscule show of ingenuity, but it's also a promise that the film will keep. "The Talented Mr. Ripley" offers diabolically smart surprises wherever you care to look.
Its opening credit sequence alone is a model of exquisitely economical suggestion, showing how the loan of a jacket with a Princeton insignia leads Tom from the life of a New York City men's room attendant to a thrillingly new world of opportunity. In a rush of gorgeous, agile exposition, Tom winds up in Europe, learning to say "This is my face" in Italian as he trains his binoculars on Dickie Greenleaf. Dickie is the spectacularly charismatic dilettante whose life Tom will eventually steal. 
 "I can tell you, the Greenleaf name opens a lot of doors," remarks the chauffeur who drives Tom away from a bleak Manhattan neighborhood and hands him his first-class ticket for an ocean passage. In light of the mind games that the movie has in store, both the remark and the carnal high-low contrast (meat hangs on hooks near the limousine) are as splendidly barbed as they can be.
As a playwright and television writer who came to filmmaking with two comparatively modest, whimsical efforts ("Truly, Madly, Deeply" and "Mr. Wonderful") before the exponential leap of "The English Patient," Mr. Minghella now establishes that his Oscar-winning triumph was no fluke. His hypnotic, sensually charged adaptation of Patricia Highsmith's fascinatingly reptilian murder story has the same kind of complex allure that made "The English Patient" so mesmerizing.
This is a more conventional opportunity, being essentially the story of a homoerotic Faustian bargain played for keeps. But Mr. Minghella, who wrote and directed "The Talented Mr. Ripley" with acute attention to every nuance, significantly broadens what Ms. Highsmith had in mind. Adding a couple of important new characters and bringing the secrets of Tom's sexual longings to the surface, he risks losing the profound chill that made Ripley so disturbing in the first place. The character is several shades less loathsome and more conscience-stricken than he was to begin with, and his homosexuality is more openly expressed. But as played by Matt Damon with a fine, tricky mix of obsequiousness and ruthlessness, the nicer new Ripley is in no danger of losing his sting.
In a scenic, voluptuously beautiful film (kudos to the cinematographer, John Seale) that has a traffic-stopping cast, Mr. Minghella carefully plants the seeds of mayhem. When Tom is hired by Dickie's father (James Rebhorn) to bring the ne'er-do-well Greenleaf scion home from Italy, he contrives to bump into Dickie on the beach and to echo Dickie's infatuation with American jazz. The year is 1958, and it seems an impossibly glamorous time as depicted among pampered American expatriates in some of Italy's most breathtaking settings.
Tom's tricks, from wearing an embarrassingly skimpy chartreuse bathing suit to casually flashing some of Dickie's favorite record albums, neatly accomplish their purpose. Soon he has made himself Dickie's latest diversion, and managed this without even alienating Marge (Gwyneth Paltrow), Dickie's girlfriend. Marge was a thick, lumpen target for Tom's misogyny in Ms. Highsmith's version. Here, though still hopelessly oblivious to sexual currents between the men, she becomes a reminder that Ms. Paltrow makes as savvy a character actress as she does a swanlike leading lady.
A word about the film's Dickie Greenleaf: this is a star-making role for the preternaturally talented English actor Jude Law. Beyond being devastatingly good-looking, Mr. Law gives Dickie the manic, teasing powers of manipulation that make him ardently courted by every man or woman he knows. During the first half of the film, Dickie is pure eros and adrenaline, a combination not many actors could handle with this much aplomb.
During one especially sharp-edged scene here, as the tensions surrounding Dickie approach the unbearable, the handsome heir indulges in what he dismissively calls "Marge maintenance" on his sailboat. Leaving Tom and another rich crony, Freddie Miles (Philip Seymour Hoffman, scene-stealingly wonderful here), to wait uneasily during this sexual interlude, Dickie avidly plays off each passenger on the boat against the others. Something has to give.
When it does, in the deadly encounter that sends Tom Ripley into his new life, the film changes greatly in tone. Once its touristy idyll is over, "The Talented Mr. Ripley" becomes an elaborate round of gamesmanship about Tom's sleight of hand and how it can be sustained. The ruse, which Mr. Damon handles coyly and credibly, if not with the nascent Norman Bates streak that the situation warrants, is given an added complication by the presence of Meredith Logue. Meredith is a needy post-debutante played irresistibly by Cate Blanchett. Once Meredith latches onto Tom, who she thinks is Dickie, whom she regards as a bored and wealthy kindred spirit, the story has developed all the dizzying cross-currents it deserves.
The last part of the film, which opens tomorrow, runs into problems. Eventually tangled up, like Tom, in the particulars of a trail of crime, it tries to use yet another of Tom's attractions (to another new character, played by Peter Smith-Kingsley) to settle his fate. And despite the occasional flash of Hitchcockian magic -- like a scene involving a razor blade in the pocket of a white bathrobe -- there are late scenes that flounder or lag. These concluding events are far less meaningful than the ones that sent Tom on his odyssey of self-invention in the first place. As with any great impostor, there's more to say about where he came from than where he has to go.
 "The Talented Mr. Ripley" is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It includes brief and implied sexual situations, strong sexual undercurrents, profanity and murder.

HEADLINE: Further Rise In Spending By Consumers Lifts Economy

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23

 BODY:
Consumers accelerated their spending in November, pushing the economy closer to a record expansion, government figures showed today.
Spending rose 0.5 percent last month, fueled by increased buying of cars and other manufactured goods, after a rise of 0.7 percent in October, the Commerce Department said. November spending was 7.6 percent above that of November 1998, the biggest year-over-year gain in more than a decade. 
 Personal incomes also rose last month, giving Americans the buying power to keep the expansion on track to set a record for length in February. "Everyone's working who wants to work, and those people who own the right stocks are getting richer by the day and so they continue to spend," said Paul Kasriel, chief United States economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
Wages, salaries, rent collections, interest and dividends grew 0.4 percent in November after surging 1.3 percent in October when farm subsidy payments and union bonuses increased the figure, the Commerce Department said.
Americans' incomes have increased about 6 percent in each of the last three years. And gains in stock market wealth are "going to spill over into next year," said Kenneth Mayland, chief economist at Keycorp in Cleveland.
Another Commerce Department report showed that factory orders for big-ticket durable goods increased 1.2 percent last month after two months of declines. Outside of transportation equipment, orders rose 2.2 percent. Both increases were the biggest since July.
"Manufacturing is back on track with more solid numbers," Mr. Mayland said. "Orders will be strong for several months" because of rising demand as well as a need to rebuild inventories, he said.
Unemployment hovering at a 29-year low has increased incomes along with confidence, and a report today from the Labor Department on weekly jobless claims gave no evidence of a change. While claims rose by 14,000 last week, to 281,000, the number is still low enough to suggest that jobs are abundant. Economists tend to view the weekly numbers cautiously this time of year because of difficulties in seasonal adjustment.
The November increase in spending reflected gains of 1.3 percent for durable goods like cars and appliances, the largest gain in three months. Spending on nondurable goods like food and clothes rose 0.4 percent, and spending on services increased 0.3 percent.
Wages increased 0.3 percent last month after rising 0.6 percent in October. Disposable income, or the money left over after taxes, rose 0.4 percent in November after gaining 1.4 percent during October. The savings rate fell to 2.2 percent in November from 2.3 percent during October.
The increase in factory orders also reflected a rebound in demand for electronic equipment, which includes household appliances, semiconductors and communications devices. Orders for those goods rose 8.7 percent, after a revised 7.4 percent drop in October. The October decline was initially reported as 15.3 percent and was mostly attributed to the effects of an earthquake in Taiwan.
Income and job growth are proving to be a powerful combination for this year's holiday shopping season.
"Given the brisk pace of retail spending, past shopping patterns and an extra shopping day this season, retailers should have a very merry Christmas year," said William Ford, senior economic adviser for the TeleCheck unit of the First Data Corporation.
In the first 24 shopping days of the season, from Nov. 26 to Dec. 19, same-store sales rose 5.8 percent, compared with results in the period a year earlier, according to TeleCheck, which analyzed checks written by consumers at 27,000 of its 210,000 sites. Checks account for about a third of all retail spending, the company says.

HEADLINE: Nov. 16 Fed Notes Show Year 2000 Concern

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve's policy-making committee was unanimous in its decision to raise interest rates at its November meeting and expressed a desire to act well before any Year 2000 computer problems, according to minutes of the meeting released today.
The Federal Open Market Committee, which includes Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, voted 10 to 0 to raise the federal funds rate -- the interest that banks charge one another on overnight loans -- by a quarter of a point, to 5.5 percent, according to the minutes of the meeting on Nov. 16. 
 That was the third time this year that the central bank raised rates to slow the economy and keep inflation at bay.
With the economy growing rapidly, all members "agreed on the need for a slight tightening at this meeting to raise the odds on containing inflation and forestalling the inflationary imbalances that would undercut the very favorable performance of the economy," the minutes stated.
The members also said that concerns about the changeover to the year 2000 were a factor in deciding to raise rates in November instead of waiting for the Dec. 21 meeting, their last meeting before the turn of the century.
The decision to raise rates "was reinforced by the prospect that the committee might not find it desirable to adjust policy at its December meeting when a tightening action could add to the potential financial uncertainties and unsettlement surrounding the century date change," the members said.
"Accordingly, any action might have to wait until the meeting in early February, and the members agreed that the risks of waiting for such an extended period were unacceptably high," they added.
At its meeting on Tuesday, the Fed left rates unchanged, citing uncertainties about Year 2000 problems. But the Fed warned that inflation dangers could be lurking in the months ahead. The minutes of that meeting will not be released until February.
Separately, a survey released today by the Fed and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said that 9 out of 10 customers think their banks will be ready for the year 2000, and a majority said they considered it unlikely that their automated teller machines would fail.
Many economists think the central bank will raise rates again in February or March if strong economic growth continues.
At the November meeting, members also unanimously agreed to move their stance on future action to neutral from one favoring an increase in rates. They maintained that stance on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Democrats Criticize Bush As Out of Touch on Poverty

BYLINE: By JIM YARDLEY

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Dec. 23

 BODY:
Gov. George W. Bush's skeptical response to a federal report detailing hunger in Texas has brought criticism from Democrats who say Mr. Bush is out of touch with poverty in his state.
The Department of Agriculture, in a study titled "Measuring Food Security in the United States," found that 5 percent of Texas households had reported suffering from hunger from 1996 through 1998. Only Oregon had reported a higher percentage, the study said. 
 "I saw the report that children in Texas are going hungry. Where?" Mr. Bush said earlier this week in an interview with The Fort Worth Star-Telegram. "You'd think the governor would have heard if there are pockets of hunger in Texas."
Democrats quickly criticized Mr. Bush, who has campaigned for the Republican presidential nomination as a "compassionate conservative."
In Washington, the Democratic National Committee distributed the comments to reporters. In Texas, State Representative Elliott Naishtat, a Democrat who is chairman of the House Committee on Human Services, issued a statement today saying that he was "appalled" at the governor's comments and that "there are massive numbers of people who go hungry."
"Could it be the governor also doesn't know that Texas ranks at or near the bottom in every recognized national poverty-related category?" Mr. Naishtat said in the statement. "Perhaps so."
A Bush campaign spokesman, Scott McClellan, noted that Mr. Bush's remarks to The Star-Telegram included a fuller comment in which the governor said, "I want to know the facts. I would like for the Department of Agriculture to show us who, where are they, and we'll respond."
Mr. McClellan said Mr. Bush signed a measure earlier this year approving $2 million for nutrition education and outreach efforts to needy families. One of the governor's priorities, the spokesman said, has been to mobilize religious groups and charities to help the poor. Mr. Bush is proposing tax benefits for people who donate money to such organizations.
"He is committed to doing something about hunger," Mr. McClellan said.
After a campaign appearance in Manchester, N.H., on Monday, Mr. Bush was asked whether he had been surprised by the hunger report.
"I'm sure there are some people who are hungry," he replied. "I don't believe 5 percent of the children in my state are hungry, and if they are, we'll fix it.
"Yeah, I'm surprised. I'm surprised all of a sudden a report floats out of Washington, D.C., as I'm launching my campaign for president. There seems to be a lot of reports to be coming out of Washington, D.C., these days."
Celia Hagert, nutrition policy analyst for the Center for Public Policy Priorities in Austin, a nonprofit organization focusing on issues affecting low-income Texans, said statistics compiled by America's Second Harvest, a network of food banks, showed that food banks in Texas distributed 25.9 percent more food in 1999 than in 1996. The amount was 118.6 million pounds, up from 94.2 million pounds.
Jan Pruitt, executive director of the North Texas Food Bank in Dallas, said demand at the food bank had increased about 12 percent over last year while donations had increased by 5 percent. Ms. Pruitt said the people seeking food were different from a decade ago, when the needy were mostly the unemployed.
"I've seen not only the need increase but the whole face of the hungry change," she said. "Now it's working people. They're employed, and they cannot feed their families."

HEADLINE: Ivory Coast Soldiers Rampage, Apparently to Demand Pay

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Dec. 23

 BODY:
Soldiers rampaged in the streets of Abidjan today, shooting wildly into the air, stealing cars and looting stores, apparently in a protest over unpaid wages.
Residents dashed for cover as soldiers zoomed through Abidjan in stolen luxury sedans and four-wheel-drive vehicles, firing automatic weapons and shouting obscenities. Stores closed throughout the city, Ivory Coast's commercial capital, and barricades went up in some neighborhoods. 
 More soldiers drove up and down the road leading east from Abidjan to Bingerville, a nearby town. Abandoned cars littered the deserted road, which is normally crowded with people and vehicles.
Witnesses said the soldiers forced people from their cars and took off with the vehicles. "I am scared for my life and for my car," said a taxi driver, Koudjo Yao. "If I lose my car, I lose everything."
Daniel Kadja, an official in the Ministry of Presidential Affairs, played down the rebellion, saying there was "no need to panic."
The violence eased somewhat late tonight. A presidential official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said negotiations were under way with leaders of the uprising.
The soldiers did not announce a reason for the protest, but individuals among them complained about unpaid salaries, poor living conditions and insufficient benefits like housing subsidies.
Ivory Coast, a country of 19 million people, has long been considered a model of West African stability. But political and social turmoil have risen steadily as the country prepares for presidential elections, scheduled for next October.
Earlier today, gunfire resounded near the national television and radio stations, which went off the air without explanation during the afternoon. Soldiers, some in uniform and others in T-shirts and caps, surrounded both broadcast centers. The gates of both were locked.
United Nations staff members were trapped in their downtown offices across the street from the radio station, which appeared to be under attack, a United Nations spokesman, Fred Eckhard, said in New York.
The gates to the American Embassy nearby were also locked. But the streets around the president's residence in suburban Cocody remained calm. The airport, on the southeastern edge of the city, continued to function normally.
The rampage subsided as night approached, but sporadic gunfire continued and soldiers blocked off the main roads leaving the city. At least one tank was seen, and the thud of explosions could be heard in the distance.
The State Department urged Americans in Abidjan to remain in their homes.
The country has been plagued by mounting foreign debt and an economic downturn linked to the falling prices of its main exports, coffee and cocoa. Government coffers were depleted further this year when the European Union and the International Monetary Fund suspended aid because of corruption allegations.
An opposition leader, Alassane Dramane Ouattara, accuses the government of harassing his political party. Last month, 12 leaders of his party, Rally of the Republicans, were jailed and a warrant has been issued for Mr. Ouattara's arrest.
President Henri Konan Bedie says Mr. Ouattara is not eligible to run for president because his father was born in Burkina Faso. Mr. Ouattara denies the claim and says he has documents to prove his father's citizenship.
Mr. Bedie, who has banned all outdoor demonstrations, went on national television on Wednesday to appeal for unity and calm. Looking nervous, he promised "reconciliation, peace, happiness and prosperity" if the opposition cooperated with the government.

HEADLINE: Mortgage Rates Increase

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23

 BODY:
Average interest rates on 30- and 15-year fixed mortgages inched higher this week, despite a Federal Reserve decision to leave interest rates unchanged, according to Freddie Mac. Thirty-year mortgage rates rose to an average 7.96 percent in the week from 7.86 percent in the previous week, while 15-year mortgages were at an average 7.57 percent from 7.47 percent. One-year adjustable rate mortgages also rose, to 6.64 percent from 6.49 percent; the new level is the highest since 6.66 percent in the week ended Feb. 17, 1995. A year earlier, 30-year mortgage rates averaged 6.77 percent, 15-year mortgages, 6.41 percent, and one-year adjustables, 5.58 percent.

HEADLINE: COLLEGES;
Rehearing Sought in Reversal On Test-Based Eligibility Suit

BYLINE: By JOE DRAPE 

 BODY:
Lawyers for four African-American athletes who sued the National Collegiate Athletic Association over the minimum test score requirement for athletic scholarships said yesterday they would ask the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit to rehear their arguments and promised to pursue legal remedies, if necessary, all the way to the Supreme Court.
On Wednesday, in a 2-1 opinion, the judges reversed a lower court decision that struck down the eligibility requirement, ruling that it was unfair to African-Americans. The decision did not address the merits of the case -- that the African-American student-athletes are unfairly affected by the initial-eligibility rule as determined by test scores. 
 Rather, the court said that college sports' governing body did not directly receive federal funding and did not have to conform with Title VI of the 1964 Civil Rights Act, which forbids discrimination on the basis of race, color or national origin. Because of that, they said, it was not necessary to address the other issues.
"The battle is far from over," said Adele P. Kimmel, a staff lawyer for the Washington-based Trial Lawyers for Public Justice. "We will ask them to rehear it. If necessary we'll ask the entire court to hear arguments. I'm certain that no matter what the decision, both sides will want to take it to the Supreme Court. This is that important."
In March, Judge Ronald I. Buckwalter held that the N.C.A.A.'s Scholastic Assessment Tests and American College Test minimum score requirement -- 820 on the former or 16 on the latter -- "has an unjustified disparate impact against African-Americans."
The lawsuit was originally brought by two African-American students, Tai Kwan Cureton and Leatrice Shaw. Both graduated from Simon Gratz High School in Philadelphia in June 1996 ranked high in their class, and both excelled in track. But despite earning academic honors, they did not do well on the Scholastic Assessment Tests and could not get athletic scholarships.
The suit took aim at the standards, called Proposition 16, which dictates initial eligibility for freshmen in the N.C.A.A.'s 302 Division I schools. The standards also include a core group of high school courses and a minimum grade-point average in that core.
Buckwalter cited the N.C.A.A.'s own research showing that the practice harmed African-American students' chances of being declared academically eligible and that the organization's goal of improving graduation rates -- the reason it instituted Proposition 16 -- could be achieved by other available methods.
Buckwalter's ruling on one of college sports' most enduring challenges -- how to improve graduation rates without excluding economically disadvantaged students -- briefly left coaches, administrators and college presidents uncertain of who is eligible for scholarships.
The debate over the use of standardized tests to determine college eligibility has long been an incendiary one that has extended beyond the realm of sports. Advocacy groups assert that the tests are not free of cultural bias and thus discriminate against minority students and lower-income students.
In the wake of the Buckwalter decision, N.C.A.A. officials argued that if individual schools were left to decide who could receive scholarships, it would create chaos. The courts ruled Proposition 16 would remain in place while the case is being litigated.
"The effect of this ruling is that the association's initial-eligibility bylaws remain in effect, and two more important jurisdictional questions have been answered with regard to the application of federal law to the N.C.A.A.," said Graham B. Spanier, chairman of the N.C.A.A. Division I board of directors and the president of Penn State University.
"We are pleased to obtain this ruling from the court," Spanier said. "But as we have said all along, we will continue to review initial-eligibility rules, including the test score cutoff."
The N.C.A.A. first began using test scores as a standard for athletic eligibility in 1986 in an effort to address concerns that athletes were being used for sports only and were not receiving an education. It followed several high-profile cases in which college athletes acknowledged that they were not being educated; in some cases they even had trouble reading.

HEADLINE: A CLOSER LOOK;
An Instant Ad on a Plan to Lower Taxes

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS 

 BODY:

On Tuesday, the Bush campaign began running the first of what it calls "crash ads," swiftly assembled commercials designed to be broadcast within a day of filming. This 30-second spot was recorded on Monday in a speech by Gov. George W. Bush at Manchester West High School in Manchester, N.H.
 
PRODUCER -- Maverick Media 

THE PITCH -- The candidate as tax-cutter and newsmaker. Mr. Bush is filmed from a variety of camera angles, as he stands at the podium in what looks like the high school's gym and comments on his own tax proposals. The sense that this is a real event is palpable, from the handmade "Welcome" sign behind the candidate to the looks on the faces of the teenagers who fill the room. The minimal graphics that flash "Bush Campaign Update" and "Manchester West High School, December 20, 1999" are meant not only to mimic news footage, but also to heighten the spot's topicality and urgency. The camera wobbles and zooms in unexpectedly, adding to the feel of an event unfolding before the viewers' eyes.
 
THE SCRIPT -- Mr. Bush: "A leader learns to take the will of the people and convert it into public policy. I'm used to having to set an agenda. It's important to cut the rates in order to keep the economy growing. If you like what you hear, endorse my plan. Send a signal to Washington that a $480 billion tax cut over five years is what they want. I've been criticized in this tax plan for it being too bold. And I've been criticized in the tax plan for it, that I'd not be bold enough. Which kind of says to me I'm doing all right."
 
ACCURACY -- The central component of the proposal Mr. Bush unveiled on Dec. 1 is a $483 billion tax cut over five years, an idea that has, in fact, come under attack from those who have called it either too generous or not ambitious enough. The proposed cut is larger than the one passed last summer by Congress and vetoed by President Clinton, who termed it irresponsible.
 
SCORECARD -- In what is coming to seem a signature of Mr. Bush's advertising team, the spot takes a lively approach to a stock campaign commercial. In over-the-shoulder shots, with a large audience staring back at him in a standard campaign panorama, the candidate looks presidential; his brisk lowering of his hand, at his mention of cutting "rates," evokes memories of his father's emphatic gestures and syntactic shorthand. The spot also places Mr. Bush in a thoroughly New Hampshire-oriented environment, at a moment in the campaign when he has come under some criticism for not spending enough time in the state. The potential for subtle lapses in making of commercials on the fly is also on view here: in one shot, a young man seated in the front row can be seen with his head bowed, as if in deep sleep. PETER MARKS
One advertisement for Mr. Bush is available from The New York Times on the Web: http://www.nytimes.com/politics

HEADLINE: Mall School Tries Reading, Writing and Retail

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 21

 BODY:
If retail is war, then the students of Providence Place Academy are the first cadets in the country to have their boot camp on the field of battle.
The academy, a fledgling alternative public high school oriented toward business training, may be the first vocational high school in the nation to be based in a working mall. Classrooms have yet to be moved to the gigantic new Providence Place mall in the heart of this reviving city, but the academy's initial 14 students, as afternoon interns, are seeing their first combat just as the fighting is fiercest: Christmas shopping season. 
 "If they can handle this, they can handle anything," Jo-Ann Ward, the school's curriculum-design specialist, said. "The rest will be a walk in the park."
The academy's administrators have been tested as well in the debate that has arisen over the school's creation.
With Nordstrom and more than 100 other stores and restaurants, Providence Place, which opened in August, is a giant deal here, tangible proof that the tired old industrial city has new life. A highway traveler who suddenly sees the mall looming above an overpass might think he had just entered the city of Filene's.
Mayor Vincent A. Cianci Jr. provided much of the motive force behind the mall and was instrumental in the conception of Providence Place Academy as well in discussions with city, school and chamber of commerce officials.
But the school's link to the mall is so unusual it has met with resistance, said Paul Gounaris, director of the "school to career" programs in the Providence school system. There have been complaints from school committee members that it will be too expensive, and criticism from opponents that it will simply funnel students into dead-end cashier jobs they could have had anyway.
One letter to The Providence Journal argued that the students would be better served by interning at high-tech companies. Another said: "This school is recruiting our most precious assets: our children. They are training them to serve the 'white elite' in menial jobs such as sales clerks, maids, food servers, and janitors. Is it just another coincidence that the majority of the students are poor and minority kids?"
The second letter-writer was partly right. Most of the 14 afternoon interns, all juniors, are black, Asian or Hispanic, and the program, which began in November, does have them ringing up sales, stocking shelves, greeting customers and busing tables. (An hour and a half of their labor is considered their internship, and if they work longer, which most do, they are paid.)
But the whole thrust of the school, its founders say, is to help the students parlay their work experiences into learning and into aspirations that can make the difference between success and failure in the real world. The idea, they say, is to use the mall as a great textbook, per a City Council resolution saying that the mall should function in part as an educational setting.
"I don't think many of them will end up working in retail for most of their lives," said Bernard Lough, the school's principal. "They're using the skills they learn to broaden their horizons."
Indeed, among a half dozen students interviewed, there seemed to be no stampede toward careers at Sak's Fifth Avenue. Rather, they were full of the revelations of that first venture into the serious working world: how to tie a tie, how so many things must be done just perfectly, even how personal tribulations must be kept at home.
"Even if you have troubles in your house, you have to always have a smile on your face," said Ana Hernandez, an intern at Nordstrom.
That is the less formal learning that goes on at the academy. The juniors also take a full academic course load in the mornings and, perhaps most important, will be linking their work experiences to the traditional "three R's" with requirements like keeping a workday log that must be grammatically correct.
In the summer, Mr. Gounaris said, the students will practice analytical, research and communications skills: figuring out what their store's market is, for example, researching the potential of that market and giving an oral presentation.
The academy is to move into its mall classrooms by late spring and is scheduled to expand to 100 students next fall. Administrators say there were many more applicants for the program than there were slots. Its focus on learning by experience fits into a broader movement intended to shift schools in that direction, Mr. Gounaris said, as well as fitting into a growing tendency for businesses to enter partnerships with schools. The academy was created in conjunction with the mall's developers, Commonwealth Development Group, and with Johnson & Wales, a Providence university that includes a well-known culinary college among its divisions.
Johnson & Wales is providing classroom space and its students are serving as mentors. The mall, aside from providing the venues where the students try their working wings, is giving them a kiosk at which they can sell their own wares. The students are planning to publish a children's book called "Hair-o" about a little Jamaican boy whose long dreadlocks have magical powers.
The stores seem happy with their roles as educators, although there has been little time to teach the finer points of Retail 101 during the Christmas rush, school officials say.
Debbie Almeida, manager of the Godiva chocolate store, said that her intern, Saveth Som, had learned what a Christmas crush was all about. "She's either going to love retail after this or hate it," Ms. Almeida said. "There's no gray in retail."
It is love for Jairo Garcia, the intern in Restoration Hardware. Still, Mr. Garcia said, "I want to be a pilot and have my own airlines."
Whether they love or hate their jobs, Providence Place interns had better not act like those teenagers who "hang" at the mall merely to wile away their time. The difference between the interns and their peers, Ms. Ward said, is, "Ours don't hang."

HEADLINE: College By the Numbers

BYLINE: By Frank H. T. Rhodes; Frank H. T. Rhodes is president emeritus of Cornell University.

DATELINE: ITHACA, N.Y.

 BODY:
When I was provost of the University of Michigan, the medical school had a student prize for medical diagnosis: the S.S.W. Award. The initials stood for "swift, sure and wrong." I am reminded of it when I hear reports celebrating Texas's "10 percent solution" -- its experiment in maintaining diversity in its public universities by guaranteeing admission for every student graduating in the top 10 percent of any high school in the state.
Attracted though we are to swift and simple solutions to national problems, this route to expanding educational opportunity for underrepresented minorities should be avoided by any university that has better choices. 
 Texas adopted the 10 percent solution only after an unfortunate federal court decision banned the traditional affirmative action policies its university had used successfully for years. California followed, taking up a 4 percent rule after a voter referendum forced it, too, to abandon affirmative action. These guarantees may well be the best these states can do to help their universities maintain the diversity that prepares students best to participate in a pluralistic society.
But now Florida, with no constraint except the threat of a state referendum, has replaced affirmative action with a variation -- a 20 percent admissions system -- and other states will likely consider similar schemes.
The excitement over the simplicity of the 10 percent solution should not blind us to its liabilities. In the admissions process itself, the policy penalizes students at a state's more demanding secondary schools, where those in, say, the second decile are often better equipped for college than those in the top 10 percent at other schools. And, by encouraging admission of less able students into more selective institutions, it may leave them struggling for survival in classes more difficult than they have been prepared to handle.
In high schools, the promise of automatic admission may be an incentive to some students to work hard, but others will be discouraged from taking the extra-hard course or enrolling in the more demanding high school for fear of jeopardizing a high class rank. Consider, too, that the 10 percent solution's very success at assuring minority enrollment depends in large part on continuing de facto segregation of Texas high schools. Is that a situation we should seek to perpetuate?
At the university level, public education itself stands to be harmed as the great public institutions run the risk of becoming less competitive with the strongest private schools. The 10 percent solution does nothing, either, to address the vital question of minority balance in graduate, medical, law and other professional schools.
For all its simplicity and attractiveness, the 10 percent solution is race-blind at the price of being individual-blind. A quota system, however well intended, and a numerically based admissions system, however well-conceived, deny the significance and priority of individuality, in all its bewildering complexity. That is a terrible price to pay.
"A university," John Henry Newman once wrote, "is not a foundry, or a mint, or a treadmill . . . but an alma mater, knowing her children one by one." One by one, person by person: that is the basis for educational success. It is also the basis for a free society: we should not lightly abandon it for a system which, however swift, however simple, not only judges individuals by numbers, but uses numbers as ambiguous as those of class standing. Even in an age bedazzled by rankings, surely we can do better than that.
Why not base admissions decisions on an assessment of the student as a whole person, with honest regard for race and ethnicity as two attributes among many others -- scholastic promise, analytical skills, comprehension, test scores, grades, essay quality, creativity, artistic and musical ability, athletic skills, community service, leadership ability, motivation, success in dealing with adversity, teacher assessment, career objectives, geographic origin, economic background, interview performance and more? That is the practice explicitly upheld by the Supreme Court in the 1978 University of California v. Bakke decision, and most of our states are free to continue to use it. Unless and until it is overturned, we should stick with it. It has served us well. 
http://www.nytimes.com
