HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
New Houses in Bronx Will Extend Neighborhood to Waterfront

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Earthmovers are clearing 22.5 acres that hug the East River in the Castle Hill section of the Bronx in preparation for a residential development that will extend the neighborhood to the water's edge and add to an old staple in the area: the two-family house.
The $40 million project, called Beechwood at Castle Hill, will have 144 such houses, all two stories. Each will have a three- to five-bedroom apartment for the owner and a studio, one- or two-bedroom rental unit. Each house will also have 1,900 square feet and a one-car garage. Most will sit on 23-by-105-foot lots, though some lots will be larger. 
 Construction of the first 70 houses is expected to begin in February, and they are being sold for $229,000 to $279,000, compared with $200,000 to $270,000 for older two-family houses in the neighborhood, said Maria Camporeale, president of Frontier Group Properties, the project's sales agent. Rents for apartments in the area are $600 to $1,000 a month.
Since sales began last month, 45 houses have been bought, she said. Mortgages, with down payments as low as 3 percent, are being made available to buyers through seven banks, she added. Ms. Camporeale noted that 75 percent of the rent from the apartment can be counted toward a buyer's total income.
The houses are also eligible for an eight-year tax abatement from the city, she said. Because of the abatement, taxes are expected to be $120 to $150 in the first year, rising to $2,000 to $3,000 after the exemption expires in the eighth year.
This is not the first project planned for the site, which is at Castle Hill and Norton Avenues and was once occupied by the Castle Hill Swim Club. The club was razed during the building boom of the mid-1980's to make way for a planned 511-unit condominium development, but that project was derailed by the recession when an earlier developer defaulted on its loan. In 1994, the mortgage holder, the River Bank of America of New Rochelle, which is now defunct, took back the property, as well as a nearby 55-acre waterfront site, also a former swim club, where the same developer had planned to build 1,100 units.
Over the next few years, the Castle Hill property sat vacant. (At the second project, known as Shorehaven, the first 256 of the 1,100 condominiums have been built, but spokesmen for the landowner declined to say when construction would begin on the rest of the project.)
Last year, judging that the housing market in the Bronx had rebounded from its doldrums, the owner of the Castle Hill property, R. B. Asset Inc. of Manhattan, the successor to River Bank, began marketing the site for redevelopment. It joined forces earlier this year with the Beechwood Organization of Jericho, N.Y., a builder of two-family houses in Brooklyn and the Bronx. The developers gave up the higher density that was allowed under special zoning granted to the first project in the 1980's. Instead, they chose to build their project according to the site's original zoning.
"The site is in a solid family community, where two-family homes predominate, but new ones haven't been built in 30 years," Leslie A. Lerner, a partner with Michael Dubb at Beechwood, said, explaining why the developers made the switch. "It's also large enough to create a new part of the existing neighborhood, which people like."
One person pleased with the new plans is Francisco Gonzalez, district manager of Community Board 9, which guides growth in the area. "The lower density along with the two-family-home concept complements the area," he said. Having the site redeveloped, he added, "will lift a drain from and upgrade that part of the community board as well as help raise property values."
Mr. Lerner said the partners see two-family homes, with their income-producing apartments, "as the basic form of housing for middle-income purchasers to buy because they can own a home, generally for less than the monthly cost of renting an apartment."
For example, he said, a person buying a $229,000 home with a 5 percent down payment would have a monthly mortgage payment of $1,500; including utilities and the abated real estate taxes, the cost would be $1,700. But a monthly rent of $1,000 from a two-bedroom unit reduces the owner's monthly cost to $700, he said.
Those advantages are among the reasons Damaso and Irisa Rosa have signed a contract to buy a house there. The Rosas now live with their two children in a rental apartment in Washington Heights, Manhattan. (He is a truck driver, and she is a dietitian at a nursing home.)
"We will get a little help with the mortgage, build up equity that we will get back when we sell the house, and our kids get a backyard to run around in and play," Mr. Rosa said. He calculates that his monthly cost to own the home will be about $700, which he said is slightly more than what the Rosas now pay in rent.
Mr. Lerner said the brick-and-aluminum-sided houses have been designed with three different layouts so buyers can choose the size of both apartments based on "how big their family is or how great their need is for the rental income." The architect is Fakler & Eliason, of Fresh Meadows, Queens.
The owners' apartments will range in size from 1,190 to 1,470 square feet and fill the first floor and part of the second, while the rentals will range from 430 to 710 square feet and occupy the rest of the second floor. In a home with a five-bedroom 1,470-square-foot unit for the owner, for instance, the rental will be a 430-square-foot studio.
Buyers will start moving into their new houses by Christmas next year, Mr. Lerner said. He said construction of the remaining 74 houses will be tied to sales.

HEADLINE: Selling Online, Delivering on Bikes;
Low-Tech Courier Services Thrive On Growth of Web-Based Retailing

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
Here at the high noon of holiday shopping in Manhattan, the future of the e-commerce revolution is increasingly dependent on a low-tech, often-despised grunt: the bicycle messenger.
Newly belted with two-way radios and data pagers, tracked by sophisticated routing software, these two-wheeled e-liverers are more in demand, more highly paid, better trained and, well, better uniformed than ever before. 
 They call themselves riders, and only they can prevail on an island where gridlock is the black hole of the traditional delivery van, in a time when an exploding number of imperious dot-commerce customers want service in less than one hour.
And the riders know it. "They need us, all these people that want things faster than ever," said William Hightower, 33, a courier for Kozmo.com who was poised to hurl his 21-speed Trek mountain bike on yet another dangerous delivery run. "And now we ride all day."
Idealized in the 1980's for their rebel glamour, bicycle messengers found themselves superseded in this decade not only by the fax machine but also the ubiquitous e-mail attachment.
They have also been excoriated in the City Council, singled out by the mayor's quality-of-life crackdowns and stigmatized by terrorized pedestrians.
But now the city's couriers are enjoying a renaissance as new Web-based retailers -- including Kozmo.com, Urbanfetch.com and Barnesandnoble.com -- are employing them as shock troops in a struggle with traditional brick-and-mortar video outlets, food purveyors and retail stores. (Even those merchants are going virtual, and employing more messengers.)
"No matter how high-tech these companies are, their products are still going to be delivered in Manhattan on the back of the guy on the bike," said Denyse Barbay-Burgess, vice president for marketing at the Earlybird messenger service in Manhattan, which is delivering book orders for Barnesandnoble.com.
"New Yorkers are the busiest people in the United States, and we're catering to their needs for convenience and instant gratification," said Joseph C. Park, the chief executive of Kozmo.com, which employs 300 messengers in Manhattan and Brooklyn Heights to provide free delivery of anything from a package of Twizzlers ($1) to a Toshiba DVD player ($319).
And so at Earlybird, "we're up 15 percent thanks to e-commerce," Ms. Barbay-Burgess said.
"In the last few months," she said, "we've been bombarded by dot-com companies that want to crack the New York market."
Earlybird has dedicated more than 100 of its 300 messengers each day just to deliver 600 to 800 orders for Barnesandnoble.com that used to be schlepped by postal or parcel delivery trucks.
"It is not more expensive to us," Jonathan Bulkeley, chief executive of the online bookstore, said of the New York pilot project, "and it's a way for us to stand out from the crowd" of competitors that ship by snail mail.
At first, the Internet challenged the messenger business "because every time someone sent an e-mail document attachment, we lost a delivery," said Robert Kotch, owner of Breakaway Courier Systems in Manhattan, which fields 120 messengers serving 3,000 city accounts, many of them dot.companies.
"But e-commerce was a godsend to us," Mr. Kotch said. "It came just at the right time."
More than 300 New York messenger companies compete for business worth about $700 million, estimated Bill Goodman, director of the New York State Messenger and Courier Association, a trade group. Cruising the city is an army of as many as 10,000 unlicensed bicycle, van and foot messengers. (The vans are for bulky items like DVD players.) About 5 percent of couriers are women, Mr. Goodman said.
The going messenger rate is $6 to $10 per delivery, at least $5 less than it was a decade ago, because of severe competition, Mr. Goodman said. Full-time bicycle couriers can log more than 30 miles a day on shifts that last 8 to 10 hours. They are paid $300 to $800 a week.
Those employed by Kozmo.com and a few other e-tailers are allowed to accept tips, and can make $15 to $60 a night.
Thanks to Internet commerce, "We've been pulling our hair out to find people to work for us," Mr. Kotch said.
Nate Kretzschmar, 26, a delivery supervisor at Kozmo.com who paid his dues as a bicycle messenger, agreed. "It's definitely a messenger's market now," he said, adding that the Internet companies "are beginning to take all the best riders."
Unless the e-house of e-cards collapses, the demand for messengers will keep surging. Earlybird is recruiting more Manhattan couriers, and Mr. Park said Kozmo planned to expand its pool to 1,000 riders by the end of next year.
These days, seasoned street warriors are getting bonuses and benefits unheard of a few years ago. Earlybird offers a 10 percent bonus for trips on rainy days, a $500 bonus for six months of perfect attendance, and 401(k) retirement accounts and contributory health insurance.
In delivering a 50,000-item inventory ranging from Palm organizers to gift certificates at the restaurant Daniel, Urbanfetch.com "has a strictly enforced no-tipping policy," said Ross L. Stevens, the company's chief executive, "because customers are uncomfortable about how much to tip on a DVD player," he said.
To compensate for its no-tipping ukase, the company offers a cornucopia of incentives to its 100 couriers so "they can make more than $800 a week," Mr. Stevens said.
Urbanfetch.com, like a growing number of competitors, uniforms its couriers (in green, white and black). And many companies now put messengers through intensive delivery training sessions "because that one moment of interaction makes or breaks the experience for our customers," said Mr. Park (whose messengers at Kozmo.com wear orange, green and navy blue).
The training strategy reassures many customers. "Usually bike messengers are kind of a crazy crew, pierced and tattooed, but Kozmo.com has some very good guys," said Jarom Fawson, 26, a computer consultant who lives in the West Village and places Internet orders every other week.
The courier industry hopes that the city's newfound need for riders will upgrade their image. "Messengers have been stigmatized, but to make the city work, you have to have them," Mr. Goodman said. "It's a tough job, it's a big city, and it's crazy out there."
The streets they ride are indeed mean. So far, 34 bicyclists have been killed this year in the five boroughs. Although the Police Department cannot say how many were messengers, most are believed to be. "Even several of our bicycle officers have been injured on their bikes," said Inspector James Hegarty, commander of the Traffic Control Division.
Riders are prey to the bristling side-view mirrors of passing vehicles and to lane-changing drivers. "I've seen taxi doors suddenly open up on riders, and it took their fingers right off," said James Douglas, 19, a Kozmo.com messenger who was waiting recently in the dispatch room of the warehouse at 111 East 12th Street -- a bare-bones space filled with shipping boxes that everyone calls the lounge.
Riders are also under intense pressure from the police. Responding to citywide complaints about bicycle messengers, the Police Department doubled its Manhattan Traffic Task Force last year from 10 to 20 mountain-biking officers. The heightened enforcement came after a man was struck and killed on a sidewalk by a food deliveryman on a bicycle in 1997.
Mr. Goodman drew a distinction between couriers and the riders who inhabit the bottom of the food chain, delivering takeout orders for tips on wobbly balloon-tire bicycles with wire baskets. Those riders provoke "the No. 1 quality-of-life complaint by the people who reside and do business in our community," said Capt. Michael E. Shea, commander of the 20th Precinct in Manhattan.
Not long ago, messengers had a transgressive chic that was mainstreamed by entertainments like "Quicksilver," the 1986 Kevin Bacon film, and "Double Rush," the 1995 CBS series about a Manhattan bicycle-messenger service. Despite Hollywood, plenty of New Yorkers seem to prefer not to share an elevator with a messenger.
"If you want to know how discrimination feels to minorities, just be a bike messenger," Mr. Kotch said. "The guy at the front door takes one look at you and tells you to go around to the back."
And since it is Manhattan, they get some extraterrestrial requests that attempt to push them where no messenger has gone before. One regular Kozmo.com customer keeps specifying deliveries from "a cute, naked messenger" in his e-mail requests.
"That's one we haven't entirely fulfilled," Mr. Kretzschmar said.
But some veteran messengers cannot get enough of the riding rush. "It's a thrill riding on the streets; you're addicted," said Andrew Terrelonge, 38, a messenger for 10 years, the last 2 at Earlybird.
"There is nothing like it," agreed Jose Arroyo, 33, a courier for 12 years. "I even ride on my day off when it's nice." That's with his wife, Maisie, and the oldest of his four children, Junior, 12, and Justin, 9.
For others, the romance, such as it is, lies in their pay envelopes. "For me, it's quick cash while I'm going to school," said Danny Barrera, 24, a part-time business student at Queensborough Community College.
Perry Benes, 22, from Haifa, Israel, found himself in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, five months ago and started riding for the money, he said. "Another few months," he added, "and I'll have enough to go to South America."
But for a majority of riders, the glamour fades after five years, said Mr. Kotch, 42, who spent a couple of years as a messenger himself. "Then you get tired of sucking down diesel exhausts."
These days, he is content to lug a folding bicycle onto New Jersey Transit for his trip to work so that he can pedal to Canal Street, where his courier company plays its part in keeping the new Internet economy clicking right along.

HEADLINE: THE CHANCELLOR'S OUSTER: THE DECLINE;
A Firebrand Who Seemed to Lose His Spark

BYLINE: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS 

 BODY:
Just a year ago, Rudy Crew seemed poised to be the first chancellor in years to make a lasting difference on New York City's public schools. From the time he arrived from the comparatively tiny Tacoma, Wash., embraced by almost everyone in New York's troubled and politically divided system, he promised quick results and often seemed to deliver.
He wrested substantial control from corrupt and incompetent community school boards. He talked about setting higher standards. He ousted bad principals and took over schools that had abjectly failed their children, promising to turn them around. He gave hope that one man could move a huge bureaucracy to new heights. 
 Yesterday, after months of Hamletlike indecision, the one-time giant came crashing down, after his own board rejected his plea for public affirmation as symbolized by his request for a long-term contract, more money and higher benefits. As he fell -- going from hero to a figure some saw as tragic -- he was publicly excoriated by some politicians and board members who had once been his supporters.
As word of his ouster became public yesterday, virtually no one -- from parents at the schoolhouse gate to union leaders to academics and educators -- publicly begged him to stay. In seclusion with his children in his official townhouse in Brooklyn yesterday, he stood alone.
"I think it's real sad," said Arthur Levine, the president of Teacher's College at Columbia University and a sometime Crew confidant. "I'm still a very big fan of his. There aren't a lot of excellent urban school superintendents in America, and I thought New York had the best."
In the aftermath, there are two views of what happened. One espoused by Dr. Crew and his associates is that in standing up for public education -- opposing the national movement toward school vouchers and warning of the risks of charter schools -- he became the target of Gov. George E. Pataki and, more importantly, of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who controlled a majority of votes on the Board of Education.
The other view is that he came in with a grand vision of taking control of the city's huge school system, executed it through pure chutzpah and a network of unions and legislators, then tripped over the delicate and difficult work of taking his hard-won powers and improving the schools.
But whatever led to his demise, supporters and detractors all say that with more political skill and sheer stomach for the fight, Dr. Crew could have salvaged his job. Mr. Giuliani, his aides say, was genuinely torn about Dr. Crew, and was looking for signals that the chancellor was willing to work with him. The mayor had hounded out a previous chancellor, Ramon C. Cortines, and a popular police commissioner, William J. Bratton, and did not want to be perceived again as a bully, officials said.
"My perspective on the fall is that he brought this on himself," said Raymond Domanico, education advisor for the Metro Industrial Areas Foundation. "I think to all observers he's been drifting for a while, and his unwillingness to make a strong commitment alienated sufficient numbers of the board to lead to his downfall."
Publicly, Dr. Crew's coalition began to fall apart last spring, when he and Mr. Giuliani carried on a bitter dispute over vouchers. Mr. Giuliani had begun lobbying the Board of Education to experiment with using government money to send poor children in failing schools to private school. Dr. Crew, saying vouchers would destroy the public school system, threatened to resign.
The two men publicly patched up their differences over the ensuing months, but aides to Dr. Crew say now that the mayor never forgot.
"I don't think it was in the mayor's nature to let that kind of message go," said Chiara Coletti, Dr. Crew's press secretary at the time. Dr. Crew's pride added to the tension, she said. "He tends to dig his heels in when he has strong convictions. If you consider the temperaments and personalities of both men, I don't consider this a big surprise."
Yet other confidants of Dr. Crew say that he seemed to have lost his fire for the job a year ago -- well before the vouchers dispute. One educator said that Dr. Crew had begun ruminating about where he might go next. Dr. Crew's wife, Kathy, was homesick for Tacoma, his friends say, and his ex-wife, the mother of his four children, was struggling with breast cancer.
Last December, Dr. Crew engaged in a bruising fight with Governor Pataki over charter schools. Dr. Crew warned that charter schools would bleed the public school system of resources and top students. Mr. Pataki, officials say, was infuriated.
Dr. Crew's aides argue that Mr. Pataki and Mr. Giuliani took their revenge by orchestrating the release of two damaging but flimsy reports on the school system over the last month, just as Dr. Crew's contract was coming up for renewal. One report revealed widespread cheating by teachers on standardized tests; the other accused city high schools of inflating attendance figures to get more state aid. Allegations of cheating and attendance inflation have plagued the school system for years. Nonetheless, the scandals put Dr. Crew on the defensive.
In September, Dr. Crew began publicly flirting with a job offer at the University of Washington in Seattle. At the same time, the Board of Education began working on its annual evaluation of the chancellor. For the first time, the evaluation was critical, praising the chancellor for his vision but faulting him for lack of follow-through.
Dr. Crew reacted defensively, dismissing the evaluation as politically motivated. Board members complained that he was not taking them seriously.
Guy V. Molinari, the Staten Island borough president, whose appointee to the board was the first to announce he would vote against Dr. Crew, said the chancellor "seemed to have lost his spark." Dr. Crew became increasingly isolated, often traveling out of town on family business and refusing to talk to board members he believed were allied with the mayor.
"You may disagree, you may feel that they're not on your side all the time, but you have an obligation to work with them," Mr. Molinari said of the board.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Online Holiday Shopping Cuts Into Traditional Sales
Online holiday shopping is increasingly cutting into the business of traditional retailers this year, with preliminary indications that seasonal Internet sales may nearly triple from last year. Visa estimates that Internet shoppers using its cards will have spent $1.47 billion this November and December, 179 percent more than in those months last year.
In the overall retail market, that figure is still small -- 1.74 percent of Visa's retail sales -- but it signals a troublesome phenomenon for traditional retailers, experts say. Stores are finding that their best customers are the quickest to move online. Page A1. 

G.M. President Upbeat About 1999
The president of General Motors, G. Richard Wagoner, gave an upbeat assessment of 1999, praising the company's strong profits, peaceful labor relations, Internet business initiatives, increased unit sales and new models. But Wall Street analysts have had growing concerns about G.M.'s slide in market share. C2.
 
Fed Was Unanimous on Lifting Rates
The Federal Reserve's policy-making committee was unanimous in its decision to raise interest rates at its meeting on Nov. 16 and expressed a desire to act well before any Year 2000 computer problems, according to minutes of the meeting. C2.
 
N.A.S.D. Steps Up Plans in Japan
The National Association of Securities Dealers, the parent of the Nasdaq stock market, is speeding up its plans for an electronic stock market in Japan that will promote cross-trading of United States and Japanese stocks. C2.
 
U.S. Investor in Czech TV Battle
A legal battle over Eastern Europe's most successful television station has turned Ronald Lauder, an heir to the American cosmetics giant Estee Lauder, against the government of the Czech Republic and threatens to taint the nation's broader business reputation. Mr. Lauder has begun an arbitration case, contending that the Czech authorities have failed to protect his investment in TV Nova, violating a treaty on mutual investment protection. C3.
 
Spending Rose 0.5% in November
Consumers accelerated their spending 0.5 percent in November, pushing the economy closer to a record expansion. Another report showed that factory orders for big-ticket durable goods increased 1.2 percent after two months of declines. C2.
 
Europe Wins Ruling in Steel Case
A World Trade Organization dispute panel sided with the European Union in a challenge to American duties imposed to counter state subsidies for British-produced steel, a day after a separate panel ruled in favor of the United States in a dispute over banana imports. C3.
 
Kristol to Leave 'This Week' on ABC
In the first move of a promised makeover of "This Week," the troubled ABC Sunday morning political discussion show, the network has parted company with the conservative commentator William Kristol, a member of the program's weekly roster of pundits. Mr. Kristol, whose current contract ends on Jan. 1, said he declined ABC's offer of a short-term deal. C2.
 
When the Classroom Is a Mall
If retail is war, then the students of Providence Place Academy in Rhode Island are the first cadets to have their boot camp on the field of battle. The academy, an alternative public high school oriented toward business training, may be the nation's first vocational high school to be based in a working mall. A12.
 
U.S. Markets Closed for Christmas
United States financial markets, government offices and banks are closed today in observance of Christmas. They will reopen on Monday. Many foreign exchanges will close early today and remain closed on Monday.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Fall on Worries About the Fed

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday, rounding out a second week of losses that pushed yields to 27- month highs on expectations that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates in February.
"The Fed is telling us that they're going" to raise interest rates next year, said Roger Bayston, who handles $10 billion in fixed-income funds at Franklin Templeton Group in San Mateo, Calif. 
 Though the market is discounting higher rates, it "will continue to see whether the Fed will stay ahead of the curve" on inflation, said Mr. Bayston, who prefers corporate, government agency and asset-backed debt for the extra income they offer over Treasuries.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond declined 14/32, to 95 9/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.49 percent from 6.45 percent on Wednesday.
Bonds pared early gains made as dealers covered short positions, or bets that the market would fall, after a report showed that factory orders for durable goods rose 1.2 percent in November, near analysts' forecasts for a 1.1 percent increase. A separate report showed that personal spending rose 0.5 percent last month, as expected, while income growth slowed from the previous month.
The Fed, which left interest rates unchanged at its meeting this week, is expected to raise rates at its Feb. 1-2 meeting to slow a growth pace that analysts say could lead to faster inflation down the road. The Fed has raised rates by a quarter of a point three times since June.
"The market's beginning to anticipate more Fed moves after the beginning of the year," said Alan Day, who helps manage some $4 billion at Stratevest Group in Burlington, Vt. A 30-year yield of "6.75 percent doesn't look very hard to get to," he added.
Trading was limited before the close at 2 p.m. New York time for the long Christmas holiday weekend. By noon, trading volume in Treasuries was 50 percent below the five-day average, according to GovPx Inc., a bond pricing service.
